webTitle: Injured Cork poised to fly home early

fields.headline: Injured Cork poised to fly home early
fields.standfirst: Hussain on the mend but fast man's back woes show no hint of recovery
fields.trailText: Nasser Hussain may be on the mend but England fast man Dominic Cork's back woes show no hint of recovery.
fields.body:
Dominic Cork's Pakistan tour may be over. The Derbyshire bowler is showing little sign of recovery from the back injury that has bothered him almost since he arrived in the country four weeks ago to prepare for the first-class leg of the trip.

Only four days ago he had a cortisone injection to try to ease the condition, but it has had little effect. If he is not fit for the three-day game against a Pakistan Cricket Board XI beginning here on Thursday, which would effectively rule him out of the back-to-back Tests in Faisalabad and Karachi, he will be flown home.

England's physiotherapist Dean Conway was pessimistic last night about Cork's chances. "He is not racing ahead as far as improvement is concerned," he said, "and he certainly needs to prove his fitness in the three-day game.

"But he has struggled to bowl in the nets and it would need a dramatic turnaround. If there is not, he cannot be in contention."

The injury is to Cork's lower back, a problem he does not have a history of. According to Conway it had a "vague onset" - rather than a specific genesis - during the opening four-day match of the tour in Rawalpindi, which is when it first appeared to become bothersome.

Towards the end of that game Cork was noticeably off the pace. He has not played since. Conway's view is that he would be better off back in England at this stage.

"We gave him the match off in Peshawar to give him a rest but he has really struggled in Lahore. I would like to get him back not just in the short term for diagnosis but with a view to the Sri Lanka tour at the end of January."

The England coach Duncan Fletcher said a replacement would not be sought if Cork was forced to return home.

There is more optimism about the other injuries in the England side. Nasser Hussain's right wrist, struck by Wasim Akram with the new ball on the final day of the first Test, remained bandaged yesterday but Conway was hopeful that the strapping would come off today and that the injury could be reassessed.

"It feels easier than initially," Conway said, "and we have no plans at present for further tests."

Nor, as he had intimated he might, did the England captain have a cortisone injection for the chronic back condition which troubled him during the Lahore Test.

"He had a scan last week," Conway confirmed, "and it showed a little bit of wear and tear. We have the option of an injection but at the moment we hope rest and treatment will be sufficient. If he is still struggling in two or three days' time then we can always take up the option. I'm hopeful he will be fit for the second Test."

Conway was generally upbeat about the fitness of Michael Vaughan, who missed the Test with a calf injury sustained during the match in Peshawar, though the physiotherapist was mindful of the danger of that type of condition recurring.

"He is improving," Conway said, "but we are being conservative. We are not going to test him prior to the three-day game but will use that as a test in itself. He is in the strengthening and rehab stage at the moment and we are going to give him as much time as possible." Vaughan was able to walk round the golf course yesterday with no discomfort, so the signs are good.

The last man on the injured list is Craig White, who has had a hamstring problem since the ICC knockout competition in Nairobi but has played all the games since, culminating in a fine all-round performance in the first Test which might easily have won him the man-of-the-match award.

At present White is in the clear but Conway said he has several general aches and pains and will be given a break during the three-day game this week to put his feet up. He has earned it.

 On a flat New Delhi track, meanwhile, Rahul Dravid (118 not out) and Sachin Tendulkar (70no) led India to 275 for two at the end of the third day of the first Test against Zimbabwe, still 147 behind.

webTitle: New Zealand raise a hope

fields.headline: New Zealand raise a hope
fields.trailText: First Test A fighting 99 by the New Zealand captain Stephen Fleming has given his side a sniff of holding out for a draw in Bloemfontein.
fields.body:
A fighting 99 by the New Zealand captain Stephen Fleming has given his side a sniff of holding out for a draw in the first Test against South Africa in Bloemfontein.

Craig McMillan, not out on 25 from 112 balls, will be the key man when the Kiwis begin the final day on 260 for five, 18 runs ahead with five second-innings wickets in hand.

Fleming, who has made 26 Test fifties but only two centuries - the last one 2 years ago - fell short of the milestone yet again when he gloved a lifter from Allan Donald to gully. Donald, with three for 41, was the best of the bowlers.

webTitle: Robson takes final shot at salvation

fields.headline: Robson takes final shot at salvation
fields.standfirst: Jefferies confirmed as new Bradford manager
fields.trailText: Bryan Robson's Middlesbrough reign may end if the club faisl to beatbottom club Bradford next Saturday.
fields.body:
After seven successive defeats and with his side grounded in the relegation zone, Bryan Robson's six-year tenure as manager of Middlesbrough may end if they fail to beat the Premiership's bottom club Bradford City on Saturday.

Robson met Boro's chairman Steve Gibson, his close friend, after the latest setback, the 3-0 humiliation by Leicester on Saturday, which left the Teesside club without a home win since March. At noon yesterday he talked with his players in an attempt to patch up battered confidence, the entire first-team squad attending a meeting which lasted roughly an hour.

"I wanted to hear their opinions," said Robson. "I thought I had put it right when I tried to simplify the game for them, yet on Saturday we didn't simplify the game, we complicated it and it cost us again.

"The players are showing me they are not as good as I thought they were because the decisions they are making are wrong. Defensively, as a unit, we are frail and that is why we haven't kept a clean sheet this season."

Robson has led Boro to two promotions and three Wembley finals since taking over in 1994, but that relative success came at massive expense with £78m spent on transfer fees. However, although he was again booed by the crowd of 27,965 on Saturday, the beleaguered manager was offered some support by the chairman of the official Middlesbrough supporters' club.

"I want to see Bryan Robson stay and succeed here, as a lot of people do," said David Buckton. "I think that he can, but time must be running out. The team has not performed well this season. Obviously the manager has got to take responsibility - and he does - which has put him under a lot of pressure.

"They could bring somebody in to help out and there is an element of supporters who want to see a change, but there are those who think that Bryan is the man for the job. I think he still has a lot to do and I don't want to see him fail at this."

Middlesbrough's £8m record signing, Ugo Ehiogu, agreed: "There's no doubt about it, we are in a dogfight now, but at the moment we just seem to be shooting ourselves in the foot," he said.

"But a win and two draws from our next three games and we're unbeaten in three and climbing the table. We can still turn it around but the gaffer can't legislate for people making mistakes in critical areas."

To make matters worse, Boro face a Bradford side with fresh impetus as the Bantams try to impress their new manager Jim Jefferies, who yesterday signed a 2-year contract at Valley Parade. Billy Brown, his assistant at his former club Hearts, will accompany him to West Yorkshire.

"Over the next few weeks we'll have a close look and I'll make decisions very quickly about who I believe is good enough to stay in the team to help the club get out of this situation," he said. "If I've got to be tough, single-minded and make decisions then I will do it because I've done it before."

"Jim is an old-fashioned football man, a great coach, motivator and judge of a player," said the Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond. "He has turned difficult situations around at his three previous clubs - Berwick, Falkirk and Hearts - and turned them round quickly. He represents our best chance of survival."

With Bradford three points adrift at the bottom of the table, the new manager's first task will be to squeeze a goal from the bluntest attack in the country. City have scored only five times in the Premiership this season, although Jefferies is looking forward to working with Benito Carbone and Stan Collymore.

"There's no doubt they are talented players, and if they play to the top of their form then Bradford will not have a problem," he said. "I will work with them and encourage them and kick their backside when I have to."

webTitle: Time to get serious, Ferguson warns United

fields.headline: Time to get serious, Ferguson warns United
fields.standfirst: Panathinaikos have no respect for reputations
fields.trailText: After getting lucky break to reach the second phase, United will their utmost tonight to prove that they deserve to be where they are.
fields.body:
Manchester United's door to the second phase may have creaked open like a rusty old gate but tonight, having already extended their luck to breaking point, they will attempt to prove that their presence is no fluke.

Panathinaikos will provide the opening examination for United in Group A and, after watching his team stagger somewhat unconvincingly to this juncture, the message from Sir Alex Ferguson was unmistakable last night: it is time to get serious.

United have already lost twice in Europe this season, against PSV Eindhoven and Anderlecht, and had it not been for the skewwhiff finishing of Dynamo Kiev's strikers at Old Trafford 13 days ago the 1999 European champions would be trying to digest the wholly unpalatable diet of Uefa Cup football.

For Ferguson it has left a smouldering sense of irritation. His team may have fine-tuned a talent for living on the edge but the United manager cannot avoid feeling that if they keep opting for the high wire they will eventually overbalance.

"We always seem to make things harder than necessary," he said yesterday. "We want to do a lot better than the first phase and, in fairness to the players, I think they will do a lot better. They realise this is the real thing now."

Ferguson believes 10 points should be enough to see the Premiership champions emerge from a group that also incorporates Valencia and Sturm Graz, both of whom United beat last season.

Then, if his early thinking goes according to plan, things will really get interesting. "With the exception of Barcelona, all the usual suspects are still there. We are capable of handling our group, I think Arsenal should qualify and Leeds might well be the surprise package; being in a tough group will be no handicap to them because the other teams might cut each other's throats," he said. "The Spanish did it last time, with three teams reaching the last four. Who knows, maybe this could be England's year."

First things first, however, and Panathinaikos have already shown little respect for reputations, having beaten Hamburg in Germany and drawn with Juventus at the Stadio delle Alpi as well as beating the Italians 3-1 at home.

The 18-times Greek champions rely on their international striker Nikolaos Liberopoulos, last season's leading scorer in the Greek first division, but their counter-attacking game is based on a sound defensive unit.

"Knocking out Juventus is no easy route to this stage, so we know what we're up against and we will have a lot of respect for them," said Ferguson. "They don't score many goals but they don't concede many either. It could be tight, possibly 1-0."

• A man has been charged with throwing missiles during the derby game at Manchester City's Maine Road ground on Saturday when Manchester United's David Beckham was pelted with coins. John Leigh, 40, of Ilkley, West Yorkshire, will appear before Manchester magistrates tomorrow. City are not expected to be punished by the FA for the coin throwing.

Manchester United (probable, 4-4-2): Barthez; P Neville, Brown, G Neville, Irwin; Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Sheringham, Yorke.

Panathinaikos (probable, 4-4-2): Nikopolidis; Henriksen, Goumas, Vokolos, Fyssas; Saric, Basinas, Karagounis, Kola; Warzycha, Liberopoulos.

• You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Captain says sorry for punch that led to coma

fields.headline: Captain says sorry for punch that led to coma
fields.trailText: The captain of Serie C club Como has apologised after an opposing player fell into a coma when he was punched in a post-match incident.
fields.body:
The captain of an Italian third division team apologised yesterday after an opposing player fell into a coma when he was punched in a post-match incident.

Doctors said the Modena midfielder Francesco Bertolotti, 33, who was born in Blackburn, was in a stable condition after overnight surgery to remove two blood clots on his brain. Bertolotti, who is married with two children, was injured on Sunday after a Serie C game won 1-0 by Como.

The Como captain Massimiliano Ferrigno, 26, was questioned by police about suspected grievous bodily harm. Como's chairman says he will not play for the club again.

"I'm desperately sorry. I never could have imagined that what happened would happen," Ferrigno told the Ansa news agency. "My every thought is with Francesco. I hope that he'll be OK soon."

The incident happened an hour after the game, during which Ferrigno had been sent off after a scuffle. The two players, once team-mates at Brescello, met in the corridors of the stadium.

According to witnesses, Ferrigno punched Bertoletti, who fell heavily, hitting his head on the floor.

Sergio Campani, president of Italy's footballers' association, said: "What happened at Como is beyond anyone's imagination, it enters into pure criminality."

webTitle: Stuff the game stats, it's the fans you ought to watch

fields.headline: Stuff the game stats, it's the fans you ought to watch
fields.trailText: Opta stats are useless at telling the story of a match. The real evidence is in the stands, and the number of Mexican waves or supporters left at the end.
fields.body:
When Tommy Boyd scored in his own net during Scotland's encounter with Brazil in the last World Cup, a watching English journalist suggested that the match statistics should be extended to read, "Shots on target/Shots off target/Shots in own foot". Sadly this brilliant suggestion has yet to be acted upon.

Perhaps that is not so surprising. Football is evenly divided between those who regard the encroachment of possession charts and the transformation of "assist" into a noun as proof positive that the game is on a slippery slope that will ultimately end with 10-man teams wearing helmets with the silhouettes of ravenous beasts air-brushed on them, and those who see statistics as a glorious one-two that at once allows them to fill up space in the deposit drawer of their memory banks with something more useful than the name of their first-born child while simultaneously offering proof that the game is a scientific operation in which coaches build hi-tech machinery from state-of-the-art parts such as Richard Shaw and Nigel Winterburn.

The schism has existed ever since the days of Wing Commander Charles Reep. It was Reep who reduced Ferenc Puskas and the Magical Magyars to simple mathematics. When the Hungarians won 6-3 at Wembley most romantically inclined observers drooled over their skill, their movement and their intricate interplay. The party-pooping RAF accountant, on the other hand, did his sums and then pointed out that only one of the visitors' goals had come from a move involving more than seven passes.

Reep's spiritual successor was the FA coaching guru Charles Hughes. When other footie folk were greeting every shinned Unibond League volley that went into the net from a distance of more than eight yards with an ecstatic cry of "If a Brazilian had done that we'd have been talking about it for years to come", Hughes compared a few graphs and announced that "Brazil have got it wrong".

In place of these two eccentric old duffers we nowadays have Opta. Every week of the season this redoubtable company produces a raft of facts and figures so sturdy it is a wonder Thor Heyerdahl has never attempted to sail one to America.

Unfortunately to my mind they are all utterly useless. The simple reason for this is that Opta bizarrely choose to focus on the pitch and the players when anyone with any imagination can see that the real story of a club's fortunes is more likely to be found in the stands.

Take a look at the statistics from the Middlesbrough versus Leicester game on Saturday, for example. Boro had 10 corners to Leicester's one and 10 shots to Leicester's eight. You might infer from those facts that the game was a close-run thing with the home side unlucky to lose 3-0. However, if Opta had also included a "Season ticket-holders still in the ground" minute-by-minute bar-chart, the snake's-armpit-low figure with a quarter of an hour remaining would have revealed that to even the most diehard fan the chances of a spirited Boro comeback seemed about as high as those of Paul Scholes hosting his own chat show.

Instead of giving us possession percentages and the number of fouls, Opta should be concentrating its efforts on more relevant things such as comparing the number of supporters who are still drinking in the bars when the game kicks off with the number in their seats at the final whistle (a most reliable guide to how pre-match expectation has been matched by reality and/or local bladder size) and the percentage of players who move the old lady in the 14ft-long hand-knitted scarf to yell, "Take him off and put my granny on."

Players from away teams are often heard talking of how it is essential to "quiet the crowd", so let's have a record of the minute in which it first becomes possible to hear either goalkeeper yelling "Channel him, Micky, channel him" so we can see if that's true.

Finally, during international tournaments the frequency of the Mexican waves is usually a more telling sign of the dullness of a match than the final score. In England this is, thankfully, not a feature of crowd behaviour. Instead the stats boys should keep an eye on that fixture of every football ground in the country, The Angry Fat Man In The Very Tight Hat. If he isn't recorded bellowing, "£18 for this shite. It's daylight robbery," within the first 20 minutes then any knowledgable reader will know he or she has missed a classic.

When the Hungarians won 6-3 at Wembley most romantically inclined observers drooled over their skill, their movement and their intricate interplay. The party-pooping RAF accountant, on the other hand, did his sums and then pointed out that only one of the visitors' goals had come from a move involving more than seven passes. Reep's spiritual successor was the FA coaching guru Charles Hughes. When other footie folk were greeting every shinned Unibond League volley that went into the net from a distance of more than eight yards with an ecstatic cry of "If a Brazilian had done that we'd have been talking about it for years to come", Hughes compared a few graphs and announced that "Brazil have got it wrong". In place of these two eccentric old duffers we nowadays have Opta. Every week of the season this redoubtable company produces a raft of facts and figures so sturdy it is a wonder Thor Heyerdahl has never attempted to sail one to America. Unfortunately to my mind they are all utterly useless. The simple reason for this is that Opta bizarrely choose to focus on the pitch and the players when anyone with any imagination can see that the real story of a club's fortunes is more likely to be found in the stands. Take a look at the statistics from the Middlesbrough versus Leicester game on Saturday, for example. Boro had 10 corners to Leicester's one and 10 shots to Leicester's eight. You might infer from those facts that the game was a close-run thing with the home side unlucky to lose 3-0. However, if Opta had also included a "Season ticket-holders still in the ground" minute-by-minute bar-chart, the snake's-armpit-low figure with a quarter of an hour remaining would have revealed that to even the most diehard fan the chances of a spirited Boro comeback seemed about as high as those of Paul Scholes hosting his own chat show. Instead of giving us possession percentages and the number of fouls, Opta should be concentrating its efforts on more relevant things such as comparing the number of supporters who are still drinking in the bars when the game kicks off with the number in their seats at the final whistle (a most reliable guide to how pre-match expectation has been matched by reality and/or local bladder size) and the percentage of players who move the old lady in the 14ft-long hand-knitted scarf to yell, "Take him off and put my granny on." Players from away teams are often heard talking of how it is essential to "quiet the crowd", so let's have a record of the minute in which it first becomes possible to hear either goalkeeper yelling "Channel him, Micky, channel him" so we can see if that's true. Finally, during international tournaments the frequency of the Mexican waves is usually a more telling sign of the dullness of a match than the final score. In England this is, thankfully, not a feature of crowd behaviour. Instead the stats boys should keep an eye on that fixture of every football ground in the country, The Angry Fat Man In The Very Tight Hat. If he isn't recorded bellowing, "£18 for this shite. It's daylight robbery," within the first 20 minutes then any knowledgable reader will know he or she has missed a classic.  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: Noades sacks himself as Bees manager

fields.headline: Noades sacks himself as Bees manager
fields.trailText: After Brentford's defeat against a non-league side on Saturday, Ron Noades the chairman became so fed up with also being Ron Noades the manager that he has decided to quit as the latter.
fields.body:
After being dumped out of the FA Cup by a non-league side on Saturday, the Brentford manager has chewed things over with the chairman and yesterday resigned.

Ron Noades the chairman has got fed up with also being Ron Noades the manager, and quit as the latter. The decision was mutual.

When Noades bought Brentford in July 1998 and installed himself as chairman and manager, he was fulfilling one of football's greatest dreams.

It started well, Noades leading them to promotion. But this season a large injury list has hit results, and fans have become increasingly critical of his decision to miss league games to be in Spain, where his son is at school.

Noades has tried to explain the situation. "It's a simple choice: travel backwards and forwards during the season a few times, or stay there permanently. I chose the former but if the Brentford fans preferred I stay there it can be arranged. I don't want to be anywhere I'm not wanted."

Faced with demonstrations after Saturday's 3-1 home defeat by Kingstonian, he has now decided to end his game of two halves.

Noades the chairman remains and he will seek a replacement for his alter ego, with Steve Coppell and the temporary manager Ray Lewington on the shortlist.

But even Noades the chairman may have had enough. "I'm not interested in making a profit out of Brentford," he said. "However, I am also not interested in funding the trading losses at £1.5m a year and at the same time being slagged off by the sort of fans who do not turn up in sufficient numbers to justify a non-league wage bill, never mind ours.

"If they want someone else to take over, fine. They can have the club for the £850,000 it cost providing they are prepared to secure the overdraft of £2.5m."

Charlton's Premiership match with Sunderland on Saturday is in doubt because of two structural defects in the 6,000 East Stand at the Valley.

Urgent building work is being undertaken but it will be tomorrow evening at the earliest before a likely confirmation that the game will go on.

Burnley have signed Stockport's striker Ian Moore for about £1m and he will make his Turf Moor debut tonight against Norwich, who agreed a similar fee last week only to be rejected by the player.

Birmingham's St Andrews ground is to stage England's Under-21 game against Spain on February 27, the night before the senior international across the city at Villa Park.

webTitle: North-west to find 1,500 homes for asylum seekers

fields.headline: North-west to find 1,500 homes for asylum seekers
fields.trailText: Councils in the Greater Manchester area have agreed to make up to 1,500 properties available to accommodate asylum seekers over the next five years. Simon Parker reports.
fields.body:
Councils in the Greater Manchester area today agreed to make up to 1,500 properties available to accommodate asylum seekers over the next five years.

A group of 11 authorities will provide the homes over the next 18 months by bringing empty properties from across the private and social sectors back into use.

Councils will also provide essential support services, helping asylum seekers to register with local doctors, find school places and access support groups.

The agreement marks the end of a year of wrangling between the authorities and ministers over who would foot the bill for the scheme. Ministers have now promised that the costs will not hit council budgets.

Marilyn Taylor, executive member for health at Manchester council - one of the 11 authorities involved - welcomed the agreement, but savaged the government's handling of the asylum issue during the negotiations. She said: "The last eight months have proved to be very problematic to this region because of the chaotic way in which asylum seekers were being directly dispersed by the Home Office into private landlord accommodation, usually with no prior consultation with councils."

Asylum seekers dispersed in this way often end up isolated and in poor quality homes, said Ms Taylor.

A Home Office spokesman responded: "Accommodation for asylum seekers is provided under contract to the national asylum support service (Nass) by both the private and public sector. All accommodation is required to meet standards drawn up by Nass in consultation with others."

The deal between the Home Office and the councils is intended to relieve the accommodation pressure asylum seekers currently place on the south-east. Asylum seekers are being dispersed on a "no choice" basis.

This is the fifth such agreement to be concluded. Ministers have already signed contracts with authorities in the north-east, Yorkshire and Humberside, the west midlands and Glasgow.

webTitle: Man Utd 3 - 1 Panathinaikos

fields.headline: Man Utd 3 - 1 Panathinaikos
fields.standfirst: Refresh this page for the latest action
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Man Utd: Barthez, P. Neville, Silvestre, G. Neville, Brown, Beckham, Butt, Keane, Scholes, Yorke, Sheringham. Subs: Van Der Gouw, Irwin, Johnsen, Wallwork, Fortune, Greening, Healy.

Panathinaikos: Nikopolidis, Henriksen, Galetto, Goumas, Warzycha, Sypniewski, Vokolos, Basinas, Nikolidis, Karagounis, Fissas. Subs: Kotsolis, Olivares, Vlaovic, Nasiopoulos, Koutsoures, Kola, Kiassos.

Referee: Domenico Messiena (Italy)

1 Panathinaikos kick off and knock the ball back into their own half before trying to work it up the right. Panathinaikos spend the first minute passing confidently before a speculative hoof towards Barthez enables United to gain possession.
3 Phil Neville plays a one-two with Beckham on the right but the move is blocked by Galetto.
4 Karagounis centres from just outside the United area and Vokolos has a crack from distance - the shot flies into the crowd.
6 United looking comfortable on the ball and doing a good job of keeping possession if not creating any early chances.
8 Panathinaikos win a free-kick 30 yards out after Keane brings down Warzycha, but the Greek side fail to capitalise.
10 Butt, Scholes and Sheringham work the ball along the line 20 yards out, but Sheringham dwells too long and is tackled. Panathinaikos then break and nearly score when the ball is lobbbed over the top of United's backline and on to the chest of Warzycha 10 yards out - Barthez comes and forces Warzycha to jab wide.
12 United living dangerously as Liberopoulos very nearly puts Panathinaikos in the lead with a swift shot from just inside the area; Barthez again saves the day by charging out early for the block.
15 United, in danger of losing their grip on the game, have their first decent chance when Butt fires in a shot from 20 yards to the right-hand post - Panathinaikos keeper Nikopolidis dives to his left to make the save; Yorke comes in for the rebound before the linesman calls time on the chance.
19 United corner from the right. Beckham takes and Panathinaikos clear.
20 A bit more balance after a handy start by the Greeks.
21 Beckham has a pop from long range - keeper Nikopolidis almost makes a hash of things when he mis-judges the flight and moves over too far, only managing to keep the ball out with a desperate flap to his left.
24 Panathinaikos break with Basinas in space on the right; he passes inside and Panathinaikos thread the ball through to find that man Warzycha galloping into the area... and away from Brown. Great work again by Barthez who is on to Warzycha in a flash to block the shot.
28 Panathinaikos come forward again, but some slack passing allows United to break with Neville on the right. A swift interchange of passes with Beckham and Keane sees things open up nicely before Keane gives the ball away when trying to pick someone out near the right byline.
30 Sheringham finds himself in space on the right side of the area but his shot is blocked Nikopolidis.
31 A series of chances for the visitors and the fine keeping of Barthez appears to have galvanised United and they have gradually begun to impose themselves on the game.
33 Perhaps the best chance so far for United; Butt picks out Beckham near the right-hand flag with a pin-point cross-field ball, Beckham crosses and Sheringham gets up for a cracking header... over the bar.
37 After enduring 15 minutes of concerted pressure, Panathinaikos wake up and move into the United half - to no avail however, and United swiftly regain possession in the middle of the park.
41 Although most of the play is now taking place in the Panathinaikos half, United are still failing to make it count in the last third of the pitch.
44 Two corners in a row from the United left; Beckham takes both and both come to nothing.
45 Liberopoulos gets in again on the right side of the area, and again it is Barthez who keeps the scores level. Half-time. Not great from United despite their superior possession. Liberopoulos and Warzycha both had great chances for Panathinaikos and United have Barthez to thank for still being in the game despite a couple of near misses from Sheringham.

46 United get the second half underway.
47 Keane wins a throw deep on the right; Keane and Beckham exchange passes on the edge of the area before Panathinaikos clear.
48 GOAL Man Utd 1 - 0 Panathinaikos A long kick by Barthez is glanced on by Yorke for Sheringham to shoot home from 12 yards with his right foot. A perfect start to the second half for United.
52 United free-kick from 30 yards. Beckham curls it and keeper Nikopolidis again looks less than comfortable when faced with something from distance.
53 A little lay-off from Beckham allows Butt to 'find' Neville deep on the right with a through-ball (Neville had to run like crazy to reach it in time). The resulting cross fails to find Sheringham.
57 A dangerous ball back has Barthez scampering to make up ground and clear - not what United want at this point in the game.
59 Keane unlucky not to get on the end of Beckham's cross from the left, Henriksen the man to clear for Panathinaikos.
62 Beckham and Sheringham exchange passes just outside the area before the ball finds Neville deep on the right; the resulting cross is no use to anyone.
64 GOAL Man Utd 1 - 1 Panathinaikos
Panathinaikos free-kick just over 20 yards out. Karagounis takes and gets it cleanly around the wall and into the right corner of the net - Barthez no hope... game on. 66 A crucial touch by keeper Nikopolidis prevents United from immediately regaining the advantage as Beckham races on to a through-ball to shoot from 15 yards. Corner, Beckham takes and Panathinaikos clear.
68 After something of a lull after United's goal, the game is now being played at knock-out pace as Alex Ferguson's men seek desperately to ensure they start their second-stage campaign with a win.
71 Yorke turns his man and gets away down the right, Panathinaikos hold their ground and head his cross clear.
72 Scholes takes on the appearance of a terrier and battles his way through a clutch of Panathinaikos players on the edge of the area to shoot wide for a corner. Comes to nothing.
75 Substitution Kiassos on for Warzycha.
76 Another lull as both teams pause for thought - United seem intent on exploiting the left and to this end the majority of Beckham's crosses this half have come from the left flank, usually aimed towards Keane deep on the far side. Shame Panathinaikos read it every time.
79 Substitution Olivares on for Sypniewski.
81 GOAL Man Utd 2 - 1 Panathinaikos A great run by Silvestre takes him past two defenders and into the area; his shot is blocked but Scholes is on to the rebound in a flash to put United in the lead.
85 Having regained the lead, United now start to live dangerously when first Silvestre and then Yorke give the ball away in their own half - even if they do fight successfully to get it back.
89 Silvestre attempts another break down the right but this time fails to reach the area. United in general are not prepared to sit back and are continually trying to push into the Panathinaikos half.
90 GOAL Man Utd 3 - 1 Panathinaikos A absolute cracker from Scholes. A gem of a lay-off by Sheringham from a Beckham centre finds Scholes on the right; he runs on and lobs the keeper from the edge of the area. Game over. Full-time.
Man Utd 3 - 1 Panathinaikos

webTitle: Race attack family denied new home

fields.headline: Race attack family denied new home
fields.trailText: Southwark council has declared a single mother and her seven children "intentionally homeless" after they were forced out of their south London house by a racist gang wielding baseball bats and knives. John Carvel reports.
fields.body:
Southwark council has declared a single mother and her seven children "intentionally homeless" after they were forced out of their south London house by a racist gang wielding baseball bats and knives.

The Labour council has given June Rowe and her family until December 11 to vacate a hostel in the Old Kent Road where it placed them after the attack in June.

In a letter explaining the decision, the council acknowledged that the Rowe family qualified as homeless and "in priority need." But officials said the council was no longer legally required to provide accommodation because of the family's poor behaviour before the attack.

Southward housing department has effectively washed its hands of the Rowes on the grounds that they could have been evicted legitimately if a gang of at least 20 white youths had not saved time by driving the family out with bricks, stones and racist insults.

The decision is particularly distressing for Mrs Rowe, 34, because her teenage daughter is seven months pregnant and the ante-natal midwife is concerned that she may give birth in bed-and-breakfast accommodation or worse.

One of her sons is due to be released from a secure unit next month and will probably be placed in care unless the family can be found a permanent home.

The attack that sparked the crisis came late one Sunday afternoon in June at the four bedroom house in Bermondsey where the Rowes had been living since they were placed there by the council in December 1997.

Mrs Rowe said her family suffered persistent racial abuse and harassment from neighbours since moving into the property. The children were becoming emotionally disturbed and this was affecting their behaviour at school. But the council refused to rehouse them.

According to Mrs Rowe's account of the attack, a large group of youths gathered outside her home, shouting abuse and throwing bricks and stones.

"They were all armed with knives and various other weapons. My son and I were hit by bricks. My son had to be taken to hospital by ambulance ... I was so terrified by the incident that I refused to stay there any longer."

The family fled to stay briefly with Mrs Rowe's brother at Lee Green in south-east London.

According to a report on the incident by the Metropolitan police race hate unit, Mrs Rowe and her son were called "black bastards" by a group of 20 to 30 people "armed with an assortment of weapons such as baseball bats, knives and possibly a sword". The boy needed continuing medical attention for his injuries, but was not detained in hospital.

The police report said: "There is a likelihood of repeat victimisation should the victims remain resident at this property."

Mrs Rowe said she was initially told by Southwark officials that her family should return to the house. When she insisted it was too dangerous to do so, they arranged alternative accommodation in a hostel on the Old Kent Road.

A single attic room on the top floor was provided for Mrs Rowe, her children aged 17, 14, 13, 11, eight, seven and four, and all their toys, cooking utensils and possessions. They slept on three double mattresses and a bunk bed and had to use the same space for eating and general living accommodation.

After intervention by Harriet Harman, the local MP, and Madeleine Lindsay, Mrs Rowe's solicitor, the family was provided with a second room in mid-October.

Last week Southwark council gave Mrs Rowe its final decision on her request for housing assistance. In spite of the police evidence about the attack on her Bermondsey home, it said it was "unable to concur that the incident was conclusively a racially motivated attack."

The family's private landlords had been unwilling to renew the tenancy because of complaints about the Rowes' noisy behaviour and damage to the property estimated at £2,000-£3,000. Managing agents served notice of repossession before the attack.

The council concluded that the family deliberately caused their own eviction.

The 1996 Housing Act says: "A person becomes homeless intentionally if he deliberately does or fails to do anything in consequence of which he ceases to occupy accommodation which is available for his occupation and which it would have been reasonable for him to continue to occupy."

On Wednesday the Guardian asked the council for an opportunity to get answers to three questions: why officials appeared to have discounted police evidence about the racist attack, why they thought a single attic room was appropriate temporary accommodation for a family of seven, and how the system could produce an outcome where nobody accepted responsibility for housing a family "in priority need."

Two days later a spokeswoman for Southwark said: "The council's legal obligation is to those who have not made themselves intentionally homeless. In the case of June Rowe investigations have shown that she had made herself intentionally homeless. We have no comment beyond that, because the decision letter states the council's position.

Mrs Rowe's lawyers are requesting a review of the decision. They have asked for her to be allowed to stay at the hostel after December 11, although the council has no legal responsibility to let her do so.

Mrs Rowe's future may depend on a human rights case being brought before the courts.
fields.bodyText: Southwark council has declared a single mother and her seven children "intentionally homeless" after they were forced out of their south London house by a racist gang wielding baseball bats and knives. The Labour council has given June Rowe and her family until December 11 to vacate a hostel in the Old Kent Road where it placed them after the attack in June. In a letter explaining the decision, the council acknowledged that the Rowe family qualified as homeless and "in priority need." But officials said the council was no longer legally required to provide accommodation because of the family's poor behaviour before the attack. Southward housing department has effectively washed its hands of the Rowes on the grounds that they could have been evicted legitimately if a gang of at least 20 white youths had not saved time by driving the family out with bricks, stones and racist insults. The decision is particularly distressing for Mrs Rowe, 34, because her teenage daughter is seven months pregnant and the ante-natal midwife is concerned that she may give birth in bed-and-breakfast accommodation or worse. One of her sons is due to be released from a secure unit next month and will probably be placed in care unless the family can be found a permanent home. The attack that sparked the crisis came late one Sunday afternoon in June at the four bedroom house in Bermondsey where the Rowes had been living since they were placed there by the council in December 1997. Mrs Rowe said her family suffered persistent racial abuse and harassment from neighbours since moving into the property. The children were becoming emotionally disturbed and this was affecting their behaviour at school. But the council refused to rehouse them. According to Mrs Rowe's account of the attack, a large group of youths gathered outside her home, shouting abuse and throwing bricks and stones. "They were all armed with knives and various other weapons. My son and I were hit by bricks. My son had to be taken to hospital by ambulance ... I was so terrified by the incident that I refused to stay there any longer." The family fled to stay briefly with Mrs Rowe's brother at Lee Green in south-east London. According to a report on the incident by the Metropolitan police race hate unit, Mrs Rowe and her son were called "black bastards" by a group of 20 to 30 people "armed with an assortment of weapons such as baseball bats, knives and possibly a sword". The boy needed continuing medical attention for his injuries, but was not detained in hospital. The police report said: "There is a likelihood of repeat victimisation should the victims remain resident at this property." Mrs Rowe said she was initially told by Southwark officials that her family should return to the house. When she insisted it was too dangerous to do so, they arranged alternative accommodation in a hostel on the Old Kent Road. A single attic room on the top floor was provided for Mrs Rowe, her children aged 17, 14, 13, 11, eight, seven and four, and all their toys, cooking utensils and possessions. They slept on three double mattresses and a bunk bed and had to use the same space for eating and general living accommodation. After intervention by Harriet Harman, the local MP, and Madeleine Lindsay, Mrs Rowe's solicitor, the family was provided with a second room in mid-October. Last week Southwark council gave Mrs Rowe its final decision on her request for housing assistance. In spite of the police evidence about the attack on her Bermondsey home, it said it was "unable to concur that the incident was conclusively a racially motivated attack." The family's private landlords had been unwilling to renew the tenancy because of complaints about the Rowes' noisy behaviour and damage to the property estimated at £2,000-£3,000. Managing agents served notice of repossession before the attack. The council concluded that the family deliberately caused their own eviction. The 1996 Housing Act says: "A person becomes homeless intentionally if he deliberately does or fails to do anything in consequence of which he ceases to occupy accommodation which is available for his occupation and which it would have been reasonable for him to continue to occupy." On Wednesday the Guardian asked the council for an opportunity to get answers to three questions: why officials appeared to have discounted police evidence about the racist attack, why they thought a single attic room was appropriate temporary accommodation for a family of seven, and how the system could produce an outcome where nobody accepted responsibility for housing a family "in priority need." Two days later a spokeswoman for Southwark said: "The council's legal obligation is to those who have not made themselves intentionally homeless. In the case of June Rowe investigations have shown that she had made herself intentionally homeless. We have no comment beyond that, because the decision letter states the council's position. Mrs Rowe's lawyers are requesting a review of the decision. They have asked for her to be allowed to stay at the hostel after December 11, although the council has no legal responsibility to let her do so. Mrs Rowe's future may depend on a human rights case being brought before the courts.

webTitle: Charity campaign won't succeed

fields.headline: Charity campaign won't succeed
fields.standfirst: Joe Saxton, head of voluntary sector services at the Future Foundation think tank, argues that the voluntary sector campaign to increase giving is unlikely to succeed
fields.trailText: Joe Saxton, head of voluntary sector services at the Future Foundation think tank, argues that the voluntary sector campaign to increase giving is unlikely to succeed
fields.body:
The government and voluntary sector bodies are planning a campaign to "Get Britain Giving". The idea is that a whole new "brand" will be established to persuade the British population to give more. The campaign is precipitated by the recent changes that have made giving to charity more tax-efficient. The Treasury, National Council for Voluntary Organisations, the Charities Aid Foundation and a number of charities have already agreed to put funds behind the campaign and last month a mailing landed on many charity chief executives' desks asking them to contribute £5,000 or more to the fund.

One of the rallying cries for any giving initiative is usually that the Americans give a much higher percentage of their income to charity. However, I find it hard to see how a generic giving campaign can ever work.

The reason for my pessimism is simple: people don't give for the sake of giving, but because they want to help something or somebody. People give to people or because they are moved by a cause, or inspired by a particular project or person. Every good fundraiser knows this and it's why the best of them become almost invisible when they ask for money. Look at the fundraising campaigns of Oxfam, the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals or any other major fundraiser, and it's the difference your donation will make to a person or an animal that shines through.

The recent changes to Gift Aid and payroll giving now mean that virtually any donation from a taxpayer can now be made more effective. But the irony is that it isn't the government or the voluntary sector bodies who need to act, but charities themselves. Too few have done enough to convert their supporters to tax-efficient giving, let alone use it as a reason to ask for more money. One major charity has only converted 15% of its 500,000 eligible supporters

This lack of action is partly down to the difficulties of changing database systems: one senior fundraiser told me that he believes that only charities with the most sophisticated databases will be able to make the most of Gift Aid. These problems are compounded because every declaration needs to archived and stored indefinitely. Worse still the wording of the forms is often wrong, making a Gift Aid claim ineligible.

The point is that almost any charity would be better off spending a spare £5,000 on converting their own supporters to Gift Aid, recruiting payroll givers directly or upgrading their database to cope with the changes. And any campaign to promote giving might be better off helping individual charities to get their own houses in order rather than create "an overarching brand image". Ultimately if individual charities with urgent, compelling causes and the millions they spend each year on fundraising, are unable to persuade the public to give more, it's hard to see how something as nebulous as an overarching brand image will do so.

webTitle: Academic strike fails to win support

fields.headline: Academic strike fails to win support
fields.body: A threatened one-day strike over pay in universities and colleges on December 5 has failed to win decisive support from union members. Instead disruption in protest against the employers 3% pay offer is likely to take the form of withholding exam marks by lecturers and an overtime ban by technical and manual workers. Staff have been encouraged by the governments announcement last week of an extra £330m for pay over three years and are calling on the employers to resume negotiations. But Peter Humphreys, chief executive of the Universities and Colleges Employers Association, insisted there was no more money for pay this year and even the extra money from next year would come with strings attached. Members of the lecturers union Natfhe voted 56% in favour of a strike (on a 45% turnout) and nearly 80% for action short of a strike but Unison staff in the higher education sector voted 52% against strike. Natfhe, which has 18,000 lecturers in the new universities and colleges, will now decide what action to take but Tom Wilson, the unions higher education officer, said they could refuse to provide exam and assessment marks (though they might give students an informal idea of how they had done). The Association of University Teachers has not balloted on a strike action but plans demonstrative action on December 5. Sir Michael Bett, whose inquiry into higher education pay reported earlier this year, said this week that the government had not done enough to prevent the sort of staffing crisis that hit nursing in the health service. We can go on as we are in higher education and nobody will notice very much but one day we will wake up and discover there is a real crisis, said Sir Michael.

webTitle: Why little boys are not sex offenders

fields.headline: Why little boys are not sex offenders
fields.trailText: Comment: Dea Birkett puts an alternative slant on the NSPCC report, Child Maltreatment in the United Kingdom.
fields.body:
Yesterday the NSPCC published a report which should horrify every adult. Child Maltreatment in the United Kingdom surveyed almost 3,000 18-24-year-olds about how they were treated as children. One in 10 said they were forced or threatened into sex acts against their will before reaching 16.

Only 14% of this abuse was said to be carried out by the person we would most readily point a finger at - the father. The most frequent culprit was, it was claimed, another child.

It is a phenomenal claim. Look around your children's class. According to this report, at least one of those schoolboy faces struggling with his five times table masks a sex offender. Then turn your eye towards your own sitting room. The child most likely to abuse your daughter is the boy watching the Tweenies with her. Forty three per cent of abuse was said to be perpetrated by a sibling. It's no longer big brother, but little brother we have to watch out for.

It is not surprising that the report's findings show physical abuse to be seven times more prevalent than sexual abuse. But the coverage has focused almost entirely on the sexual element. This focus on child-on-child sex abuse has arisen from exactly the same professional quarters that introduced us to the atrocities of adult sex offenders.

But you cannot and should not apply the same judgments and analysis to children's behaviour. A seven-year-old showing his willy to a four-year-old is not the same thing as a 40-year-old man flashing at a woman in the park.

Kiss chase in the playground is not a form of indecent assault. It's a game, even if occasionally an unwelcome or unwanted one. The intention, understanding, meaning and effect are entirely different.

The respondents to the survey endorsed this. They identified the most distressing form of abuse by far as not sexual nor even physical abuse, but bullying.

Of course, not all children's activities are harmless, but some are more harmless than others. The report encompasses a wide range of actions that could count as sexual abuse, from kissing and cuddling to forcible oral and penetrative sex.

What inevitably happens is that overall terrifying statistics are quoted, then, as an example, an incidence of the most extreme kind is given. The London Young Abusers Centre cites oversexualised five-year-olds, sexually abusive 11-year-olds, 14-year-old rapists and even sexual homicides. The impression is that a huge number of young teenagers are buggering little boys.

Yet even according to the NSPCC's own calculations, the more extreme examples only make up a small minority of the abusive actions that actually occur. The commonest form of sexual contact was "exposed their sex organs or other private parts of their body to you in order to shock you or excite themselves"; by far the least common was anal intercourse.

I hope this report's intention is to alert us to an under-reported problem. But my concern is, as with the attention given to "stranger danger" after the murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne last summer, it will not make us more alert; it will simply make us more fearful. We will redirect our suspicion away from adult males to our own children. Brothers and sisters sharing baths, helping each other to dress, even showing each other their genitals will be revisited with an over anxious eye.

The case of 11-year-old Raoul Wuthrich, who was accused by a watchful neighbour in Colorado, US, of touching his five-year-old sister "in an inappropriate way" while helping her to pee in the garden, is a sign of just such presumptions. The case against him eventually collapsed.

There is one more worrying aspect of the report. It automatically assumes that the respondent is a victim, not a perpetrator. Of the 213 questions in the survey, not a single one asked the interviewee if he or she had ever committed abuse as a child. It all happens to you, and is never done by you. So who are these children who sexually abuse others of a similar age? The answer is simple: it wasn't you, and it certainly isn't your child. It's somebody else's family; somebody else's problem.

You should be afraid. You should be very afraid. But the fear should not be of our children, or those of our next-door neighbour, or the stranger's son with the lousy hair who lives up the street. We should be afraid that childhood has become the latest landscape to be invaded by often misrepresented statistics that can fill even the most stalwart and sensible parent with terror.

There is a real problem of child physical abuse. There is terrible emotional neglect. There is even some sexual abuse by children of children. Let's tackle it. But let's not try and make cheap points for our own ends and not the wellbeing of damaged children. It only makes us worry far more and helps far less towards solving the real problems.

webTitle: TV race deal delayed again

fields.headline: TV race deal delayed again
fields.trailText: The long-drawn out battle for the TV rights to UK horse-racing has been delayed by another week, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The long-drawn out battle for the TV rights to UK horse-racing has been delayed by another week, after today's Race Course Association meeting failed to choose between the Go Racing and Carlton bids.

The RCA said the owners of Britain's 59 racecourses would "make a final decision on or just before" next Thursday, November 30, when the offers on the table from Go Racing - a consortium including Channel 4, BSkyB and Arena Leisure - and Carlton run out.

webTitle: My inspiration: Jacqueline Wilson

fields.headline: My inspiration: Jacqueline Wilson
fields.trailText: Jacqueline Wilson, one of Britain's most popular children's authors, on her own schooldays
fields.body:
Jacqueline Wilson is one of Britain's most popular children's authors. Her latest book, Vicky Angel, has just been published.

"I was born in Bath, but we moved to south London when I was a year old. I had no brothers or sisters and from an early age I became one of those weird children who live in their imaginations. I would sit in corners nattering to myself, and after I learnt to write I used to fill exercise books full of stories. For inspiration I would cut out photos of girls from pattern books and stick cardboard on the back to turn them into paper dolls, each with its own personality.

"My first school was Lee Manor Infants, though I remember very little about it, except crying at school dinners. After a year we moved to Kingston, where I went to the Latchmere Infants and Junior School. It was hard at first as everyone had already been there a year and had made friends, but after a while I came to love it. My favourite teacher was Mr Townsend. He was kind and good-looking and I had a bit of a crush. He was encouraging about my writing and painting.

"I passed my 11+ at the second attempt and went to Coombe Girls' School in New Malden, which was run by a terrifying headteacher, Miss Hazlett, who used to take any breaches of discipline, such as not wearing a beret on the way home, immensely seriously. I was reasonably good at English, which was taken by a Miss Pierce. She was not one to praise or flatter unduly, but she taught us essay structure and had a way of gently pointing you in the way of authors worth reading.

"I passed five or six O-levels; I didn't want to to stay on to do A-levels. Had I known about sixth-form colleges or techs, I would have continued. I then spent a year at secretarial college before I replied to an ad for teenage magazine writers in the Evening Standard; I sold my very first story for three guineas, then wrote a few more, before being offered a full-time job at the magazine. I guess I was just very lucky."

webTitle: Politics: England alone in charging fees?

fields.headline: Goodbye to all that
fields.standfirst: England could soon be alone in charging fees, say  Paul McGill  and Donald MacLeod
fields.trailText: 21 November: England could soon be alone in charging fees, say Paul McGill and Donald MacLeod.
fields.body:
The government's policy on student funding is looking less and less tenable as Northern Ireland and Wales attempt to follow Scotland's move away from up-front tuition fees.

Northern Ireland's Assembly votes today on a report from its Committee for Higher and Further Education, Training and Employment which recommends the abolition of the fee of £1,050 per year for higher education. All six parties represented have agreed on the Scottish model of a graduate endowment fund.

The Welsh Assembly has initiated a review of all post-16 education, which will investigate student support. Although it lacks the tax-changing powers of the Scottish Parliament, the assembly could add weight to the campaign by the National Union of Students to abolish fees and restore targeted grants which last week brought thousands onto the streets of London.

Owain James, president of the National Union of Students, said England would soon be isolated. "It backs up our claim that the current government position is not working. The Cubie report called it discredited. The repayment threshhold for student loans is far too low and maintenance support for students from the poorest backgrounds needs to be reintroduced."

On the other flank, ministers face pressure from several influential university heads who believe they can only guarantee world-class standards if tuition fees are increased. This would be much less painful if these were paid after graduation along the lines introduced in Scotland following the Cubie report, rather than up-front, as is now the case in the rest of the UK.

In Northern Ireland the committee is proposing that graduates should pay only 9% of any income above £25,000, and the same threshold will apply to repayments of student loans. This is a major difference from Scotland, where graduates will contribute if earning more than £10,000 per year, and has led to fears that it will divert funds from helping students from poor backgrounds and put the money back in middle-class pockets.

The report is the committee's contribution to the review of student finance by the minister, Dr Sean Farren, but it may bounce him into decisions that run totally counter to the Executive's declared intention to widen participation as part of its Targeting Social Need policy.

If the report is accepted, critics argue, it would mean handing back to the middle class about £14m that could be used to pay for 7,000 bursaries of £2,000 each to help disadvantaged groups get into further and higher education.

In the 1999 New Earnings Survey, only 18.3% of adult employees in Northern Ireland earned more than £25,000, and it is likely that most of these are well into their careers, so only a tiny minority of recent graduates will pay anything.

Tuition fees have not deterred traditional school-leavers, whose numbers entering undergraduate courses continue to rise - by 14.3% in the four years to 1999/2000. By contrast, the number of adult entrants to undergraduate courses has fallen by 17% over the latest four years. But for disadvantaged students, and most adults, tuition fees for full-time courses are not an issue because they do not have to pay them - the problem is the prospect of a debt of £10,000 for a three-year course. The committee responded by proposing grants of up to £2,000 for "disadvantaged young people and full-time mature students", but offered nothing to ease the plight of those forced into part-time study.

In the longer term, much depends on whether the endowment fund works. A mechanism is needed to track every Northern Ireland student; those who graduate in England will have already paid up-front fees; if they graduated from the republic they will not have to pay anyone and if they came out of Scottish colleges they will have to contribute to the Scottish fund. Only if they graduated from Northern Ireland will they have to pay into the local fund, but many will emigrate. Systems will be needed to track them down worldwide, to see if they earn more than £25,000 sterling and to enforce payment.

 Paul McGill has written two recent reports on Targeting Social Need. He can be contacted at pmcgill@iol.ie.

webTitle: Goodbye to all that

fields.headline: Goodbye to all that
fields.standfirst:
England could soon be alone in charging fees, say Paul
                                                  McGill and Donald MacLeod
fields.trailText:
21/11/2000: The government's policy on student funding is looking less and
                                                  less tenable as Northern Ireland and Wales attempt to follow
                                                  Scotland's move away from up-front tuition fees.
fields.body:
The government's policy on student funding is looking less and less tenable as Northern Ireland and Wales attempt to follow Scotland's move away from up-front tuition fees.

webTitle: Liddiment hits back over BBC Millionaire claims

fields.headline: Liddiment hits back over BBC Millionaire claims
fields.trailText: ITV chief David Liddiment has hit back at BBC claims that the first million pound winner on Who Wants to be a Millionaire? may have been fixed, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
David Liddiment, ITV director of programmes, has hit back at BBC claims that the first million pound winner on Who Wants to be a Millionaire? may have been fixed, dismissing them as "very childish".

Mr Liddiment, speaking at today's launch of ITV's Christmas and winter schedule, was responding to BBC suggestions that the first millionaire on Millionaire was timed to hit the ratings of the last ever One Foot in the Grave on BBC1.

He said: "I am disappointed the BBC has to stoop so low as to suggest some kind of tampering was going on - it maligns the production company, Celador, and ITV."

Mr Liddiment said "that kind of pettiness does the BBC no service" and was "very childish".

He said the BBC ought to be "celebrating" the fact that Millionaire and One Foot in the Grave had between them brought an extra "four or five million" viewers to TV on Monday night.

"They both achieved fantastic ratings."

webTitle: University heads consider future of research

fields.headline: University heads consider future of research
fields.trailText: Could things be more uncertain over the future direction of university research? The research community awaits the conclusion of no fewer than seven different reviews. And you dont have to be geneticist bioinformatician to spot the underlying theme.
fields.body:
Could things be more uncertain over the future direction of university research? The research community awaits the conclusion of no fewer than seven different reviews. And you dont have to be geneticist bioinformatician to spot the underlying theme.

The topics cover: allocating money to researchers (government spending review); making sure it is properly spent by academics (transparency review); allocating money for research more efficiently in the future (funding council reviews, quinquennial review of research councils); making more money out of research (government science white paper and Foresight consultation); and, finally, making sure money isnt spent on duplicating research (European research area).

New budgets for the governments six research councils will be unveiled tomorrow following the conclusions of the Whitehall spending review. And there will be good news for scientists from disciplines as diverse as astronomy and particle physics, to medical research and engineering.

Apart from healthy real terms increases for most of the councils core budgets, they will all get something from the £250m cross cutting themes being announced. So, the biotechnology and biological sciences, and medical sciences will benefit from more money for genomic research. The particle physicists and environmental scientists will benefit from extra funding for e-science, and future powerful computing networks. The engineers will be able to build new detectors and instruments through extra support for basic technologies. And the social scientists are getting some extra funds for business schools.

And all this comes on the back of the surprise announcement last week that academic salaries will be boosted to the tune of £330m over the next three years.

University heads next week have organised a conference to partly digest these new funding plans, but also to consider the future direction of research.

Leading the stock-taking exercise will be Sir Howard Newby, president of the Committee of vice-chancellors and Principals. Newby was the central proponent for a new hub and spoke model for postgraduate funding during the recent funding council research review. Plans to concentrate postgraduate funds into top rated departments (the hubs) were watered down in the final report. But the issue is nonetheless set to be one of the few controversial topics emerging from the review.

There will also be an update on the transparency review, which for the first time will estimate how much time academics spend on research, teaching, and other activities. It will not shock anyone that one of its main conclusions is that academics are working overtime to subsidise their work. The conference meanwhile will hear about the governments latest attempts (Foresight programme and science white paper) to get UK industry to start investing in research. Perhaps the biggest development from the white paper will be at least 25 new Faraday partnerships, networks which bring academics and businesses together. There will also be a discussion on the 'European Research area'. Bureaucracy of European grant schemes alienates many researchers, but they should be aware of plans to establish a the ER area, which could promise an open market of research grants across the continent.

21st Century Research: New Challenges for Universities is being held on Tuesday 28 November at the Commonwealth Institute, London W8. Bookings can be made by calling Neil Stewart Associates on 01932 893 859, or info@newlstewartassociates.co.uk

webTitle: Preparations for the 2001 Research Assessment Exercise

fields.headline: The race is on
fields.standfirst: Neat tactics helped Oxford beat Cambridge in the last Research Assessment Exercise -  Donald MacLeod and  Lee Elliot Major take a look at preparations for 2001
fields.trailText: Neat tactics helped Oxford beat Cambridge in the last Research Assessment Exercise - Donald MacLeod and Lee Elliot Major take a look at preparations for 2001
fields.body:
The head to head between Oxford and Cambridge will be one of the most eagerly anticipated events of the academic calendar next year. And we are not talking about the boat race, varsity match, or even Jeremy Paxman's University Challenge TV quiz.

The competition is the Research Assessment Exercise - a national obsession for academics. The goal is to secure top research ratings for as many departments as possible - careers depend on it and each department knows its research funding will be dictated for the next four years by the figure that emerges. Universities will pursue just about every possible tactic to get the grades: poaching star researchers from other universities; filling academic posts before they actually fall vacant; and restructuring whole departments so that they correspond more closely to the areas of expertise on panels of referees.

The ratings, largely based on the strength of published academic papers, bring both academic kudos and cash. But what makes the exercise such an intriguing guessing game is that no one knows how much money will be allocated per researcher for each rating. The million dollar question (quite literally for many departments) is whether they will make more money by submitting larger numbers of academics at a guaranteed lower rating, or by selecting only the very best researchers and gambling for a higher rating.

The big talking point after the last RAE results, announced in December 1996 (there were over 300 hits on the RAE website on Christmas Day), was that Oxford's gamble to select relatively few academics in the exercise had played off. In terms of grants won, Oxford had deposed Cambridge from the top of the league table.

As the records of the Cambridge academic board reveal, Oxford's tactical coup is still a source of dented academic pride: "While other institutions used this tactic to a greater or lesser degree in 1996, Cambridge generally eschewed it as a matter of policy: only some 2% of the university's staff were not included, as against (for example) 9% at Oxford. The vice-chancellor has recently offered a robust criticism of the practice of other universities. Although it is frankly admitted that by adopting a similar policy Cambridge would have achieved a higher proportion of 5-star ratings (and maybe, consequently, more research funding)."

Now overseeing Cambridge's 2001 RAE submissions in the run-up to the 30 April deadline, Professor Hugh Mellor, the university's pro-vice-chancellor, concedes: "Oxford gambled one way, we gambled another. It did appear to pay off for them, they did get more money."

Despite the events of five years ago, Mellor says that the university will not be systematically more selective this time, but will invite heads of department to make judgments over who is chosen for the assessment. Oxford's RAE organisers refused to speak directly about the exercise, but released a statement denying that their 1996 submission was "unusually selective". They also pointed out that they submitted more researchers in total than Cambridge (1,764 compared with 1,595). Could this argument signal that the university will adopt a more selective approach again for 2001?

According to Mellor, Cambridge also fell victim last time round to "an unreasonably frenetic" transfer market of academics during the late stages before the deadline for the exercise. The university countered with "proleptic" appointments - filling vacancies before they arise (Mellor's own words). According to the minutes of the academic board, "some 28 appointments, in 20 units of assessment, were made in connection with the [1996] RAE. Seven of the new professors were persuaded to move from other institutions. The other two were internal promotions."

For the 2001 exercise, the university's board authorised £1.3m to be spent on such appointments, "to be filled by 1 October 2000, primarily based on the existing needs of institutions and the prospects of improving or maintaining ratings".

At least 23 senior appointments have been made through the scheme: eight in the school of physical sciences; four in each of the schools of arts and humanities, humanities and social sciences, and biological sciences; and three in technology.

Oxford suffered a huge blow to its research standing last month when a trio of professors - Roy Anderson, Brian Spratt and Geoff Smith - and about 80 researchers moved to Imperial College London. Attempting to dismiss this as "part of the normal movement of academic staff between leading research-intensive universities", the university has appointed a number of high-profile academics in the past year - for example at the Said Business School, the new Wellcome Trust Centre for Human Genetics, and the new therapeutic immunology research unit.

In fact both universities have introduced more flexible pay and appointment procedures for staff since the 1996 exercise, improving their ability to hire (and retain) academic high-fliers, while Oxford has created a new Department of Politics and International Relations to "improve the capacity of the sub-faculty of politics to respond to the Research Assessment Exercise."

Not only does a 5-star bring in money from the funding councils - more than four times as much as a 3b for the same volume of research activity - but it confers the prestige a department needs to win contracts from the research councils and private industry. High ratings attract postgraduates and have a disproportionate impact on newspaper league tables because they affect staff-student ratios and library spending.

Throughout the country, submissions are being prepared and revised and revised again in preparation for the April 30 deadline. Gone are the innocent days when a department, asked by senior management to beef up its submission, sent back the same sketchy statement in larger type.

For the 2001 exercise, preparation has been more intense than ever. The paperwork is voluminous and complex, including regulations about staff who die while in their posts.

Edinburgh has just finished a dummy run of submissions from all departments. Glasgow - which only managed 35 departments in the top three categories in 1996, compared with its east coast rival's 42 - has been preparing for 18 months.

But at Southampton the director of planning, John Taylor, says preparations for 2001 started as soon as the last exercise was announced. The university did a dummy run two years ago, with every department filling in the forms and external academics offering comments and advice: "We aimed to identify weaknesses when we had still an opportunity to do something about them."

While a lot of universities plan to play the Oxford gambit and be more selective about the staff they enter as "research active", Southampton will enter more staff this time - 95% instead of 85%. "We believe the quality of our staff has gone up," says Taylor.

Not only does each department have to decide which staff to enter but also which of the 69 units of assessment to choose - tricky in some cases. Professor Peter Holmes, vice-principal for research at Glasgow University, points out that biomedical scientists working on cardiovascular disease could come under at least three units of assessment: biological sciences, clinical laboratory sciences or studies and professions allied to medicine. New research income at the university has doubled in four years to £110m, but tactics are still vital.

Glasgow will be entering a small number of joint submissions with its neighbour Strathclyde, though Holmes feels collaboration is not adequately recognised or rewarded.

But how glittering will the prizes for this marathon turn out to be? It depends how the funding councils decide to cut the cake in the light of the results - possibly departments rated 3b will get no research funding (today 1-star and 2-star get nothing). Almost certainly there will be a bigger crop of high grades. Funding is unlikely to keep pace, though research seems to have done well in the government's spending plans. Some departments could lose money despite maintaining or improving ratings.

Comments Geoffrey Copland, vice-chancellor of Westminster, a new university which had some successes in 1996: "A general uplift of scores without an uplift in money is not going to help anybody very much."
