Professor Peter Holmes, vice-principal for research at Glasgow University, points out that biomedical scientists working on cardiovascular disease could come under at least three units of assessment: biological sciences, clinical laboratory sciences or studies and professions allied to medicine. New research income at the university has doubled in four years to £110m, but tactics are still vital. Glasgow will be entering a small number of joint submissions with its neighbour Strathclyde, though Holmes feels collaboration is not adequately recognised or rewarded. But how glittering will the prizes for this marathon turn out to be? It depends how the funding councils decide to cut the cake in the light of the results - possibly departments rated 3b will get no research funding (today 1-star and 2-star get nothing). Almost certainly there will be a bigger crop of high grades. Funding is unlikely to keep pace, though research seems to have done well in the government's spending plans. Some departments could lose money despite maintaining or improving ratings. Comments Geoffrey Copland, vice-chancellor of Westminster, a new university which had some successes in 1996: "A general uplift of scores without an uplift in money is not going to help anybody very much." Researching the research Could things be more uncertain over the future direction of university research? The research community awaits the conclusion of no fewer than seven different reviews. And you don't have to be geneticist bioinformatician to spot the underlying theme. The topics cover: allocating money to researchers (government spending review); making sure it is properly spent by academics (transparency review); allocating money for research more efficiently in the future (funding council reviews, quinquennial review of research councils); making more money out of research (government science white paper and Foresight consultation); and, finally, making sure money isn't spent on duplicating research (European research area). New budgets for the government's six research councils will be unveiled tomorrow following the conclusions of the Whitehall spending review. And there will be good news for scientists from disciplines as diverse as astronomy and particle physics, medical research and engineering. Apart from healthy real-terms increases for most of the councils' core budgets, they will all get something from the £250m cross-cutting themes being announced. So the biotechnology and biological sciences and medical sciences will benefit from more money for genomic research. The particle physicists and environmental scientists will benefit from extra funding for e-science, and future powerful computing networks. The engineers will be able to build new detectors and instruments through extra support for basic technologies. And social scientists are getting some extra funds for business schools. And all this comes on the back of the surprise announcement last week that academic salaries will be boosted to the tune of £330m over the next three years. University heads next week have organised a conference partly to digest these new funding plans, but also to consider the future direction of research.

webTitle: PM interview questions secret

fields.headline: PM live interview questions top secret claims ITV
fields.standfirst: 10.30am: Blair gives live interview on ITV
fields.trailText:
6pm:The producer of ITV's Ask the Prime Minister show insists Blair will not know the questions to be asked by the public before the show, writes Jason Deans
10.30am: Blair gives live interview on ITV
fields.body:
The executive producer of ITV's live Ask the Prime Minister insists Tony Blair will not know the questions to be asked by the public before the show. But Will Smith admitted that the production team would be letting No 10 know five or six areas of discussion likely to be covered in the live 60-minute special, which will be broadcast at 7pm on Tuesday December 12.

The topics will be selected from questions submitted by members of the public, via the phone line ITV is opening tomorrow.

Callers to the Ask the Prime Minister number, which will be a national rather than premium rate line, will be asked "What do you most want to ask the prime minister?".

The studio audience of around 300 for the show will also be drawn predominantly from people who call the phone line over the next three weeks.

Mr Smith said a polling firm would be used to select an audience that was representative of ITV's overall viewer profile.

Ask the Prime Minister will be broadcast from a TV studio outside London. But ITV director of programmes David Liddiment said it definitely would not be coming from the National Exhibition Centre in Birmingham, which was where the broadcaster's much criticised Monarchy debate was filmed.

Mr Liddiment said that if the format proved a success, he would "absolutely" consider doing it again.

But controller of news Steve Anderson said ITV was "not obliged to offer the opposition" a similar platform for William Hague, as the programme was being broadcast outside a general election.

The BBC today blasted ITV bosses for their claims.

webTitle: No time limit on supreme court deliberations

fields.headline: No time limit on supreme court deliberations
fields.trailText: There is no schedule for the Florida supreme courtÍs potentially crucial announcement on whether or not to keep the manual recounts going in the contested US election, an official insisted today.
fields.body:
There is no schedule for the Florida supreme courtÍs potentially crucial announcement on whether or not to keep the manual recounts going in the contested US election, an official insisted today.

It had been anticipated that there might be a ruling soon, which could effectively decide the fate of the US presidential deadlock between George W Bush and Al Gore.

However, Craig Waters, a spokesman for FloridaÍs highest court, said all speculation was unfounded. He said: "There is no timetable at the present time as to when a decision is going to be made. We just donÍt know."

Seven judges are struggling with a quandary central to the outcome, which is: how to save the state from being counted out of the election while protecting the rights of all voters to have their say.

Mr Waters said that while some of the judges had been absent from court today because of ceremonial duties, they and the teams of lawyers were working very hard.

FloridaÍs chief justice Charles T Wells declared yesterday: "We have a long-standing policy ... that says the real interests here are the voters." He spoke as the seven-member court heard oral arguments on the disputed manual recount, how the counts should be done and whether those results should be included in the final state tally of about 6m votes.

Mr Wells asked repeatedly how long the state had to certify a winner and still have its voice heard when the electoral college meets to pick a president.

The magic date, mentioned repeatedly by Democrats during yesterdayÍs hearing, was December 12, the day designated in federal law for Florida to pick its electors. The electoral college meets six days later.

On that basis, the justices could rule as early as today, or not for weeks.

At mid morning, Mr Waters emerged from the court to say "there's nothing new". He explained he was only making a statement because of a flood of rumours, and to assure reporters there was no decision yet. "We are still in the same stage we were yesterday," he said.

With public interest reaching fever pitch, the court's website posted an advisory, reading: "Please do not call the court expecting to speak with a Justice about the election cases."

However, Joe Klock, representing FloridaÍs secretary of state, Katherine Harris, insisted she was bound by a state law that required her to certify a winner by seven days after the November 7 election, a deadline now long gone.

Yes, Mr Klock conceded, the recounts could begin late, just before the electoral college deadline. But he suggested they never would be completed. He said: "That is the same basic rule I had in high school with term papers. You can start the term paper the night before if you want to but it still must be turned in on time."

An election law professor, Richard L Hasen, of Loyola University Law School in Los Angeles, said the justices' top concern seemed to be that Florida's 25 votes in the electoral college be counted. A second priority, he said, is to assure that the hand recounts taking place in three counties get in "under the wire".

The candidate who gains those 25 electoral votes stands to become the nation's 43rd chief executive. Mr Gore leads Mr Bush 260-246 in electoral votes with 270 needed to win. The US presidency is determined not by the popular vote, which Mr Gore won, but by the electoral college where each of the 50 states is allocated votes based on population.

Mr Wells said: "The court is certainly aware of the historic nature of this session and is aware that this is a matter of utmost and vital importance to our nation, our state and our world." In legal debates that stretched to two and a half hours yesterday, justices aggressively questioned lawyers.

webTitle: uTravel folds

fields.headline: Now uTravel, now you don't
fields.trailText: 4pm: United News & Media has closed online travel site uTravel.co.uk. Dan Milmo reports.
fields.body:
United News & Media has pulled the plug on its uTravel.co.uk travel website, after it failed to break into a crowded market.

The site, launched in August 1999 by United's Xilerate new media division, provided information on holidays and a list of travel agents near a customer's home.

Despite reaching 6m page impressions a month and garnering 80,000 unique users, the venture could not keep up with rivals such as ebookers.com.

"The online holiday market was very competitive and people had much more critical mass than us," said an Xilerate spokesperson.

Andrew Nugee, chief executive of Xilerate, said the company will focus more on its business-to-business sites. The admission throws a spotlight on the future of United's Dotmusic site and lads' portal Megastar, which do not fit easily into the group's B2B ambitions.

United is to change its name to United Business Media before the end of the year, confirming its transformation from a multi-media giant into a business information company.

webTitle: OK! takes legal action against Hello

fields.headline: OK! takes legal action against Hello
fields.trailText: 5pm: Hello magazine has been taken off the streets today after a legal row with its arch-rival OK!. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
OK! magazine has issued an injunction against its arch-rival, Hello, which is thought to have rushed out a spoiler issue including photographs of the wedding of Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones.

OK! editorial director Paul Ashford confirmed that it was taking "legal action" against the magazine over the photos, which Mr Ashford said were "not very good".

OK!'s own wedding special is due to be published on Friday.

The magazine, together with Mr Douglas and Ms Zeta Jones, is reported to have gone to extraordinary lengths to safeguard the exclusive pictures, for which OK! was paying £1m.

Newsagents in the London area were today issued with a mini-poster warning them about the injunction and instructing them not to put copies of Hello on sale.

The notice from WH Smith News said: "We have received notification from Northern & Shell (publishers of OK! magazine) that they have obtained an injunction on Hello issue 639 and you should not offer any copies.

"We have received official notification of this injunction after the packing/distribution had been undertaken. We will be contacting you regarding the collection shortly.

"Apologies for any inconvenience caused."

webTitle: Arrests follow TV sex abuse claims

fields.headline: Arrests follow TV sex abuse claims
fields.trailText: Merseyside police have arrested two men in their early 70s after a TV programme identified a great-grandfather as an alleged serial child sex abuser.
fields.body:
Merseyside police have arrested two men in their early 70s after a TV programme identified a great-grandfather as an alleged serial child sex abuser.

BBC2's Newsnight claimed a 71-year-old regularly raped his three stepdaughters in Birkenhead, Merseyside, but was not on the sex offenders register.

The BBC said the programme had "not been an exercise in naming and shaming" and that the alleged victims, police and social services had been aware in advance.

Police chiefs have promised to investigate the claims made in last night's broadcast and at lunchtime announced that two men had been arrested in connection with the programme. Merseyside police would not name them but said they were both in their early 70s and were from Merseyside.

When confronted by Newsnight, the man admitted that he started having sex with one of the children when she was 10 or 11. One of his stepdaughters told the programme she thought he was still capable of abusing children in the future.

The report also claimed that the man passed his stepdaughters on to others for sex. It alleged his only conviction, for indecent assault on a minor, dated back 23 years.

The alleged abuse is thought to have taken place in the 1970s. Both alleged victims are now grown-up women.

A police spokeswoman said: "As a result of the Newsnight programme and further investigations by Merseyside police, fresh evidence has come to light and Merseyside police responded positively."

Assistant chief constable Grahame Barker said in a statement: "We would be concerned about any programme or newspaper article which identified alleged sex offenders. This can only serve to damage the detailed work being carried out by all agencies and to inflame the public."

A BBC spokesman said last night: "This has been a long-term serious detailed investigation designed to explore the reality of child abuse occurring within the family rather than children snatched off the street."

Did the BBC act responsibly when it decided to identify an alleged child abuser? Is Newsnight's disclosure likely to help or hinder agencies working with child abuse victims and children being abused? To debate the issue, please click here

webTitle: Race attack family denied new home

fields.headline: Race attack family denied new home
fields.standfirst:
Council says mother and children who were forced out of their house by armed gang are 'intentionally homeless'
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A single mother and her seven children have been declared "intentionally homeless" after being forced out of their south London house by a racist gang wielding baseball bats and knives.
fields.body:
A single mother and her seven children have been declared "intentionally homeless" after being forced out of their south London house by a racist gang wielding baseball bats and knives.

Southwark's Labour council has given June Rowe and her family until December 11 to vacate a hostel in the Old Kent Road where it placed them after the attack in June.

In a letter explaining the decision, the council acknowledged that the Rowe family qualified as homeless and "in priority need." But officials said the council was no longer legally required to provide accommodation because of the family's poor behaviour before the attack.

Southward housing department has effectively washed its hands of the Rowes on the grounds that they could have been evicted legitimately if a gang of at least 20 white youths had not saved time by driving the family out with bricks, stones and racist insults.

The decision is particularly distressing for Mrs Rowe, 34, because her teenage daughter is seven months pregnant and the ante-natal midwife is concerned that she may give birth in bed-and-breakfast accommodation or worse.

One of her sons is due to be released from a secure unit next month and will probably be placed in care unless the family can be found a permanent home.

The attack that sparked the crisis came late one Sunday afternoon in June at the four bedroom house in Bermondsey where the Rowes had been living since they were placed there by the council in December 1997.

Mrs Rowe said her family suffered persistent racial abuse and harassment from neighbours since moving into the property. The children were becoming emotionally disturbed and this was affecting their behaviour at school. But the council refused to rehouse them.

According to Mrs Rowe's account of the attack, a large group of youths gathered outside her home, shouting abuse and throwing bricks and stones.

"They were all armed with knives and various other weapons. My son and I were hit by bricks. My son had to be taken to hospital by ambulance ... I was so terrified by the incident that I refused to stay there any longer."

The family fled to stay briefly with Mrs Rowe's brother at Lee Green in south-east London.

According to a report on the incident by the Metropolitan police race hate unit, Mrs Rowe and her son were called "black bastards" by a group of 20 to 30 people "armed with an assortment of weapons such as baseball bats, knives and possibly a sword". The boy needed continuing medical attention for his injuries, but was not detained in hospital.

The police report said: "There is a likelihood of repeat victimisation should the victims remain resident at this property."

Mrs Rowe said she was initially told by Southwark officials that her family should return to the house. When she insisted it was too dangerous to do so, they arranged alternative accommodation in a hostel on the Old Kent Road.

A single attic room on the top floor was provided for Mrs Rowe, her children aged 17, 14, 13, 11, eight, seven and four, and all their toys, cooking utensils and possessions. They slept on three double mattresses and a bunk bed and had to use the same space for eating and general living accommodation.

After intervention by Harriet Harman, the local MP, and Madeleine Lindsay, Mrs Rowe's solicitor, the family was provided with a second room in mid-October.

Last week Southwark council gave Mrs Rowe its final decision on her request for housing assistance. In spite of the police evidence about the attack on her Bermondsey home, it said it was "unable to concur that the incident was conclusively a racially motivated attack."

The family's private landlords had been unwilling to renew the tenancy because of complaints about the Rowes' noisy behaviour and damage to the property estimated at £2,000-£3,000. Managing agents served notice of repossession before the attack.

The council concluded that the family deliberately caused their own eviction.

The 1996 Housing Act says: "A person becomes homeless intentionally if he deliberately does or fails to do anything in consequence of which he ceases to occupy accommodation which is available for his occupation and which it would have been reasonable for him to continue to occupy."

On Wednesday the Guardian asked the council for an opportunity to get answers to three questions: why officials appeared to have discounted police evidence about the racist attack, why they thought a single attic room was appropriate temporary accommodation for a family of seven, and how the system could produce an outcome where nobody accepted responsibility for housing a family "in priority need."

Two days later a spokeswoman for Southwark said: "The council's legal obligation is to those who have not made themselves intentionally homeless. In the case of June Rowe investigations have shown that she had made herself intentionally homeless. We have no comment beyond that, because the decision letter states the council's position.

Mrs Rowe's lawyers are requesting a review of the decision. They have asked for her to be allowed to stay at the hostel after December 11, although the council has no legal responsibility to let her do so.

Mrs Rowe's future may depend on a human rights case being brought before the courts.

webTitle: Gurkha ex-soldier sues on pay bias

fields.headline: Gurkha ex-soldier sues on pay bias
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A Gurkha ex-soldier yesterday won the right to sue the army for racial discrimination because of the difference between his pay and conditions and that of Britons.
fields.body:
A Gurkha ex-soldier yesterday won the right to sue the army for racial discrimination because of the difference between his pay and conditions and that of Britons.

Lance Corporal Hari Thapa claimed compensation for 15 years of low pay and wanted his £58 monthly pension to be raised to £500, the amount an equivalent Briton would have received. He claimed he had been forced to sell his home because he could not afford mortgage repayments. Mr Thapa, 38, son of a Gurkha officer and holding dual citizenship, lives in Cwmbran, south Wales, with his British partner and baby daughter.

The commission for racial equality is backing his case, which if successful might lead to £2bn of claims from 30,000 Gurkhas and 6,000 widows in Nepal. "Gurkhas do not get equal rights as British soldiers even if they do the same job," said Mr Thapa, who is now a security guard. "We get paid nothing like the same wage, the pension is a pittance, and everything from medical treatment to accommodation is of a lower standard."

He received an exemplary discharge after 15 years' service with a resettlement sum of £1,500; a Briton would have received £6,000. His barrister, Robin Allen QC, told the tribunal: "There has been an unlawful segregation of Gurkhas' terms and conditions from British soldiers'." Though Gurkhas served alongside Britons, pay was significantly worse until 1997. The basic of £17.50 a month was formerly topped up with variable allowances; the latter were now standardised to ensure income matched that of an equivalent Briton.

webTitle: Fowl, Fish, Meet, and Veg

fields.headline: Fowl, Fish, Meet, and Veg
fields.trailText: I AM JON FOWL-UP, BLAME ME
fields.body:
I AM JON FOWL-UP, BLAME ME

Hi, my name is Jon Fowler. I work for Football Unlimited in a menial capacity (which is all my intellectual capabilities will allow) clearing out the bins and administering mailing lists. This morning, while doing one of the incredibly simple tasks that I am paid a king's ransom to perform, I accidentally sent out a message to everybody on the Fiver mailing list, about how some Canadian or other had made it into the England under-21 squad. This should not have happened, and will not happen again. I am very sorry, and have voluntarily given up a month's pay as punishment. Please forgive me, I am a wretch.

Yours Jon Fowler

EDITOR'S NOTE: If you think that Fowl-up has got off too lightly, please send your mails of vituperation to the.boss@theguardian.com, and we will make sure to shove them down his throat.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

KEANE AS (DIJON) MUSTARD (ON A SLICE OF GRANARY BREAD TOPPED WITH LAMB'S LIVER)

If it wasn't for the twitchy 'Daniel-Day-Lewis-in-My-Left-Foot' instep of Dynamo Kiev "striker" George Demetradze, Manchester United would not be facing Panathinaikos in the Big Cup tonight. And the Fiver wouldn't be stuck in a 27-mile tailback on the M1 either. But don't worry about us: the chicken tikka sandwiches have been packed in the hamper - prawn sandwiches are so Group stage one - and a nice, air conditioned executive box is waiting. And so, it seems, is the United skipper, Roy Keane.

Today the £50,000-per-week prole said he stood by his attack on those fancy-dan United fans who eat fish sandwiches and never get behind their team. "Every comment you make gets blown out of all proportion, but I felt it had to be said," an unrepentant Keano told the Manchester Evening News, before revealing he wasn't the only one at Old Trafford with these quasi-Marxist views (MI6, please take note). "A lot of the lads felt the same way in the Kiev match," he claimed, "and sometimes as captain you have to be the one who puts your head on the chopping block - and it was just about chopped off completely!" Not the last time we looked Roy, although these things can be arranged.

What's more, after scolding supporters for their lack of support, Keane then had the cheek to ask them to cheer on the Reds tonight! "Fans have to understand that even when you are 1-0 up, if you are not on top of your game, like we weren't against Kiev, then you need the crowd behind you at that stage," he urged. "It's no use them getting behind the team when you are four or five goals up. The fans have to dig deep, like we do, and help out. Now we must all concentrate on this game." Damn right Roy, but not until the Fiver has finished our five course meal, coffee, truffles and the rest of that 82 Bordeaux.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

LUCK BE A LEARY TONIGHT

If David O'Leary was a jolly Irish stereotype which - we hasten to point out, he is not - then today he would have discovered a pot of gold at the end of a rainbow while kissing the blarney stone with a leprechaun who has close personal friends in the four leaf clover business. Yes, if it wasn't for the fact that O'Leary's O'Leeds were set to face Real Madrid in Big Cup tomorrow night without anything remotely approximating a midfield, then today would be his lucky day.

Take for example the news that Harry Kewell (remember him?) is set to return from his long-term Achilles injury within the next three weeks. That's about a whole month earlier than expected! Wow! No wonder O'Leary sounded downbeat this morning. "The big problem is that Harry missed the whole of pre-season and that is six weeks of training that sets you up for the season," he moaned. "But the good news is that he started light training last week, and we'll have him back and ready to play inside the next three weeks."

But the glad tidings of joy didn't stop there. O'Leary was also invited by the ever caring FA to visit Lancaster Gate to discuss fixture congestion. "We regard David O'Leary as an outstanding manager for whom we have the highest regard," David Davies said today after O'Leary became the umpteenth manager of a big club to demand fewer games (but, interestingly, the first one to be granted an audience with the FA). "The matters which he has expressed concerns about are clearly very important to him and we would like to discuss them with him."

What a lucky blighter. And that's without Luis Figo popping up to insist that tomorrow night's game will be one of Madrid's "most serious challenges of the season". And, what's more, the Portuguese international (who'll be vying with Jacob Burns and Matthew Jones for midfield supremacy tomorrow) really meant it. Wow.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I have a love child." Franz Beckenbauer admits to getting it on with mystery Munich secretary Elizabeth L at Bayern Munich's last Christmas party. Their union produced a son, Johann, but the Kaiser has vowed to stay with his wife, Sybille.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

COUNTDOWN TO DOOMSDAY

There is, the Fiver is sorry to bring to your attention, an outside possibility that defeat against Bradford this weekend could lose Bryan Robbo his job as manager of Middlesbrough. This is troubling news for all fans of chequebook football, not to mention those with a fetish for physically-damaged 30-somethings. But no matter how well-prepared you are for the news, there is nothing you can do about it. Only one man has the power to make a change and, yes, that's Robbo.

Resuming a series of lectures that didn't do too well when he first aired them a year ago, Robbo took his soapbox out today to remind his players that performances on the field are not his responsibility. "Players have to stand up and be counted," he said. "They have to realise they are the ones who are making mistakes." Of course (the Fiver, at this point, resists the urge to point out that it wasn't the players who signed Noel Whelan).

Warming to his theme, Robbo went on: "It doesn't matter about tactics or formations that you play if people are making bad individual errors then you are going to lose football matches." True, and probably even more compelling if Kelvin Koogan hadn't said something similar after Euro 2000. "They're not just letting me down, they're letting the club and themselves down," Robbo concluded stirringly, without checking on whether letting club and self down actually bothers his players or not.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Leeds have given West Ham a £15m "take it or leave it" ultimatum for Rio Ferdinand, according to Teamtalk. The website quotes Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale, who claims: "West Ham can take it or leave it. The player may only be worth £5m to them in the near future depending on the outcome of EU deliberations. Our bid already constitutes a world record for a defender, and is a measured valuation. There will be no more."

Honduras international defender Samuel Caballero is being lined up to replace either Sol Campbell at Spurs or Rio Ferdinand at West Ham, according to Planet Football.

Manchester United are ready to sell Dwight Yorke if they receive an offer of around £15m.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Lazio have banned Sven-Goran Eriksson from travelling to Villa Park to watch England's friendly against Spain in February. A statement from Lazio's director general, Massimo Cragnotti, said: "We made an exception in allowing him to go to Turin for the England v Italy match, accompanied by Lazio staff. But to allow him to go to another stadium to watch another England friendly, this time at Villa Park, would not be right for Lazio's players, for the fans or for the club. It is not going to happen."

Sander Westerveld has criticised his teammates for their woeful performance against Spurs. "There's no point in pretending otherwise, if we continue to play the way we did against Tottenham we'll be out of Europe very quickly and we won't finish any higher than sixth in the Premiership," he told icons.com. "We must improve on Thursday when we play Olympiakos in [Euro Vase]," he added. "If we make the same mistakes again we'll be beaten 5-0."

John Hartson's £4m move to Charlton is in danger of collapsing after the Addicks board failed to agree to his wage demands.

Jack Dyson, a member of Manchester City's 1956 FA Cup-winning team, has died in Oldham at the age of 66. Dyson, a striker who scored 26 goals in 63 league appearances for City, also made 150 appearances for Lancashire county cricket team over a 10-year period, scoring 4,433 runs and taking 161 wickets.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match (10.30pm) Man Utd highlights. No other matches tonight mean that there's no point getting angry about having to wait till 11.30 for the second half of the show. No point, but still an option.

The Big Match (2am) Or you could pretend that you had to wait till 2am. Now that would be frustrating.

Channel 4: Football Italia (2.10am) More Serie A action, beamed to England via a very slow satellite.

Channel 5: Argentinian football (4.15am) Max Bretof and Christian Bozzo - the best commentating duo in football. Why don't you find out for yourself?

Sky Sports 1: World Football show (6.30pm) It's Tuesday evening! It's 6.30! Time for Burundian box-to-box thrills!

Sky Sports 2: Inside Scottish football (7pm) Featuring Dick Advocaat's "Red, Hot and Dutch" - a guide to the best mediocre Dutch footballers on the market.

Onsport 1: AC Milan v Galatasaray - Live (7.30pm) If you're watching this you've probably pressed the wrong button.

Onsport 2: Man Utd v Panathinaikos - Live (7pm) Either that or you're the sort of protesting prawn-muncher who doesn't even deserve his subscription to "Reds under the bed" monthly.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football Live (7pm) More football without pictures, when will they learn?

webTitle: BT moves into web entertainment

fields.headline: BT set to move into entertainment
fields.trailText: 11am: BT is to produce entertainment programmes for the internet, which could be sold to terrestrial TV stations. Dan Milmo reports.
fields.body:
BT is to produce its own entertainment programmes for the internet and could sell them to terrestrial TV stations.

The telecoms giant has been negotiating with major US film studios and independent television companies with a view to creating game shows and comedies for its BTopenworld broadband service.

A BT spokesman said that negotiations with US companies were at an early stage, but the plan was to syndicate the programmes to cable and terrestrial networks around the world.

He said: "We are not primarily a content provider, but the boundaries are changing now. The key factor is that we have started this early and some of these content deals could blossom into appearances on terrestrial TV."

BT's decision to get involved in programming comes at least five years after it first mooted the notion of dial-up movies and entertainment across the net.

John Raczka, senior vice-president for content at Btopenworld, has been leading the radical initiative, which will see programmes broadcast down high-speed internet connections onto a customer's computer.

The programmes are likely to be short, and BT expects broadcasting to begin before the end of 2001.

BT will share rights to the projects, giving it a share of the spoils if they are transformed into television shows.

BT has already signed over 90 content deals with companies including MTV and Reuters, though this latest development is a significant departure for the group.

Telecoms, internet and media companies are racing to find original content that would be suitable for a combination of TV, computers and wireless devices.

webTitle: EasyGroup launches best-buy site

fields.headline: EasyGroup launches best-buy site
fields.trailText: 2.45pm Stelios Haji-Ioannou's easyGroup has expanded its internet empire with a site that compares prices for online shoppers, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Stelios Haji-Ioannou, founder of easyGroup, has extended his internet empire with the launch of easyValue.com, a price comparison service.

The service, which is pitching itself again the likes of DealTime and ShopSmart, launches today with four product categories - CDs, DVDs, books and videos.

Two more product categories, life insurance, flights and video games, are due to be added soon.

EasyValue works by comparing prices from different online stores, including Whsmith, Jungle, Amazon, HMV, Tesco and Audiostreet, so that consumers can check out the best deals before they buy.

When visitors to easyValue are ready to buy, they click through to the chosen retailer's website to complete the transaction. EasyValue will take a small commission on completed sales generated from its website.

EasyValue adds to the growing raft of easyGroup websites, which include easyRentacar and easyEverything.

webTitle: Government puts £1m into campaign to boost charity donations

fields.headline: Government puts £1m into campaign to boost charity donations
fields.trailText: Treasury Minister Stephen Timms has announced a £1m package to launch a new charity sector-led campaign to boost charitable giving.
fields.body:
Treasury Minister Stephen Timms has announced a £1m package to launch a new charity sector-led campaign to boost charitable giving.

The campaign, led jointly by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) and the Charities Aid Foundation (CAF), aims to raise awareness of the Getting Britain Giving package. Their plan is to develop an "overarching brand for charitable giving".

The £1m investment will be backed up by the secondment of government staff to the campaign team. Speaking at the annual NCVO lobby conference today, Mr Timms said: "NCVO, CAF and others from the voluntary sector are working very hard to put together a campaign team to boost the giving of both time and money. The team, which will be run by charity sector professionals, will focus on such diverse groups as businesses, high net worth individuals, young people and volunteers."

He added: "The Getting Britain Giving package offers the best ever opportunity for the charitable sector to increase donations, but it needs to be widely publicised if it is to reach its full potential. Our new investment, both of time and money, will help the charitable sector fully tap this opportunity."

Michael Brophy, chief executive of CAF, welcomed the news. "This is great news for charitable giving in this country," he said. "Not only do we have the most liberal tax environment in the world as a result of changes introduced this year, we now have more money with which to start spreading the message."

However, Joe Saxton, head of voluntary sector services at the Future Foundation think tank is sceptical. "If individual charities with urgent, compelling causes and the millions they spend each year on fundraising, are unable to persuade the public to give more, its hard to see how something as nebulous as an overarching brand image will do so," he said.

webTitle: Product placement more influential than ads

fields.headline: Product placement more influential than ads
fields.trailText: 2pm: Product placement has a greater influence on children's desire for products than advertising, says a leading academic. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Clandestine marketing methods such as product placement have a greater influence on children's desire for products than advertising, according to a leading academic.

Els de Bens, a professor at the University of Ghent in Belgium, said product placement and merchandising where children are not always aware they are being sold to, were more damaging than TV commercials.

Much research has been done on product placement in prime time shows; car, food and clothing companies are desperate to get their wares on big TV shows. But little research has been done about the presence of toys, soft drinks, books and even clothes in children's TV programme.

Speaking at the Advertising Association conference on advertising for children, Ms de Bens said: "It is preferable to have blocks of advertising that can be regulated by the authorities, than to have advertising forced to use clandestine methods.

"It is impossible to shield children from the various forms of commercialism but education is better than censorship."

Ms de Bens said the authorities should ensure that misleading advertising was not broadcast and she advocated Britain's ITC code as a good model for other European countries.

The Flemish speaking part of Belgium bans ads from being broadcast during the five minutes either side of children's programmes. But Ms de Bens said that the ban was ineffective because children in Belgium could watch channels broadcast from other countries such as Holland and France.

webTitle: Health: The diary of a junior dorctor

fields.headline: The animal in us
fields.standfirst: The diary of a junior doctor
fields.trailText: The diary of a junior doctor.
fields.body:
Patients are like wild animals: you can never show fear, or they will attack. I'm tempted to believe that we have a habit of over-complicating things, not just to patients, but to each other, in order to bolster some illusory sense of control.

On some level, even to the most educated and involved patient, we routinely lie in our mannerisms and attitudes, because medicine just isn't a precise business, and if you took a moment to be honest with yourself, you would admit that you find it hard to cope with that, especially when mortality is hitting you for the first time, and especially in A&E.

You don't want me standing over you in casualty thinking out loud: "Buggered if I know, but you can't die too quickly as long as I hit you with some oxygen and keep your circulation moving."

You want nurses and doctors dashing in and out of the cubicle, barking out coded instructions with thinly veiled urgency: you want the machine that goes ping, you want to be seen the moment you walk in the door, and you want it all to happen to the soundtrack of a drum and bass remix of the Casualty theme tune.

What you get, of course, after waiting for several hours in a crowded waiting room full of screaming toddlers and haemorrhagic tramps, is a junior doctor like me. And once I've ascertained that you're not on the verge of death, while you are sizing me up for the haggard-looking teenager I appear to be (I promise you, I'm 24 and I work well under pressure), I'm trying to work out what kind of doctor you want me to be, because most of the time, it's harder than diagnosing your (frankly rather pedestrian) angina attacks.

The stakes are high. I've had patients, who were either demented or plain belligerent, just clam up on me: I swear, I was so friendly and charming, they just stopped taking me seriously, and waited for the real doctor to arrive. I may feel the same way myself sometimes, but believe me, those real doctors can take a very long time to answer their bleeps.

I know I can't expect it to be any other way. I don't expect you to tick the box marked "authoritarian medical practitioner please" any more than I expect you to fall out of the ambulance with Subdural Haematoma Scan My Head Please written on your T-shirt.

But what I don't like is when it gets complicated and you uppity, over-educated Guardian readers start off all bitchy about me not telling you exactly what diagnostic options are passing through my head and then start demanding a more precise logical explanation of exactly why your 97-year-old mother fell off the commode this morning when the best I can come up with is that her house is a mess, the telephone cable is spangled across the room at ankle height, she can't see without her specs, and her children should do the honourable thing and either stick her in a home or let her move in with them in their flash central London pied à terre.

Am I ranting? My humblest apologies. Just try to remember that if you're going to die on the doorstep, we'll save you if anyone can, and if you're not, then we're doing just fine, Holby City histrionics or not. This is a teaching hospital for God's sake: we spew out doctors faster than you spew up blood. This is as good as it gets.

On a more important note, I'd like to share with you my research findings on the transmissibility and infective nature of body odour. My interest was first aroused when the groins on one particular geriatrics ward started smelling the same as that of Mr P, a relatively new arrival to our surreal little salon, by which I mean that he had been festering in an acute medical bed at risk of hospital-acquired infections while social services quietly ignored him for a trifling three weeks.

Body odours, it seems, are the result of a peculiar interplay between the nutrients secreted in your body's natural juices, and the microbes that feed on them. Just as different species of bacteria and fungi have furnished the French with a wide variety of cheeses from the same kind of milk, so a different selection of invisible helpers are apparently at work in the armpits, gussets and insoles of us all. This is an area in which I have recently become something of a connoisseur.

At first the aroma of condensed egg white and vinegar was confined to the other gentlemen sharing his bay, whose sores had been tended by the same team of nurses. Within a week it had spread throughout the male end of the ward, and recently we have been detecting it on the surgical wards three floors below.

And now, this morning, as I sit in my towel waiting for the doctor with whom I share a bathroom to finish his interminable shower, I cannot ignore the heady, familiar aroma which fills my nostrils. It is not a chain of events on which I wish to dwell.

webTitle: Health: Football is bad for you

fields.headline: Injury time
fields.standfirst: Chris Arnot on why football is bad for you
fields.trailText: Chris Arnot on why football is bad for you.
fields.body:
Is football bad for your health? An absurd question, on the face of it. Surely youthful muscle and sinew, hearts and lung can only benefit from chasing a ball around. And as for those happy few who make it to the Premier League of the professional game, they would appear to be cosseted like racehorses. Their exercise regimes are scientifically controlled, their diet prescribed - high in carbohydrates, low in fat and even lower in alcohol. Water rather than beer is now the traditional after-match tipple.

But how will they fare later in life? The latest evidence suggests that many will pay a price for their inflated salaries in the form of inflamed joints. Almost half of former top-flight pros are suffering from arthritis. One in three has had surgery and one in six is registered disabled, according to a Coventry University survey into the long-term health impact of professional football in the UK.

The Football Association is carrying out its own audit into the physical toll on players. By February next year, every injury which has kept a player out of training for 48 hours or more should have been registered. "Once the facts are known, we will be better able to develop prevention strategies," says Alan Hodson, head of the FA's medical education centre."

But surely today's professionals are fitter and better informed than their forerunners in the 60s, 70s and 80s? "That's true," says Hodson. "And if everything had stood still, the prevalence of injuries should have gone down. Unfortunately, though, the demands of the game at the top level have gone up."

Nobody is more aware of those demands than managers, under pressure from fans and chairmen to get results at all costs. They want their best players out on the park, whether they are carrying injuries or not.

"I know of one player who took two painkilling injections every match between the end of December and the end of the season last May," says sports researcher Martin Roderick of Leicester University. "Others take anti-inflammatory and painkilling tablets as if they were Smarties. Professional sport isn't conducive to good health, and the career of a footballer is usually a catalogue of injuries."

Roderick is co-author, with Dr Ivan Waddington, of Managing Injuries in Professional Football - a report on the role of club doctors and physiotherapists, commissioned by the Professional Footballers' Association. "There are more chartered physios and full-time doctors than there used to be," he says. "But half the physios in football aren't qualified for a job in the NHS. Their appointment is a gift of the manager."

Indeed, the great Liverpool sides of the 70s and 80s were run by a dynasty that might have been known as the Order of the Magic Sponge. Bill Shankly's successor was his physiotherapist, Bob Paisley. He in turn was succeeded by his physio, Joe Fagin. Only comparatively recently did Liverpool appoint a chartered physiotherapist, Mark Leather. He has since moved on to Blackburn Rovers, allegedly after an argument over the state of Michael Owen's hamstring with the manager, Gerard Houllier.

Houllier, though, appears mild-mannered compared to some of the tyrants of the touchline who have controlled English clubs in the past. Perhaps the most abrasive of all was Brian Clough - to many the greatest manager England never had, but not a man to offer sympathy to the injured. "If you weren't fit enough to be in the side, you might as well have been in Australia as far as he was concerned," recalls Alan Durban, a member of Cloughie's Derby County side which, incredibly, won the championship in 1972 with a squad of just 16 players.

Now 59, Durban is relaxing after playing tennis at Telford Racquet Centre in Shropshire, where he was general manager until recently. Although he retains a good eye for a ball and excellent positional sense, he moves around the court with evident discomfort.

Two years ago, he had a hip replacement operation. "I need to hang on to the banisters to get downstairs in the morning because my joints aren't too good," he says.

Reluctantly, he concedes that football took its toll. "I had a few cortisone injections because I was fearful of losing my place. In those days you could only earn a decent wage through appearance money in a successful team."

Derby's quagmire of a pitch made twists and strains more likely. Regular tanglings with uncompromising opponents like Norman Hunter of Leeds, Chelsea's Ron "Chopper" Harris and Tommy Smith of Liverpool put at risk any bone from the knee down.

Smith was arguably the craggiest defender of his generation. Now in his mid-50s, he became the most high-profile footballing victim of arthritis when his disability benefit was drastically reduced after he took a demonstration penalty before the 1996 FA Cup Final. "I was drugged to the eyeballs," he later admitted, this proud former "iron man" who had to go before a DSS tribunal and tell how he could no longer get dressed, tie his shoelaces or even get on and off the toilet without the help of his wife.

In Smith's day, cortisone was the routine way of masking pain before a match. "Some players had over 20 injections in the same joint," says Andy Turner, who did the survey of 284 former professionals in the Coventry University study. Turner, 38, had to give up playing local football nine years ago after developing osteoarthritis in one of his knees.

Reasearch from Scandinavia, he says, suggests that amateur footballers are even more at risk. They are less fit to start with, have lower skill levels and hence less awareness of how to avoid crude tackles. What's more, as Turner puts it, "They don't fancy spending Saturday night in casualty getting immediate treatment while their mates are out having a few pints."

He is now engaged in follow-up qualitative research with the old pros who responded to his initial survey. "One of them told me that if he could get hold of the doctor who administered cortisone, he'd strangle him." Why? Because the hormone damages tissue if taken to excess. The FA now has guidelines on the number of injections that can be administered: no more than three.

But do the clubs take any notice? Dr Roger Wolman, consultant in rheumatology and sports medicine at the Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital in Stanmore, Middlesex, is doubtful. "I have a feeling that the attitude of the clubs hasn't really changed," he says.

He sees at least one former professional footballer every month. "It's a sport that involves twisting on a weight-bearing joint. So there is always a risk of ligament or meniscus (cartilage) damage which makes them more prone to osteoarthritis in later life."

So how can the risks be reduced? "Lots of conditioning exercises to strengthen the muscles that support the knee - leg presses, exercise bikes, swimming. And take the advice of an experienced clinician after an injury."

Leicester University's researchers praise Sheffield Wednesday as the most enlightened club when it came to giving its players time to recover. At the end of last season, alas, Wednesday were relegated from the Premier League.

webTitle: Health: Burn victim Alfred Page

fields.headline: Skin deep
fields.standfirst: In May, Alfred Page, left, suffered 70% burns, but thanks to an ingenious combination of silicon and shark skin, he has made a remarkable recovery. Jeevan Vasagar reports
fields.trailText: In May, Alfred Page, left, suffered 70% burns, but thanks to an ingenious combination of silicon and shark skin, he has made a remarkable recovery. Jeevan Vasagar reports.
fields.body:
Around 100,000 people attend hospital casualty units each year with burns injuries. The culprits are often the dangers lurking in every kitchen - steaming kettles, bubbling hot oil or fat, and scalding cups of tea or coffee - and the victims tend to be toddlers, unsteady on their feet, hugely curious, and completely lacking a sense of danger.

But one of the most horrific burns cases in recent months was that of Alfred Page, a 12-year-old boy from Gillingham, Kent, who was injured not in the home but while out playing with home-made petrol bombs. He suffered 70% burns when another boy sparked a lighter near him, and will bear permanent scars.

The other boy, also 12, still faces a sentence after admitting, at a court case that ended last week, "recklessly" causing grievous bodily harm.

Alfred, however, has made a remarkable recovery since the incident in May. He no longer takes painkillers, can walk without a frame, and has started studying again. But his fightback is far from over and he faces further skin grafts.

Alfred was treated at the St Andrew's Centre at Broomfield hospital in Chelmsford, Essex, where surgeons have pioneered work on the restoration of burns victims' skin using an artificial replacement made from an extraordinary combination of silicon and derivatives of shark's skin and cowhide.

This "artificial skin", Integra, can achieve remarkable and rapid results for burns sufferers. But it is expensive enough to make NHS accountants go pale. A sheet of Integra about 10 inches by eight inches costs about £1,500. Typically, at least 10 will be needed to treat a burn, depending on the size of the injury and the victim's age.

The treatment works by using the body's own regenerative powers. The artificial skin - which looks like a semi-transparent clingfilm wrap and initially smells of the alcohol it is preserved in - is laid over the wound once all the dead tissue has been excised.

Normal healthy skin is made up of two layers: the epidermis, which is the waterproof protective layer on top, and the dermis, which contains more complex structures like the hair follicles, sweat glands and sebaceous glands that produce oils.

In a deep burn, both these layers are destroyed. Victims with extensive deep burns have no temperature controls because they cannot sweat.

In the immediate aftermath of the burn, they can sometimes even walk around feeling no pain because the nerve endings in their skin have been stripped away.

Integra is also made up of two layers: silicon on top, and a mix of bovine collagen and shark fin cartilage underneath.

Collagen is the basic building block of the human body, says Peter Dziewulski, consultant plastic surgeon at the St Andrew's Centre.

"If you think of the body as a house, collagen makes up the structure, the bricks as it were," he says.

In the case of Integra, it comes from special herds of cattle that are guaranteed BSE-free, combined with the shark derivative, chondroitin-6 sulphate, which acts "like the cement between the bricks that binds the collagen more tightly together".

Blood vessels grow into the collagen lattice to form a new dermis, and the burn victim's body uses the animal material to create new cells.

The body does not reject the shark and cow matter as it would do transplants of pig skin or another person's skin (both of which are alternatives) because it is not intact "foreign" cells but a kind of potpourri of reconstituted biological material.

It usually takes about three to four weeks for the blood vessels to reach the top of the collagen layer, after which the silicon is peeled off and a very thin skin graft is used to replace the epidermis.

"[Integra] allows us to take away the all the dead tissues very quickly after the injury. Dead tissues always attract bacteria," says Dziewulski.

It gets the wound closed, which protects against infection and reduces water losses, and reduces the metabolic overdrive experienced by a burn victim as the body battles to recover.

It also means that the patient does not have to go through the unpleasant experience of having grafts taken from other parts of his body (in some cases the burn is so extensive there is not much skin left on the patient to graft over the burns).

But what Integra does not recreate is all the complex structures, the hair follicles and glands that provide essential functions - such as helping insulate us, and keeping the skin oiled and waterproof - that we do not notice unless we lose them.

Here the surgeons at the St Andrew's centre have made an advance on existing treatment. Consultant plastic surgeon Jim Frame has found that implanting hair follicles into the Integra will stimulate the growth of new skin.

Working on the scalp of a badly burned patient last year, he found that cells from the hair follicles grew up the hair shaft and provided a new layer of epidermis over the wounded area.

In two weeks, a new epidermis had grown around the hairs, removing the need for a second operation to apply a skin graft. The patient, a man in his 20s from Essex, became the first person in the world to benefit from the new treatment. The ultimate aim of the surgeons' quest is to regenerate new skin as soon after the burn injury as possible.

And what does the future hold for Alfred Page, who was finally allowed home in September after four months in hospital and 20 operations? He declared at the weekend that he was looking forward to indulging once more in his favourite hobby - fishing.

"I went with Dad for three hours the first week I came home," he said. "It was great just breathing in some sea air."

 The Burned Children's Club runs an overseas exchange scheme and annual outdoor pursuits holiday for young burn victims treated at the St Andrew's Centre. Readers can make donations to the club, a registered charity, at 114 Middle Crockerford, Vange, Basildon, Essex, SS16 4JA.

Treating burns: then and now

Ted Rogers, 82

Treatment for burns may have been less hi-tech 50 years ago, but it proved effective for injured second world war soldier Ted Rogers, whose face and hands were ravaged in an explosion caused by a German bomb hitting a lorry carrying ammunition.

"I was an anti-tank gunner with the 7th armoured division against the Axis forces in the desert.

"I went with the eighth army under Montgomery from Alamein to fight at Mareth in Tunisia, where the Germans had a strong defensive line. In March 1943 I was in a slit trench and a Stuka dive bomber dropped a bomb that unfortunately hit the truck, which was carrying about 120 rounds of artillery ammunition and I don't know how many gallons of petrol.

"The blast went down into the trench and I was very seriously burned, mostly my hands and face. All I could see was fire.

"I was flown from Tripoli to Cairo, where they cleaned the wound up. The orderly picked bits off you that were coming away, like a bit of my ear.

"My eyelids were replaced with skin from my arms. The skin on my hands was replaced with grafts, which was done in England when I was transferred to a hospital in County Durham. I had dozens of operations.

"All the skin off the back of my hands had to be replaced. That was done with skin from my stomach, and in order to replace the skin on my stomach they took a fairly thick lump from my thigh. Little bits of skin were taken off my arm to make up what was lost from my thigh. I felt extremely ill; I almost weep at the thought of it now."

Painful though the operations were, he made a successful recovery. On his return to civilian life, Rogers resumed his peacetime occupation of bricklaying, and even went on to build a yacht, which he sailed across the Atlantic.

One remarkable side-effect of the burns is that he has found it acts like "a built-in facelift" as he has grown older. "People who have severe burns, your face is initially contracted, but as the years go by this acts as a facelift, instead of your face sagging it remains fairly firm in contour," he says.

Terry Everitt, 46

But one of the most horrific burns cases in recent months was that of Alfred Page, a 12-year-old boy from Gillingham, Kent, who was injured not in the home but while out playing with home-made petrol bombs. He suffered 70% burns when another boy sparked a lighter near him, and will bear permanent scars. The other boy, also 12, still faces a sentence after admitting, at a court case that ended last week, "recklessly" causing grievous bodily harm. Alfred, however, has made a remarkable recovery since the incident in May. He no longer takes painkillers, can walk without a frame, and has started studying again. But his fightback is far from over and he faces further skin grafts. Alfred was treated at the St Andrew's Centre at Broomfield hospital in Chelmsford, Essex, where surgeons have pioneered work on the restoration of burns victims' skin using an artificial replacement made from an extraordinary combination of silicon and derivatives of shark's skin and cowhide. This "artificial skin", Integra, can achieve remarkable and rapid results for burns sufferers. But it is expensive enough to make NHS accountants go pale. A sheet of Integra about 10 inches by eight inches costs about £1,500. Typically, at least 10 will be needed to treat a burn, depending on the size of the injury and the victim's age. The treatment works by using the body's own regenerative powers. The artificial skin - which looks like a semi-transparent clingfilm wrap and initially smells of the alcohol it is preserved in - is laid over the wound once all the dead tissue has been excised. Normal healthy skin is made up of two layers: the epidermis, which is the waterproof protective layer on top, and the dermis, which contains more complex structures like the hair follicles, sweat glands and sebaceous glands that produce oils. In a deep burn, both these layers are destroyed. Victims with extensive deep burns have no temperature controls because they cannot sweat. In the immediate aftermath of the burn, they can sometimes even walk around feeling no pain because the nerve endings in their skin have been stripped away. Integra is also made up of two layers: silicon on top, and a mix of bovine collagen and shark fin cartilage underneath. Collagen is the basic building block of the human body, says Peter Dziewulski, consultant plastic surgeon at the St Andrew's Centre. "If you think of the body as a house, collagen makes up the structure, the bricks as it were," he says. In the case of Integra, it comes from special herds of cattle that are guaranteed BSE-free, combined with the shark derivative, chondroitin-6 sulphate, which acts "like the cement between the bricks that binds the collagen more tightly together". Blood vessels grow into the collagen lattice to form a new dermis, and the burn victim's body uses the animal material to create new cells. The body does not reject the shark and cow matter as it would do transplants of pig skin or another person's skin (both of which are alternatives) because it is not intact "foreign" cells but a kind of potpourri of reconstituted biological material. It usually takes about three to four weeks for the blood vessels to reach the top of the collagen layer, after which the silicon is peeled off and a very thin skin graft is used to replace the epidermis. "[Integra] allows us to take away the all the dead tissues very quickly after the injury. Dead tissues always attract bacteria," says Dziewulski. It gets the wound closed, which protects against infection and reduces water losses, and reduces the metabolic overdrive experienced by a burn victim as the body battles to recover. It also means that the patient does not have to go through the unpleasant experience of having grafts taken from other parts of his body (in some cases the burn is so extensive there is not much skin left on the patient to graft over the burns). But what Integra does not recreate is all the complex structures, the hair follicles and glands that provide essential functions - such as helping insulate us, and keeping the skin oiled and waterproof - that we do not notice unless we lose them. Here the surgeons at the St Andrew's centre have made an advance on existing treatment. Consultant plastic surgeon Jim Frame has found that implanting hair follicles into the Integra will stimulate the growth of new skin. Working on the scalp of a badly burned patient last year, he found that cells from the hair follicles grew up the hair shaft and provided a new layer of epidermis over the wounded area. In two weeks, a new epidermis had grown around the hairs, removing the need for a second operation to apply a skin graft. The patient, a man in his 20s from Essex, became the first person in the world to benefit from the new treatment. The ultimate aim of the surgeons' quest is to regenerate new skin as soon after the burn injury as possible. And what does the future hold for Alfred Page, who was finally allowed home in September after four months in hospital and 20 operations? He declared at the weekend that he was looking forward to indulging once more in his favourite hobby - fishing. "I went with Dad for three hours the first week I came home," he said. "It was great just breathing in some sea air."  The Burned Children's Club runs an overseas exchange scheme and annual outdoor pursuits holiday for young burn victims treated at the St Andrew's Centre. Readers can make donations to the club, a registered charity, at 114 Middle Crockerford, Vange, Basildon, Essex, SS16 4JA. "I was an anti-tank gunner with the 7th armoured division against the Axis forces in the desert. webTitle: Health: Dear doctor

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.standfirst: Dr Ann Robinson
fields.trailText: Dr Ann Robinson.
fields.body:
Penile pain

I have a painful penis. I sometimes have a mild pain when I ejaculate but otherwise can still enjoy sex. Sometimes it is uncomfortable to urinate which I do more often than usual. I have had urine and blood tests, a rectal ultrasound of my prostate which was horrible, and a battery of tests for sexually transmitted infections. Every test has proved negative. I think my GPs are sick to death of me but I am in despair. No one can tell me what is wrong, my penis still hurts and I find I'm checking myself whenever I can during the day and night.

You would be amazed how many men have so-called chronic pelvic pain syndrome, like you do. The pain is long-lasting and can be in the penis, anus or area in between. Mild urinary discomfort and pain while ejaculating are other typical symptoms. All tests prove to be negative in 95% of cases - the other 5% have infections in the prostate gland or bladder which can be treated with antibiotics.

Chronic pelvic pain often seems to start after severe pain from an infection, operation or accident. The pain causes anxiety and that may fuel the long-term problem. Some men may be more susceptible than others in the case of particularly sensitive pelvic floor muscles or a tendency for urine to reflux into the prostate causing inflammation.

Treatment is difficult. Avoid activities such as cycling, which make the pain worse. Hot baths are soothing. Regular ejaculation is good. Antibiotics such as doxcycline are often prescribed for a month at a time and can be repeated if helpful.

Finasteride, a drug that shrinks enlarged prostates, looks promising. Painkillers, antidepressants and counselling to deal with the pain and anxiety can help. There is a large research project on chronic pelvic pain under way in the US so expect progress on this up-and- coming subject.

Cold comfort

I'm particularly busy at work and travelling a lot. I want to stave off colds and coughs this winter. I had a flu jab and take vitamin C daily. Any other tips?

Vitamin C has entered popular mythology as a defender against many ills. But its fine reputation is largely undeserved with no consistent evidence that supplements prevent colds. Less than a gram a day probably does no harm, but larger doses can cause kidney stones and possibly have a negative impact on health by acting against antioxidants and causing cell damage.

Zinc may help reduce prolonged symptoms once you have a cold but is not proven to be preventive. Echinacea, derived from purple coneflower, is also widely available. It is said to stimulate the immune system.

The scientific trials are favourable though not unanimous. It may damage the liver and is best avoided in conjunction with other drugs - including alcohol - that affect the liver. Allergic reactions are possible and potentially serious. To avoid colds, you have to avoid people.

Losing it

My hair is falling out in the bath at an alarming rate and starting to look distinctly thinner. I'm a woman of 28 in good health - what should I do?

We shed hair all the time but it looks most obvious and alarming in the bath.Hair thinning is fairly often due to an underlying iron deficiency. It is important to have a blood test.

Iron levels can be low enough to cause thinning but not enough to cause anaemia. A simple full blood count, the standard test for anaemia, may miss milder iron deficiency. Iron supplements will restore iron levels to normal and may help your hair to return to its previous thickness.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

webTitle: Newsnight's paedophile scoop sees ratings soar

fields.headline: Newsnight's paedophile scoop sees ratings soar
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: Newsnight's investigation into a paedophile has almost doubled its ratings. By Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Newsnight's undercover investigation last night into a Merseyside paedophile has almost doubled the programme's ratings.

It pulled in an average of 1.9m viewers and a 13% audience share.

Incredibly, it almost outdid ratings for BBC1 with a peak audience of 2.2m. Omnibus on BBC1 managed just 1.9m viewers, a 14% share.

"We really coudn't have hoped for better. It is just fantastic that so many people watched it," said Newsnight producer Sarah Macdonald.

Newsnight chronicled the activities of a 71-year-old who confessed on camera to sexually abusing his step-daughters.

Police said two men were arrested today as a result of the programme.

A police spokeswoman said: "As a result of the Newsnight programme and further investigations by Merseyside police, fresh evidence has come to light and Merseyside police responded positively.

"We can now reveal that two men are in custody and are detained at a police station on Merseyside."

Ms Macdonald had been researching the case for the past six months but no publicity was given to the show because of fears that the police may have tried to put an injunction on the programme.

webTitle: Directory enquiries faces overhaul

fields.headline: Directory enquiries faces overhaul
fields.trailText: Directory enquiries is to receive a radical overhaul from Oftel, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Telephone networks' directory enquiries are the latest telecoms services to receive a radical overhaul from the Oftel industry watchdog.

The regulator will consult consumers, telecoms companies and consumer groups in the shake-up, which will result in a range of new services and the replacement of the 192 number.

Oftel wants to change the current system, which allows operators to run an exclusive directory enquiries service on their own network.

This practice will be scrapped, allowing rival operators to offer alternative services on their competitors' networks.

David Edmonds, head of Oftel, said: "Opening up the market to competing service providers will provide greater choice and a wider range of services for consumers, as has already happened in a number of European countries."

Consumers will be asked if they want the familiar 192 number to be replaced with a new 118xx code, which will create room for different services.

Ideas for new services include immediately patching customers through to the number they have requested.

Mr Edmonds stressed that the new numbers will only be introduced if there is broad support from the public.

BT welcomed the move, saying it expected the high regard for its service to be reflected in the survey.

A spokesman said: "There is nothing wrong with competition, and we have nothing to fear from the opening up the service, as we think that ours is best of breed."

webTitle: Relenza verdict good news for patients

fields.headline: Relenza verdict good news for patients
fields.standfirst: The guidelines for the drug's availability on the NHS show that the body can be driven by objectivity rather than pharmaceutical companies' lobbying power, writes Patrick Butler
fields.trailText: The guidelines for the drug's availability on the NHS show that the body can be driven by objectivity rather than pharmaceutical companies' lobbying power, writes Patrick Butler
fields.body:
At first glance, the announcement that the NHS "ban" on the anti-flu drug Relenza is to be lifted looks like a dazzling result for the pharmaceutical industry and an embarrassing u-turn for the health service technologies regulator, the national institute for clinical excellence (Nice).

But Nice's latest guidance, which replaces last autumn's interim guidance advising GPs not to prescribe Relenza on the grounds that there was no clear evidence that it would help the NHS treat flu patients, shows that the institute's original decision was basically sound.

Nice now accepts that clinical trials have shown that there are some benefits for patients at risk of serious complications from flu. But it does not accept that Relenza can be anything more than a niche anti-flu drug, at least as far as the NHS is concerned.

When the Relenza debate blew up last year, there was speculation that the costs to the NHS of providing it could be at least £10m a year and at most £100m a year - a handsome earner for Glaxo, not just in the UK but also overseas, where the Nice decision is closely monitored.

But the institute's latest figures show that, if correctly prescribed by GPs in line with Nice guidance, the amount paid out by the NHS on the drug could be as little as £2.3m, or, at the most, £11.7m - a miniscule amount in terms of the total NHS budget and Glaxo's profits.

Although the ban is lifted, very few people will actually get the drug, at least from NHS GPs. If there is no mass flu outbreak this winter, as few as 97,000 "at risk" patients - essentially those who are over 65 and suffer from asthma, heart disease, or diabetes - will be able to take Relenza.

Rather daringly, the NHS has decided to take an unusually commonsensical approach to any flu outbreak. It believes that its old technology immunisation programme, together with the even older school remedy of staying at home and wrapping up warm can beat flu this winter.

Nice's decision is a small but fair concession to Glaxo, and may calm the drug giant's legendary temper. Last autumn, enraged at the ban, it threatened to shift its £1bn research and development programme from the UK to the United States.

More importantly, the Relenza affair shows that NHS purchasing decisions can be driven by objective scientific, clinical and value for money criteria, rather than by the commercial muscle and political lobbying power of pharmaceutical companies. That is good news for patients.

webTitle: Amstrad lightweight phone late

fields.headline: Amstrad misses Xmas window
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: Electronics company Amstrad has admitted that sales of its latest mobile phone product will be disappointing. Dan Milmo reports.
fields.body:
Amstrad, the electronics company owned by Tottenham Hotspur football club chairman Alan Sugar, has admitted that sales of its latest mobile phone product will be disappointing.

Production delays mean that the small, lightweight phone will not hit the shelves until next year, destroying the company's plans for a pre-Christmas launch.

Amstrad added that sales figures for the whole year will fall below expectations as a result.

Amstrad is hoping its new phone will take a significant chunk of the mobile phone hardware market. But today's announcement means the company will miss the lucrative December rush for mobile phones, when handsets are bought as presents.

The stock market reacted fiercely to the news, marking Amstrad's shares down 19p to a year low of 134.5p.

webTitle: Blair to give live interview on ITV

fields.headline: ITV serves up Blair for studio grilling
fields.trailText: ITV has pulled off an impressive journalistic coup by persuading prime minister Tony Blair to take part in a live peak-time grilling by a studio audience.
fields.body:
ITV has pulled off an impressive journalistic coup by persuading prime minister Tony Blair to take part in a live peak-time grilling by a studio audience.

Ask the Prime Minister, which will go out at 7pm on Tuesday December 12, is to be presented by Jonathan Dimbleby and produced by LWT.

As well as fielding questions from a studio audience, Mr Blair will answer queries by telephone.

The hour-long programme has been months in the planning and follows last week's suggestions by Downing Street spokesman Alastair Campbell that Mr Blair would contemplate a head-to-head TV debate with William Hague.

David Liddiment, ITV director of programmes, said: "Ask the Prime Minister is a real example of television's ability to empower our audience, reflect their concerns and engage viewers in the democratic process."

The studio audience for the live special is to be selected to be demographically representative of the ITV audience across the UK.

ITV will be opening a national phone line - 0870 2425666 - tomorrow, allowing viewers to register questions for the prime minister in advance. Questions can also be sent in via email.

The studio location for Ask the Prime Minister will not be revealed until nearer transmission for security reasons.

The live special is to be produced for LWT by Alaina MacDonald, with David Mapstone programme editing and Alexander Gardiner and Will Smith executive producing.
