webTitle: Most passengers miss out on rail compensation

fields.headline: Most passengers miss out on rail compensation
fields.trailText: Millions of passengers will be denied compensation for the recent rail chaos because they have not kept their tickets, the train companies announced today.
fields.body:
Millions of passengers will be denied compensation for the recent rail chaos because they have not kept their tickets, the train companies announced today.

Only annual and monthly season ticket holders will automatically be reimbursed for the post-Hatfield delays, which closed rail routes across the country as Railtrack carried out emergency engineering work.

Weekly season ticket holders and those who have bought daily tickets will have to show them to be eligible for the scheme.

Compensation is likely to be a number of days of free travel for season ticket holders and money back or vouchers for other passengers.

There have been reports that season ticket holders could get £250 cheques or as many as 21 days of free travel under the special compensation plan.

But a spokeswoman for the association of train operating companies said the deal is still being discussed. The association cannot say "exactly" who will get what or when the deal will be announced.

Earlier this month, Railtrack announced that around £150m would be made available to the train companies to compensate for the delays. But the train companies indicated that they wanted around £330m and discussions with Railtrack have been continuing.

Yesterday, train companies finally published post-Hatfield emergency timetables. Although more than half the companies are now running normal or near-normal services, some of the companies operating the high-speed long-distance routes are only able to offer a limited number of trains.

Passengers have been warned to expect the emergency timetables to run for a few weeks and to contend with weekend engineering work into the new year.

webTitle: Yentob poaches his deputy from United News and Media

fields.headline: Yentob poaches  deputy from United
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Alan Yentob has poached Jan Rowland from United News & Media to head up his BBC drama, entertainment and children's division. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Alan Yentob has poached a business and legal adviser from United News & Media for the new role of chief operating officer of the drama, entertainment and children's division.

Jan Rowland, currently director of legal and business affairs at the media and entertainment division of United Broadcasting & Entertainment, is the first BBC executive to bear a title more often associated with the commercial world of high technology and banking.

Ms Rowland, who will act as deputy to Mr Yentob, will take responsibility for managing finance, co-production management and legal issues across the drama, entertainment and children's divisions.

She will work closely with Mr Yentob on the planned new children's services and the film division.

Ms Rowland, a former solicitor who was spotted by BBC director general Greg Dyke to co-present and report for ITV current affairs series Eyewitness, joined MAI before it merged with United News to become United News & Media.

webTitle: Call for council reform in Islington

fields.headline: Call for council reform in Islington
fields.trailText: The London borough of Islington will today face calls for a "consultative referendum" on political restructuring.
fields.body:
The London borough of Islington will today face calls for a "consultative referendum" on political restructuring.

The borough's democracy commission, set up by the council in March to examine the options for reform, makes the recommendation in the latest draft of its report on Islington's political structures. The final version is due for release this evening.

One of the commission's key tasks was to examine the government's three options for reforming council political structures: cabinet-style government, a directly elected mayor with cabinet, and a directly elected mayor and city manager - essentially a high-powered chief executive.

The draft said: "Local people should determine their local political structures. A consultative referendum offering a choice between the three models (for political restructuring) should, therefore, be held." The referendum would not be legally binding, but the report says the council should accept the outcome.

The commission argued that Islington should adopt cabinet-style local government, arguing that this could increase efficiency and would be more inclusive than a mayoral model. It added that: "The arguments for a directly elected mayor are less persuasive for a London borough than provincial cities, given that there is already a London mayor."

Islington's ruling Liberal Democrat group is against the mayoral option, and is welcoming the report's recommendations. The council's Labour group, however, is still pushing for a "legally binding and timely referendum" on a mayor.

The commission said there is no groundswell of support for that option in the borough.

But if local people decide they want a mayor, Islington could become embroiled in a bewildering series of local polls, as councillors ask voters to participate in a consultative referendum, a mayoral referendum and a mayoral election.

The three-person democracy commission, led by local government academic Sue Richards, also recommends that Islington should create four new area committees, covering four council wards each, to help engage residents in decision making.

webTitle: Xmas TV shows

fields.headline: Ross Kemp to play Scrooge in new ITV adaptation
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: A modern day version of A Christmas Carol, with Ross Kemp as loan shark Eddie Scrooge, takes centre stage in ITV's festive schedule, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
A modern day version of A Christmas Carol, with Ross Kemp as council estate loan shark Eddie Scrooge, will take centre stage in ITV's festive schedule.

ITV's line-up for Christmas 2000 also features Simon Nye's all-star TV adaptation of Aladdin, featuring Martin Clunes, Griff Rhys Jones, Paul Merton and Patsy Kensit.

Among factual highlights, the broadcaster will be reuniting the actors who played the Von Trapp children in Julie Andrews musical The Sound of Music for an After They Were Famous special.

And ITV bosses confirmed today that they had snatched Blankety Blank from the BBC.

The game show, made famous by Terry Wogan, underwent a revival last year under new presenter Lily Savage. ITV exercised an option to broadcast the show after it poached the cross-dressing star played by Paul O'Grady.

ITV's Christmas schedule also includes pop acts Westlife, Steps and Lulu performing hits from the 60s Detroit hit factory in Motown Mania.

Other highlights include Sinatra: Good Guy, Bad Guy, a documentary featuring Hollywood stars such as Janet Leigh and Eddie Fisher talking about the legendary singer and actor.

For winter, ITV has lined up an impressive drama offering, with major new costume adaptations of classic novels The Mayor of Casterbridge and Nicholas Nickleby.

The multi-million pound classic productions are being seen as part of an attempt by ITV to catch up on the BBC's drama department, which has made costume drama its hallmark.

ITV's winter schedule will also feature Thursday 12th, a new thriller from Politician's Wife writer Paula Milne; and Plain Jane, an Edwardian drama scripted by Lucy Gannon starring Kevin Whately.

In addition, John Thaw and Sarah Lancashire are coming together on screen for the first time in drama The Glass. And feature film Waking Ned, a comedy about a small Irish village gripped by lottery fever, starring Ian Bannen and James Nesbitt, will be premiering on ITV this winter.

Entertainment offerings include Popstars, the Australian real life soap format that follows the creation and launch of a new band; and High Stakes, Richard Wilson's new ITV sitcom.

ITV's winter factual highlights include serial murder series To Kill and Kill Again, from heavyweight indie documentary producer Brook Lapping Productions; Some Liked it Hot, a look at the British on holiday from oral history specialist Steve Humphries; and Time of Our Lives, which looks at the post war social changes that have transformed Britain.

webTitle: Relenza available on NHS

fields.headline: Relenza available on NHS
fields.trailText: The controversial anti-flu drug Relenza will be made available on the NHS on a strictly limited basis this winter after a health service advisory body overturned its own ban on the drug, issued last Autumn.
fields.body:
The controversial anti-flu drug Relenza will be made available on the NHS on a strictly limited basis this winter after a health service advisory body overturned its own ban on the drug, issued last Autumn.

But the decision is bound by tight prescribing guidelines - the drug will only be made available to groups at risk of severe complications from flu such as the elderly, and only during officially classified general flu outbreaks.

The decision means Relenza may be prescribed to as little as 97,000 people, at a cost to the NHS of just £2.3m according to estimates by the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice), which today issued its guidance on the use of the drug.

Nice predicts that if its guidance is effective, the numbers of patients eligible to receive Relenza would be limited to between three and 17 for each of the 29,000 GPs in England and Wales during the "flu season."

Trials suggest Relenza reduces the duration of flu symptoms from six to five days, and can allow infected adults to "return to normal activities" about half a day earlier than would otherwise be the case.

But the institute makes it clear that Relenza should not be used to treat flu in otherwise healthy people. "These patients are advised not to visit the GP but advised to stay at home and take medicines from the chemist to relieve the symptoms."

Separate guidance to GPs issued today by the Department of Health makes it clear that the government's flu immunisation programme, which it hopes will reach at least 60% of the 65 and over age group, will the "first line of defence" against the illness.

Relenza will be prescribed only to those patients who present themselves to GPs within 36 hours of the onset of "flu-like" illness when flu is "circulating generally in the community", and who are able to begin their course of treatment within 48 hours of the onset of symptoms.

A course of the drug, which is taken through an inhaler-like device twice daily, lasts five days and costs £24. It works by stopping the influenza virus from spreading between cells in the lungs.

Official guidelines state that flu is "circulating in the community" when there are between 50 and 400 cases per 100,000 GP consultations a week. Normally less than 50 out of every 100,000 visit their GP with flu-like symptoms every week.

An epidemic is defined as more than 400 cases per 100,000 GP consultations. The last official epidemic in the UK was in 1989-90 when 29,000 people died from flu.

Last October Nice advised that Relenza should not be available on the NHS because there was insufficient evidence that it would have a positive impact on the ability of the NHS to tackle flu.

Its manufacturer, Glaxo Wellcome, said today it welcomed Nice's latest recommendation as an admission that Relenza had "a role to play in the treatment of influenza when the virus is circulating in the community for the treatment of at risk adults".

But Nice's decision represents only a partial vindication for the drug giant, which reacted furiously to last year's ban, at one point threatening to move its £1bn research and development operation from the UK to the United States.

webTitle: Relenza verdict good news for patients

fields.headline: Relenza verdict good news for patients
fields.standfirst: The guidelines for the drug's availability on the NHS show that the body can be driven by objectivity rather than pharmaceutical companies' lobbying power, writes Patrick Butler
fields.trailText: The guidelines for the drug's availability on the NHS show that the body can be driven by objectivity rather than pharmaceutical companies' lobbying power, writes Patrick Butler.
fields.body:
At first glance, the announcement that the NHS "ban" on the anti-flu drug Relenza is to be lifted looks like a dazzling result for the pharmaceutical industry and an embarrassing u-turn for the health service technologies regulator, the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice).

But Nice's latest guidance, which replaces last autumn's interim guidance advising GPs not to prescribe Relenza on the grounds that there was no clear evidence that it would help the NHS treat flu patients, shows that the institute's original decision was basically sound.

Nice now accepts that clinical trials have shown that there are some benefits for patients at risk of serious complications from flu. But it does not accept that Relenza can be anything more than a niche anti-flu drug, at least as far as the NHS is concerned.

When the Relenza debate blew up last year, there was speculation that the costs to the NHS of providing it could be at least £10m a year and at most £100m a year - a handsome earner for Glaxo, not just in the UK but also overseas, where the Nice decision is closely monitored.

But the institute's latest figures show that, if correctly prescribed by GPs in line with Nice guidance, the amount paid out by the NHS on the drug could be as little as £2.3m, or, at the most, £11.7m - a miniscule amount in terms of the total NHS budget and Glaxo's profits.

Although the ban is lifted, very few people will actually get the drug, at least from NHS GPs. If there is no mass flu outbreak this winter, as few as 97,000 "at risk" patients - essentially those who are over 65 and suffer from asthma, heart disease, or diabetes - will be able to take Relenza.

Rather daringly, the NHS has decided to take an unusually commonsensical approach to any flu outbreak. It believes that its old technology immunisation programme, together with the even older school remedy of staying at home and wrapping up warm can beat flu this winter.

Nice's decision is a small but fair concession to Glaxo, and may calm the drug giant's legendary temper. Last autumn, enraged at the ban, it threatened to shift its £1bn research and development programme from the UK to the United States.

More importantly, the Relenza affair shows that NHS purchasing decisions can be driven by objective scientific, clinical and value for money criteria, rather than by the commercial muscle and political lobbying power of pharmaceutical companies. That is good news for patients.

webTitle: See the full Hannibal trailer on the web

fields.headline: See the full Hannibal trailer on the web
fields.standfirst: Plus: Harris joins Crowe in A Beautiful Mind; 46 countries up for best foreign-language film Oscar; Ridley Scott signs up for pirate epic; Claudia Schiffer defends her acting after bad reviews; and is Al Pacino heading for the London stage?
fields.trailText: Plus: Harris joins Crowe in A Beautiful Mind; 46 countries up for best foreign-language film Oscar; Ridley Scott signs up for pirate epic; Claudia Schiffer defends her acting after bad reviews; and is Al Pacino heading for the London stage?
fields.body:
 The long-awaited full trailer for the Silence of The Lambs sequel, Hannibal, has been posted on the Entertainment Tonight Website. The trailer gives viewers the first chance to see Julianne Moore in the role of Clarice Starling.

 Ed Harris has signed up to star opposite Russell Crowe in Ron Howard's next project, A Beautiful Mind, which is scheduled to begin shooting in New York in mid-March. In the fact-based drama, Crowe will portray the central character of John Nash, a diagnosed paranoid-schizophrenic who won the Nobel Prize for work on game theory, while Harris will portray a high-ranking intelligence officer.

 A record 46 countries have submitted films to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for Oscar consideration in the foreign-language film category for 2001, including the first ever entry from Ecuador. Some of the films up for competition include Taiwan's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, directed by Ang Lee; Hong Kong's In the Mood for Love, directed by Wong Kar-Wai; China's Breaking the Silence, directed by Sun Zhou; Israel's Time of Favour (Ha Hesder), directed by Joseph Cedar; and Mexico's Love's a Bitch, directed by Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu.

 Variety reports that Ridley Scott's next project will be the swashbuckling epic, Captain Kidd. The film will be based on a real-life pirate who started his high seas adventures as a merchant marine in the 1600s, but soon became an outlaw, although he remained a hero to his crew. The film will be produced by Disney who bought the project in a seven-figure deal.

 Claudia Schiffer has hit back at the critical savaging of her turn in Black and White, despite the fun that has been poked at her performance. The supermodel told reporters, "They think I'm going into acting for the wrong reasons, that I'm just doing it for fun. But I am working hard at it I'm enjoying it. I'm well aware I'm not going to get any Oscars for this. I'm only starting out and I've got a lot to learn. Most of the scripts I've had cast me as a model. But what's the point of just playing a beautiful woman? I wanted something I could actually act the fact is I'm 30 and have to recognise I can't be a model for ever."

&#149: Rumour has it that Al Pacino may be the latest Hollywood star to succumb to the lure of the London stage. Pacino is considering appearing at the Old Vic Theatre, where American Beauty star Kevin Spacey, who appeared in The Iceman Cometh last year, is now a consultant. Pacino has said that he is keen to return to the boards if the right project comes along and, although insiders say there is no firm commitment, a project is being sought to suit the American megastar.

webTitle: Despite rumours, Spacey won't be next Bond baddie

fields.headline: Despite rumours, Spacey won't be next Bond baddie
fields.standfirst: Recent internet gossip suggesting that Kevin Spacey will be the villain in the next James Bond film have been denied by a spokesperson for the movie's producers
fields.trailText: Recent internet gossip suggesting that Kevin Spacey will be the villain in the next James Bond film have been denied by a spokesperson for the movie's producers
fields.body:
Rumours which have been circulating on the internet that Kevin Spacey was to appear as the baddie in the forthcoming James Bond film have been firmly quashed by the films producers.

Catherine McCormack, the publicist for the film's producers, EON films, told Film Unlimited that the rumours were "completely untrue", putting an end to a day of speculation across the internet and in the British tabloids.

The stories which started on the Teletext website had US film site Coming Attractions fuming over the implausibility of the story.

"This has got to be the lamest rumour we've reported so far on this page," the website ranted. "We already know the British press has an awful track record when it comes to printing the weakest movie rumours but this... this news story beats them all. No sources are given in Teletext's story. Nothing to give us any indication their 'report' comes from a trustworthy source. And to further weaken their report, the 'Beyond the Ice' title is nothing more than internet fanboy speculation, not even worth the photons it takes to print the title out on your screen."

Spacey himself has not commented on the rumours. Since his Oscar-winning performance in American Beauty, he has been linked to innumerable projects, and he is currently preparing for his role in the big screen adaptation of E Annie Proux' s The Shipping News which is due for release late next year.

And to further weaken their report, the 'Beyond the Ice' title is nothing more than internet fanboy speculation, not even worth the photons it takes to print the title out on your screen." Spacey himself has not commented on the rumours. Since his Oscar-winning performance in American Beauty, he has been linked to innumerable projects, and he is currently preparing for his role in the big screen adaptation of E Annie Proux' s The Shipping News which is due for release late next year.

webTitle: Jarvis Cocker set to go behind the camera

fields.headline: Jarvis Cocker set to go behind the camera
fields.standfirst: Jarvis Cocker, the flamboyant frontman of Pulp, is rumoured to be about to fulfil a dream by directing a screen adaptation of the novel Slow Down Arthur, Stick to Thirty, by Harland Miller
fields.trailText: Jarvis Cocker, the flamboyant frontman of Pulp, is rumoured to be about to fulfil a dream by directing a screen adaptation of the novel Slow Down Arthur, Stick to Thirty, by Harland Miller
fields.body:
Gossip site peoplenews.com reported today that pop star Jarvis Cocker is ready to temporarily hang up his microphone and pick up his camera to begin a film directing career.

The 37-year-old lead singer of Pulp is rumoured to have been approached by Miramax films to direct a big screen adaptation of the novel Slow Down Arthur, Stick to Thirty, written by Cocker's friend, Harland Miller.

Although details have yet to be confirmed, the eccentric singer has already expressed his desire to transform the book into a film. Set in a Yorkshire town in the 1980s, the story focuses on Billy "the Kid" Glover who can't decide what to do with his life until he meets David Bowie impersonator Ziggy Hero.

When Cocker reviewed the book upon its publication earlier this year, he claimed it was: "Right up my strasse: thoroughly inappropriate behaviour in an urban setting. The shittier the circumstances, the bigger the dream. Smashing."

A 'friend' claims that, "He [Cocker] wanted to buy the rights to the book when he first read it, but Harland's agent was already in talks with Miramax but now they are looking for a director and Jarvis is on top of the wanted list."

Although this would be Cocker's first big feature, the singer studied cinematography at St Martin's College of Art and recently exhibited a short film at the Institute of Contemporary Arts in London.

webTitle: England could soon be alone in charging fees

fields.headline: Goodbye to all that
fields.standfirst: England could soon be alone in charging fees, say  Paul McGill  and Donald MacLeod
fields.trailText: England could soon be alone in charging fees, say Paul McGill and Donald MacLeod
fields.body:
The government's policy on student funding is looking less and less tenable as Northern Ireland and Wales attempt to follow Scotland's move away from up-front tuition fees.

Northern Ireland's Assembly votes today on a report from its Committee for Higher and Further Education, Training and Employment which recommends the abolition of the fee of £1,050 per year for higher education. All six parties represented have agreed on the Scottish model of a graduate endowment fund.

The Welsh Assembly has initiated a review of all post-16 education, which will investigate student support. Although it lacks the tax-changing powers of the Scottish Parliament, the assembly could add weight to the campaign by the National Union of Students to abolish fees and restore targeted grants which last week brought thousands onto the streets of London.

Owain James, president of the National Union of Students, said England would soon be isolated. "It backs up our claim that the current government position is not working. The Cubie report called it discredited. The repayment threshhold for student loans is far too low and maintenance support for students from the poorest backgrounds needs to be reintroduced."

On the other flank, ministers face pressure from several influential university heads who believe they can only guarantee world-class standards if tuition fees are increased. This would be much less painful if these were paid after graduation along the lines introduced in Scotland following the Cubie report, rather than up-front, as is now the case in the rest of the UK. In Northern Ireland the committee is proposing that graduates should pay only 9% of any income above £25,000, and the same threshold will apply to repayments of student loans. This is a major difference from Scotland, where graduates will contribute if earning more than £10,000 per year, and has led to fears that it will divert funds from helping students from poor backgrounds and put the money back in middle-class pockets.

The report is the committee's contribution to the review of student finance by the minister, Dr Sean Farren, but it may bounce him into decisions that run totally counter to the Executive's declared intention to widen participation as part of its Targeting Social Need policy.

If the report is accepted, critics argue, it would mean handing back to the middle class about £14m that could be used to pay for 7,000 bursaries of £2,000 each to help disadvantaged groups get into further and higher education.

In the 1999 New Earnings Survey, only 18.3% of adult employees in Northern Ireland earned more than £25,000, and it is likely that most of these are well into their careers, so only a tiny minority of recent graduates will pay anything.

Tuition fees have not deterred traditional school-leavers, whose numbers entering undergraduate courses continue to rise - by 14.3% in the four years to 1999/2000. By contrast, the number of adult entrants to undergraduate courses has fallen by 17% over the latest four years. But for disadvantaged students, and most adults, tuition fees for full-time courses are not an issue because they do not have to pay them - the problem is the prospect of a debt of £10,000 for a three-year course. The committee responded by proposing grants of up to £2,000 for "disadvantaged young people and full-time mature students", but offered nothing to ease the plight of those forced into part-time study.

In the longer term, much depends on whether the endowment fund works. A mechanism is needed to track every Northern Ireland student; those who graduate in England will have already paid up-front fees; if they graduated from the republic they will not have to pay anyone and if they came out of Scottish colleges they will have to contribute to the Scottish fund. Only if they graduated from Northern Ireland will they have to pay into the local fund, but many will emigrate. Systems will be needed to track them down worldwide, to see if they earn more than £25,000 sterling and to enforce payment.

 Paul McGill has written two recent reports on Targeting Social Need. He can be contacted at pmcgill@iol.ie

webTitle: Internet boost to lifelong learning

fields.headline: Internet boost to lifelong learning
fields.standfirst: A revolution in adult learning is under way. Thanks to the internet, training opportunities can be delivered straight to the desktop.
fields.trailText: A revolution in adult learning is underway. Thanks to the internet, training opportunities can be delivered straight to the desktop.
fields.body:
UK plc is well on the way to becoming a knowledge-based economy, and we are certainly operating in global marketplace, but we are still not good enough at learning. Around a third of the workforce has never been offered any training by their current employer. Among small firms, only a third provide any kind of off-the-job training.

Last year's Moser Report reminded everyone involved in lifelong learning that one in five people still can't use the Yellow Pages to find a plumber.

On the other hand, we know that knowledge-based industries require high added-value skills - not just IT skills, but communication and higher literacy skills, problem-solving and interpersonal skills as well. We also know that there is a strong link between learning, earnings and job prospects; and we know that more people would get back into learning if it was easier to access.

One way of removing some of the barriers which put people off from learning, or make it hard to come by, is to deliver it at the time, place and pace that people and businesses want it. This kind of flexibility has been a watchword for adult education and company training for at least the last decade. But it has been difficult to achieve. This is because of the in-built inflexibility of much traditional face-to-face learning. There are timetables with fixed classes; there are the cash and time costs involved in travelling; there are childcare costs; and, for employers, there is downtime, which can be particularly difficult for small companies and owner mangers.

At last, with the arrival of the internet, real flexibility is within reach and a revolution in adult learning is under way. At the heart of this revolution is the internet's capacity to cut through many of the usual barriers to learning. It can deliver high-quality courses directly to the desktop - at work, at home, at on-line learning centres or cybercafes, even abroad. In fact, it can deliver learning anywhere the learner can get internet access. So it is not surprising to find that, according to a recent MORI poll, three out of five internet users have already searched the web for training opportunities and one in five has identified a course they could not find elsewhere.

Skills gaps

On-line learning works for companies as well as individuals, and at relatively low cost. Small businesses can use e-learning to offer employees short intensive bursts of training to fill immediate and pressing skills gaps. Large companies can use it to add value to their existing IT investment, typically by networking on-line training materials across the whole company and even its supply chain. e-learning also makes it easier than ever before to offer employees individually tailored, self-managed learning.

All this is happening not just in the area of IT skills, but across all subjects and levels. On-line learning opportunities linked to occupational standards and national qualifications are now available or being developed from entry level right through to specialist courses supporting continuing professional development.

Learning through using computers, wanting to be able to use the internet and being part of the digital society are also emerging as strong motivators which can draw adults with poor levels of literacy and numeracy into learning.

As e-learning is still in its infancy, skills and standards in on-line support, tutoring and mentoring are still being developed. However, early feedback to Ufi from learners experiencing e-learning for the first time through learndirect is very encouraging. They like e-learning and nine out of ten surveyed have said that they have or would recommend it to other people.

Classrooms may not yet be, and may never be, a thing of the past; and there are some hands-on skills that do not lend themselves to an e-learning solution. But there is little doubt that as competition between the telecommunications companies reduces internet costs and improves connectivity, e-learning will transform the adult learning landscape.

 Dr Anne Wright is chief executive of Ufi Ltd, the government-backed lifelong learning initiative, which is creating learndirect, the nation-wide on-line learning network.

 learndirect is Ufi's network of on-line learning and information services, which is being rolled out nationwide across England, Wales and Northern Ireland following a successful national pilot.

 A Fresh Start by Sir Claus Moser was issued in March 1999, as a result of the working group set up to advise the government on developing and supporting basic skills provision.

webTitle: TV millionaire thanks to Henry II...

fields.headline: TV millionaire thanks to Henry II...
fields.standfirst:
'Anybody can do it' says garden designer who won quiz's top prize

Could you be a millionaire? Those £1m questions in full
fields.trailText: Victor Meldrew would not have believed it. After two years and just as its appeal appeared to be on the wane, ITV's Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? turned up its first £1m winner just in time to see off the demise of Britain's favourite curmudgeon on BBC1.
fields.body:
Victor Meldrew would not have believed it. After two years and just as its appeal appeared to be on the wane, ITV's Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? turned up its first £1m winner just in time to see off the demise of Britain's favourite curmudgeon on BBC1.

Judith Keppel, 58, who is distantly related to Camilla Parker Bowles, achieved what many had thought impossible by scooping the top prize with a remarkably wide-ranging grasp of history and geography combined with sound judgment and an element of good luck.

Ms Keppel, a garden designer from Fulham in west London, contemplated how to spend her new-found fortune at a secret location last night. And, as overnight ratings appeared certain to favour the hit quiz show over the last-ever episode of One Foot in the Grave, her success gave ITV chiefs almost as much reason to celebrate. After all, they have already given away £11,800,000 to get here.

Right to the last, the show's compulsively irritating host, Chris Tarrant, kept up the pressure on Ms Keppel and those members of the viewing public who had somehow missed the news of the big win. Seeing the £1m question: "Which king was married to Eleanor of Aquitaine?" Ms Keppel took the option that no other contestant on the British version of the show has done before - she decided to gamble £468,000 by answering.

An incorrect reply would have sent her winnings plunging to £32,000, and the show's producers intensified the atmosphere by cutting to a commercial break. It was three minutes before Tarrant revealed what he knew as soon as she had replied: that Henry II was the correct answer.

As the audience leapt to its feet in joy (understandable since their witness to the making of television history netted one or two a tidy sum in calls to tabloid newsdesks a few minutes later), Ms Keppel remained as cool as she had been since starting out on the journey to £1m. Her daughter Rosie ran down from the audience to hug her, while Tarrant voiced amazement at her calm. Ms Keppel replied: "I can't believe it, that's why." She then turned to her daughter and joked: "What do you want for Christmas?"

Ms Keppel yesterday attributed her success to a combination of luck at getting a batch of questions to which she knew the answers, a couple of lucky guesses and a friend who knew her Shakespeare. "I've always felt about this show that you can do it - anybody can do it."

Viewers first saw Ms Keppel on Saturday night, when she was the only prospective contestant who correctly placed four former prime ministers in date order. Her next hurdle came on the £16,000 question when she required the audience's help to name Mr Blair's country of birth. The location of Duffel, the town which gave its name to a variety of coat, proved more problematic. She used her 50-50 lifeline to whittle the possible answers down to Belgium and Holland. After a process of deduction and a gambling instinct, she hit on Belgium. "It sounded more French. So I chose Belgium. That was my real gamble."

It paid off, because she was stumped by a question about a stage direction from Shakespeare's The Winter's Tale. Fortunately her friend of 10 years, Jilly Greenwood, who happened to be deputy controller of arts and features at LWT, shrieked: "I know the answer darling," and she scooped £125,000.

Tarrant said the strategy had saved her. "She was very clever at using her lifelines. She could have used her phone-a-friend on the duffel coat question but she said 'no, my friends wouldn't know this'." He denied BBC accusations questions were made easier as the ratings war intensified.

Ms Keppel, a twice-divorced sometime bereavement counsellor who was once married to comedy scriptwriter Neil Shand, has three grown-up children: Rosie, a 28-year-old artist, Alexander, a 32-year-old art dealer, and Sibylla, 34. But BT thought she had a "rampant teenager" in the house after she called the programme's premium-rate phone number more than 50 times to secure a place.

She confessed to having had "quite a nice time" drinking Coke in the studio bar after Sunday's recording. But she insisted her plummy voice and blue-blood lineage - she is granddaughter of the ninth Earl of Albermarle and great-granddaughter of Alice Keppel, mistress of the Prince of Wales, the future Edward VII - betrayed a more modest background. "Money has not been a terrible problem and I'm obviously not on the breadline, but I'm really looking forward to spending it."

webTitle: Relenza receives limited approval

fields.headline: Relenza receives limited approval
fields.trailText: The controversial anti-flu drug Relenza will be made available on the NHS on a strictly limited basis this winter after a health service advisory body overturned its own ban on the drug issued last autumn. Patrick Butler reports.
fields.body:
The controversial anti-flu drug Relenza will be made available on the NHS on a strictly limited basis this winter after a health service advisory body overturned its own ban on the drug issued last autumn.

The decision by the National Institute for Clinical Effectiveness (Nice) is bound by tight prescribing guidelines - the drug will only be made available to groups at risk of severe complications from flu, such as the elderly, and only during officially-classified general flu outbreaks.

Nice predicts that the cost to the NHS of its latest guidance will be between just £2.3m and £11.7m - and these costs could fall if, as a result, fewer patients are hospitalised after developing severe flu-related problems.

The decision marks the latest round in a tussle between the pharmaceutical industry and the health service treatment and technologies regulator over whether new drugs should be made openly available on the NHS.

Last October Nice gave interim advice that Relenza should not be available because there was insufficient evidence that it would improve the ability of the NHS to tackle flu.

Nice has now accepted that clinical trials offer evidence that Relenza can work - reducing the duration of symptoms by one day from six to five - but has ruled that its benefits should be targeted at high-risk groups.

The decision means that, if guidelines are followed, Relenza may be prescribed to between 97,000 and 500,000 people, according to Nice. It predicts that the numbers of patients eligible to receive Relenza will be limited to between three and 17 for each of the 29,000 GPs in England and Wales during the "flu season".

Glaxo Wellcome, which manufactures Relenza, welcomed Nice's latest guidance as an admission that Relenza had "a role to play in the treatment of influenza when the virus is circulating in the community for the treatment of at-risk adults".

But Nice's decision represents only a partial vindication for the drug giant which reacted furiously to last year's ban, at one point threatening to move its £1bn research and development operation from the UK to the United States.

Trials suggest Relenza can allow infected adults to "return to normal activities" about half a day earlier than would otherwise be the case. (This is a different measure of effectiveness from the one-day gain in relief from symptons.)

However Nice makes it clear that Relenza should not be used to treat flu in otherwise healthy people. "These patients are advised not to visit the GP but to stay at home and take medicines from the chemist."

Separate guidance to GPs issued today by the Department of Health makes it clear that the government's flu immunisation programme, which it hopes will reach at least 60% of the 65-and-over age group, will be the "first line of defence" against the illness.

Relenza will be prescribed only to those patients who approach their GPs within 36 hours of the onset of "flu-like" illness when flu is "circulating generally in the community", and who are able to begin their course of treatment within 48 hours of the onset of symptoms.

A course of the drug, which is taken through an inhaler-like device twice daily, last five days and costs £24. It works by stopping the influenza virus from spreading between cells in the lungs.

Official guidelines state that flu is "circulating in the community" when there are between 50 and 400 cases per 100,000 GP consultations a week. Normally less than 50 out of every 100,000 visits to GP concern flu-like symptoms every week. An epidemic is defined as more than 400 cases per 100,000 GP consultations. The last official epidemic in the UK was in 1989-90 when 29,000 people died from flu.

The decision by the National Institute for Clinical Effectiveness (Nice) is bound by tight prescribing guidelines - the drug will only be made available to groups at risk of severe complications from flu, such as the elderly, and only during officially-classified general flu outbreaks. Nice predicts that the cost to the NHS of its latest guidance will be between just £2.3m and £11.7m - and these costs could fall if, as a result, fewer patients are hospitalised after developing severe flu-related problems. The decision marks the latest round in a tussle between the pharmaceutical industry and the health service treatment and technologies regulator over whether new drugs should be made openly available on the NHS. Last October Nice gave interim advice that Relenza should not be available because there was insufficient evidence that it would improve the ability of the NHS to tackle flu. Nice has now accepted that clinical trials offer evidence that Relenza can work - reducing the duration of symptoms by one day from six to five - but has ruled that its benefits should be targeted at high-risk groups. The decision means that, if guidelines are followed, Relenza may be prescribed to between 97,000 and 500,000 people, according to Nice. It predicts that the numbers of patients eligible to receive Relenza will be limited to between three and 17 for each of the 29,000 GPs in England and Wales during the "flu season". Glaxo Wellcome, which manufactures Relenza, welcomed Nice's latest guidance as an admission that Relenza had "a role to play in the treatment of influenza when the virus is circulating in the community for the treatment of at-risk adults". But Nice's decision represents only a partial vindication for the drug giant which reacted furiously to last year's ban, at one point threatening to move its £1bn research and development operation from the UK to the United States. Trials suggest Relenza can allow infected adults to "return to normal activities" about half a day earlier than would otherwise be the case. (This is a different measure of effectiveness from the one-day gain in relief from symptons.) However Nice makes it clear that Relenza should not be used to treat flu in otherwise healthy people. "These patients are advised not to visit the GP but to stay at home and take medicines from the chemist." Separate guidance to GPs issued today by the Department of Health makes it clear that the government's flu immunisation programme, which it hopes will reach at least 60% of the 65-and-over age group, will be the "first line of defence" against the illness. Relenza will be prescribed only to those patients who approach their GPs within 36 hours of the onset of "flu-like" illness when flu is "circulating generally in the community", and who are able to begin their course of treatment within 48 hours of the onset of symptoms. A course of the drug, which is taken through an inhaler-like device twice daily, last five days and costs £24. It works by stopping the influenza virus from spreading between cells in the lungs. Official guidelines state that flu is "circulating in the community" when there are between 50 and 400 cases per 100,000 GP consultations a week. Normally less than 50 out of every 100,000 visits to GP concern flu-like symptoms every week. An epidemic is defined as more than 400 cases per 100,000 GP consultations. The last official epidemic in the UK was in 1989-90 when 29,000 people died from flu.

webTitle: £1m winner beats Meldrew swansong in ratings war

fields.headline: £1m winner beats Meldrew swansong in ratings war
fields.standfirst: Could you be a millionaire? Those £1m questions in full
fields.trailText: Last night's Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? jackpot programme attracted 3m more viewers than the last ever One Foot In The Grave, according to unofficial figures released today.
fields.body:
Last night's Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? jackpot programme attracted 3m more viewers than the last ever One Foot In The Grave, according to unofficial figures released today.

BBC insiders accused ITV of fixing the quiz show to ensure that its first jackpot winner would coincide with the final episode of its long-running sitcom.

According to the unofficial figures released by the TV companies, an average of 13.9m people tuned in to watch 58-year-old Judith Keppel, a distant relative of Camilla Parker Bowles, become the first £1m jackpot winner. Viewing figures peaked at 14.9m but then dipped to 12.7m after she won the prize.

The last episode of One Foot In The Grave, which showed the death of Victor Meldrew, attracted an average of 10.7m viewers, peaking at 11.6m.

But the BBC claimed an "excellent evening" of viewing figures for the channel. "I'm sure Victor Meldrew couldn't believe it that the figures were so great, despite what ITV tried to throw at it. One Foot In The Grave has always been a popular show and it was an excellent evening for the BBC," a spokeswoman said.

Viewers of the 122nd episode of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? saw Mrs Keppel become the first contestant to successfully negotiate the 15 questions needed to scoop the jackpot.

But a BBC insider said that the last big winner had also occurred when there was an important ratings battle taking place. "It is a bit of a coincidence," said the BBC insider. "Call me suspicious but it seems to me you can drastically improve your chances of becoming a millionaire if you check your BBC1 schedule before going on the programme."

ITV reacted furiously to the accusations, accusing its rival of "unpleasant and unfounded attacks". A spokesman for the network said: "It is a great shame to see the BBC reacting with such cynicism. In doing so they are ignoring the facts: Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? has been winning the ratings battle with One Foot In The Grave for weeks now."

webTitle: Centaur flotation off

fields.headline: Centaur postpones flotation
fields.trailText: 13.45pm:Centaur Communications has postponed the £250m flotation which was expected by the end of the year, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Centaur Communications has postponed the planned £250m flotation, which was expected by the end of the year.

One analyst said the float had been "pulled", but other Centaur sources suggested that the plans had just hit a temporary hitch.

Centaur, which publishes Marketing Week, New Media Age, The Lawyer and Money Marketing, was hoping to raise as much as £100m cash from the float.

The decision to postpone the launch could affect the company's expansion plans.

The company recently promoted former Lawyer editor Sean Brierley to a new role spearheading new magazine launches. Brierley was unavailable for comment.

But insiders have suggested that the company, which made £11m profit on sales of £80m in its last financial results, could still afford to focus on new launches.

The company's financial spokesman said the company "would not comment on market speculation". But it is understood that market conditions have put the kibosh on the float, which was due before the end of the year.

webTitle: Egypt recalls ambassador from Israel

fields.headline: Egypt recalls ambassador from Israel
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Egypt has ordered its ambassador to Israel to return home immediately after a night of rocket attacks on the Gaza Strip.
fields.body:
Egypt has ordered its ambassador to Israel to return home immediately after a night of rocket attacks on the Gaza Strip.

Foreign minister Amr Moussa said the decision to recall ambassador Mohammed Bassiouny to Cairo was taken because of a deliberate “use of force” against the Palestinian people.

Last night Israeli helicopter gunships pounded the Gaza Strip with dozens of rockets in the most punishing strike in two months of fighting. Two policemen died in the attacks that left more than 60 people wounded.

Mr Moussa said the strike marked an “escalation of aggression” in the region.

Egypt is one of only three Arab countries that have diplomatic ties with Israel. But its government has become increasingly angered by Israel’s refusal to allow aid vehicles to cross the border into Gaza.

Jordan and Mauritania, the other two states, will come under pressure to recall their ambassadors from Tel Aviv. Last month a resolution at an Arab League meeting called on members to reconsider their ties with Israel.

In Cairo, an Israeli embassy spokeswoman said that officials were studying the implications of the Egyptian recall but the ambassador would stay in his post.

Mr Bassiouny, the ambassador to Israel for two decades, was briefly recalled in 1982 after Israel’s invasion of Lebanon. But Egypt has refused to cut relations that grew out of its 1979 peace treaty with Israel, the first by an Arab state.

President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt has that said dialogue is the only way out of the current crisis.

webTitle: Roma rampant as the big boys struggle again

fields.headline: Roma rampant as the big boys struggle again
fields.trailText: Yes, they have yet to play any of the 'big teams' this season. And yes, seven out the eight sides they have played are currently languishing in the bottom half of Serie A. But make no mistake: Roma are on a roll.
fields.body:
Yes, they have yet to play any of the 'big teams' this season. And yes, seven out the eight sides they have played are currently languishing in the bottom half of Serie A. But make no mistake: Roma are on a roll.

On Sunday, Fabio Capello's side increased their lead at the top of the table with a 4-1 victory away at Verona that was so convincing - and so surprisingly smooth - that talk of the Lupi achieving their first Scudetto since 1983 slipped off the tongue as comfortably as a lunchtime coffee.

On paper it shouldn't have been as easy as this: Verona's home fortress, the Bentegodi stadium, had not been breached since 23 January and, worse still, Roma hadn't won there for 22 years. But this season, something about Fabio Capello's side is different - and it's not just their suave new kit, or their expensive new signings. It's their attitude.

Perhaps in previous years Roman heads would have dropped when Verona opened the scoring after seven minutes. Not this time, however. Instead goals from Vincent Candela, Francesco Totti and Gabriel Batistuta (2) - his seventh and eighth strikes of the season in only six Serie A matches - made even the gruff Capello loosen his usually tight guard.

"We were looking for the win from the outset and I am very pleased with the performance. We gave away very little and created a lot," he admitted. "Compared to last season we are more convincing, we want to beat everyone we play and we are playing with real anger and determination."

They are also playing with plenty of panache. With the volatile Totti - who has just signed a new £75,000-a-week contract - looking contented and creative, and combining so well with Batistuta, it's no wonder that Roma are averaging almost three goals a game. Whether they can keep it going during a difficult looking December, where they face Udinese, Lazio and Juventus in successive weeks, will determine the fate of their season.

After crashing at Parma last week, Udinese bounced back into second with a comprehensive 3-0 win at home to struggling Reggina. Stefano Fiore - heavily criticised for his anonymous performance against England last week - was again at the hub of most of Udinese's good work and grabbed the second goal from the penalty spot.

But despite the result, Udinese manager Luigi De Canio was again downplaying his side's Scudetto chances. "I think it's too early to say if my team could be a real danger to Roma or the other big teams," he claimed. "I will be happy if we could get a place in the Champions League though."

Fortunately for the assembled journalists, he soon slipped out of David O'Leary mood, admitting: "I'm really happy with how my team played. I feared that some of the players would be in a great rush to score - that's always dangerous. But on the contrary we played with patience and understanding,"

Fiore was also pleased. "I always accept criticism, even when I disagree, so it was good to score a today and test Massimo Taibi with three shots," he said.

Elsewhere Atalanta slipped to third following a "very lucky" 0-0 draw at Napoli (manager Giovanni Vavassori's words, not mine) in which the Azzurri hit the bar three times in the second half. Another one of Serie A's unfashionable clubs, Bologna, climbed to fourth with a 2-1 win over in-form Parma, Ricardo Cruz hitting the winner six minutes from time.

The big teams meanwhile - like the new Marks and Sparks Autumn/Winter collection - were again colourless and uninspired. Juventus failed to unlock Brescia coach Carlo Mazzone's catennecio and drew 0-0, Lazio and AC Milan shared a 1-1 draw on Saturday night, while a struggling Internazionale side - minus Robbie Keane - squeezed past Perugia 2-1.

Yet by Sunday night the talk wasn't of Roma or Udinese or the other big teams, but of the Serie C match between Como and Modena. Following the game - which ended 1-0 to Como - Modena player Francesco Bertolotti was punched from behind by Como captain Massimilano Ferrigno, and hit his head on the dressing room floor.

Blackburn-born Bertolotti was immediately rushed to hospital where he needed four hours of surgery to reduce two blood clots in his brain. He is now in a stable condition and should recover.

Meanwhile, Ferrigno, who has questioned by police and is being investigated for grievous bodily harm is deeply repentant. "I'm desperately sorry. I never could have imagined that what happened would happen," he told the ANSA news agency. "My every thought is with Francesco. I hope that he'll be okay soon," he added - a sentiment that has been echoed by everyone in Italian football.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Community leadership means councils working with other organisations

fields.headline: Community leadership means councils working with other organisations
fields.standfirst: Sir Jeremy Beecham, chairman of the Local Government Association, sets out the association's view of community leadership
fields.trailText: 11am:Sir Jeremy Beecham, chairman of the Local Government Association, sets out the association's view of community leadership
fields.body:
Many of the issues facing local communities today - health, community safety, the environment, social inclusion, unemployment, regeneration - can only be tackled effectively if the wide variety of public, private and voluntary sector organisations involved at local level work together.

No single organisation acting alone has the complete answer - but working together gives us the best chance to maximise our combined effort, avoid duplication and make the greatest impact on our communities.

This has always been part of what local authorities do, but the Local Government Act 2000 gave this idea of "community leadership" a role in law. It gives councils new powers to do anything to promote the "well-being" of the communities they represent - encouraging them to look beyond simple service delivery to the wider social, economic and environmental issues in their localities. It requires councils to develop a strategy for their community - with both local people and partner organisations.

Some councils have already started to embrace this role - but many have hardly begun. Councils cannot just assume leadership. It is a role that has to be earned and then played out on a daily, practical basis. Leadership in two or three-tier areas requires county, district and parish councils to work together. All councils must also recognise the vital role played by community organisations. Part of community leadership should involve councils creating the context where other leaders can grow and develop.

So at the Local Government Association we challenge local government to take a fresh look at community leadership - the potential benefits for councils, their partners and - most importantly, the local community.

We do not pretend that this will be easy, or can be delivered overnight. This new role means councils will need to think carefully about the meaning of leadership. In a context of growing partnerships, this does not necessarily mean taking centre stage. Sometimes it is about creating the right environment for others to act.

Councils cannot call themselves leaders if they are not in constant touch with the people they are supposed to lead. They need to recognise that there are different communities within the locality they represent, and they need to listen carefully to their partners - the business and voluntary sectors, and other parts of the public sector with which they work. They can bring a valuable perspective - because they deliver on such a wide remit - and as part of the community have an equal right to be heard.

There are many good examples of councils listening to their communities. There is Cambridge city council, which surveyed young people to ask about their priorities for the city, and then organised a jury to prioritise the two most important issues. The London borough of Enfield published budget proposals, then asked local residents for their views on how council money should be spent.

Councils have a key role in initiating the development of a strategy for their area, but this is not something they can do alone. Good community strategies will reflect the needs and aspirations of local people and contain a shared commitment and understanding among partner organisations about how they are to be met.

Developing a vision for a community is not easy. The different aims and interests of people are not always compatible. The local council - as an elected body - must take a hand in managing these tensions and reconciling different views.

An outstanding example is Durham County Council - which has worked in partnership with private and voluntary groups to repair the devastation of most of County Durham's coastline after a century of tipping colliery spoil on the beaches.

Community leadership is ultimately about councils creating opportunities for citizens to exercise more control over their own lives and to take direct control of their own futures. As democratically elected representatives, councillors are uniquely placed to represent the interests of those they are selected to serve. Working with partners from across the private and public spectrum, the LGA believes community leadership will not just be a theory, but a practical response to local needs.

webTitle: Making a difference to social work

fields.headline: Making a difference to social work
fields.standfirst: High stress and low pay will continue to force social workers out of the sector until they get the satisfaction they deserve, writes Judy Hirst
fields.trailText: If social services didn't exist we'd have to invent them, health secretary Alan Milburn assured the sector's annual conference in October. Judging from the numbers fleeing social work, that day may not be far off.
fields.body:
If social services didn't exist we'd have to invent them, health secretary Alan Milburn assured the sector's annual conference in October. Judging from the numbers fleeing social work, that day may not be far off.

Nearly two-thirds of authorities are short of social workers, with London and the south-east facing vacancy levels as high as 20%. What's putting off new recruits and driving out old hands faster than you can say "case conference" is not just the miserly pay (roughly £18,000 for a newly qualified social worker). It's also the phenomenal stress levels, falling job satisfaction, and a blame culture that holds social workers personally responsible for every social ill.

Why then would anyone want to choose social work as a career? Trite though it may sound, because they want to help people, says Mike Leadbetter, training spokesperson for the Association of Directors of Social Services. "There's still a deep desire to make a difference for people worse off than themselves, and there's not too many outlets for doing that these days." A recent survey by the social work training council CCETSW confirms that most people enter the profession because they have that old fashioned quality: a social conscience.

There are other reasons, says Jennifer Bernard, chief executive of the training agency TOPSS UK. "A lot have had some sort of early life experience, perhaps a family break up, or a sibling with a disability, that prompts them into this line of work and gives them an empathy with service users."

Hard sell
Employers and the government are waking up to the fact that they need to capitalise on these factors to beat the recruitment crisis, repackaging social work as a career choice that can make a difference. The hard sell starts soon with a Local Government Association advertising campaign backed by the Department of Health. It will invite the public to "thank a social worker" for helping people, young and old, who are traditionally ignored and encourage social workers to "introduce a neighbour" to the profession.

But it's likely to be an uphill battle. Social work's image problems run deep and the campaign will face stiff competition from slicker, more expensive recruitment drives for teachers and other public sector employees. And without major changes to their hostile working environments, social workers' natural altruism will continue to get a heavy battering.

"They need flexible working arrangements, better training and career opportunities and much more management support," says John Ransford, head of health and social care at the LGA. "A lot of qualified social workers are in their 30s and 40s, with caring responsibilities themselves. Employers have got to take account of this." As a new audit commission/social services inspectorate report, People need People, shows, local authorities that provide the best services for users also treat their staff the most considerately.

Mike Leadbetter's social services department in Essex has adopted a novel approach to tackling its severe recruitment and retention problems. It is paying its social workers a welcome £1,000 per year more - plus counselling and time out from the pressures of the job. The Tavistock Clinic, which has been helping with the programme, has come up with some findings that Mr Leadbetter admits have shocked and surprised him. "They show the intense level of distress and burnout that our frontline staff are experiencing. There are lessons here for other authorities about the type of back-up they need."

People who help other people - battling, against the odds, to get them scarce resources and emotional support - have made a positive, if unfashionable, career choice. But as the decline in their numbers shows, social workers are not saints. They need tender loving care themselves.

Nearly two-thirds of authorities are short of social workers, with London and the south-east facing vacancy levels as high as 20%. webTitle: Sweden's children's ads ban 'doesn't work'

fields.headline: Swedish children's ads ban 'doesn't work'
fields.standfirst: Nov 17: 'Ads more powerful than parents'
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: Sweden's ban on advertising aimed at children has not worked, according to a leading academic. By Claire Cozens.
Nov 17: 'Ads more powerful than parents'
fields.body:
Sweden's ban on advertising aimed at children has not worked, according to a leading Swedish academic.

Erling Bjurstrom, who has advised the Swedish government on advertising legislation, said the ban did not work in practice.

He said this was because children in Sweden could access TV channels based elsewhere in Europe that do not have to abide by Swedish law.

TV3, for example, is a Swedish company that takes advantage of a legal loophole by broadcasting by satellite from the UK. By basing itself in London, it comes under Independent Television Commission rules, not those of the Swedish TV regulators.

Mr Bjurstrom, who is an associate professor at Sweden's National Institute for Working Life, made his comments during an Advertising Association conference on children.

The industry called the conference as part of its bid to stop the Swedish government from trying to force through a Europewide ban on ads aimed at children.

webTitle: Miles de ovejas cruzan Madrid

fields.headline: Miles de ovejas cruzan Madrid
fields.standfirst: Spanish shepherds took their livestock through the capital to campaign in favour of seasonal migration.  Eulàlia Furriol reports   Glosario/Glossary
fields.trailText: Spanish shepherds took their livestock through the capital to campaign in favour of seasonal migration. Eulàlia Furriol reports
fields.body:
Más de dos mil ovejas, caballos, bueyes, mulas y perros cruzaron en octubre el centro de Madrid. Su destino era el parque de Monfragüe, en Extremadura. Los turistas, sorprendidos, se hacían fotos con las ovejas.

Por el centro de Madrid pasan los antiguos caminos medievales para la trashumancia. Los pastores piden la conservación de estos caminos que atraviesan España. Quieren seguir con la tradición de ir con el ganado en verano al norte de España y en invierno al sur. Para trashumar necesitan conservar los caminos y las infraestructuras para beber y descansar. Y necesitan incorporar más pastores jóvenes. Por esto es el séptimo año que cruzan el centro de Madrid con su ganado. Salieron de Extremadura hace seis meses. Ahora regresan después de recorrer 1.200 kilómetros.

Tiene futuro el oficio de pastor?

Tomás Ramos (21 años, Villanueva de la Serena, Cáceres, Extremadura): Sí, porque es un oficio digno. La gente no lo quiere porque es muy esclavo. Es todo el día, desde que sale hasta que se pone el sol. Y es todos los días, sin fiestas ni nada. Aquí, al menos, nadie lo quiere. Yo soy pastor desde que tengo catorce años. Tenía una beca para estudiar pero prefería ser pastor. Soy el encargado del rebaño de 1.300 ovejas en una finca.

Miguel Redondo (20 años, Villanueva de la Serena): No tiene futuro porque no da para vivir. Los pequeños ganaderos desaparecen todos. En mi familia mi padre, mis abuelos, mi tío, todos tenían ganado. Pero lo vendieron. A mi ni se me ha pasado por la cabeza ser pastor. La informática me gusta más y tiene más futuro. Soy técnico en una tienda de informática. Aquí, los únicos que siguen son los grandes ganaderos.

Tengo amigos que trabajan en las fincas. No es que les guste, sino que es el trabajo que han encontrado.

Irene Peiró (19 años. Madrid): Futuro no tienen mucho, aunque siempre harán falta pastores. Aunque sea para conservar las tradiciones. Yo soy de Madrid y estudio segundo curso de Ingenieros de Montes. Quiero trabajar en la gestión de montes y en prevención de incendios.

Crees que los jóvenes seguirán con la trashumancia? Cruzar Madrid puede ayudar a ello? Se deberían mantener las vías pecuarias?

Tomás: La trashumancia desaparecerá porque la mayoría de personas prefieren trasladar las ovejas en camiones. Es más cómodo. La trashumancia es muy dura. Son seis meses de pasar mucho frío. Cruzar Madrid puede ayudar a mantener esta tradición. También es imprescindible mantener los caminos de paso. A mi me gustaría ir a la trashumancia. Hay mucho compañerismo, pues todos dependen de los demás. Hay mucha convivencia entre los pastores.

Miguel: Desaparecerá. No tiene salida. Los pastores ganan poco dinero. Además no se lleva ser pastor.

Irene: Siempre habrá pastores para la trashumancia. Es una tradición. Cuando cruzan Madrid es un espectáculo. La gente piensa entonces que es una actividad atractiva. La gente está a favor de los pastores a pesar de que bloquean la ciudad. Es importante mantener los caminos para el ganado. Son parte del paisaje. Y pueden ser caminos para pasear pero la gente no los conoce.

Cómo afecta al medio ambiente?

Tomás: La trashumancia beneficia al medio ambiente. Las ovejas van en verano al norte porque hay pastos. Y mientras en Extremadura la vegetación descansa y se regenera. Y cuando vuelven las ovejas tienen bellotas y vegetación para comer.

Miguel: Siempre ha sido así y los resultados son buenos.

Irene: Si el ganado está al aire libre y come pasto es bueno para la salud del animal, para la salud del consumidor y para el medio ambiente. La Unión Europea debería promocionar la ganadería al aire libre.

Está reñida la vida rural con la modernidad? Y la tradición con la modernidad?

Tomás: La vida moderna y el campo están muy apartados. Internet no existe en el campo.

Miguel: Las personas que viven en zonas rurales son bastante diferentes. Son más anticuados. Y las tradiciones tienen sus defensores en el campo y en la ciudad también.

Irene: La vida rural es muy diferente a la vida en la ciudad, pero no riñe con la modernidad. Internet puede ayudar, aunque de momento en España los pueblos están muy aislados. Y los jóvenes modernos de la ciudad cada vez quieren mantener más las tradiciones.

Dónde se vive mejor, en los pueblos o en las ciudades?

Tomás: A mi me gusta más aquí. Pero en la ciudad está todo más a mano . Yo vivo en una finca y no lo cambiaría.

Miguel: En el campo, bastante mejor. Hay más tranquilidad, nadie te obliga a nada. Nadie te exige por dónde andar, por ejemplo, y en la ciudad los coches son los que mandan .

Irene: Depende de los pueblos. La comida es mejor en los pueblos, porque sabes de dónde vienen los productos. Depende también de las prioridades. Para la sanidad las ciudades son mejores.

Glosario/Glossary

a mano handy

al aire libre in the open air

anticuados old-fashioned

una finca small farm

el ganado livestock

mandar to rule

el medio ambiente environment

no se lleva it is not in fashion

el pasto pasture

el pastor shepherd

reñir con to be at odds with

trashumar to move to winter/ summer pastures

webTitle: WH Smith a bully, say magazines

fields.headline: Magazines accuse WH Smith of bullying tactics
fields.standfirst: Nov 20: WHS opens up second front
fields.trailText:
12pm: Magazine publishers have accused WH Smith of putting pressure on them to join its controversial distribution system, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Nov 20: WHS opens up second front
fields.body:
WH Smith has been accused of browbeating magazine publishers into accepting its controversial national distribution system, less than two months after promising to work with publishers on a new distribution solution.

Documents obtained by MediaGuardian.co.uk show that WH Smith was trying to push small publishers on to the network in early November.

WH Smith phoned Newsweek, The Lady, The Stage and Dog World asking them to join its national distribution network. The publishers received a letter thanking them for their co-operation before they had even agreed.

The publisher of Dog World, a magazine for dog enthusiasts, received a letter from WH Smith dated 7 November, saying: "We are pleased to confirm your agreement to the national distribution of your titles to all of our stores through WH Smith News.

"This will commence from the week beginning 8 January 2001. Either Simon Gage or John Chapman of WH Smith will contact you direct to discuss the details of the changeover.

"We will contact wholesalers during the week of 13 November to give the necessary six weeks notice."

But Jon Montgomery, publisher of Dog World, claims that the publishing company had not agreed to join WH Smith's national distribution system before the letter was sent.

The company had received a telephone call from WH Smith asking if it would discuss the issue, to which Dog World agreed. But the title changed its mind a few days later following conversations with other publishers.

Mr Montgomery said he had found WH Smith "arrogant" and said it had shown a "total disregard for all the hard work and negotiations that have gone on in the last five years".

Meanwhile, another publisher, which wants to remain anonymous, also claimed it took an initial phonecall from WH Smith, followed by "a letter saying 'welcome aboard'."

He said "It's absolutely untrue that we've agreed to come on board their distribution network."

WH Smith said in September that it would work with the Periodical Publishers Association on its new "blueprint" - designed to streamline magazine distribution without upsettting magazine publishers and existing retailers.

WH Smith had promised to suspend its new national distribution system while the blueprint was implemented.

In the summer, WH Smith infuriated publishers including Gruner + Jahr and H Bauer by threatening not to stock their magazines unless they subscribed to its new wholesale distribution network. Publishers accused the newsagent of bullying tactics.

The PPA blueprint was designed to create a compromise, providing a central distribution system which nevertheless allowed the existing distribution companies greater control.

webTitle: NHS to prescribe flu drug

fields.headline: NHS to prescribe flu drug
fields.trailText: The flu drug Relenza is to be made available to some NHS patients this winter after the National Institute of Clinical Excellence (Nice) today approved its prescription to elderly people and those with heart problems.
fields.body:
The flu drug Relenza is to be made available to some NHS patients this winter after the National Institute of Clinical Excellence (Nice) today approved its prescription to elderly people and those with heart problems.

The turnaround comes a year after the health body refused to sanction the drug, saying manufacturer Glaxo Wellcome had not proved its effectiveness in high risk groups.

webTitle: The Middle East: Unholy terror in the Holy Land

fields.headline: Unholy terror in the Holy Land
fields.standfirst: Israelis and Palestinians are on the brink of a potentially cataclysmic war, writes Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Israelis and Palestinians are on the brink of a potentially cataclysmic war, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Israel and the fledgling Palestinian state are trembling on the brink of open warfare. At least six people have been killed in the past 24 hours, and the Gaza Strip, scene of the fiercest clashes, is echoing again today to the sound of gunfire.

Last night's air and sea bombardment of Gaza reflects the victory - for now at least - of the hawks in the Israeli government and military high command. They hold Palestinian president Yasser Arafat entirely responsible for the past two months of bloodshed, and believe they can bombard him into halting it.

More moderate Israelis believe the crisis has now spiralled hopelessly beyond Mr Arafat's influence, let alone control. Around 240 people have been killed in the past two months, the overwhelming majority of them Palestinian. Around eighty of the victims have been children.

The pent-up fury of the refugee camps and slums which are home to most of the two million Palestinians of the Gaza Strip and West Bank, is matched by bitter anger among Israelis over the relentless guerrilla attacks on their soldiers, and on Jewish settlers in the Palestinian territories.

Monday's callous bombing of a settler bus in Gaza, in which two Israelis died and three children were mutilated, sparked a wave of retaliatory attacks by helicopter gunships and naval vessels on buildings used by Mr Arafat's ragbag security forces. At least one person was killed and scores were wounded.

Three more Palestinians died in overnight gun battles. Both sides talk of "terrorism" and both sides inflict it. The ferocity of the fighting is now matched by the inflammatory rhetoric being deployed by Israeli and Palestinian leaders.

Israel's beleaguered prime minister, Ehud Barak, has all but abandoned his persona as a seeker of peace. During a visit to victims of the Gaza bus bombing, he called the attack "barbaric", and warned the Palestinian Authority, headed by Mr Arafat, that it would gain nothing through violence.

"The PA has consistently violated agreements, and is becoming the address from which we will demand the price of the victims," he said.

During the cabinet meeting which authorised the retaliatory air and sea strikes, former army chief and tourism minister Amnon Lipkin-Shahak, termed the actions taken as "warlike" and "leading us into a limited war."

The language of war is also being freely used by Palestinian high officials. Hanan Asfour, a member of the Palestinian cabinet, said that Israel has declared war on the PA. "The Israeli government is a government of murderers," he declared, adding ominously that Israel "will now have to start counting its dead."

In another disturbing new development, Egypt has recalled its ambassador to Israel, Mohammed Bassiouny. The decision was made by President Hosni Mubarak, citing "the Israeli escalation of aggression".

Egypt has been Israel's staunchest ally in the region for the past 20 years, and has played a key role in the rollercoaster peace process. The diplomatic snub is being taken extremely seriously in Tel Aviv, where there are obsessive fears of another, potentially cataclysmic, Israeli-Arab war.
