webTitle: Troubled times for online estate agents

fields.headline: Online estate agent puts up 'For Sale' sign
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Cracks have emerged in the online housing market, with a high-profile internet estate agent falling victim. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Cracks have begun to emerge in the fledgling online housing market, with a high-profile internet estate agent falling victim to the dot.com depression.

Just two days after CGNU-owned assertahome announced it would buy two-month-old smove, easier.co.uk has pitched up the "For Sale" sign.

In a statement, easier.co.uk said: "Shareholder value will be best served by disposing of the company's business, goodwill and non-cash assets and leaving the company as a cash shell, available as a route to market for another company via a reverse takeover."

The company, which was launched just over a year ago, said it would consider all offers.

It added: "The board will also consider bona fide offers for the company, either before or after the sale of the company's business."

Nevertheless, easier.co.uk should be applauded for doing something that most UK dot.coms have so far been unable to do - operate for more than nine months.

The site's downfall was undoubtedly its massive TV and billboard advertising campaign, on which it spent millions.

The company raised £11.2m from its flotation on AIM in February this year, but shares have fallen by about 88% this year.

The company's revenue model was based on generating commission from the sale of houses, as well as selling on details of buyers and sellers to third parties.

So far, some 71,457 people have used the site and 15,419 properties have been registered. During the sale process, easier.co.uk will continue to trade.

The future of competitor smove, set up by husband and wife team Nancy and Jim Cruickshank earlier this year, was called into question last month when its incubator, EOS Internet Ventures, closed.

Smove was bought last week by another online estate agent, assertahome. As part of the deal Ms Cruickshank, CEO of smove, will become assertahome's head of business development, while Mr Cruickshank will become head of marketing.

The developments are the first sign of the shake-out hitting the dozens of property websites launched in the past 18 months.

webTitle: Children's poetry books

fields.headline: Pure poetry
fields.trailText: Mary Byrne rounds-up the best in children's poetry
fields.body:
Juggling with Gerbils
Brian Patten, illus by Chris Riddell

(Puffin £3.99, 7yrs to adult)

Brian Patten gets better with each new collection. He can be anarchic, subversive and just plain silly but is also insightful, thought-provoking and highly original in his use of language and imagery. "Inside the dandelion seed is a clock/Inside the egg is a chicken farm/Inside a fist an army waits/Inside a kiss is an open palm." Chris Riddell's marvellous illustrations are the perfect accompaniment to Patten's verse.

Charles Causley's Collected Poems for Children
illustrated by John Lawrence
(Macmillan £9.99, 8 yrs to adult)

A tenner is a small price to pay for a share in a national treasure so put this in someone's stocking this Christmas. Causley's rich and lyrical poetry begs to be read aloud, to be memorised and to become part of your daily life. Divided into eleven sections like Charm And Flower, Seasons And Festival, some of his best poems are in the Salt-Sea And Shore section which is steeped in his love of Cornish life and folklore:

"Mother, I hear the water/Beneath the headland pinned/And I can see the sea gull/Sliding down the wind/I taste the salt upon my tongue/As sweet as sweet can be/Tell me, my dear, whose voice you hear?/It is the sea, the sea."

First Poems
compiled by Julia Eccleshare
(Orchard, £7.99, 4+ yrs)

The Jumblies, The Owl and the Pussycat and The King's Breakfast rub shoulders with work from contemporary poets such as Wendy Cope and this one from John Agard "Call alligator raggedy-mouth, call alligator bumpy-bum/call alligator all dem rude word/ but better wait/till you cross river." This selection is a perfect introduction to "real" poetry for the very young but will also give much pleasure to older readers.

I Saw Esau
edited by Iona and Peter Opie, illus. Maurice Sendak
(Walker £7.99, 4 yrs to adult)

A true classic for the home, school or library, this chunky volume is beautifully produced and contains over 170 rhymes, chanted by children in the playground for generations. It is bursting with rhymes of insults and retaliation, graces, riddles, lullabies and lamentations. "I saw Esau kissing Kate/The fact is we all three saw/For I saw him/And he saw me/And she saw I saw Esau." An invaluable document of childhood it most certainly is but it is also a boisterous collection to be read and enjoyed by everyone.

Pet Poems
John Foster and Korky Paul
(Oxford University Press, £4.99, 4+ yrs)

This is the sixth poetry collaboration from Foster and Paul and it is brimful of vitality, fun and totally anarchic illustrations - a perfect marriage of words and pictures. John Foster is expert at choosing just the kind of poem to appeal to the subversive side of every child and Korky Paul's illustrations take each verse even further towards total madness. Take a look at My Dog or Beware! Beryl the Budgie. If this combination of verse and illustration doesn't make you laugh out loud then you must have missed out on the sense-of-humour gene.

The Oldest Girl in the World
Carol Ann Duffy
(Faber £4.99, 11 yrs to adult)

Signal Award-winning poet Carol Ann Duffy shows her remarkable talent and versatility in this, her second collection for young people. Her poems can be light-hearted, as in Irish Rats Rhymed to Death, or serious, but each is perfectly crafted as she introduces us to peculiar and intriguing characters and addresses both the tiny moments and some of the bigger questions in our lives. These poems that stretch the mind will appeal to adolescent and adult readers alike.

webTitle: Augenzeuge: US election

fields.headline: Augenzeuge: US election
fields.standfirst: Exchange student  Christian Langheinrich  gives a German view on the US election
fields.trailText: Exchange student Christian Langheinrich gives a German view on the US election
fields.body:
D as Kuriose am Wahlsystem der USA ist meiner Meinung nach, dass ein Kandidat gewinnen kann, der bei der direkten Abstimmung durch die Bürger weniger Stimmen erhalten hat als sein Gegenspieler. Dies ist wohl auch schon vorgekommen, haben mir amerikanische Freunde erzählt.

Bei uns in Deutschland ist das alles viel einfacher: Man wählt eine Partei. Die stellt dann den Bundeskanzlerkandidaten.

Der Tag der Präsidentenwahl ist für Amerikaner etwas ganz besonderes. Dies fiel unter anderem dadurch auf: Jeder, der gewählt hatte, machte sich danach einen Aufkleber an die Kleidung. Er wollte damit wohl sein Interesse an der Politik verdeutlichen.

In den Vorgärten einiger Leute habe ich sogar Wahlplakate gesehen. Dieses Interesse an der Politik findet man bei uns in Deutschland nicht. Meine Wahlnacht in den Staaten war wirklich spannend. Den ganzen Tag und die folgende Nacht waren Hochrechnungen und Prognosen im Fernsehen zu sehen. Jeder Bundesstaat wurde einzeln bewertet. Auf jede Änderung des Ergebnisses reagierten meine Freunde mit Jubel oder Verdruss.

Als ich an diesem Tag auf den Straßen Cincinnatis unterwegs war, hörte ich sofort, welcher Kandidat gerade mehr Wählerstimmen hatte. Der Bundesstaat Ohio ist eher republikanisch eingestellt. Das spiegelt sich auch im Wahlergebnis wider. Nun sind ja Unstimmigkeiten bei der Stimmauszählung aufgetreten.

Jetzt müssen die Amerikaner neu zählen. Und das bedeutet, es wird noch einige Zeit vergehen, bis das Ergebnis feststeht. Die meisten Amerikaner sind ziemlich gereizt. Einer Umfrage zufolge ist die Mehrheit aber dafür, erst alle Zweifel auszuräumen, ehe eine Entscheidung getroffen wird.

Den Amerikanern sind ihre Wahlen eben sehr wichtig.

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip couldn't care less who was married to Eleanor of Aquitaine
fields.trailText: Manchester United are ready to sell Dwight Yorke, the Daily Star reports. The paper claims that Sir Alex Ferguson has become exasperated with Yorke's high living, and is prepared to let him leave the club for £15m. Yorke has scored only three goals this season.
fields.body:
Manchester United are ready to sell Dwight Yorke, the Daily Star reports. The paper claims that Sir Alex Ferguson has become exasperated with Yorke's high living, and is prepared to let him leave the club for £15m. Yorke has scored only three goals this season.

While various papers report another attempt by Leeds United to sign Rio Ferdinand for £15m, the Mirror suggests that the Yorkshire club have upped the stakes to £18m. But website One Football goes one better, claiming that Juventus are ready with an offer of £20m. The young England defender has also attracted the attention of Bayern Munich. Coach Ottmar Hitzfeld is quoted as saying: "Rio Ferdinand is an excellent player and he has a great future ahead of him."

The Daily Mail believes that, while he may not be joining Rangers, Tore Andre Flo has definitely asked to leave Chelsea and that his replacement is likely to be West Ham's Frederic Kanoute. The paper says that the skilful Frenchman would cost the Blues £8m, more than twice what the Hammers paid Lyon for Kanoute's services in the summer.

Les Ferdinand has turned down a move from Tottenham to Manchester City, according to the Sun. The paper claims the 33-year-old does not want to leave London, and that West Ham and Fulham could move to sign Ferdinand when his contract expires next summer.

Manchester United have made yet another attempt to sign Laurent Blanc from Internazionale, according to Planet Football. United were apparently prompted into action by reports that Marseille wanted their former captain to return to the South of France.

Sunderland are on the verge of signing Swedish international Anders Svensson, according to Teamtalk. The 24-year-old Elfsborg midfielder has been invited to Wearside by Peter Reid to discuss personal terms.

webTitle: November 21 ratings

fields.headline: Millionaire buries Meldrew
fields.trailText: 11am TV overnights: ITV's Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? won the ratings battle with the last ever One Foot in the Grave on BBC1 last night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? won the ratings battle with the last ever One Foot in the Grave last night.

But it wasn't the comprehensive defeat that everyone expected, with a gap of just 3.2m between ITV's Chris Tarrant quiz show and Victor Meldrew's demise on BBC1.

An average audience of 13.9m watched Camilla Parker Bowles' cousin, Judith Keppel, working her way to a million over 60 minutes from 9pm on ITV, while Victor Meldrew's final grump drew 10.7m to BBC1 from 9.15-10pm, according to unofficial overnights.

Exactly 1m viewers switched off ITV once Ms Keppel had won, boosting the BBC's ratings.

Ms Keppel scooped the jackpot 15 minutes before the quiz show ended. Luckily for the BBC, it was the moment when Victor was meeting his maker in a car accident. The BBC saw its ratings rise to 11.6m while Millionaire's dropped to 12.7m.

Overall, both programmes' audiences were well up on last week, Millionaire by 3m and One Foot in the Grave by 2m.

The BBC will also have been well pleased with its one-off documentary, I Don't Believe It! The One Foot in the Grave Story, which preceded the comedy on BBC1.

I Don't Believe It! averaged 10.3m over 45 minutes from 8.30pm.

The BBC said it was delighted with the ratings.

"We started the night off with a 51% share for EastEnders and continued to do amazingly well, despite what ITV tried to throw at us," said a spokeswoman.

Final ratings for the BBC are expected to rise by about 2m once video recording figures are taken into account.

Research shows that ITV gained 3m extra viewers for the final episode of Inspector Morse last week.

webTitle: US elections: High politics and low farce

fields.headline: High politics and low farce
fields.standfirst:
The shambles of the US election has been displayed so openly as to give pause to even the most hardened cynic, writes Julian Borger in West Palm Beach

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText:
The shambles of the US election has been displayed so openly as to give pause to even the most hardened cynic, writes Julian Borger in West Palm Beach.

Special report: the US elections
fields.body:
As in a saintly vision, Donato Dalrymple appeared, as he seems to whenever television cameras are gathered together. The odd thing was that even many hardcore correspondents failed to recognise him at first. He looked familiar, but then the place was crawling with familiar looking people, so Dalrymple looked as though he almost fitted in.

Then the penny dropped. This was the fabled fisherman who had rescued Elian Gonzalez from the ocean and spent the next six months burnishing the legend. In fact, Dalrymple was a house cleaner being taken on one of his first fishing trips, and he stayed on the boat while his cousin plunged into the water to lift the traumatised Cuban five-year-old from the car inner tube he had been clinging to. But those details were subsumed in the born again Dalrymple's over-arching faith in Elian the Redeemer, which finally reached its zenith in that final traumatic photograph of Elian being taken from Dalrymple's arms by heavily armed police.

Now, five months later and just before Dalrymple had been forgotten entirely, he was back poking his head in front of the cameras outside West Palm Beach's Emergency Operations Centre (EOC), an anti-hurricane bunker where some of Florida's awkward ballots were being counted. It was as if the star of one discontinued Florida soap opera had stumbled onto the set of another.

Describing himself as "a victim of the administration", Dalrymple said he had come to check on reports of skullduggery by Gorites inside the EOC.

Rumours had been spreading of lost chad, the tiny fragments of cardboard on which we now discover US democracy stands or falls. As the cynical are now fond of repeating: Chad happens. It happens in particular when voters punch holes in their punch-card ballots but fail to dislodge entirely the little rectangular perforated plug they were supposed to punch out. It clings on and causes problems in the machines.

When it came to the manual recount in West Palm Beach and Broward counties, Republican observers were finding little bits of chad on the floor after recounting sessions. This, they claimed, was clear evidence of ballot tampering, or at least, mishandling. The Democrats countered that the chad was destined to fall off. It proved that it had only been hanging on by one or two corners, so by dropping away it was simply revealing voter preference.

This difference of opinion caused several minor scuffles in the rush to get to a piece of chad first, and one accusation by a Republican observer that a piece of chad had been eaten by his Democratic counterpart.

From the point of view of a reporter, chad is fairly amusing at first, and there has been much guffawing at "pregnant chad", which describes the condition of a punch-card which has been punched but not penetrated, so that the chad protrudes but holds on with all four corners. It is cumbersome to describe.

But think of the foreign press and what linguistic gymnastics they have to go through . The Germans have come up with "Shwangeres Konfetti mit Ausbeulung" - pregnant confetti with a cavity. In Cantonese, it is, phonetically, "dye toad see", which roughly translates back as big stomach paper. For the Italians it is "scheda elettorale malperforata", badly perforated ballots.

In any language it is a perfect story, mixing high politics and low farce, low-tech voting in a hi-tech economy. It is ridiculous enough to silence the usual American boasts about the "greatest democracy on earth", but the mess has been displayed so openly and with such transparency as to give pause to even the most hardened cynic.

The Germans have come up with "Shwangeres Konfetti mit Ausbeulung" - pregnant confetti with a cavity. In Cantonese, it is, phonetically, "dye toad see", which roughly translates back as big stomach paper. For the Italians it is "scheda elettorale malperforata", badly perforated ballots. In any language it is a perfect story, mixing high politics and low farce, low-tech voting in a hi-tech economy. It is ridiculous enough to silence the usual American boasts about the "greatest democracy on earth", but the mess has been displayed so openly and with such transparency as to give pause to even the most hardened cynic. webTitle: Schools and the Immigration Service

fields.headline: Welcome here
fields.standfirst: Last week, three children faced deportation. Their schools decided to prevent it.  David Ward reports
fields.trailText: Last week, three children faced deportation. Their schools decided to prevent it. David Ward reports
fields.body:
The little boy in the grey school sweatshirt walked into his headteacher's office, handed him an official letter that had been sent to his home and burst into tears. "I am writing to inform you," said the letter from the UK Immigration Service, "that arrangements have been made for your removal from the United Kingdom." Additions in ink instructed Zhao Hong Su on the day and time he was to report to Heathrow to catch a flight to Beijing; that was in 1997 when Zhao was eight.

Dai Williams, long-serving head of Lyndhurst primary school in Duckinfield, Greater Manchester, then realised that one of his ablest children was about to be deported. "I tried to calm Zhao down," said Williams. "I told him we would do our best to keep him, that we didn't want to lose a good pupil like him."

Zhao, now 11, arrived in Britain with his mother Xiao Fang, his sister Miao, 16, and brother Jing, 14, in 1995. Three years earlier, his father Lian Hu Su had fled to this country and sought refugee status on the grounds that he could be persecuted for sheltering students during the Tiananmen Square massacre. The family's asylum applications have been turned down. Dates for their deportation have come and gone; the latest was last Wednesday but no police officers arrived at Lyndhurst or nearby Astley High, the comprehensive attended by Miao and Jing. (It now seems there may been a stay of execution for a week, or possibly a month; nothing is certain.)

Even if the law had turned up, neither Williams nor John Mayes, Astley's head, would have let them in. "I would have told them they could not come in without a prior appointment," said Williams. "And if they had made a prior appointment, I would have made sure Zhao wasn't here."

As in similar struggles against deportations at other schools, the Duckinfield heads have chosen to come off the fence to lead active campaigns that have involved pupils, teachers, non-teaching staff and governors. Theoretical lessons about anti-racism, law, justice, politics and the media have suddenly taken on a local, practical resonance.

Three years ago, Lyndhurst's pupils helped to gather 3,000 signatures on a petition and shortly after that, things went quiet. But ominous letters again began arriving at the Su home a couple of months ago. "We told Zhao's classmates, explaining that he would like to stay but an aspect of the law said that he had to go," said Williams. "The children said that they didn't want to lose his friendship and the football team didn't want to lose a star player."

When the latest deportation notices began to arrive, Zhao cried again and was comforted by his class teacher Hazel Heron. "I was horrified that this child who had been in our school for so long was so upset and so unsure of what was going to happen to him," she said. "I felt helpless."

The children fired off letters to the home secretary, Jack Straw. "They really care for Zhao and remember that he didn't know what snow was when he first came here," added Heron. Classmate Sally Backhouse, 11, gave her own tribute to her friend: "He's funny, kind and generous and he helps me with my work."

Over at Astley High Miao's friends, fired with a sense of injustice, queued up to plead her case. "She was one of the first friends I made when I came here," said Roxanne Taylor, 15. "When I found out that she could be sent to China, I got very upset and bought her a present. I can tell her everything and she won't tell anyone else. We have never fallen out."

"She's a bit quiet but people soon got to know her because she gets top marks in tests," added Louise Pearson, 15. "I would like her to stay because all this is upsetting for her and her friends. I don't want to lose a friend."

On the classroom blackboard English teacher Damaris Revell has written the name and address of home office minister Barbara Roche: more letters will soon be on their way from Duckinfield to Whitehall.

Revell's group has been reading Harper Lee's To Kill A Mockingbird as a GCSE set book and has moved on to learn about the civil rights movement and to study Martin Luther King's "I have a dream" speech. The girls were asked to write their own speeches about something important to them. Some wrote about their families and friends; one wrote about the Omagh bombing; Caroline Williams wrote about Miao's plight: "If the deportation takes place, it won't only be me who will feel upset and hatred towards the government but the entire school, her friends and their families. Remember these are real people with real feelings. This is real life. Please don't ignore it."

Revell senses that the threatened deportations have given a sense of urgency to the girls' consideration of human rights: politics has come into the classroom. "I encourage freedom of speech in my lessons," she said. "I have no qualms about what I am doing.

"I have two young sons and they are at the centre of my universe. I would do anything to keep them safe. Everyone has a right to feel safe and I don't care about passports or borders. We are talking here about three children whom we love."

Astley's head, John Mayes, keeps a cricket ball on his desk and you sense that he would like to throw it at an immigration official. He wrote to the immigration service on behalf of the Su children in September last year and did not receive a reply until 11 months later. It suggested a review of the family's case was under way; but it arrived on the day letters began arriving to give formal notice of deportation.

Astley High's campaign has been run in consultation with Miao and Jing. "It would be easy for me to raise emotions in an assembly and I asked the children if I should do that. They said no, so explanations have been given in a more subtle way in tutor groups," said Mayes. "There has been no tub-thumping. I would prefer our pupils to feel genuine emotion rather than to have things scripted for them. That can be counterproductive."

But Mayes worries about the impact of the campaign on British officials (will it make them more obdurate?), on Chinese officials (will they victimise the Sus if they are forced to return to China?), on the Su children themselves.

Whatever the risks, active campaigning by schools seems to work. The Institute of Race Relations has set up a Schools Against Deportations website, which tells of success stories at three London schools. Staff at Forest Gate school learned that Natasha Matambele was to be sent back to Angola only a day before the deportation was due to take place. With pupils, they launched a campaign that drew in the media. The Home Office delayed the deportation and eventually allowed the family to stay. At Haggerston school in Hackney, east London, Mansanga Nanga, Feliciana Nanga and Muyeke Lemba all faced deportation to Angola. A campaign at the school helped to win them the right to stay. Lal Mohammed, a pupil at Rokeby school in Stratford, was threatened with deportation to Tanzania last year at the age of 15. Lal's plight was explained to pupils in an assembly and refugee topics were covered; pupils wrote letters to ministers and collected signatures. Other agencies were involved. "This should not be part of my job," said English teacher George Fuller. "But none of us had a choice. The school is a ready-made community that can respond quickly in these situations. And that's what made the difference.

"There is no question of manipulation. The letters students wrote were very honest - Lal was quite capable of being unpleasant while this was hanging over him. Many wrote to say he wasn't their mate but felt that what was being done to him was wrong. With some of our boys, it's a sweat to get them to write a couple of lines for coursework. But some of their letters about Lal ran to a whole page."

Lal was allowed to stay, has left school and now hopes to join the navy. "Without the teachers and pupils at Rokeby, the campaign would have been much more difficult," he said.

Dr A Sivanandan, director of the Institute of Race Relations, suggests teachers cannot remain impartial. "Lots of teachers are beginning to take sides because they see the unfairness and injustice of it all," he said. "They are beginning to realise that the ideals taught in schools have to be translated into the world outside. The injustice is so apparent you can touch it. Teachers are becoming alive to that."

Back in the Astley High classroom, Samantha Chadwick considered the school's campaign on behalf of the Su family and said: "If something happens to one person, it happens to the rest of us, too."

 The Institute of Race Relations' Schools Against Deportations website is at: www.irr.org.uk/sad/enter.htm

webTitle: View from the Middle East: 'Restraint' strikes fear into Palestinians' hearts

fields.headline: 'Restraint' strikes fear into Palestinians' hearts
fields.standfirst:
In a strongly worded attack, Middle East editor Brian Whitaker condemns Israel's offensive on the Gaza Strip
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: In a strongly worded attack, Middle East editor Brian Whitaker condemns Israel's offensive on the Gaza Strip.
fields.body:
If there's one word that ought to strike fear into the hearts of Palestinians every time they hear it, it's "restraint".

Whenever the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, announces that he has thought carefully about the situation and has decided to continue his policy of restraint - as he did yesterday - we can be sure that some new and horrifying offensive will follow within hours.

Last night's "restraint" was an unprecedented two-hour bombardment of the Gaza Strip - in which more than 30 missiles were fired and electricity was cut off - plus the bulldozing of Palestinian farms, in response to a terrorist attack which killed two adults aboard a bus carrying Israeli settlers' children.

As if to confirm that such onslaughts really are restraint, other Israelis always step forward after the event to condemn Mr Barak for not being tough enough. It's one of the oldest tricks in the book, but the Israelis are masters at it.

The secret is never to be caught defending the indefensible. Instead of trying to justify your disproportionate response to riots and relatively minor acts of terrorism, you shift the debate into even more preposterous territory. The effect of this is to make outrageous actions appear reasonable by comparison.

We saw the same technique at work last week, when US President Bill Clinton asked Congress to provide $450m "emergency" aid for Israel. This consists of $200m to pay for Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon last May, and $250m to protect Israel from a new type of Iranian missile - a privilege not accorded to any of the other countries within firing range.

There is no sensible justification for these payments, but Mr Barak had made it known beforehand that Israel really needed $800m - and he has been complaining ever since.

Hey presto! Instead of Congress asking, "Why on earth should we pay this money?" they will ask: "Is it enough?"

Over the last few weeks I have had several emails from Israel apologists about the Palestinian children killed in the conflict. The general drift of these is to blame their parents for not keeping them out of the way of Israeli bullets.

The same point could equally be made of yesterday's bus bombing. What sort of parents put their children in the front line of battle and send them to school in an armoured bus with a military escort?

The answer is Israeli settlers. "Settlers" - the word has connotations of romance and adventure, but also of seeking a better life, tilling the soil. For Americans it probably conjures up images of quiet homesteads on the prairie.

But in the case of Israeli settlers, "thieves and brigands" would be a better description. They live on stolen land and have been known to shoot Palestinian neighbours for quietly going about their own business picking olives.

All the world, apart from Israel itself, regards the settlements as illegal, but Israel treats any attack on them as an unjustified outrage.

Without the settlers, peace would have come long ago. For the sake of 200,000 bigots in the West Bank and Gaza, the conflict continues, threatening now to destabilise the entire Middle East.

One day, the international community may wake up and impose some real restraint.

webTitle: CJD fears could lead to blood donor ban

fields.headline: CJD fears could lead to blood donor ban
fields.standfirst: Move could cut number of donors by 190,000
fields.trailText: The NHS is considering banning anyone who has received blood transfusions from giving blood themselves amid rising concerns that they may unknowingly pass on the fatal human variant of BSE.
fields.byline: James Meikle, health correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
Such a move could cut Britain's 1.9m volunteer donors by up to 10% and create such huge shortages that transfusion services would struggle to meet demand.

The possibility, first secretly investigated two years ago, is being re-examined as EU scientists and officials decide whether guidance should be offered on blood safety throughout the union.

But some insiders are concerned that such a drastic step could create a level of panic among the whole donor population that would threaten more lives through shortages than might be saved from what is, at present, regarded as only a theoretical risk.

Seven of the 85 British victims of variant CJD, the human equivalent of BSE, have been identified as donors before they showed obvious symptoms of the disease. Recipients of their blood have not been informed but the Department of Health and ethics committees on health authorities are seeking to develop protocols for doing so in the future.

There is as yet no test for detecting vCJD and many patients might not wish to know whether they had been exposed to the risk of a condition for which there is not even at present a treatment to moderate its effects, let alone cure it.

White blood cells are already filtered out of blood donations because they have been thought most likely to carry the agent responsible for vCJD and there is a ban on most British-sourced plasma products.

But the government is anxious to test whether red blood cells carry the agent too. Importing enough blood to meet needs in operating theatres in this country - 2.5m units a year, each about a pint - would be impossible because of its short shelf life so all options that might minimise the threat of contamination are now being reassessed.

The health department confirmed last night that it had ordered the review as to whether those who had received transfusions should be eligible to be blood donors. "The whole issue of cleanliness [of blood] is under review. This is just part of that."

A spokesman for the national blood service said: "We have been working on the basis [that] between 5% and 10% of blood donors have received transfusions. If it were the case that 10% were knocked off our donor data base, we would be struggling to meet the needs of the country."

At present, potential donors are not routinely asked whether they have received blood themselves. Some donors may not even know because by no means all operations involve transfusions.

But the service is to question new donors among the 10% of volunteers it has to recruit each year to replace those who can no longer donate blood, or choose not to, in an effort to assess the position more accurately.

Belgium, Austria and some German states, as well as Switzerland, are already following the example of the United States, Australia, Canada and New Zealand in banning donations from anyone who spent more than six months in the UK between 1980 and 1996, the years in which exposure to BSE through infected meat, vaccines, cosmetics or other possible routes was highest.

The blood authorities in those countries considered they could stand the loss of such donors.

It is also understood that the NHS is in discussions with Jehovah's Witnesses about their experience with recycling of patients' own blood during operations and other blood-saving techniques, as officials and surgeons step up their search for alternatives to traditional donation so they can eke out supplies.

Witnesses have already raised funds for several machines in NHS hospitals that wash and process blood lost in surgery for transfusion back into the same patients.

webTitle: Mentors are encouraging pupils in danger of exclusion to reach their full potential

fields.headline: Mutual support
fields.standfirst: Mentors are encouraging pupils in danger of exclusion to reach their full potential. And what's more, it's helping them in their own careers.  Eileen Fursland  explains
fields.trailText: Mentors are encouraging pupils in danger of exclusion to reach their full potential. And what's more, it's helping them in their own careers. Eileen Fursland explains
fields.body:
At nine o'clock each Monday morning for the past year, Aliesher Burrell from Handsworth Wood Girls' School in Birmingham has been meeting up with Partab Hirani at her school. Hirani, an art and technology student at Birmingham University, is Aliesher's mentor. "We sit and talk about how I'm getting on at school, home, friends or anything that troubles me," says Aliesher, 14. "It's good to have a mentor, because the teachers are not always there to listen. He helps me with my maths and encourages me, and we set targets," she says.

"I think I was given a mentor because I flip sometimes and start thinking negative things about myself. He says I shouldn't always follow my friends, I should be myself and get on with my life - and I've been able to do that now I've got a bit more confidence and I'm getting better at dealing with problems. I have done well in my SATs and I think I will do well next year."

Hirani is one of 29 Birmingham students who are earning extra cash by doing something more interesting than working in a supermarket checkout.

Spending a day a week doing work that makes a real difference to the local community nets the students £2,000. It also enhances their own personal development and makes them more attractive to prospective employers.

The Birmingham Mentoring Consortium (BMC) runs the scheme, which enables degree-level students to apply for Millennium Awards worth £2,000 each. The students act as mentors for young people at secondary school who are underachieving or at risk of school exclusion. They also design and carry out a one-year project in a local West Midlands community.

"Each mentor supports two or three young people and, together with four hours a week on the community project, this works out at about a day a week," says Gethin Davies, consultant director of Second City; Second Chance, which is part of the BMC.

"We do not advise third-year students to do it for obvious reasons, and year one is stressful in other ways, so it's better for year two students," Davies adds.

Ian Webber is a mature student on a degree course in sports, physical education and community studies at Birmingham University who aims to become a primary school teacher. He has just completed the second year of his course, during which he mentored two 13-year-old boys.

"They are capable of achieving decent passes at GCSE but they don't have stable home lives and they were giving the teachers hassle," says Webber. "The idea of mentoring is to give the kids someone to talk to, advice and a bit of leadership."

Webber also got the boys involved in his community project, a basketball team for disaffected young people. Webber - who is married with a three-year-old son - has two jobs, one in a bar and one at Aston Villa Football Club, as well as working full-time through the summer vacation.

"The Millennium Award does make a difference," he says. "It means I don't have to work so many hours and I can have time to study when I really need it."

But the rewards have not all been monetary. "I've benefited as much as the kids have. I've been able to use skills that have been lying dormant - I'm a good trainer, a good motivator. It's given me valuable insight into schools and the systems they use for discipline."

Webber has a mixed ethnic background - "I don't class myself as either black or white, and I've had varied influences through my childhood," he says. "The two boys I was mentoring both come from a very strong black background and their parents speak patois. This is one issue we tried to address. I have read about it and it seems that in certain cases, black children speak patois to the teacher as a way of striking out. I explained that it's not a crime to speak patois but it's more polite to address people in formal settings using formal language. I said I didn't mind them slipping into patois but their teachers might find it a problem."

The boys gave this suggestion a frosty reception at first, he says, but recently their teacher told Webber that things had improved dramatically.

The Birmingham Mentoring Consortium is an inter-cultural mentoring organisation, currently embracing the Hindu, African-Caribbean, Bangladeshi and Sikh communities, as well as people from white and ethnically mixed backgrounds. Most mentees are supported by mentors from the same ethnic background as themselves.

"The concept of same-race support is important in terms of the role modelling dimension of mentoring," says Gethin Davies of Second City, Second Chance, who was recently awarded the OBE in recognition of the value of the scheme.

Everyone wins, he says. The hard-pressed undergraduates get extra cash and valuable experience, while the kids benefit from having role models and mentor support.

What's more, a range of new community projects was set up by the first 29 Millennium Award mentors, including schemes to help refugees into employment, to support young mothers and to teach computer skills to African-Caribbean elders.

Dr Stephen Nepaulsingh, Aliesher Burrell's headteacher at Handsworth Wood Girls' School, says the scheme is good for his school. In each of the last two years, half a dozen pupils - some who have behavioural problems and are disruptive, some lacking in self-esteem, some who need adult support - have had mentors and he feels this has made a difference to their lives. Girls will often listen to an outsider rather than to their parents or teachers, he says.

"And the mentors are young people, closer to them in age, who can relate to them better." There are a number of other schemes around the UK that involve university students in mentoring - some of which are paid.

But wouldn't someone who is doing it for altruistic reasons make a better mentor than someone attracted by the dosh? That may be true in individual cases, says Davies, but it is not statistically true. Recruitment and retention of mentors is a big problem for most mentoring schemes - without paying mentors it is difficult to get the long-term continuity that is so vital.

In the BMC scheme, all the mentors who started the year were still there at the end. If £2,000 to buy the mentor's time is what it takes to make the scheme work, he says, so be it.

 In the National Mentoring Pilot Project, set up by the Department for Education and Employment in 1999, 16 universities and one higher education college have been linked with schools in Education Action Zones. Each higher education institution involved in the project has between 40 and 100 students working as mentors. The students earn £5 an hour for four hours' work each week, mentoring pupils from schools that are considered to need extra support.

 The Birmingham Mentoring Consortium aims to extend its work to the Pakistani community in Birmingham. If its bid to the Millennium Commission is successful, mentors of Pakistani background will be needed next year. Volunteer mentors are urgently needed now in preparation for this. For more information, ring Second City; Second Chance on 0121-414 0190.

webTitle: Britain scoops four Emmys

fields.headline: Brit shows scoops four Emmys
fields.trailText: 9.45: Britain has scooped four out of seven awards at this year's Emmy Awards ceremony in New York last night, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Britain has scooped four out of seven awards at this year's prestigious International Emmy Awards ceremony in New York.

The second series of Channel 4 sketch show Smack the Pony, which is made by TalkBack Productions, scooped the popular arts award.

Another indie producer, Kudos Productions, picked up the children's and young people award for BBC1 drama The Magician's House.

ITN came out on top in the news category, with a report for ITV on the Mozambique floods.

The other UK winner last night was the BBC, which won the best performing arts award for Gloriana, a Film.

webTitle: EMI and Bertelsmann merger 'far from concluded'

fields.headline: EMI and Bertelsmann merger 'far from concluded'
fields.standfirst: Nov 20: EMI strikes internet deals
fields.trailText:
9.30am: The planned merger between EMI and Bertelsmann is still in its 'very early stages' according to Eric Nicoli, boss of the UK record company. By Dan Milmo
Nov 20: EMI strikes internet deals
fields.body:
The proposed merger between EMI and German media giant Bertelsmann is far from concluded, according to the boss of the UK record company.

Eric Nicoli, chairman of EMI, said discussions about joining BMG, Bertelsmann's music operation, have been "entirely constructive".

But he would put no time frame on completing negotiations and would not go into details about the deal.

EMI was forced to abandon its £12bn merger with Warner Music last month after it became clear that EU regulators were likely to block the deal unless both parties made major concessions.

"These discussions are in very early stages, and we have everything to assess. We had our first conversation 11 days ago, and the Warner deal took four months to put together," said Mr Nicoli.

The chairman added that it was "far from clear" that the possible merger would please EMI's shareholders, who were disgruntled with the terms of the Warner deal, or get past the EU's stringent watchdogs.

Mr Nicoli's comments came as EMI admitted legal costs from the failed Warner project and widening losses at its new media division had led to a hefty cut in profits.

Legal and banking costs of £42.9m for the failed merger and widening losses at its new media division were blamed for the shortfall.

First-half pre-tax profits fell 31.7% to £59.1m.

However, sales rose 5.9% to £1.144bn and the figures were marginally above analysts' expectations. EMI is expecting big sales from a packed winter release schedule, which includes Radiohead's Kid album and the Beatles' eagerly awaited No.1 hits collection.

Mr Nicoli denied that the Warner merger had distracted management, leading to a flat first-half performance.

He said: "The results speak for themselves. There is no evidence of deal distraction. Our corporate staff have been largely focused on deals and our operating management have been focusing on the business."

Mr Nicoli added that his job would not be under threat if the BMG talks came to nothing, although he was hired with the mandate of finding a merger partner.

webTitle: Blow for Gore in Florida recount

fields.headline: Blow for Gore in Florida recount
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush was clinging determinedly to a small but clear lead in the Florida election last night as two of the three controversial county recounts appeared to be falling short of supplying Al Gore with the votes he needs to capture the White House.
fields.body:
George W Bush was clinging determinedly to a small but clear lead in the Florida election last night as two of the three controversial county recounts appeared to be falling short of supplying Al Gore with the votes he needs to capture the White House.

With more than two-thirds of the ballots recounted in Broward county, Mr Gore was showing a net gain of only 114 votes over Mr Bush. In neighbouring Palm Beach county, Mr Gore had an even smaller net gain of just three votes after a fifth of the ballots had been recounted. If those trends are replicated in the final re count results, it would not be enough to overturn Mr Bush's existing 930-vote lead in the contest for Florida's decisive 25 electoral college votes.

There was another key tactical gain for Mr Bush last night. Florida's Democratic attorney general, Bob Butterworth, bowed to Republican pressure and the political might of the military lobby, instructing counties to count overseas postal votes from US military personnel even if they failed to carry the postmark normally required by law. Up to 1,100 military ballots, generally thought to favour Mr Bush, that had initially been excluded from the count may now be re-examined.

The recounts continued as lawyers for both sides appeared in the Florida supreme court in Tallahassee in a hearing that could go a long way towards deciding whether Mr Bush or Mr Gore succeeds Bill Clinton on January 20.

Inside the crowded courtroom, the chief justice, Charles Wells, said: "The court is certainly aware of the historic nature of this session and is aware that this is a matter of utmost and vital importance to our nation, our state and our world."

The seven member bench is due to rule as early as today on whether the recounts can continue and form part of the final result in Florida. Mr Bush wants the court to allow Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state, to declare a final result which excludes the recounts.

Mr Gore wants the recounts to continue, in the hope that they will generate enough new votes to give him the victory that would make him president.

The two hour court session was marked by a rapid-fire exchange between the court and lawyers for the two sides on the principles and practicalities of Florida voting law.

Ms Harris's decision to debar hand recounts was "flatly wrong", Gore lawyer Paul Hancock told the court. "It elevates machines over voters." The test for accepting the disputed voting papers "has always been the intent of the voter", a second Gore lawyer, David Boies, stressed.

"What I'm concerned about is the rights of those voters who may not have their votes counted if we don't honour the recounted votes and the rights of all the voters who might have their rights denied if the certification doesn't get in within the time limit," Judge Wells said.

webTitle: Peoplesound seals MP3 music deals

fields.headline: Peoplesound seals MP3 music deals
fields.trailText: 9.30am: European MP3 download site Peoplesound.com has clinched distribution deals with five high-profile websites, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
European MP3 download site Peoplesound.com has clinched distribution deals with five high-profile websites.

The deals will give Peoplesound.com the reach and profile it needs to survive the expected shake-out of online music websites.

Peoplesound's 10,000 artists and 30,000 free MP3 tracks will now be publicised and available for download from AltaVista, LineOne, Liberty Surf and intermusic.

The deal with Amazon will enable users to purchase CDs from Peoplesound artists from the music and books retail giant.

MP3 tracks by unsigned artists can be downloaded for free at Peoplesound, or customers can opt to buy work by those artists in CD format.

Peoplesound recently linked up with the V Shop chain - the reincarnation of Our Price - to install kiosks in stores.

Ernesto Schmitt, president and CEO of peoplesound.com, said: "By teaming with these high-profile internet players, peoplesound.com will be offering access to great music to an even bigger audience as well as offering a number of new services to our own users."

webTitle: Excessive overtime causing havoc to families

fields.headline: Excessive overtime causing havoc to families
fields.trailText: Workaholic habits are damaging productivity and playing havoc with families' attempts to improve their work-life balance, the government warned yesterday in the first official report on the social consequences of excessive overtime.
fields.body:
Workaholic habits are damaging productivity and playing havoc with families' attempts to improve their work-life balance, the government warned yesterday in the first official report on the social consequences of excessive overtime.

One in nine full-time employees works more than 60 hours every week - mostly men with children. And one in eight regularly works both Saturdays and Sundays.

The survey found most men wanted more flexible arrangements such as job-sharing and a reduced working week. But two-thirds thought working part time would damage their careers.

Most women said they would rather work more flexibly after the birth of a child than have longer maternity leave. But almost half the employers thought this would be regarded as unfair by the rest of their staff.

The government billed the survey as the first and largest research into work-life balance in Britain. It was based on interviews with 7,500 employees, 2,500 employers and 250 company head offices.

Margaret Hodge, the equal opportunities minister, said the problem facing industry was not absenteeism but presenteeism. "The long hours culture is alive and kicking ... We are all working too long hours and it is making us ill. That doesn't help productivity and it certainly doesn't support families."

Mrs Hodge was disappointed that overtime had increased since 1997 when the government introduced the EU working time directive stopping most firms from making staff work more than 48 hours a week. "We need to ask why introduction of the 48-hour week has not led to greater change in hours of work and presenteeism."

But the government was encouraged that 55% of employers in the survey agreed it could be acceptable in some circumstances for staff to switch to part time working.

The survey found 14% of men who lived as a couple with dependent children worked more than 60 hours a week. This compared with 7% of women in the same family circumstances, 9% of single parents and 9% of people who were single or members of childless couples.

"The long hours of many males in couple households with children may reflect both a need for income (associated with children) and the opportunity to work long hours (associated with the presence of a partner)," the report said.

Almost half the employers offered stress counselling, but only 9% gave assistance with childcare. "It feels as if we are dealing with the consequences and not the cause of people not getting the right balance between work and the rest of their lives," Mrs Hodge said.

But the "good news" was that 60% of employers let staff vary their hours, 24% of employees work flexitime and 12% have arranged to work only during term time.

John Monks, general secretary of the TUC, said bad employers would not be forced to cut long hours until there were changes in the law. "The one thing the government could do is announce its intention not to renew the individual opt out to the working time directive which sees many people work excessively long hours."

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, said: "It is right that we should hold a carrot out to the thousands of good employers, but it is time that the government showed a willingness to wave a stick at the bad ones."

Peter Elwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB and chairman of Employers for Work-Life Balance, said: "We recognise that men need to balance their work and life outside work just as much as women."

Mrs Hodge, who admitted working "incredibly" long hours, said men had been excluded from previous campaigns for a better work-life balance. "Now fathers too are calling for a better deal. With 14% of fathers working over 60 hours every week, it means that men are less and less able to spend the time with the family that they want."

 Work-life Balance 2000 survey, by Institute for Employment Research, University of Warwick and IFF Research: 40-page summary report from DfEE publications

Rural bliss in a hi-tech haven

'Fortunately I'm married to someone who shares childcare'

 Joy Kingsley: managing partner of Manchester solicitors Pannone & Partners. Mother of two.

I start work after dropping the children off at school - they are four and eight - and finish between 7.30pm and 8pm. It takes me half an hour to get home. One night, normally Thursday, I carry on working at home.

The hours have increased over the years but my hours are not as bad as they are for those working in London. I don't work Friday afternoons - that is the time I have to pick the children up from school and be a normal mum. Since I was 23 or 24 I have worked long hours running branch offices and I came back to work four months after having each child.

"The hours lawyers work have increased dramatically, especially in London. It is because of client demand and increased competition. These days the rules have changed. Everything is a bit of a free-for-all. Before letters would be sent and a reply would have to be dictated and sent back. Now with faxes and e-mails, the process is speedier and clients expect more. Ten years ago lawyers would always finish work at 5pm or 6pm and make a good living doing that.

"Fortunately, I have good support at home. I'm married to someone who takes an equal share of childcare. I do the morning, he does the evening. It may get better if there is more working from home.

Journalist finds better lifestyle in home county environment

 Tim Dwelly, 36, freelance journalist in Cornwall. Father of three.

Until six years ago I was editor of the charity Shelter's in-house magazine, Roof. I suffered some health problems and decided to move to Cornwall, where I was born. The charity was supportive, allowing me to continue working from home as a staff reporter. I swopped my grotty flat in Lambeth, south London, for a regency townhouse.

I made enough contacts for me to get enough work to become a freelancer. Recently I wrote a paper for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation on working from home. I've also been able to team up with other people living in Cornwall doing the same sort of thing as me. There is quite a cluster of people here. I became chair of the Digital Peninsula Network, which has funding from the government and from Europe and work on projects with top quality graphic designers and website designers.

The new technology makes it possible to work from home. I've got the best of both worlds. Penzance has some of the best beaches in the country, good climate and a growing new technology industry. I have found that living in that city and having a family did not work.

Now I do not need to grab weekends in the country because I'm already here. I want time with the family and this style of working gives me that.

webTitle: We don't believe it: BBC fumes in millionaire row

fields.headline: We don't believe it: BBC fumes in millionaire row
fields.standfirst: Interactive quiz: Can you answer the Millionaire questions?
fields.trailText:
Television bosses caught in a ratings war between Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? and One Foot In The Grave were
today waiting for unofficial viewing figures.
fields.body:
Television bosses caught in a ratings war between Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? and One Foot In The Grave were today waiting for unofficial viewing figures.

BBC insiders have accused ITV of fixing the quiz show to ensure its first jackpot winner would coincide with the final episode of its long-running sitcom.

But show host Chris Tarrant denied accusations of "dumbing-down" to allow Judith Keppel, a 58-year-old distant relative of Camilla Parker Bowles, to become the first winner of the £1 million jackpot. He said: "The questions are hard...We refused to dumb the question down. We said it will happen one night. We always said it would come out of the blue and it has."

It is not yet known how quickly the unofficial viewing figures could be available to settle the ratings clash between the quiz and the last episode of One Foot In The Grave, which showed the death of Victor Meldrew.

Viewers of the 122th episode of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? saw Ms Keppel become the first contestant to successfully negotiate the 15 questions needed to scoop the jackpot.

A BBC insider said that the last big winner had also occurred when there was an important ratings battle taking place. "It is a bit of a coincidence," said the BBC insider. "Call me suspicious but it seems to me you can drastically improve your chances of becoming a millionaire if you check your BBC1 schedule before going on the programme."

But ITV reacted furiously to the accusations, accusing its rival of "unpleasant and unfounded attacks".

A spokesman for the network said: "It is a great shame to see the BBC reacting with such cynicism. In doing so they are ignoring the facts - Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? has been winning the ratings battle with One Foot In The Grave for weeks now."

Ms Keppel, a 58-year-old grandmother and former convent girl, told a news conference that she was looking forward to spending the "huge amount of money".

She said despite her success on the game show she had never been a gambler. "I'm not a gambler. I'm the opposite of gambling. I've never really won any money before."

Despite being related to the Prince of Wales' partner, Ms Keppel said people would be wrong to assume she was already rich, and in fact at one point her finances were so bad she had considered selling up her house in Fulham and moving to France.

She said: "It's a huge sum of money. Money has not been a terrible problem and I'm obviously not on the breadline.

"But I'm really looking forward to spending it."

webTitle: No 10 in row over GPs tally

fields.headline: No 10 in row over GPs tally
fields.trailText: Downing Street traded insults with doctors' leaders yesterday after the British Medical Association warned that the government's health plan was bound to fail because of a shortage of GPs.
fields.body:
Downing Street traded insults with doctors' leaders yesterday after the British Medical Association warned that the government's health plan was bound to fail because of a shortage of GPs.

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, accused the BMA of stepping up pressure on the government to strengthen its hand in pay negotiations.

His remarks were immediately attacked by the BMA which said that its warnings on GP numbers were unrelated to pay and had "everything to do with patients".

The war of words erupted yesterday after the BMA chairman, Dr Ian Bogle, warned that there would not be enough GPs to guarantee every patient an appointment within 24 hours by 2004, a central pledge in the NHS plan. "On the timescale envisaged the plan is not deliverable," Dr Bogle said. "There is no way we are going to get enough GPs."

The NHS would need an extra 10,000 doctors, an increase of one third. "The plan promises an extra 2,000 by 2004 and even that may turn out to be impossible to achieve," he said.

Yesterday Mr Campbell expressed surprise at Dr Bogle's intervention because the BMA chairman had put his signature to the NHS plan earlier this year. "The same man said not long ago he supported 97% of the plan," Mr Campbell said. "He obviously felt the need to draw attention to the other 3%. We are into the phase of negotiations over pay."

The exchanges yesterday highlighted growing tensions between ministers and GPs over the government's plans for the NHS. Dr Bogle singled out the new NHS Direct telephone helpline for particular criticism, claiming it had been introduced too quickly "and had very equivocal results".

webTitle: Ministers plan to widen net as job pledge is met

fields.headline: Ministers plan to widen net as job pledge is met
fields.trailText: Ministers are preparing to announce a major revamp of the new deal for the unemployed in the wake of meeting one of their five key manifesto pledges, to take 250,000 youngsters off the dole.
fields.body:
Ministers are preparing to announce a major revamp of the new deal for the unemployed in the wake of meeting one of their five key manifesto pledges, to take 250,000 youngsters off the dole.

Employment ministers hope to announce they have met the pledge next week. The announcement will trigger a wider political debate on the value of the new deal and the need to help the economically inactive into work.

A more flexible new deal will be aimed at bringing over 1m people into contact with the labour market, including lone parents, the disabled and the older long term unemployed. The aim is to target the hard core unemployed, including tens of thousands put onto incapacity benefit in the 1980s. The labour force survey shows that as many as 800,000 who claim sickness and disability benefits actually want to work.

As a first step, the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, is considering requiring new incapacity benefit claimants to attend "a work-focused interview".

At the same time the employment minister, Tessa Jowell, is determined to ensure the government reaps political benefit from its record of job creation - something the US Democrats conspicuously failed to do in the presidential elections.

The government celebrated the creation of 1m extra jobs in the economy last summer with a press conference in Downing Street given by Tony Blair. A similar fanfare is planned for the new deal figures for the young unemployed.

Officials say it is "touch and go" whether they meet the 250,000 target for the young unemployed this month, or at the end of December.

Latest statistics published in October show that almost 245,000 18-24 year olds unemployed for six months or more have found work, just 5,000 short of the manifesto pledge. Critics claim 58,000 found work for less than 13 weeks and many of them would have work anyway.

Ministers are confident that the announcement will be followed quickly by other achievements in job creation.

Despite the surprise 3,500 rise on the unemployment count last week to 1.047m, the government expects to see this measure of unemployment fall below the politically sensitive 1m within four months, for the first time since the mid-70s.

Ministers also hope that they will be able to claim Britain is becoming a full employment economy for the first time since the 60s. The chancellor, Gordon Brown, in his first full budget redefined full employment as 75% of the population of working age in jobs. At present, the figure stands at 74.7%, the second highest figure in Europe.

The numbers in work, compiled on the basis of a rolling three month average, is increasing at a rate of 0.1% two or three months, suggesting Britain will reach the 75% target by the time of an election in late spring next year.

Although the 75% figure, then measured annually, was reached in 1990, this temporary success was immediately followed by recession. Employment officials insist the chancellor wants to be able to project a sustained period of employment growth.

The post-war peak in employment took place in 1974 when 75.7% of the working age population was in work.

With the population of working age growing by 134,000 over the past year, employment will need to grow by an additional 110,000 to reach the 75% target.

Key elements of the new deal mark two include from April next year transformation of the current employment service into a working age agency responsible for the administration of a much wider range of benefits. The agency will not simply be aimed at the unemployed, but all the economically inactive.

Ministers are also providing tougher and longer procedures for those going through the new deal in a bid to ensure they stay in jobs longer.

The 150,000 people aged 24 to 55 and unemployed for 18 months or more will be subject to the same sanctions regime as the young unemployed. They will be guaranteed a job or training place, and like those aged 16-24 could lose benefit for as long as 26 weeks if they break the sanctions regime three times.

The government has already toughened the regime for 900,000 lone parents on income support by requiring them to attend initial job advice interviews, if their children are aged over five. The offer of training course or jobs will remain voluntary for the forseeable future.

In two extensions of the scheme, lone parents with children as young as three will now be offered interviews. Help will also be extended to the 150,000 workless lone parents not on income support.

Ministers recognise that the short term impact of bringing people currently not registered as unemployed onto the claimant count will be to boost the headline total of the unemployed. However, they believe that in a second term Labour government this will be a price worth paying.

webTitle: BBC attacked by rival over children's channels

fields.headline: BBC attacked by rival over children's channels
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Nickelodeon today claimed that the BBC's planned children's channels could put its kids' TV channel, Nick Jnr, out of business. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Nickelodeon bosses have today claimed that Greg Dyke's planned children's channels could put its television station, Nick Jnr, out of business.

A report from Arthur Andersen commissioned by the channel, claims that independent children's TV producers could lose up to £400m over five years in lost subscription and advertising revenue if the BBC launches its promised children's services.

Nickelodeon is set to write to culture secretary Chris Smith in protest at a move that it believes will make Nick Jnr unprofitable.

The broadcaster also claims that the new BBC channels will hit "quality" services particularly hard.

Nickelodeon general manager Paul Lindley said: "If the BBC gets the go-ahead, Nickelodeon's track record will be undermined and Nick Jr could go out of business altogether."

The BBC, however, claims that Nickelodeon has massaged its figures, and pointed out that most of the broadcaster's programming has been commissioned from the US.

A spokesman said: "The BBC believes that UK licence payers and their children would want the choice of a wide range of quality and predominantly British-made public service programmes in an advertising-free environment."

The BBC has just completed its consultation process on the new services, which have to be submitted to the Department of Culture, Media & Sport for approval.

webTitle: NTL/Universal film channel picks HHCL for launch ads

fields.headline: NTL/Universal film channel picks HHCL for launch ads
fields.trailText: The Studio, the new film channel being launched by NTL and Hollywood studio Universal, has hired HHCL & Partners to create a multi-million pound launch advertising campaign.
fields.body:
The Studio, the new film channel being launched by NTL and Hollywood studio Universal, has hired HHCL & Partners to create a multi-million pound launch advertising campaign.

The channel already has a strong line-up of films, including Notting Hill, Babe and The Flintstones, thanks to Universal's involvement.

The joint venture is part of NTL's aim to build its own content instead of relying on products from Sky, as well as generating additional revenues by selling the channels to other broadcasters.

The channel will launch "within the next six months", according to the company.

Deborah Fitzgerald, marketing and communications director for Universal Studios Networks UK, said: "We decided to invite HHCL to develop ideas for The Studio before looking at agencies because we are delighted with their work on Sci-Fi.

"This is a challenging brief for HHCL in that the two channels represent entirely different proposition and we anticipate an innovative and instinctive approach to them both."

webTitle: John West Salmon in £1m TV ad campaign

fields.headline: John West Salmon leaps in with £1m TV ads
fields.trailText: 8.15am: John West Salmon made its return to TV advertising last night with a £1m campaign, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
John West Salmon made its return to TV advertising last night with a £1m campaign aimed at positioning the fish brand as the best in its market.

In what is John West Salmon's first outing on TV for more than 10 years, the campaign features a Jim Henson bear costume with an animatronic face fighting with a fisherman over fish.

Created by Paul Silburn while he was at Leo Burnett and directed by Danny Kleinman, the campaign includes two executions - 10-second and 30-second - were shot in the Scottish highlands.

The commercials carry on the tagline, "John West endures the worst to bring you the best", which broke in the recent TV commercial it ran for its tuna product.

John West has a 30% market share of the canned fish market in the UK, and a 38% share in the canned red salmon market.

webTitle: £7m from Millionaire contenders

fields.headline: £7m from callers who want to be a contender
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Callers to the premium rate phone lines for Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? have swelled the prize fund by more than £7m since the show started.
fields.body:
Callers to the premium rate phone lines for Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? have swelled the prize fund by more than £7m since the show started.

In the show's first seven series (the current one is the eighth) more than 20m aspirants have called. Producers of the show say contestants are chosen at random.

Gross revenue for the calls has been £20m. Once VAT and the phone company's charges are deducted, this has generated around £7.69m.

Phone line money pays for publicity and the costs of selecting contestants - all of the remaining profit then goes into the prize fund, which is rolled over from series to series.

In the event of no new shows being commissioned, says Celador, the production company, remaining funds would be donated to charity.

The total prize money won has risen from £377,000 in the first series to top the £1m mark in each of the last four series.

As of last Thursday, the cost of calling rose from 50p to 60p per minute. The average cost of making a call during the previous series was 76p.

A spokeswoman for Celador said the increase was because charges for all premium rate phone lines had gone up.

Callers to the number are greeted by the pre-recorded voice of Chris Tarrant, inviting them to choose which forthcoming show they might like to appear on by pressing the keys of their phone for the appropriate date.

The question being posed yesterday was: "Which official represents the British Crown in a colony?"

Answers on offer were: chief constable, sheriff, governor or lord mayor.

Giving the correct answer leads to a message congratulating the caller and informing him or her that Celador is currently selecting contestants for future shows.

Tarrant sounds cheery as he burbles "thanks for calling and - good luck!", and with another 70p or so in the prize pot, well he might.

webTitle: Rowland takes BBC creative role

fields.headline: BBC radio drama head takes on creative role
fields.trailText: 5pm: Kate Rowland, BBC head of radio drama, is to take up the new post of creative director, new writing within Alan Yentob's BBC drama, entertainment and children's department. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Kate Rowland, BBC head of radio drama, is to take up the new post of creative director, new writing within Alan Yentob's BBC drama, entertainment and children's department.

In her new post Ms Rowland will expand the new drama writing initiative she set up two years ago, to encompass entertainment and children's programmes.

She will commission two new writing strands, The Wire on Radio 3 and Radio 4's The Friday Play, as well as working across other radio, TV and new media projects.

Ms Rowland, whose production credits during three years as head of radio drama include Lee Hall's critically acclaimed Radio 4 drama, Spoonface Steinberg, will report to Susan Spindler, head of innovation and factual drama.

She said: "This role allows me to take risks, nurture diverse voices and work with the most distinctive writing talent."

The head of radio drama job is to be advertised.

webTitle: Retreat on euro ballot safeguards

fields.headline: Retreat on euro ballot safeguards
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The government yesterday bowed to Eurosceptic accusations that it could fix the results of referendums on the euro or electoral reform, by agreeing to give its proposed independent electoral commission powers to warn if the proposed question is unintelligible.
fields.body:
The government yesterday bowed to Eurosceptic accusations that it could fix the results of referendums on the euro or electoral reform, by agreeing to give its proposed independent electoral commission powers to warn if the proposed question is unintelligible.

Tory Eurosceptics have been campaigning to prevent the government from retaining the exclusive power to frame the wording of a euro referendum.

During the report stage of the political parties, elections and referendums bill in the Lords, the Home Office minister, Lord Bassam, said it was right for the commission to advise on referendum wording. But he rejected Tory pressure to give the commission the power to express views on whether the referendum question was fairly worded, because this would drag it into party politics. The government will also appoint a political parties' panel to advise the commission.

Conservatives have claimed that the government will try to manipulate any referendum on a single currency in the next parliament by framing a loaded question.

The Conservative spokesman, Lord Mackay, yesterday welcomed the concessions, adding that any self respecting government would not proceed with a referendum when the electoral commission had pronounced it unfair.

 Peers last night backed a Tory wrecking amendment to the disqualifications bill, allowing members of the Irish parliament to stand for election to the UK parliament. Ministers said they will overturn the measure in the Commons.

webTitle: Straw extends youth tagging

fields.headline: Straw extends youth tagging
fields.trailText: Nationwide tagging scheme to be rolled out as part of government attack on 'yob culture', writes Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
The government last night signalled a crackdown on yob culture by announcing a nationwide electronic tagging scheme for all 10- to 15-year-old offenders as a part of an attempt to extend curfew orders on the young.

Most curfews will require convicted youngsters to stay off the street at night.

The measure follows a pilot project in 20 courts in Greater Manchester and Norfolk initiated by the last Conservative government's home secretary, Michael Howard.

The powers to impose the curfew orders nationwide will be handed to courts early next year.

The Home Office claimed commissioned research showed that the tagged curfew orders were popular with sentencers and that, generally, offenders and their families preferred to deal with the restrictions of the tagged curfew rather than the alternative of a custodial sentence.

However, the study of the pilot programme also showed that low use of curfews stemmed from the belief that they were suitable only for a small number of young offenders. Social workers pointed out that nigthtime curfews could exacerbate tensions at home or add to a lack of familiy stability.

The scheme was attacked by the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders and by Harry Fletcher, assistant general secretary of the National Association of Probation Officers.

Mr Fletcher said: "Tagging has no effect on crime or criminality and there is no proven deterrent effect. The danger is that younger children won't understand it and that older ones will see it as a trophy. What is needed is supervision and guidance, not electronic gimmicks."

Defending the move yesterday the home secretary, Jack Straw, said: "The orders will help to break patterns of offending by keeping young offenders off the streets and out of trouble at the times they are most likely to offend."

He claimed the tag monitored curfews would bring order to often chaotic lives. The Home Office research found that 155 curfew orders had been imposed in Manchester and Norfolk between March 1998 and February 2000. In total 10 orders were applied to girls and and none were made on 10-year-olds. Most were made on 14 to 15-year-olds.

Over half the orders were imposed for theft or burglary with two thirds of the youngsters facing tags of between two to three months. The curfew normally lasted 10 to 12 hours a day, almost always at night.

The research found that very little information on the tagging reached school officials with schools sometimes only hearing of the tag after being contacted by the parent. Most curfewed children said it meant they spent more time at home watching TV or sleeping, and less time pursuing leisure activities.

In some cases, parents found they had to give up their jobs to look after their curfewed child. "There were only two cases where we were told a curfew enabled a young offender to make a break from a crowd of peers who had led them into trouble," the pilot study report concluded.

The Home Office predicted about 1,200 curfew orders would be imposed nationwide thoughout England and Wales at a cost of £1.8m. Ministers have yet to decide whether to extend the scheme by making tags a condition of bail.

The government hopes to go further on youth crime in the Queen's speech next month when they will propose fixed penalty fines for loutish antics, including drunkeness and anti-social behaviour.
