webTitle: Obituary: Frederick Clarke

fields.headline: Frederick Clarke
fields.standfirst: Magazine publisher whose fierce independence led to regular clashes with Hollywood
fields.trailText: Frederick Clarke, owner, editor, graphic artist and writer of the groundbreaking American magazine Cinefantastique, has committed suicide aged 51
fields.body:
Frederick Clarke, owner, editor, graphic artist and writer of the groundbreaking American magazine Cinefantastique, has committed suicide aged 51.

A fan of the science fiction genre since he saw the film When Worlds Collide as a child, Clarke earned a bachelor's degree in physics at the University of Illinois before taking the publishing gamble that would make him a hero of every fantasy film aficionado and the nemesis of such Hollywood heavyweights as Steven Spielberg and George Lucas. Fired by the more serious approach taken to the genre by the New Jersey-based 60s fanzine Castle of Frankenstein, Clarke first produced Cinefantastique as a newsletter, mimeographed in his mother's attic, during his years at college, where he studied quantum mechanics.

In the autumn of 1970, he published the first glossy edition, featuring Catch-22 on the cover, at a total cost of $280 while working as a laboratory supply salesman. After several loss-making years, he finally left his day job, turned his obsession into his profession and built up the circulation of the magazine (affectionately known as CFQ) from 1,000 to its current 30,000.

Eschewing the hyperbole and celebrity gossip of the era's film periodicals, Clarke explained in painstaking detail the financial structuring, auteur methods, splatter make-up tricks and special-effects backgrounds of his favoured retro classics and all the current fantasy blockbusters. "I have pretences of covering the field better than anyone else," Clarke told the Los Angeles Times in 1986 of the ethos behind his magazine with a self-confessed "sense of wonder". His labours were almost totally financed by subscriptions and newsstand sales, because he felt studio advertising would compromise the integrity of his earnest endeavour.

That decision helped Clarke overcome numerous clashes with Hollywood due to his fiercely independent editorial stance. When he divulged the plot of Return of the Jedi in 1983 long before the third Star Wars episode went on release, he incurred the wrath of producer George Lucas, who issued a directive to his Lucasfilm personnel forbidding future cooperation with any CFQ writer. Clarke and his writers found themselves similarly banned by Warner Bros when he published photos of the helicopter accident that killed actor Vic Morrow during the filming of Twilight Zone: The Movie. Joe Dante, the director of Gremlins, was among those who refused to be interviewed by CFQ. But even Dante admitted: "I've probably bought every copy. In terms of what it does, nobody does it better."

Famous for its unfussy layout, in-depth analysis of filmmaking techniques, exclusive behind-the-scenes photos and unflattering critiques, CFQ blazed a trail for the explosion of fantasy film-orientated magazines that occurred in the wake of Star Wars as other publishers woke up to the fact that the genre had broken out from its cult margins and become mainstream.

Starlog, Cinefex, Fangoria, Starburst, The House of Hammer, Shivers and Gorezone all owe a debt to the landmark journalism of Clarke, who went to great pains to ensure that it was doggedly accurate and acerbically honest. He once told the Chicago Tribune: "We treat the genre the way a serious magazine on the art of film would treat film-making."

Clarke launched other publications: Imagi-Movies in 1993 (an attempt to recreate the early CFQ formula, devoting space to obscure classics and foreign releases) and AnimeFantastique in 1999 (an overview of world animation). But only Femme Fatales, launched in summer 1992, became as big a success as his original brainchild. Focusing on actresses involved in all fantasy strata, from B-video starlets to Oscar-winning legends, Femme Fatales features erotic pin-ups alongside lengthy career interviews. Its meteoric circulation accomplishment was so great that at one stage Clarke produced an issue every three weeks.

Clarke is survived by his wife, Celeste Casey Clarke, two children and two step-children.

 Frederick Clarke, journalist, born 1949; died October 17 2000

When he divulged the plot of Return of the Jedi in 1983 long before the third Star Wars episode went on release, he incurred the wrath of producer George Lucas, who issued a directive to his Lucasfilm personnel forbidding future cooperation with any CFQ writer. Clarke and his writers found themselves similarly banned by Warner Bros when he published photos of the helicopter accident that killed actor Vic Morrow during the filming of Twilight Zone: The Movie. Joe Dante, the director of Gremlins, was among those who refused to be interviewed by CFQ. But even Dante admitted: "I've probably bought every copy. In terms of what it does, nobody does it better." Famous for its unfussy layout, in-depth analysis of filmmaking techniques, exclusive behind-the-scenes photos and unflattering critiques, CFQ blazed a trail for the explosion of fantasy film-orientated magazines that occurred in the wake of Star Wars as other publishers woke up to the fact that the genre had broken out from its cult margins and become mainstream. Starlog, Cinefex, Fangoria, Starburst, The House of Hammer, Shivers and Gorezone all owe a debt to the landmark journalism of Clarke, who went to great pains to ensure that it was doggedly accurate and acerbically honest. He once told the Chicago Tribune: "We treat the genre the way a serious magazine on the art of film would treat film-making." Clarke launched other publications: Imagi-Movies in 1993 (an attempt to recreate the early CFQ formula, devoting space to obscure classics and foreign releases) and AnimeFantastique in 1999 (an overview of world animation). But only Femme Fatales, launched in summer 1992, became as big a success as his original brainchild. Focusing on actresses involved in all fantasy strata, from B-video starlets to Oscar-winning legends, Femme Fatales features erotic pin-ups alongside lengthy career interviews. Its meteoric circulation accomplishment was so great that at one stage Clarke produced an issue every three weeks. Clarke is survived by his wife, Celeste Casey Clarke, two children and two step-children.  Frederick Clarke, journalist, born 1949; died October 17 2000

webTitle: Rebel MP backtracks on deal

fields.headline: Rebel MP backtracks on deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: The rebel MP, Dennis Canavan, yesterday announced he had withdrawn his application to rejoin Labour, leaving the party facing the prospect of an embarrassing byelection in his Westminster seat.
fields.body:
The rebel MP, Dennis Canavan, yesterday announced he had withdrawn his application to rejoin Labour, leaving the party facing the prospect of an embarrassing byelection in his Westminster seat.

Although he was expelled from Labour in 1999 for standing as an independent in the Scottish parliamentary elections, Mr Canavan said earlier this month that he believed reconciliation was a "distinct possibility".

Mr Canavan stood on an independent ticket for the Scottish parliament after he was rejected as "not good enough" by Labour selectors, even though he had been an MP for more than 20 years. He went on to win the largest majority in the Scottish parliament.

He had decided to return to the Labour fold after the death of Donald Dewar, with whom he shared a great deal of personal animosity. But in a shock announcement yesterday, the Falkirk West MP and MSP said he was withdrawing his application after receiving additional information about his rejection by Labour.

"As a result, I have no confidence in the present leadership of the Labour party and I therefore no longer wish to pursue my application to rejoin the party," he said in a letter to Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh.

webTitle: No 10 in row over GPs tally

fields.headline: No 10 in row over GPs tally
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Downing Street traded insults with doctors' leaders yesterday after the British Medical Association warned that the government's health plan was bound to fail because of a shortage of GPs.
fields.body:
Downing Street traded insults with doctors' leaders yesterday after the British Medical Association warned that the government's health plan was bound to fail because of a shortage of GPs.

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, accused the BMA of stepping up pressure on the government to strengthen its hand in pay negotiations.

His remarks were immediately attacked by the BMA which said that its warnings on GP numbers were unrelated to pay and had "everything to do with patients".

The war of words erupted yesterday after the BMA chairman, Dr Ian Bogle, warned that there would not be enough GPs to guarantee every patient an appointment within 24 hours by 2004, a central pledge in the NHS plan. "On the timescale envisaged the plan is not deliverable," Dr Bogle said. "There is no way we are going to get enough GPs."

The NHS would need an extra 10,000 doctors, an increase of one third. "The plan promises an extra 2,000 by 2004 and even that may turn out to be impossible to achieve," he said.

Yesterday Mr Campbell expressed surprise at Dr Bogle's intervention because the BMA chairman had put his signature to the NHS plan earlier this year. "The same man said not long ago he supported 97% of the plan," Mr Campbell said. "He obviously felt the need to draw attention to the other 3%. We are into the phase of negotiations over pay."

The exchanges yesterday highlighted growing tensions between ministers and GPs over the government's plans for the NHS. Dr Bogle singled out the new NHS Direct telephone helpline for particular criticism, claiming it had been introduced too quickly "and had very equivocal results".

webTitle: Blair's messenger faces firing squad

fields.headline: Blair's messenger faces firing squad
fields.standfirst: Today's vote by Labour backbenchers will send warning to PM
fields.trailText: Backbench Labour MPs will today send a stern warning to ministers to take their views more seriously when many of them vote to "shoot the messenger" who carries their concerns to Downing Street.
fields.body:
Backbench Labour MPs will today send a stern warning to ministers to take their views more seriously when many of them vote to "shoot the messenger" who carries their concerns to Downing Street.

Whether or not Clive Soley, MP for Acton and Shepherd's Bush, loses his job as chairman of the Parliamentary Labour Party (PLP) to fellow MP, Tony Lloyd, when the votes are counted tonight - or whether the contest goes to a second ballot tomorrow - both sides admit the result will be tight.

Though part of Mr Soley's unpopularity is attributed to his support for Tory, Sir George Young, to become Speaker, instead of Labour's own Mick Martin - who won easily - the defeat of a London loyalist by a Mancunian would also be seen as a "heartlands" protest by some MPs.

The third runner in today's contest among the 413 MPs who take the Labour whip is Andrew Mackinlay, MP for Thurrock in Essex since 1992, and aradical of the Old Labour right who believes that the PLP chairman's role should be beefed up into that of a caucus leader with direct access to the prime minister.

Mr Mackinlay is an outspoken member of the Westminster "awkward squad" who is admired. But his critics say he would behave too much like Sir Marcus Fox, ex-chairman of the Tory 1922 committee - the PLP's equivalent body - dashing out to tell the TV cameras what he had just lectured Tony Blair about.

If he comes third and no one gets a clear majority, his votes could split either way. Unsurprisingly his supporters and those of Mr Lloyd, a dapper ex-minister dropped last year, stress that they are not trying to "give Blair a bloody nose".

Equally predictably, the Soley camp says that their man is carrying the can for the failure of ministers to note such grassroots concerns as the 75p pension rise, the sell-off of the air traffic control system (Nats) and the fuel tax crisis.

A victory for Mr Mackinlay would be tantamount to MPs "rattling the bars rather loudly". A win for Mr Lloyd - the favourite last night - would amount to sending a tougher message, "to shooting the messenger and dropping the body outside Blair's door", said one Soley voter.

There were complaints by cabinet members at Friday's special meeting in Chequers that some colleagues were failing to keep in touch with backbench opinion, as Mr Blair promised they would in 1997. Some of the hostility to Gordon Brown which has surfaced this year is attributed to the 75p pensions misjudgment and the Nats privatisation.

Mr Lloyd, who has deliberately kept a low profile, is backed by such "heartlands" campaigners as Peter Kilfolyle, another ex-minister.

Though he is the establishment candidate, Mr Soley, chairman since 1997, also wants to see the role of the PLP chair expanded, so that there is a better conduit from party to government.

He stands accused by some MPs of being too much No 10's spokesman to the troops than the other way around.

Yesterday Mr Mackinlay was the only candidate to make a direct appeal to the 413 voters. In a letter he explained: "I want to see the PLP becoming the main focus group for the party, accompanied by more collegiality in decision making ... to argue that changing the person occupying the chair would imply a criticism of the prime minister or the government is a nonsense.

"I know how insensitive and reckless statements to the press can damage and bitterly disappoint those struggling for every possible vote in marginal and winnable seats. I understand the need for discretion. That is why I argue for greater candour, behind closed doors."

webTitle: Fujimori 'seeks sanctuary in new passport'

fields.headline: Fujimori 'seeks sanctuary in new passport'
fields.trailText: The Peruvian president, Alberto Fujimori, remained tight-lipped about his planned resignation yesterday despite speculation that he is seeking Japanese citizenship to avoid corruption charges at home.
fields.body:
The Peruvian president, Alberto Fujimori, remained tight-lipped about his planned resignation yesterday despite speculation that he is seeking Japanese citizenship to avoid corruption charges at home.

Mr Fujimori announced his decision to stand down in a terse statement issued on Monday in Japan, the birthplace of his parents. The formal email was drafted in a heavily guarded Tokyo hotel, where he has been staying since he arrived in Japan last week for an unscheduled visit.

His cabinet resigned en masse in protest, complaining that he had not made it clear whether he would return home.

Earlier the Peruvian embassy in Tokyo said Mr Fujimori was in Japan to ask for economic aid, and that his visit had been extended because he had a cold. It now refuses to say how long he will stay.

Alejandro Toledo, the main opposition leader, believes Mr Fujimori is trying to obtain long-term refuge to avoid returning home to explain his role in a bribery and intimidation scandal.

He said in Spain: "We've just heard there has been a request for a Japanese passport."

The opposition parties, who have gained control of congress since Mr Fujimori went abroad, want to question him about the activities of his former spy chief Vladimiro Montesinos, who is now in hiding.

Mr Montesinos is accused of human rights abuses, electoral fraud and receiving millions of dollars from drug barons.

Mr Fujimori has refused to discuss matters relating to his 10 years of hardline rule, but he is bound to fear a supreme court to which three judges he had sacked have been reinstated.

How long he will remain in Japan is unclear. Japan has a history of refusing asylum applications, but Mr Fujimori is entitled to apply for citizen ship because his parents were born there.

He has plenty of time to lodge an application - foreign ministry officials said he would be allowed to stay for a year with diplomatic status even after leaving his post.

A request for citizenship could open a constitutional can of worms.

The Peruvian media claims that he was born in Japan, which would mean that he was not entitled to become president.

The government denies the claim.

In Lima yesterday opposition leaders said they were preparing to remove him from the presidency on the grounds of moral unfitness.

Congressman Cesar Zumaeta Flores of the centre-left party Aprista said any resignation letter would be rejected and his post declared vacant. He said: "His moral behaviour as president leaves a lot to be desired; the fact he has fled is totally shameful."

Such a move could thwart Mr Fujimori's plans for his second vice president, Ricardo Marquez, to take over until elections are held in April, and let the opposition run a transitional government.

The outgoing prime minister, Federico Salas, said Mr Fujimori might run for congress to get immunity from the criminal investigations.

Speculation about the president was further compounded yesterday when removals vans entered the presidential palace.

webTitle: Japanese PM saved by rebel climbdown

fields.headline: Japanese PM saved by rebel climbdown
fields.trailText: A possible last-minute backroom deal with party rebels yesterday seems to have saved the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, from the greatest threat to his seven-month premiership.
fields.body:
A possible last-minute backroom deal with party rebels yesterday seems to have saved the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, from the greatest threat to his seven-month premiership.

After the retreat from a potentially damaging split, the Liberal Democratic party (LDP) and its coalition allies easily defeated a no-confidence motion tabled by the opposition in a chaotic parliamentary session late last night. The motion was beaten by a margin of 237 votes to 190.

"The general public has never said 'no' to the policies I have been pursuing since I took office," Mr Mori said, vowing to move beyond the political turmoil by focusing on new measures to stimulate the ailing economy.

But his victory may prove short-lived because the rifts in the LDP are unlikely to heal without his removal from power.

The no-confidence vote was an anti-climax to weeks of frenzied political speculation about the possible break-up of the party that has held power for all but 12 months of the past 45 years.

The marathon session was interrupted by heated rows between MPs, including a conservative - a former wrestler - who was expelled from the chamber after he threw water over a heckler.

Until the motion was tabled, the 480-seat lower house of parliament appeared to be split down the middle. But at the last minute Koichi Kato, the former general secretary of the LDP who led the rebellion, suddenly advised his supporters to abstain rather than vote against the government and risk expulsion from the party.

"You should retreat with dignity," he said tearfully.

"Unfortunately, the outlook for the vote is extremely delicate and we are not in a situation where we could necessarily claim victory."

In an unusually public attack on his party leader, Mr Kato had earlier promised to force the resignation of Mr Mori at any cost.

The Harvard-educated former diplomat said the country risked sinking like the Titanic if it continued with the unpopular prime minister's tax-and-spend policies, which have given Japan the biggest public deficit in the industrialised world.

His defeat is a blow to the reformers in the LDP, who have seen the crisis of the past fortnight as the best opportunity for seven years to change the country's politics.

The reason for the capitulation remained unclear last night, but it appeared that Mr Kato decided to yield ground after losing the numbers game, both in parliament and among the public.

Earlier in the day more than 20 members of his faction - led by elderly cabinet members such as the finance minister Kiichi Miyazawa - refused to join his attack, which critics dismissed as a personal push for power.

An opinion poll by the Asahi TV station showed that two-thirds of voters want the gaffe-prone Mr Mori to step down, although just 35% thought Mr Kato would make a better prime minister.

Just before his u-turn, Mr Kato is believed to have met Hiromu Nonaka, the LDP's most-powerful "shadow shogun", prompting rumours that they might have agreed to remove Mr Mori later on to preserve party unity.

Toku Yamasaki, head of another dissident LDP group, said the compromise paved the way for a future leadership challenge by Mr Kato. "This may appear to be a failed attempt, but we must make this the new beginning." He said they must not lose the chance for Mr Kato to lead the LDP.

But the public may find it difficult to forgive Mr Kato, who has now managed to betray both his conservative leader and reform-minded members of the government and opposition parties.

"This wasn't just a vote about Mr Mori, but about whether the Japanese nation will go bankrupt or not," Takayoshi Igarashi, professor of politics at Hosei University, said. "Without reform and a new leader, Japan cannot survive."

webTitle: Arts: Painter Brice Marden

fields.headline: Give us a swirl
fields.standfirst: Adrian Searle gets entangled in Brice Marden's crisscrossing twists of colour
fields.trailText: Adrian Searle gets entangled in Brice Marden's crisscrossing twists of colour.
fields.body:
At 10 to four on a winter afternoon, I'm looking at Brice Marden's paintings in London's Serpentine Gallery. My eye follows the loops and arcs and intersections of the lines that fill them, crossing and recrossing the canvases, swerving, wallowing, climbing and dipping. The line is never slack. It stays alert.

Yet the longer I look, the more the painting's colour becomes fugitive and unfixable, the harder it is not to snag on details, and lose the thread of the structure of the painting and my own place in it. There's no beginning or end.

Now there seems to be something wrong with my eyes: the paintings flicker, brighten up and then go dim again. But no, at this time of day, with the daylight going and the gallery lighting taking over, what I'm seeing is the flux of the National Grid, the surges in the power lines.

I imagine all those hidden wires underground, a map of arteries and connections, the electrons pulsing down wires, and that somehow my own wiring has become entangled with the paintings, hooking me up to these fluctuations in the line.

The painting I'm looking at is one of the earliest, and certainly the largest, in this survey of Marden's work of the past decade. It is called The Muses, a big, sallow, faded green canvas traversed by endless looping lines, endless complications.

The painting, and the line, evokes natural things - weedy unkempt tangles and tendrils, autumn vines whose leaves have gone. There are bodies in there, too, a deja vu of breasts and hips, legs and necks, the curve and fall of drapery. There is a lot of air and space between the lines, and the thin greenness beyond is more like atmosphere, or the memory of a scent, than colour itself.

Commentaries on this painting tell me it has something to do with Marden's father, and his love of nature, as well as the artist's own sojourns in Greece, the ghosts of gods in the rocks and vineyards, and his adolescent daughters dancing in the studio on the island of Hydra.

It is a fertile image. It also inevitably recalls Jackson Pollock, and looks forward to some of Gary Hume's recent paintings of female bodies, duplicated and replicated and overlain in skeins of line, entangled with indoor plants.

But Marden's painting stays resolutely itself, revealing its own indeterminacies in the fitful gallery light. Like all his works here, you want to look at it for a long time, go away, then look some more.

It has been almost 20 years since Marden - who was born in 1938 - last had a major show in Britain, and almost 30 since, as a student, I saw that first grey and grainy catalogue of his, which had the artist standing naked alongside his gummy, waxy, painted monochromes.

The paintings were dedicated to Otis Redding and Janis Joplin. (Artist take care: what if he'd name-checked Donny Osmond or Neil Diamond? What kind of slant would that have given the work?) Looking at The Muses, those old photos of the artist as a young man, interposing his own body next to the near-blank early paintings, come back as another faint echo.

Early Marden was minimalism with soul. His work was evidently hand-made. It was contemplative yet also concise, reserved and somehow street-wise. His recalcitrant art implied hidden depths; but unlike Rothko's, say, it didn't make you feel put-upon or guilty if you didn't get the heavy-handed reverberations.

Marden went on to dedicate drawings to poets Kenneth Rexroth and Gary Snyder, and to relate his later multi-panel paintings to the lintels and posts of Greek architecture. Classical allusions, and evocations of Mediterranean light, as well as to eastern mysticism, lent his work impeccable, austere credentials.

But, at some point, we all stopped reading The Way of Zen and Marden's paintings sort of disappeared, amidst the noise and bluster of neo-expressionism.

It was clear that Marden never wanted to go back to the tabula rasa. His paintings were always about fullness rather than emptiness. What was behind Marden's monochrome painting was drawing. Marden has always drawn, and for decades there was a sense of a split between his work in the two media.

His drawings were always linear and, even when they related to the grid, there were enough accidents, blots, misrulings and spatters to make them interesting. One group was called Suicide Notes, and they looked to me like rehearsals for the scaffold.

It took a long time for the drawing to get into the paintings in a full-blooded way. The line, when it did arrive, was spiky, tense and nervous. It appeared that it - or the man wielding the brush - was wired up or strung out.

On the way from A to B, Marden's line had crying jags and anxiety attacks. It was jangly and tense, as if it had drunk too much coffee. It related to calligraphy, but it was abstract, uncertain whether it was structural or a form of invented writing. Sometimes a bit of a body, or a memory of a shape, would emerge, only to disappear again.

Somehow, Marden marshalled this line and set it to work in his paintings, bringing with it incident, accident, overdrawing and erasure, all the impedimenta and clutter of drawing. Gradually - this exhibition shows us how - the curve got cleaner, the line more regular, its charge more even.

Everything in the painting started to work in concert, from the ground up, and from the last layer and mark back to the first. Where does drawing end and painting begin? It doesn't matter.

In Holland, where I spent a bit of time teaching this year, I'd hear the mutter that "The Mondrian project is over", uttered with regretful finality. The Mondrian project being, I suppose, a sort of utopian abstraction.

And at a conference I attended this weekend, people were talking about the "post-medium paradigm" (only at conferences will one hear such a cloth-eared phrase, uttered without a hint of irony), and we perhaps ought to look at painting in the light of the fact that the medium is not the message.

But never say it's over. Marden, quite unexpectedly, took up Mondrian's regular line, introducing it to late, late Willem de Kooning on the way. Marden's lines loop the loop. They arc and dip and wiggle, take purposeful open curves, drive over the painting's centre, then pull onto the hard shoulder of the canvas edge to negotiate corners with a tight turn.

They circulate endlessly. You drive them with your eyes, first one way, then another. The line is even and smooth. This is driving over clean Tarmac with new tyres. Returning to the whole, you keep finding shapes, then losing them again. Your eyes switch from the blue line to the black, then onto the yellow for a while. It is the enjoyable pursuit of nothing, in search of a resolution that never comes.

The evenness and uninflectedness of Marden's recent line - a line with even width and speed, a line that never falters or runs ragged - lends the paintings a sort of fixatedness. The colour is resonant and full, even when it is interestingly dirty. The paintings are flat, but not so cleaned up as to be mechanical.

The line, which looks layered and colour-coded (red running over a blue-green over black, all on a bluish-grey ground, for example), is all in the same surface. The layering is optical as much as it is physical. You can't always tell in what order the colours were laid down, nor quite how many reversals and revisions have taken place. What passes for painterliness is the residue of the works' manufacture, rather than self-conscious attempts to be personal, stylish or anecdotal.

Marden's recent work, especially over the past seven or eight years, is the end of the line for Mondrian - the Mondrian terminus, the closing of a loop. Mondrian, of course, began as a kind of art nouveau artist, and his work was filled with arcs and curves. It ended in straight lines, going up and down, left and right. Marden reintroduced the curve, the bulge, the hook and the arc, re-animating Mondrian's ghost.

Yet of all ghosts - of history, of earlier painters and paintings - the strongest presence here is de Kooning, whose last works were driven entirely by instinct for painting, when even his sense of personality and self was dissembled by Alzheimer's disease.

Marden does nothing if not pay homage to very late de Kooning, whose last coherent works were a kind of memory of the body and its boundaries - the artist's own, the bodies he admired and desired - all distilled into pure gesture and aching colour.

If de Kooning's last works are for us about his own disappearance, a last behavioural trace, Marden's sense of the body is fully conscious of itself. It knows where it has been, it knows where it is going.

The fixatedness of his line, inscribing and reinscribing itself on the bounded plane of the canvas, recording its passage, is fully aware and self-conscious. These are, I think, paintings about that sense of self-awareness, and the complications it entails. Looking at them, you become acutely aware of your own act of looking, of standing still in front of something that is both an abstraction, and utterly concrete. These are beautiful conundrums.

webTitle: Ban on Yahoo! Nazi site

fields.headline: Ban on Yahoo! Nazi site
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: In a decision that could have repercussions for internet users around the world, a Paris judge yesterday ordered the US web giant Yahoo! to bar French surfers from a US site selling Nazi memorabilia.
fields.body:
In a decision that could have repercussions for internet users around the world, a Paris judge yesterday ordered the US web giant Yahoo! to bar French surfers from a US site selling Nazi memorabilia.

Jean-Jacques Gomez confirmed an earlier ruling that Yahoo!'s US auction pages - which invite bids for Nazi paraphernalia such as SS daggers and swastikas - are "an apology for Nazism, a contestation of Nazi crimes, and an offence to France's collective memory".

Acting after complaints from Jewish and anti-racist groups in France, Judge Gomez said Yahoo! must abide by French laws prohibiting the advertisement, exhibition or sale of any objects likely to incite racial hatred.

He gave Yahoo! three months to implement the ruling or face fines of up to £1,000 a day. Although its French-language portal, Yahoo.fr, does not offer such material for auction, French web surfers can access the offensive memorabilia in English.

Yahoo! has argued that Yahoo.com is governed by US legislation and that auctions of Nazi memorabilia are legal under the US constitutional right to freedom of speech. It said it was technically impossible to identify all French users and block their access to the sites.

This month, however, experts concluded that it would be possible to block up to 70% of French web surfers from the offending pages by using a filter to identify the address of their internet service provider or ISP.

A further 20% could be blocked by checking the keywords used in their searches and through a voluntary declaration of nationality surfers would be asked to complete before entering the site.

Yahoo! said it was studying ways to appeal against the verdict. Christophe Pecnard, a lawyer for Yahoo!, said: "We hope that other countries won't take the same route."

webTitle: 100,000 troops committed to EU force

fields.headline: 100,000 troops committed to EU force
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Britain threw its full weight behind the European Union's new defence effort yesterday, pledging 12,500 men for a rapid reaction force in the face of what ministers dismissed as "hysterical" Tory warnings that the country's over-stretched armed forces were being drawn into an anti-Nato morass.
fields.byline: Ian Black in Brussels and Michael White
fields.body:
Britain threw its full weight behind the European Union's new defence effort yesterday, pledging 12,500 men for a rapid reaction force in the face of what ministers dismissed as "hysterical" Tory warnings that the country's over-stretched armed forces were being drawn into an anti-Nato morass.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, made the long-trailed announcement at an EU meeting in Brussels, where the 15 member states offered a total of 100,000 troops, 400 aircraft and 100 ships for crisis management operations.

They will be used for peacekeeping and humanitarian purposes, not for more war-like "peacemaking" operations, and no British troops will be sent anywhere without the explicit consent of the government of the day, Downing St stressed as the Tories and their media allies condemned "a political gesture".'

The presence of Lords David Owen and Denis Healey, as well as such retired senior officers as General Sir Anthony Farrar-Hockley, among the critics of the force added weight.

But the EU's lack of key military assets - troop-carrying aircraft, satellites for intelligence, and logistical support - effectively made the case that the new force's use will be limited.

On a day seen as an historic milestone in giving the EU military muscle to match its economic weight, the council of ministers' building bristled with officers dripping gold braid and medals among the standard diplomats' suits.

But Mr Hoon was distracted by a familiar UK battleground. He insisted that there was no question of creating a standing force, or anything else resembling the European army that the Tories claim is evidence of the government's "stealthy march to a superstate".

Underlining the British point, the conference declaration said there would be no "unnecessary duplication" of Nato functions or assets. It stated explicitly: "This does not involve the establishment of a European army."

Lord George Robertson, the Nato secretary-general, joined the chorus of voices saying the RRF would strengthen Nato, not undermine it - and stressing that, whoever wins the White House, the US wants Europe to build up its military capacity after its weakness was exposed in former Yugoslavia.

But illustrating the familiar difficulty that the EU means different things to different people, the German foreign minister, Joshka Fischer, said: "This is part of the European integration process."

Few EU leaders, including Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, agree with him.

Mr Hoon said: "It is extremely disappointing that what is a sensible commonsense way of planning a European commitment should become the subject of rather hysterical comment from Eurosceptic elements of the Conservative party."

He insisted that there had been no discussion of controversial issues such as EU badges or uniforms.

Yesterday's contributions, still not formally announced, range from 13,500 troops from Germany to just 100 from tiny Luxembourg, according to previously leaked figures.

Ministers were given three secret annexes with details of current assets, assets needed, and the shortfall between the two.

A sensitive issue is the creation of a review mechanism to ensure that the gap is closed.

The pledges confirm that the EU should be able to meet its 2003 goal of being able to field a force of up to 60,000 within 60 days and to maintain it for one year.

Javier Solana, the EU's defence and foreign policy chief, said the union needed to keep up the pace, notably by a deal with Nato on future cooperation.

The force will be used for crisis tasks ranging from the evacuation of EU nationals, say from an African civil war, to Bosnian-style peace enforcement requiring heavily armed combat troops and the equipment to match.

Highly mobile ground forces are seen as essential at a time when most of Europe's 2m soldiers - too many of them unsuitable conscripts - are still trained and equipped for cold war static defence. They lack state of the art equipment.

Field Marshal Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of Britain's defence staff, said: "With two million men and women under arms in Europe today, 60,000 doesn't seem so many."

No new forces are being created to meet the goal and many of the troops pledged are also already committed to Nato.

Any decision to deploy troops must be unanimous, and in a major operation the commander of the RRF will be the European who always holds the Nato post of deputy supreme allied commander, Europe: currently the Briton General Rupert Smith.

The force commander will be the German General Rainer Schuwirth.

The opposition leader, William Hague, has suggested repeatedly that troops from the 15 member states will fight under EU insignia, saying: "If it looks like an elephant and sounds like an elephant, then it is an elephant."

webTitle: Arnault joins Suez in 3G bid

fields.headline: Arnault joins Suez in 3G bid
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: One of France's top businessmen, Bernard Arnault, is teaming up with Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux to develop their interests in broadband interactive services.
fields.body:
One of France's top businessmen, Bernard Arnault, is teaming up with Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux to develop their interests in broadband interactive services.

In a two-part deal Suez is paying €300m for a 30% stake in a company which includes the bulk of Mr Arnault's internet investment company, Europatweb, while Mr Arnault's Groupe Arnault will join Suez and the Spanish telecoms group Telefonica in their bid for a third generation mobile telephone licence in France.

Groupe Arnault will take a 10% stake in the Suez company which owns 60% of the consortium bidding for the French licence. The partners expect to recruit other companies for the 3G consortium "notably international companies".

Unlike Britain and Germany, France will allocate its UMTS licences on the basis of a "beauty contest" rather than simply on the amount of money a bidder is prepared to pay and the link with Europatweb is seen as giving the Suez consortium internet content and services to add to its telecoms operations.

"Today's alliance considerably boosts our position on the net and our chances of obtaining a UMTS licence ... in a beauty contest whose criteria include quality and variety of content," according to Suez chairman Gerard Mestrallet.

Although the deal involves 46 of Europatweb's investments some analysts expressed concern that four - internet service provider LibertySurf, luxury goods website eLuxury, online bank Zebank and Akka Technologies - were not included.

However Suez and Europatweb said yesterday that LibertySurf and Zebank were expected to sign marketing agreements with Suez.

On the Paris stock market shares in Suez slipped 2% in a falling market, though analysts said the stock remains supported by hopes that the company will float its telecoms arm if it wins a 3G licence.

webTitle: Dot.coms battle to buck the downhill trend

fields.headline: Dot.coms battle to buck the downhill trend
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Cyberspace is proving tricky to navigate for the young entrepreneurs who dreamed of making millions from the internet.
fields.body:
Cyberspace is proving tricky to navigate for the young entrepreneurs who dreamed of making millions from the internet.

Yesterday saw another high-profile US dot.com, SkyAuction, pull its flotation, and in Silicon Valley workers have taken to dubbing the worst performing stocks on Nasdaq as members of the 90% club - a reference to how much the companies have lost compared with their value at the peak of the internet boom.

In Britain the picture is just as bleak. One of Unilever's forays into the web recently ended when Wowgo, a site aimed at teenage girls, folded and the financial news site TheStreet closed its Clerkenwell offices on Friday. Shopping advice site Ready2shop is also scaling back its ambitions.

Webmergers, a US-based investment site, said at least 130 internet companies have shut down worldwide since the beginning of this year. Nearly 100 of those companies focused primarily on a consumer rather than a business audience. The rate of closure has accelerated in November, according to Webmergers.com.

Few of Britain's more high-profile launches have survived. Boo.com, which lost an estimated £80m in about seven months, and Clickmango, fronted by Joanna Lumley, both failed in their original forms.

This gloomy picture has not discouraged everyone, however. It has just emerged that Henry Lane Fox has left Lastminute.com, the much hyped etailer co-founded by his sister Martha, to set up his own business to business dot.com company.

Lastminute, valued at £731m at its peak is now worth £140m.

A company spokesperson refused to give details about Mr Lane Fox's new venture, apart from saying it is a business-to-business company that is not in the same area as Lastminute. Mr Lane Fox, a 25-year-old Oxford graduate, has been with the company for two-and-a-half years and worked in the product strategy department.

By setting up a dot.com in the current market conditions Mr Lane Fox is bucking the negative trend that sees at least one dot.com go under every day.

Wowgo, which provided fashion, health and beauty tips for teenage girls, closed just over a week ago. The company was backed by Unilever and Durlacher. A Unilever spokesperson gave no explanation for its closure.

The market conditions have also forced Xyratex, a network infrastructure systems company, to postpone its Neuer Markt listing because of weak capital markets conditions. The company had planned to list next month.

"From our point of view, the current capital market environment is not ideal for a qualitatively high valued placement," Ken Wilkie, Xyratex's chief executive said.

Burst.com, a site specialising in the delivery of online video and audio, yesterday said it was cutting 80% of its staff to help reduce its monthly expenditure to $500,000 (£360,000)..

Trinny Woodall and Susan nah Constantine, who set up the company to provide women with shopping advice, yesterday confirmed they were looking for a strategic partner.

webTitle: Climate: US stung by critics

fields.headline: US concession fails to please experts
fields.standfirst:
America stung by criticisms
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: There were few visible signs of progress at the climate talks yesterday, although the US made late concessions on the most contentious issue - its insistence that it can compensate for its own carbon emissions by removing carbon from the atmosphere by planting forests.
fields.body:
There were few visible signs of progress at the climate talks yesterday, although the US made late concessions on the most contentious issue - its insistence that it can compensate for its own carbon emissions by removing carbon from the atmosphere by planting forests.

Its chief negotiator, Frank Loy, said that rather than insisting on all the carbon captured in forests being counted, it would ask for only 20% plus one third of whatever more than that could be scientifically verified.

The EU welcomed the concession, and Michael Meacher, the British environment minister, said: "It is a good sign; we will study the details carefully."

Mr Loy and his 150 delegates have clearly been stung by the international media's repeated portrayal of the Americans as unwilling to make domestic cuts in carbon dioxide emissions. It has accused them of using "loopholes" in the agreement to plant forests at home and abroad to absorb carbon instead of cutting fossil fuel burning at home.

Mr Loy, the undersecretary of state for global affairs, said: "In recognition of concerns expressed by some countries we are willing to reduce the scale of credit we think we should be entitled to. We were talking about real cuts and real carbon tonnes but if it means coming closer to agreement we are prepared, we will ask for less than intended."

He went on to stress President Clinton's close personal interest in reaching a deal.

"The president raises the issue of climate change with every head of state he meets. He is extremely concerned and fully understands the issues. He has instructed us to do our best to get an agreement."

Earlier John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, had predicted it would be tomorrow night before the 37 points points of major disagreement between the parties were whittled down to a manageable number. "All sides are still involved in long distance shelling," he added.

In a speech to the conference Jacques Chirac, the French president, demanded action from Mr Clinton, saying that the average American created three times as much greenhouse gas as the average French resident.

"Europe is resolved to act and has mobilised to fight the greenhouse effect. Europe calls upon the other industrialised countries to join with us in this fight. The time has come for action," he said.

The US position was undermined by Robert Watson, the chairman of the 3,000 scientists who make up the UN intergovernmental panel on climate change.

"The US claim for credits for planting and managing forests is based on policies in place well before 1990, the period from which the calculations on saving carbon are supposed to be made.

"On that basis it is fair to say that the US will be doing nothing extra than was being done in the ordinary course of events. There will be some savings, obviously, but it would have happened without the climate treaty. If they do get credit for that it will be a political decision."

John Lanchbery, the climate officer for the RSPB, said: "The new US proposals are out of Alice in Wonderland. Their original claim was prepos terous, they are merely asking for less of something that was not real in the first place."

Yesterday climate change was on the agenda when Tony Blair flew to Moscow to meet President Vladimir Putin.

Russia has "saved" millions of tonnes of carbon since 1990 because of the collapse of its economy.

Under the terms of the treaty being negotiated in the Hague, Moscow may be able to add up the savings and sell them to the US and other countries for cash.

Mr Blair reportedly wants to ensure that this money does not simply disappear, but is earmarked for a "green" fund to be used for energy efficiency measures and building cleaner power stations.

webTitle: Sweetener for motorists to go green

fields.headline: Sweetener for motorists to go green
fields.standfirst:
Climate Clean fuel subsidies
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of motorists will be able to claim a government subsidy to convert their cars to cheap gas power or buy new electric ones under a scheme announced yesterday by John Prescott, the deputy prime minister.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of motorists will be able to claim a government subsidy to convert their cars to cheap gas power or buy new electric ones under a scheme announced yesterday by John Prescott, the deputy prime minister.

The environment secretary, famously derided as "two jags" Prescott, is to make £30m available over the next three years to put 35,000 converted or new cars on the road. He has already equipped his ministerial car to run on gas.

Grants will be provided to adapt popular models such as the Ford Mondeo and Vauxhall Astra to run on liquid petroleum gas (LPG) or compressed natural gas in addition to petrol. The two companies already sell dual petrol/gas cars. They cost between £1,500 and £2,000 more than the standard model.

Electric cars and dual electric/petrol cars will get a subsidy of up to £4,500. They perform like normal cars but can go only 50 miles before they need recharging.

It is 40p a litre cheaper to run a car on gas rather than petrol, which means that conversion makes sense for large mileage motorists, but the government hopes that a subsidy will make the switch popular with a wider market. There are already 500 gas outlets in Britain, making the fuel reasonably widely available.

Mr Prescott said: "This confirms the commitment in our 10-year transport plan to accelerate the take-up of cleaner fuels and more fuel efficient vehicles. We want to improve air quality and reduce the impact of vehicles on climate change.

"Motorists can play their part by choosing cleaner, more efficient vehicles."

The announcement is part of a £39m programme to make vehicles cleaner in order to help local authorities meet their air quality objectives.

One of the ideas being put forward is to close city and town centres to polluting vehicles. This would mean owners of gas or electric powered vehicles would be the only ones permitted to drive into towns where air quality limits were exceeded.

More than 120 local authorities in the EU and half the capitals of Europe have already joined the Alter project (Alternative Traffic in Towns) and are pledged to convert municipal vehicles to clean fuels.

Thirty British cities are involved, including Birmingham, Bradford, Cardiff, Edinburgh, Leeds, Leicester, Liverpool, Manchester, Newcastle, Nottingham and Oxford.

The market for alternative vehicle fuels is rapidly expanding in Britain, thanks largely to the low rate of duty of clean road fuels. The government has already offered a limited number of grants for conversion, and this extra money is expected to vastly increase the number.

To qualify for conversion vehicles must be new or less than one year old and have done less than 25,000 miles. The applicant must get an estimate of how much it will cost to convert, apply for a grant, and identify an outlet where the vehicle will be fuelled.

In the case of an electric vehicle, that can be the normal home supply.

The grant will be between 40% and 75% of the cost of conversion, depending on the advantage to the environment of switching fuels.

Drive for air quality

Conversions

From diesel or petrol engines to those that run on petrol and liquid petroleum gas (LPG) or compressed natural gas. Vehicles need second tank in boot for gas

Ford Mondeo (above) Con-version £2,000 - grant 40%

Vauxhall Astra Conversion cost £1,500 - grant 60%

New cars

Toyota Prius / Honda Insight (above) Duel electric/petrol car. Switches from electric to petrol15 when driving at over 15mph. Total cost £16,000. Government offering £1,000 cashback

Peugeot 106 Electric Government will pay 75% of difference between electric and petrol version - around £4,500 off list price of £15,000

webTitle: I was framed, says people's poet

fields.headline: I was framed, says people's poet
fields.standfirst: Convicted robber Mzwakhe Mbuli claims he is the victim of a South African police conspiracy
fields.trailText: On the face of it the evidence against Mzwakhe Mbuli - the radical poet who performed at Nelson Mandela's inauguration as South Africa's first black president - was overwhelming.
fields.body:
On the face of it the evidence against Mzwakhe Mbuli - the radical poet who performed at Nelson Mandela's inauguration as South Africa's first black president - was overwhelming.

When the police stopped his car just 200 metres from - and minutes after - a bank robbery in Pretoria three years ago, they found the stolen cash and weapons inside.

His bizarre explanation why he was sitting with the proceeds of an armed robbery on his lap did not do his case much good. He claimed that a complete stranger had lobbed the bag, stuffed with money, a gun and a grenade, through the open car window and run off.

The judge did not believe a word of it at the trial last year and jailed Mbuli for 13 years, along with two accomplices. An appeal court agreed that his description of events was "highly improbable".

But Mbuli, known as the "people's poet", has found an unusual champion for his claim that he is the victim of a high-level conspiracy to prevent him revealing the names of top government officials involved in drug trafficking.

Helen Suzman is an old hand at taking on the establishment. She sat in the whites-only parliament for 13 years as the only voice against apartheid. Now the grand dame of white liberalism is championing the cause of the angry black poet in Pretoria central prison, believing he is a victim of the injustice of the new South Africa.

"There is a conspiracy which the police are in on. I think the police are capable of anything. I've seen what they can do in the past and they're no better now," she said.

Mrs Suzman, 83, was hauled on to the case through her niece, the actress Janet Suzman, who had been approached by Mbuli's agent in London. At first Mrs Suzman was sceptical of the poet's protestations of innocence but she agreed to use her influence to look at the case.

"I wasn't convinced at all of his story. I didn't know the man from a bar of soap, but I got to know him well. I was impressed with the man, with his good character," she said.

There were two aspects that particularly troubled Mrs Suzman. Mbuli is not poor. He has a large following and eight albums to his name, built on his fame as a rabble-rousing poet at the burials of anti-apartheid activists.

Some praised his work as liberation poetry, others dismissed it as Marxist agitprop.

Either way, by the time of the robbery he could command more for a single performance than the 15,000 rand (£1,400) stolen from the bank. In addition, he is famous enough in South Africa for plenty of people to recognise him if he robbed a bank without shielding his identity.

"It seemed to me quite incredible that a man who was making a good living should walk into a bank with a hand grenade but no disguise, which is important because he is a very striking man and his face is very well known," Mrs Suzman said.

"He performed at former president Mandela's inauguration. He is very well known. It doesn't make sense.".

Only two of the six witnesses could pick out Mbuli in an identity parade, and the process was so irregular that one of them had to be discounted.

Mbuli claims that he was framed after threatening to reveal the names of prominent South African politicians involved in drug smuggling, given to him by a Swazi police officer. Mrs Suzman says there were two attempts to murder him.

"Then he was phoned by a guy who said he had information about who was responsible for the assassination attempts," she said.

"He said to meet at a certain time in Pretoria. They were waiting when a chap threw a canvas bag into the car, said 'the evidence is in the bag' and ran off.

"They turned the car around and the police stopped them. When they searched the car they found the hand grenade, the money and a pistol."

The police say they stopped Mbuli's car because it had tinted windows and they thought it suspicious. If true, it is a remarkable stroke of luck for them that the only vehicle stopped at the time happened to be the one used in the robbery.

Sceptics have challenged Mbuli to reveal the names of those he alleges are drug traffickers. Mrs Suzman believes he should. "We have to clear this up," she said.

Mbuli has another appeal pending. He is putting a lot of his faith in the woman who has become his most frequent visitor.

"I had always looked at Helen Suzman as a white woman. But here she is, like my mother twice over," he said.

"I would never have believed that this woman would be an enormous source of strength to me.

"She sits, talks to me, touches me, holds my hand."

webTitle: Kenyan leaders to block 'divisive' equal rights bill

fields.headline: Kenyan leaders to block 'divisive' equal rights bill
fields.trailText: Protests by Muslim women against two forthcoming civil rights bills have prompted President Daniel arap Moi to declare that Kenya has no need of such legislation.
fields.body:
Protests by Muslim women against two forthcoming civil rights bills have prompted President Daniel arap Moi to declare that Kenya has no need of such legislation.

The women say that the equal rights and affirmative action bills, due to be published next week, are a direct challenge to Islamic law on the place of women in society.

President Moi said: "What is this affirmative action women are talking about? I want unity because I stand for the unity of all Kenyans. If affirmative action divides women, I'm not for it."

Although neither bill deals exclusively with women's rights, together they have been interpreted as a sign of the burgeoning of Kenyan feminism.

The affirmative action bill promises to guarantee women and minority groups, including disabled people, a minimum of 33% of representation in parliament and on local authorities. Currently, only nine of Kenya's 250 MPs are women.

The equal rights bill is intended to convert several international human rights charters already signed by Kenya into law, guaranteeing the rights of minority groups to, for example, basic medical care and equitable inheritance.

"It is totally misleading to think of the rights bill as a women's bill," said Martha Coombe, chairwoman of the association of women lawyers which drafted the bills.

"It is the usual thing - men think we want to overthrow them. But this bill talks about giving equal treatment to all Kenyans."

Muslim groups object particularly to the plan for equal inheritance rights. The proposal runs contrary to Islam's patriarchal sharia law, which decrees that sons receive twice as much as daughters.

"Whether this is just or not, it is divine law so we have no choice," said Abeda Ali, head of the Muslim Sisters Network.

"The constitution acknowledges our right to sharia law, so unless Muslims are made exempt from this provision it will be discriminating against Muslims," she said.

Ms Coombe argues that the vast majority of Kenyan women need their inheritance rights protecting. She days that Muslims are free to follow sharia law regardless.

Muslims, who make up 20% of Kenya's population, also say that a proposed ban on discrimination based on sexual preference would encourage homosexuality, which is outlawed in Islam.

"We do not want a bill through which homosexuality and lesbianism will be introduced. This bill is foreign," said Said Asman, of the Supreme Council of Kenyan Muslims.

With the ruling Kanu party and the National Development party vowing to block votes against the bills, they seem certain to fail.

But Ms Coombe is undeterred. "They may use their clout against the equality bill but we will shame them into changing their minds," she said.

She claimed that the Muslim women's protests had been orchestrated by high-ranking politicians as a smoke screen for their own agenda. Equal rights would mean an end to tribal patronage, to which most Kenyans owed their jobs, she said.

"The women did not even know why they were demonstrating," she said.

"The real reason the government doesn't want this bill is that they fear an audit being taken of who is where, and how they got there. It would reveal a system based on ethnicity."

Jam Karanja, of the United Disabled Persons of Kenya, is also sceptical about the protests.

"The bill intends to outlaw all forms of discrimination. It therefore comes as a surprise to us that Muslim women want to reject it before they have had a chance to examine it fully," he said.

Muslims, who make up 20% of Kenya's population, also say that a proposed ban on discrimination based on sexual preference would encourage homosexuality, which is outlawed in Islam. "We do not want a bill through which homosexuality and lesbianism will be introduced. This bill is foreign," said Said Asman, of the Supreme Council of Kenyan Muslims. With the ruling Kanu party and the National Development party vowing to block votes against the bills, they seem certain to fail. But Ms Coombe is undeterred. "They may use their clout against the equality bill but we will shame them into changing their minds," she said. She claimed that the Muslim women's protests had been orchestrated by high-ranking politicians as a smoke screen for their own agenda. Equal rights would mean an end to tribal patronage, to which most Kenyans owed their jobs, she said. "The women did not even know why they were demonstrating," she said. "The real reason the government doesn't want this bill is that they fear an audit being taken of who is where, and how they got there. It would reveal a system based on ethnicity." Jam Karanja, of the United Disabled Persons of Kenya, is also sceptical about the protests. "The bill intends to outlaw all forms of discrimination. It therefore comes as a surprise to us that Muslim women want to reject it before they have had a chance to examine it fully," he said.

webTitle: Democrats could gain from a weak Bush presidency

fields.headline: Democrats could gain from a weak Bush presidency
fields.standfirst:
The more the wrangling goes on, the less attractive is the White House
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The American presidency is a very big deal. In electoral politics there's no bigger deal in the world.
fields.body:
The American presidency is a very big deal. In electoral politics there's no bigger deal in the world. The drives towards it of Al Gore and George W Bush have been different. For Gore the presidency is something he has been seeking with fixated energy for at least 20 years, through an apprenticeship in Congress and then eight years as vice-president. For Bush the urge has not been there so long. He discovered a political career only in mid-life, and still appears to be the vessel for other people's ambition as much as his own. But for both, the battle to establish which of them got the highest number of honest votes in Florida now puts their very lives as public men on the line.

The scale of what's at stake also impresses the American people. There is little apparent resentment at what is going on. The emblematic image of election 2000 will always be that of three exhausted ordinary citizens in Palm Beach county, peering at a voting card back and front, up and down, as if reading the runes in search of a message they know no other way to divine. Such is the American respect for process that the prospect of this being done 6m times, a hand count of the complete Florida vote, is not appalling. Normal life carries on. Stable countries survive chronic political uncertainty, their economies booming, for a long time. Look at Italy.

On the other hand, this can't go on for ever. Short of the supreme court justices counting those 6m votes themselves, there will always be complaints of bias, negligence or fraud. Any outcome will be imperfect. But there has to be finality somewhere, a point that puts Al Gore to the hardest question. He is, after all, the demandeur . On the counts so far, he has always been behind. At some point he runs the risk of being seen as the pedantic and vexatious litigant who is determined to place on Florida the entire weight of electoral imperfections that could surely be turned up in every other state by anyone motivated to try hard enough to do so.

Politically, moreover, he faces the beginnings of a split with his party. His personal interest is totally in the battle. If he doesn't win this one, after squandering huge advantages, he will not be seen again. But for the Democratic party, the gains from a president elected by nit-picking, chad-challenging legal manoeuvres are reaching expiry point. Democrats now see some advantage in the installation of Bush as the weakest president for more than a century.

For one thing, he would be able to do very little. The signal that America was turning its back on Clintonism has already been effaced by these weeks of incorrigible ambiguity - a point, incidentally, that removes from William Hague any chance of a Bush presidency announcing a global resurrection of the right. Bush can make it to the White House only as damaged goods. He will have neither the votes nor the mandate of a plurality, which every other president since 1876 has had.

This weakness will be made worse not better by the Republicans' control of Congress. On the face of it, a weak Republican president and a razor-thin majority for his party on the Hill should shore each other up and deliver a programme. In practice this will not happen. Moderation, to the point of impasse, will transfer from a split electorate to a hung Congress. The Republicans' hold on both the political organs of the state will deprive the party of any alibis, as it grapples with an economic downturn and fails to enact the domestic agenda, especially the tax cuts Bush promised in the campaign. He will have responsibility without power, the prerogative of the loser throughout the ages.

So, as well as Bush's manifest personal inadequacies, gridlock beckons. The same fate would befall Gore. But it was Bush who promised the end of those terrible Washington games, and vowed to coax into being an era when politics turned clean and effective. He will get an early opportunity to feel his words being stuffed down his throat, and will find whatever healing powers he has obliterated by the clear awareness that, in these fateful circumstances, the country is likely to repay an impotent Dubya by punishing his party at the 2002 Congressional elections, with the 2004 presidency to follow. The Democrats, in short, will not play ball.

Such is a logical Democrat calculation. Very soon it may prove to be a convenient rationalising of the inevitable. If the Florida supreme court's response to yesterday's titanic legal encounter is to invalidate any hand recounting, then Bush should be home, unless the Gore people's righteousness drives them to yet more legal challenges, or possibly to make the case for interfering with the normal protocols of the electoral college. But equally, if the court decides not to move decisively in that direction, Gore should still be thinking hard about whether victory is worth having, out of a court process that will attract enough challenges to delegitimise its outcome in the eyes of many people, whatever recount is done.

I f the point now at issue were the several thousand votes clearly handed in error to Pat Buchanan, it might be a different story. But that is no longer the frontline battle. Instead we have those puzzled scrutinies of chad holes by good but partisan people who have been told they can do a better job than machines. The moral of this extraordinary story is plainly that there needs to be an American version of electoral reform, starting with mass re-tendering for the supply of efficient voting machines: less obviously that Al Gore will have made an unanswerable case for having overtaken George W Bush as the heir to presidential legitimacy.

A Bush presidency, though neutered by this history, would be an unattractive prospect. As argued here before, it would be especially alarming to America's allies and counterparts in global geopolitics. There are enough foolish Washington strategists hooked on a national missile defence system to encourage the president to take forward this guarantor of instability. There will be some repellent constituencies, pro-gun and anti-environment, to satisfy. The Republicans would have all the patronage, starting with maybe a quarter of the supreme court. To Democrats generally this would mark a transition as bitter as it would be terminal to Gore himself.

But little of enduring substance could happen before 2002. The presidency will lack potency as well as grandeur, which means most of its moral authority. That's true of either man for sure, and it's something the rest of the world will have as many reasons to regret as to applaud. Meanwhile, the virtues of a domestic impasse ought to be becoming clearer to the Democrats, to balance against the polluted victory that would be the best their man could claim.

Gore didn't win the election in the way he had every chance of doing. He could take with him into oblivion the moral victory of the popular vote. But there comes a time when victory by lawyers, with lawyers, for barely half the people, is not worth having - and that time is probably going to be this week.

webTitle: Notebook: Why Brown should not risk a smile yet

fields.headline: Why Brown should not risk a smile just yet
fields.standfirst: Bank could upset election plans
fields.trailText: On the face of it Gordon Brown should have every reason to be cheerful. Despite the distraction of rows over who should be saying what about Europe, the chancellor can draw quiet satisfaction from the state of the public finances. Rather more to the point, his stewardship of the public purse means that Labour party strategists seeking vote winning policies for an election, which could well be held next spring, will not be constrained by lack of cash to pay for them.
fields.body:
On the face of it Gordon Brown should have every reason to be cheerful. Despite the distraction of rows over who should be saying what about Europe, the chancellor can draw quiet satisfaction from the state of the public finances. Rather more to the point, his stewardship of the public purse means that Labour party strategists seeking vote winning policies for an election, which could well be held next spring, will not be constrained by lack of cash to pay for them.

Not unnaturally the Brown camp is trying to play down expectations about just how much the chancellor will have to give away. Mr Brown is naturally a prudent chap. For him a pound in the hand will always be worth two in the bush.

Extrapolations of the state of the public finances based on the figures so far may be over-egging the pudding. Even if they are not Mr Brown will not want his budget thunder pre-empted, if not stolen, by private sector analysts who have second guessed or even exaggerated the extent of his generosity well ahead of time.

There are other reasons for caution, too. Bumper tax receipts are not the only contributor to the healthy state of the public finances. A secondary element is that the government is not meeting its existing spending targets. Hardly good news for an administration keen to burnish its public services credentials.

Then there is the private sector. Borrowing remains buoyant. Figures from the council of mortgage lenders suggest home-owners are cashing in some of their equity, with remortgaging last month up 38% on October 1999. Some of that will find its way into spending.

With the government trying to spend more and the consumer - egged on by actual and expected tax cuts - determined to do so, it is a moot point as to whether the economy will be able to take the strain of continued above trend growth. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development for one is warning that UK rates may have to rise. If the Bank of England's monetary policy committee was to share its concerns - as well it might if Mr Brown proves overly generous - the chancellor could find himself locking horns with his own creation in the run-up to the election. But then that is the point of an independent Bank of England.

Motivator

Performance-related pay is a staple of the City crib sheet on how to explain salaries that might otherwise raise eyebrows outside the rarified world of high finance. Fair enough. Pay that motivates strong performance is to be encouraged across any industry.

But sometimes it can be hard to see the link. Take the $650m it is costing Old Mutual to retain two fund managers, little known outside the United States. The South African company, which is listed in London and which has built itself a stock broking and asset management business through a variety of acquisitions, was at pains yesterday to insist the hefty bill was an appropriate reward to Harold Baxter and Gary Pilgrim for their efforts in building their Pilgrim Baxter & Associates business over the past decade.

Buying out their past performance was, perhaps inevitably, going to be expensive. Keeping the pair - who have been used to earning some $60m a year for a tidy spell - motivated will now be crucial. This is why Old Mutual is staggering part of the payments over a six year period and creating a new phantom share scheme to keep the two men interested for a total of eight years.

Will it work? Old Mutual's shareholders know how much their company has paid. In return they must expect truly sensational performance. Anything less should have them reviewing their board's pay and performance.

Limited access

For many the auction of third generation mobile phone licences in Britain became a model of how to get the best deal for taxpayers.

For others its success in raising cash for the public purse prompted concerns that the successful bidders would have trouble getting a return or, if they did so, would only be able to do so by asking consumers to pay through the nose.

The auction of broadband fixed wireless access, however, has turned into the reverse of the 3G licence process. Instead of the £1bn expected it has raised a meagre £38m with only 16 of the 42 licences on offer being snapped up. This time round the government's problem is not what to do with the money but how to get rid of the licences no one appears to want.

It will need to come up with an answer. The licences awarded were for centres with large populations. Other, less populous, regions need the access to high speed web technologies offered by broadband fixed wireless access, too.

webTitle: Floods and fuel costs hurt Hanson

fields.headline: Floods and fuel costs hurt Hanson
fields.trailText: Hanson, the building materials group, yesterday issued a profits warning on the back of rising fuel costs, heavy rain and softer demand in the US.
fields.body:
Hanson, the building materials group, yesterday issued a profits warning on the back of rising fuel costs, heavy rain and softer demand in the US.

The price of oil will add £40m to Hanson costs this year, the company said, and help push pre-tax profits before exceptionals below the 1999 figure of £314.3m.

Shares fell 10% in early trading and finished the day down 34.75p at 336.25p. Analysts predicted rivals in the building materials sector could make similar warnings in future.

A spokesman for Hanson said the group would start a new round of savings in a bid to deal with the downturn but he declined to give details.

The most significant impact has been the rising cost of fuel, which has affected Hanson's haulage, marine dredgers and mobile plant.

Weaker aggregate demand in the south of England and Wales has been exacerbated by the recent heavy rains which all but halted activity at some construction sites.

Mark Hake, a building analyst with Merrill Lynch, said he had cut his current year profit forecast for Hanson from £326m to £293m.

webTitle: Business: Germans hit out at UK over post

fields.headline: Germans hit out at UK over post
fields.standfirst: Liberalisation of letter services 'too slow'
fields.trailText: German finance minister Hans Eichel yesterday delivered a warning to Britain and France over the pace of liberalisation of postal services.
fields.body:
German finance minister Hans Eichel yesterday delivered a warning to Britain and France over the pace of liberalisation of postal services. He said he was opposed to state-owned postal monopolies seeking to move into Germany at a time when their domestic markets remained "safe havens".

Speaking at a conference marking the stock market debut of Deutsche Post, Mr Eichel said: "The internal European Union market has only potential when it is fully liberalised. We must all move at the same pace and I say that looking at France and the UK."

The issue is a crucial one for Deutsche Post, which under German law is scheduled to lose its letter monopoly at the end of 2002. It could see the deadline extended if the German government is unhappy about progress towards opening up postal markets being made elsewhere. It would, however, require new legislation for that to happen.

The EU is proposing to reduce national letters monopolies from the current limit of 350 grams to 50 grams in 2003 with further changes in 2007. France is opposed to the move while Britain is pressing for the limit to be cut only to 150 grams.

Trading in Deutsche Post stock got off to a brisk start with turnover topping $1bn (£715m), though the price managed only a modest improvement on the €21 (£13) at which the shares were offered to investors, closing at €21.50 - above the low for the day of €20.93.

Retail investors were among early sellers but the price was underpinned by institutional demand driven in part by expectations that Deutsche Post will take its place in Frankfurt's main stock market index, which makes it an essential stock for index tracking funds.

The €6.6bn issue is the largest stock market issue this year and the company's management said they were pleased with the outcome of the offer.

"We are satisfied with the opening price, but especially that the issue was eight times oversubscribed," said chief executive Klaus Zumwinkel. Retail demand was especially strong in Germany on the back of a $44m advertising campaign, even though earlier stock market offerings from Deutsche Telekom and T-Online subsequently slipped below the offer price.

"It is a slow start but it is a positive one. It is not a bad sign," said one Frankfurt-based equity strategist.

Analysts, however, have some reservations about the outlook for Deutsche Post, which has sought to diversify into global logistics and e-commerce but remains heavily dependent on its postal and banking business.

"Electronic commerce and logistics still make up too little of the business," according to Pia-Christina Schulze, an analyst at Merck Finck.

To celebrate the market launch, Deutsche Post brought a herd of plastic bulls to Frankfurt painted in the company's trade mark yellow.
