webTitle: Business: Equant boost for France Telecom

fields.headline: Equant boost for France Telecom
fields.trailText: France Telecom yesterday sought to bolster its international ambitions with a complex multi-billion euros cash, shares and assets transaction that will give it a controlling stake in network service provider Equant.
fields.body:
France Telecom yesterday sought to bolster its international ambitions with a complex multi-billion euros cash, shares and assets transaction that will give it a controlling stake in network service provider Equant.

The French telecoms group is to buy out Equant's leading shareholder, the SITA Foundation, in exchange for its own shares in a deal which values the SITA stake at €3.5bn (£2bn). It will also inject the data business of its Global One subsidiary, plus $300m (£215m) in cash, into Equant in exchange for further shares which will give it a stake of 54.3%.

France Telecom has also agreed to invest $1bn in the new Equant business in exchange for preference shares. The move is seen as a big step forward for France Telecom, which includes Britain's Orange mobile phone business.

Equant claims to be the world's biggest network provider offering corporate customers services ranging from voice and data to internet and integration. The addition of the Global One operations will give it 10% of the global business data communications market. It will have some 3,700 business customers - including more than three-quarters of the world's top 100 companies.

France Telecom shares slipped 4% to €103 on the Paris bourse while Equant shares ended the day up by 1.5%.

The addition of the Global One operations will give it 10% of the global business data communications market. It will have some 3,700 business customers - including more than three-quarters of the world's top 100 companies. France Telecom shares slipped 4% to €103 on the Paris bourse while Equant shares ended the day up by 1.5%.

webTitle: Takeover take-off TBI back in play

fields.headline: Takeover take-off TBI back in play
fields.trailText: Airports operator TBI group yesterday announced it was again in takeover talks following the collapse of a previous suitor's approach.
fields.body:
Airports operator TBI group yesterday announced it was again in takeover talks following the collapse of a previous suitor's approach.

The company, which was formed in 1995 and has an interest in 33 airports, including Cardiff International, above, said it was holding "preliminary" discussions with a number of interested parties. Keith Brooks, the chief executive, also hinted he would be on the look-out for acquisitions if the number of air passengers rises as predicted.

"We are continuing discussions with other parties," he said in a statement to the stock market. "These discussions are also preliminary and may or may not lead to an offer being made for the company."

The news was greeted with scepticism in the City owing to previous takeover failures. One analyst said TBI appeared to be "permanently in play", though he admitted some of its portfolio would be highly desirable.

"I don't find this a particularly attractive business," he said. "It's got two great assets in Cardiff and Belfast airports, but its waters are muddied by minority stakes it holds elsewhere."

TBI also announceda 26% increase in half-year profits before tax, interest and depreciation to £23m. Turnover for the six months to September 30 rose to £78m from £40.2m, while the interim dividend was also up 17% at 0.70p.

webTitle: Analysis: EU's rapid reaction force

fields.headline: May the force be with you
fields.standfirst:
Call it defence or call it crisis management, the EU's rapid reaction force raises a range of financial and political questions for those involved

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Call it defence or call it crisis management, the EU's rapid reaction force raises a range of financial and political questions for those involved.
fields.body:
"We don't want to fight but, by jingo, if we do, we've got the ships, we've got the men, we've got the money, too." No, that was not the tune defence ministers whistled yesterday in Brussels at the pledging conference for the EU's rapid reaction force. Fighting is old hat: "crisis management" is much the preferred phrase. Yet the unjingoistic EU does in principle have both the ships and the men.

EU members have 2m people under arms, so a joint force would need to call on only 9% of these including full backup. With a total of 400 aircraft and 100 ships, the five aircraft and helicopter carriers needed for the new force are easily available - and even if only one-sixth of the 60-odd vessels needed for strategic sea transport have been promised, commercial charter could take care of the rest.

Money is another story, however. Conventional wisdon says 2% of GDP is the minimum commitment for the next three decades. The chart would imply that is not so painful, but its average is buoyed up by big-spending France and the UK. Getting there would involve a substantial increase for the Germans. How will defence minister Rudolf Scharping help pay for the 73 military Airbus aircraft now on order when he is pledged to cut defence spending further?

There are ticklish guns and butter questions, too. The Belgians spend over 6% of their GDP on education but only 1.5% on defence, a ratio of 4:1. In the UK the ratio is under 2:1; in Greece it is 2:3. Even with maximum pooling of military resources - which of course raises questions of command and control, not to mention sovereignty - big additional amounts will have to be spent if the EU force is to get airborne.

Kit is being built. The UK is collaborating with the French and Italians on missile defence for ships. The French and British are hand-in-glove on a new air-to-ground missile based on the French Apache system. The UK and Germany are working on a medium-range infantry weapon to pierce tank armour.

But there are lumps ahead - those "big lift" aircraft keeping Mr Scharping up at nights, new "suppression of enemy air defence" aircraft and satellites, without which you need to rely on someone else's intelligence.

Procurement is shot through with political considerations. The UK government is buying the Eurofighter but it is also involved in the early stages of the American-inspired Joint Strike Fighter which the Americans say would retail at just over half the Eurofighter's cost of $60m per plane (those are mid-90s prices, too). Down the road lies some tricky transatlantic bargaining - some think it as important as the geopolitics or the institutional architecture.

Take a small example - buying UK forces a state-of-the-art digital radio system. The bidders for a contract worth some £1.7bn include General Dynamics and TRW of the US and Thomson-CSF of France (owners of Racal). Where does the logic of Euro-procurement point?

Harmonisation of procurement has long been desired but is still far from being achieved, the Commons defence select committee said with distinct understatement. The MPs' very useful report can be read at www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm199900/cmselect/ cmdfence/264/26402.htm.

Perhaps money really is the key. In a pamphlet published last week by the Institute for Public Policy Research* Peter Truscott came close to a new version of the third way embracing big welfare and big defence. We are contemplating European rearmament; the "peace-dividend" from the end of the cold war has come and gone. Centre-left governments are learning to love soldiers. The career of Javier Solana, the ex-socialist and staunch opponent of Nato, is indicative as he moves seamlessly from Nato to head EU defence.

And there are political bonuses in expanding defence. EU members get a stake in cutting-edge technology; the Americans no longer sing all the best songs. How many Labour (or German social democrat or French socialist) parliamentarians have grown, metaphorically speaking, to love the bomb, provided its parts are made in their constituencies? Defence is regional policy writ large. Labour's policy of "defence diversification" has not really got off the ground: time to put money back into the shipyards and hangars of what remains of the industrial base.

Perhaps this is the real reason why the Tories have suddenly become so jittery about a project of which they, historically speaking, were the progenitors. The big moves in the direction of pan- European defence, after the 1950s rejection of a European Defence Community, were made by Tory prime ministers, including John Major. "It is unreasonable to expect our North American allies to be involved in every operation falling short of territorial defence. In the case of peacekeeping, humanitarian or other crisis management operations, European countries should be able to act on their own when necessary." What better statement of purpose for the reaction force? And that was written in 1996.

Condoleezza Rice, shadow national security adviser to George W Bush, is doubtless a pin-up for William Hague. But she goes about telling the Europeans they should do more. Americans are anti-big-government except when it comes to defence. They have also been remarkably consistent on European defence collaboration - it was that well known federalist Jack Kennedy who coined the phrase "European pillar".

*European Defence: Meeting the Strategic Challenge, IPPR
david.walker@theguardian.com

webTitle: Business: Sullivan looks at Spurs

fields.headline: Sullivan looks at Spurs
fields.trailText: Yesterday shares of Tottenham Hotspur rose 1p to 61.5p as dealers latched on to renewed speculation that David Sullivan might be looking to increase his stake in the club controlled by Alan Sugar.
fields.body:
It might have been the 2-1 victory over Liverpool that lifted the North London club to ninth place in the Premiership that did it.

Yesterday shares of Tottenham Hotspur rose 1p to 61.5p as dealers latched on to renewed speculation that David Sullivan might be looking to increase his stake in the club controlled by Alan Sugar.

Mr Sullivan, best know for his magazine empire, has already acquired a 1% stake in Spurs and is said to want more. But because he owns a 40% controlling stake in First Division outfit Birmingham City FC he is not allowed under Football Association rules to increase his stake in Spurs above 9.9%.

Nevertheless, dealers fully expect Mr Sullivan to dip into the market and build toward the threshold in the near future.

Recent reports have indicated that Mr Sullivan will not make an attempt to buy Spurs until he has finished his job at Birmingham.

webTitle: Business: More fuel for Hinduja rumours

fields.headline: More fuel for Hinduja rumours
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: It is a fair bet that if something comes up for sale at the moment then the Hinduja brothers will be linked with it. From the Daily Express to Air India, and more recently budget airline Go, the billionaire brothers are said to want them all.
fields.body:
It is a fair bet that if something comes up for sale at the moment then the Hinduja brothers will be linked with it. From the Daily Express to Air India, and more recently budget airline Go, the billionaire brothers are said to want them all.

However, gossips in the Square Mile reckon their first move could be a little lower down the corporate food chain. They reckon the Hindujas are in advanced negotiations to buy Britain's largest independent chain of petrol stations, Save Group . It seems they want to bring their Gulf Oil brand back to the UK and view Save, with its 400 stations, as the perfect way to do it.

James Frost, chairman of Save, effectively put the company up for sale in July after admitting it was holding talks with potential bidders. Dealers say the key to any deal will be the position of Jack Petchey, one of Britain's biggest private investors, who has built up a 24% stake in Save.

A spokesman for the Hindujas refused to comment on the Save speculation but admitted that negotiations to buy a petrol retailing business were taking place. Save shares closed unchanged at 61.5p.

But this was not the only interesting tale heard in City dealing rooms yesterday. Computer games group Eidos was a hot topic of conversation as speculation grew that a predator is stalking the group.

But first the facts. On Friday Eidos shares moved sharply higher after Dresdner Kleinwort Benson sold 1.9m shares on behalf of a leverage fund. The line of stock - equivalent to 1.8% of of the company - had been depressing Eidos's share price for quite a while. With the overhang gone the stock moved higher and market punters concluded a bid must be on the way.

Although the stock drifted 13p to 209p yesterday on profit taking, punters were not giving up. They say with current trading better than expected Eidos is looking vulnerable. "It's bombed out and has some good assets; that must make it a sitting duck," said one dealer.

The more sceptical pointed out that the whole sector was in buoyant mood yesterday. Sony's launches its Playstation2 games console on Friday, and although only 165,000 units will be available before Christmas, analysts expect game designers like Eidos, and Rage , up 0.75p to 18p, to cash in when Sony increases shipments next year.

After a morning session spent drifting in and out of positive territory, leading shares went into a sharp reverse yesterday afternoon as the Nasdaq composite fell back below 3,000 points in New York. The move came after analysts at Morgan Stanley made negative comments about the network equipment sector, including a price target downgrade for Cisco. Oracle also slumped after losing its second senior executive in five months.

By the close, the FTSE 100 had fallen 95.1 points at 6,345, with technology and telecom stocks predictably leading the way lower. Vodafone was one of the worst hit, falling 16.25p to 246.75p and wiping 44 points from the FTSE 100. Bookham Technology was also under fire, slipping 125p to £13, while Baltimore fell 23p to 407p and Marconi lost 44p to 730p. The FTSE Techmark 100 fell 86.53 to 3,060.09.

On the upside, Lloyds TSB rose 24.5p to 703p after analysts at CSFB recommended a switch out of Royal Bank of Scotland , off 22p to £14.68. Soft drink and chocolate group Cadbury Schweppes advanced 17.5p to 496.5p, lifted by Coca-Cola's offer to buy Quaker Oats.

Meanwhile, the FTSE Mid 250 slipped 49.5 points to 6,664.1 on disappointing earnings news. Building materials group Hanson fell 37p to 334p after it said full profits would come in below last years, while poor figures undermined gearbox maker Torotrak , down 27.5p to 410p.

Things were no better in the small cap world with e-business consultancy Nettec, off 49.5p to 58p, and Itnet , down 102.5p to 187.5p, suffering after warning on sales and profits respectively.

webTitle: Working hours

fields.headline: Working hours
fields.trailText: Men in full time employment work an average of 46.2 hours a week, compared with 42 hours for women full-timers.
fields.body:
Men in full time employment work an average of 46.2 hours a week, compared with 42 hours for women full-timers.

Occupations with the longest average overtime are professionals (11 hours), operatives (10.5 hours) and managers (10 hours). Shortest overtime averages are in clerical and secretarial work (6.7 hours) and retailing (7.5 hours).

80% of workplaces have employees who work more than their standard hours and 39% of employees doing overtime get no extra pay.

One in five employees work for companies open 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

One in eight employees work Saturdays and Sundays.

One in nine full time employees work more than 60 hours every week. Men are twice as likely to work such long hours.

Only a fifth of employers are fully aware of women's increased rights to maternity leave and 24% of new paternity leave rights.

webTitle: OECD sees threat to growth

fields.headline: OECD sees threat to growth
fields.standfirst: Thinktank warns of rising oil prices and falling hi-tech shares
fields.trailText: Rising oil prices and further falls in hi-tech stock markets could endanger healthy global growth, the west's leading think tank said yesterday.
fields.body:
Rising oil prices and further falls in hi-tech stock markets could endanger healthy global growth, the west's leading think tank said yesterday.

In a generally upbeat assessment of the world economy, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development said the biggest threats to the economic outlook were renewed turbulence in financial markets and another rise in energy prices.

"Global economic growth appears to have peaked during the first half of 2000, but world economic prospects remain relatively bright," the OECD said in its twice yearly economic outlook.

Despite the global slowdown, borrowing costs will have to rise by half a percentage point in the US and the euro zone to curb inflation - according to the Paris-based body.

The OECD predicts that crude oil prices are likely to stay above $30 a barrel until next summer, helping to trim global growth back to 4.1% next year from a healthy 4.75% this year.

But there is risk that oil prices could revisit the 10-year highs they hit in October, which would cut between 0.2 and 0.4 percentage points off output in the west.

A downturn in technology stocks could affect the forecast by depressing consumer confidence, particularly in the US, "triggering a sharper than projected slowdown in activity", the report said.

The think tank warned western governments against softening the blow of higher oil prices by cutting fuel duties, a move it said could make it harder for countries to meet international commitments on reducing greenhouse gases.

"Protests have prompted governments in a few European countries to reduce certain taxes on oil consumption," the report said. "Such measures should be taken very cautiously. To the extent that this is successful in lowering oil prices for users, this is a step in the wrong direction in terms of environmental policies."

The OECD gave the UK economy a generally clean bill of health but warned that unless consumer spending slowed to make room for higher public spending, the Bank of England would have to raise interest rates. The warning coincided yesterday with new figures showing consumer borrowing in October at a 14-year high, suggesting that consumers are not yet reining in spending.

Personal loans and overdrafts rose last month by the largest amount since 1986, according to the British Bankers Association. After two months of subdued increases lending expanded significantly, by £1.02bn in October, well above the £631m trend.

A flood of special offers from banks and building societies may have caused the rise in lending, according to the BBA.

Richard Iley, an economist at ABN-Amro - which is bucking the trend among banks by predicting interest rates have further to rise - said the latest numbers show consumer demand remains above its long-term average.

"It's still too strong for comfort and the long anticipated slowdown in consumer demand is a long way from being in the bag," said Mr Iley.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Bid talk boosts Countrywide
fields.body:
Bid talk boosts Countrywide

Shares in Britain's biggest estate agent, Countrywide Assured, surged 16% yesterday after it confirmed it had received several approaches from parties interested in buying all or parts of the business.

The shares closed the day 16p higher at 116p following its announcement that it had held "initial discussions" with potential bidders. These were rumoured to include Italian financial services group Mediolanum, although this was denied yesterday afternoon.

Lloyds TSB boss speaks out

The chairman of Lloyds TSB said yesterday that the European financial services sector was ripe for consolidation.

Brian Pitman told a conference in London that an increasingly international profile of shareholders in continental European firms and a new breed of managers meant there was now greater emphasis on maximising shareholder value. He would not say, however, whether Lloyds TSB was on a European acquisition trail.

NatWest alters approach

NatWest, which along with its parent Royal Bank of Scotland has a 30% of the small business banking market, is to tackle one of the issues hampering small businesses by proving them with "portable credit histories" along with their statements.

NatWest also pledged to "turn current industry practice on its head" by ending the clause in overdraft agreements that warns businesses the loan is "repayable on demand". The bank said it would give small businesses a new overdraft commitment for up to 12 months. The credit history could be used by small business as proof of creditworthiness to suppliers, NatWest said.

Invensys wins metering firm

Troubled engineering group Invensys is paying £37m for a metering business which boasts sales of £30m and 2.1m energy customers across south-east England. It is buying Meterpoint Data Services, which enables British companies to outsource meter reading, from US-owned Seeboard. webTitle: Church quits GKN

fields.headline: Church quits GKN
fields.standfirst: Anglicans sell £15m shares for ethical reasons
fields.trailText: The Church of England is getting rid of its shares in GKN on the grounds that the engineering company's record of selling defence equipment to foreign regimes makes it an unsuitable investment for Christians.
fields.body:
The Church of England is getting rid of its shares in GKN on the grounds that the engineering company's record of selling defence equipment to foreign regimes makes it an unsuitable investment for Christians.

The decision follows an ethical review of the church's £5.6bn share portfolio, which has concluded that suppliers of "defence platforms" such as military aircraft, tanks and helicopters are unacceptable.

A spokesman for the Church Commissioners said: "We're allying ourselves to what we think most Christians would find acceptable. The reality is that these kinds of companies are no longer investing in areas which we would have said are appropriate."

The church's shares in GKN were thought to be worth about £15m. In the past, the commissioners had invested in companies supplying military equipment to help nations defend themselves, or for peacekeeping missions.

However, an ethical advisory committee has concluded that companies manufacturing defence equipment are increasingly selling their products internationally, making it difficult for the church to monitor where weapons are going.

As a result, new rules have imposed a blanket ban on suppliers of weapons, weapon systems and defence platforms, with only restricted investment permitted in firms making "non-offensive military systems" such as radar, software and avionics.

The Church Commissioners' spokesman said: "What we would traditionally have said are appropriate would be sales to Nato and Commonwealth countries. But they're now selling well outside those boundaries."

He said that the disposal of further investments was likely. "Others will come along soon, I'm sure."

The Campaign Against Arms Trade, which has been lobbying the church, applauded the decision.

Spokeswoman Rachel Harford said: "We welcome this very, very much. It's quite a statement for the church to make."

About one quarter of GKN's sales are from its Westland helicopters business and from supplying parts for civil and military aircraft.

A GKN spokesman said: "This is an issue for the church - we never comment investment decisions by shareholders."

Shares in GKN finished the session 10p higher yesterday at 795p.

webTitle: Railtrack runs short of investor confidence

fields.headline: Railtrack runs short of investor confidence
fields.trailText: Railtrack's shares fell almost 10% yesterday, or 93p, to 902p as the City worried about the prospects for the company following the sudden departure of Gerald Corbett, its chief executive.
fields.body:
Railtrack's shares fell almost 10% yesterday, or 93p, to 902p as the City worried about the prospects for the company following the sudden departure of Gerald Corbett, its chief executive.

The shares rallied at the end of the day after initially falling to 891p because of confidence in a meeting between Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority and Sir Philip Beck, Railtrack's chairman.

Sir Alastair's meeting was part of a two-day investigation study to see what plans Railtrack has to turn itself around now that Mr Corbett has gone.

Sir Alastair is the government's leading representative in the rail industry. He has the difficult task of working out a strategy with Railtrack to return the railway back to normal as soon as possible. This is not likely to happen until the early part of next year.

One of the biggest problems is the need to get sufficient ballast to rebuild miles of track damaged by the recent flooding. Unofficial estimates suggest that at least 22,000 tonnes are urgently required which will cost Railtrack millions of pounds in remedial work.

Sir Alastair will today meet Railtrack's chief executive, Steven Marshall, formerly its chief financial officer. A source close to Sir Alastair last night made it clear that he could not force further resignations on the company.

Two years ago, Sir Alastair was being tipped as a possible chairman of Railtrack, but John Prescott, deputy prime minister, wanted him to head the strategic rail authority.

Commuters are expected to react angrily today to an announcement by the train operating companies excluding passengers with weekly or daily tickets from compensation.

Passengers who have purchased yearly or monthly season tickets are to be given free travel for up to a month as compensation for the inconvenience they have suffered.

The train companies say they fear bogus claims. Only yearly and monthly season ticket holders have names and addresses recorded upon purchase. For delays of an hour or more, a weekly or daily ticket holder can only claim back 20% of the cost of that particular journey.

The Association of Train Operating Companies said that it was meeting the shadow strategic rail authority to decide how passengers not covered by today's package could be compensated.

webTitle: Coca-Cola tempted to reap Quaker Oats

fields.headline: Coca-Cola tempted to reap its oats
fields.trailText: Coca-Cola is expected to join the bidding for food and drinks group Quaker Oats, topping an existing offer from France's Groupe Danone and an earlier move from its rival PepsiCo.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola is expected to join the bidding for food and drinks group Quaker Oats, topping an existing offer from France's Groupe Danone and an earlier move from its rival PepsiCo.

The Coca-Cola board are meeting today to discuss an offer of around $15bn for the Quaker Oats group.

Last night Coca-Cola shares fell 6% amid fears that it would be tempted to overpay for Quaker, which owns Gatorade, the top-selling sports drink. Quaker's shares rose to a 52-week high of $96.75 (£68) yesterday, valuing the business at $12.7bn.

The stock market value of the company has risen sharply this year as evidence emerged that it would be taken over in a rapidly consolidating industry.

Senior executives at Chicago-based Quaker are thought to have met over the weekend to discuss proposals from Coca-Cola and Danone. Earlier this month, PepsiCo, the world's second largest soft drinks business, held talks with Quaker which are understood to have valued the target at about $13.7bn. These talks fell through without agreement.

Management at Coca-Cola were understood to have started talks with Quaker in a bid to prevent Pepsi from taking over Gatorade, which dominates the American sports drink market.

Analysts have questioned the ability of Quaker Oats to expand the brand aggressively overseas - doubts which have attracted rival bids from larger companies. Quaker Oats refused to comment on any talks yesterday.

Several reports suggested that Coca-Cola would be willing to pay 1.9 of its own shares for every share of Quaker Oats. Before yesterday's decline wiped some $900m from this deal, this would have valued Quaker Oats at about $16bn.

Investors were wary yesterday as Coca-Cola has only recently started to perform strongly after a new management team was appointed earlier this year. The company announced a $192m settlement to solve damaging race discrimination lawsuits last week.

Jennifer Solomon, analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, downgraded Coca-Cola, citing takeover uncertainty.

John McMillin, a food industry analyst at Prudential, said that the market was concerned that the intense competition in the industry would drive up prices.

Groupe Danone refused to comment on reports that it had made a lower offer for Quaker Oats yesterday.

The French group joined with Cadbury Schweppes of the UK earlier this year in an abortive effort to buy Nabisco Holdings.

Among Quaker's products are:

Gatorade energy drink

Cap'n Crunch cereal

Quaker Oats porridge

Quaker Grits grits (milled corn kernels)

Aunt Jemima pancake mixes and syrup

Rice A Roni rice products

webTitle: Leader: Europe on the march

fields.headline: Europe on the march
fields.standfirst:
But the EU's new force faces a long slog

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Long-standing plans to give the European Union a joint military capability took a big and welcome step forward in Brussels yesterday. Britain, rightly, is at the forefront of this effort. If the nations of Europe are to maximise their influence in a world they no longer control, they do better to speak with one voice.
fields.body:
Long-standing plans to give the European Union a joint military capability took a big and welcome step forward in Brussels yesterday. Britain, rightly, is at the forefront of this effort. If the nations of Europe are to maximise their influence in a world they no longer control, they do better to speak with one voice. If shared European principles concerning democracy, human rights and the rule of law are to be promoted, then it is logical for EU members to pool their resources in support of those objectives. If Britain, sidelined for example by the euro-zone countries, is to demonstrate that it can lead in Europe, defence is one area of enhanced cooperation where it has the potential to excel. But to work effectively, the EU's nascent common foreign and security policy needs teeth and clout. The 60,000-strong rapid reaction force, backed by significant naval and air assets, is intended to provide it.

In the post-Cold War era, when military forces are becoming smaller, more professional, and ever more expensive, it makes sense to concentrate joint efforts and budgets on the new tasks of humanitarian assistance, crisis management, peacekeeping and peacemaking. In theory, the days when France acts unilaterally (and ineffectually) in Rwanda (as in 1994), or Britain in Sierra Leone (as now), or when a pressing international crisis is largely left to others to resolve (as in East Timor last year), or when Europe intervenes late or not at all (as in Bosnia, Kurdistan, and Chechnya) may soon be passing - and not before time. In theory, if they existed now, EU battalions could form the neutral force currently proposed for the Occupied Territories.

But in practice, there is still a very long way to go. Two main problem areas remain: logistical and political. Immediate difficulties surround differing standards of training, equipment and weaponry which are often neither up-to-date nor compatible. The force will need improved strategic air and sea transport capabilities. Joint procurement programmes, such as Eurofighter, air missiles, and the A400M heavy lift aircraft, are in their infancy, with national governments still vulnerable to competitive bids from US manufacturers. Although not a standing army, the reaction force will ultimately involve significant additional costs. But across the EU, defence spending is in decline; only Britain and Finland have so far arrested the post-1989 downwards trend. Compared with the US, and as Kosovo embarrassingly showed, Europe also gets considerably less bang for its buck. All this will take time and determination to overcome.

The political objections to the EU force advanced by William Hague and other Tories are too juvenile for serious consideration. There was a time when matters of national security were held to be above partisan point-scoring or, at least, worthy of sensible debate. No longer, it seems. Mr Hague's europhobia grows delusional. Are his elephants pink, we wonder? But from the US political perspective, there are legitimate questions to be asked. In one way, the advent of the EU force is the answer to a long-uttered prayer: at last the Europeans are getting the message on burden-sharing.

In another way, however, there is no disputing that this robust, independent military capability, especially as it expands to involve non-EU countries like Norway and EU hopefuls like Turkey, potentially undermines the cohesion of the US-dominated Nato alliance - and may even one day render it as redundant as the Warsaw Pact. Not a bad idea, perhaps; in any case, an idea that is likely to gain ground after yesterday's watershed.

webTitle: Matthew Norman's diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Hats off to Lord Michael Henderson, who repays the Daily Telegraph for some of the notepaper on which he writes his pithy letters by coming second in Wisden's cricket writer of the year poll. Meanwhile, he has some typically strong words for E W Swanton, the doyen of his trade, in an attack his fans will find reassuringly familiar.
fields.body:
 Hats off to Lord Michael Henderson, who repays the Daily Telegraph for some of the notepaper on which he writes his pithy letters by coming second in Wisden's cricket writer of the year poll. Meanwhile, he has some typically strong words for E W Swanton, the doyen of his trade, in an attack his fans will find reassuringly familiar.

Hendo finds time to show off his musical knowledge while dismissing Mr Swanton as a "boring" writer and "frightful snob" - a classic instance, some will feel, given his own work and the tone of his letters, of a kitchen vessel becoming confused about its own pigmentation. Two things mark this attack out, however. It came not in a letter but in a Wisden magazine article; and Mr Swanton is dead (he died in January aged 93).

We gather that the Wisden piece is in fact an obituary spiked by the Telegraph, which commissioned a more conventional effort from Simon Hughes. I myself am working on an obituary of Lord Henderson, and would appreciate any anecdotes or reflections from his many friends.

 Following up Friday's item here about the mysterious darkening of Gordon Brown's hair, the Daily Mail quotes Treasury sources denying the use of dye, and claiming our pictures relied on "a trick of the light". Oooooh, as the weirdo chancellor's Carry On role model Frankie Howerd would have put it, sauce! Unless the denial is retracted by Thursday and the product in question named, we will have no option but to run two further photos for use in a You, The Jury phone poll.

 If anyone should be embarrassed by the Mail on Sunday's collation of cabinet leaks from soon after Mr T came to power, it is that standard bearer of the left, Clare "Bomber" Short. In the cabinet meeting of June 12 1997, the Hammer of Belgrade chips in: "We are right to cut back first but it sounds like a problem in three to five years." She was correct about that second bit, but to find her vocally supporting sticking to Ken Clarke's absurd spending limits, which have reduced the NHS to a level of disintegration never seen before, is something else. Bomber, Bomber, hang your head in shame.

 So trendy has Michael Portillo made metamorphoses for rightwingers rejected by the electorate that another former Tory MP has undergone a shock transformation. While the member for Dover, David Shaw's attitude to visitors from foreign lands was so pithy that he became well known for them. What a change of heart a loss of seat can effect. Only last month, David (whose previous experience of Asian culture was thought limited to employing Pamella Bordes as a researcher) popped up at a Hindu festival in Kingston, where he he is standing for the Tories next time. Marvellous.

 One looks to social commentators such as the Sunday Telegraph's Mary Kenny to provide insights into the issues of the day. So how good it was to hear Mary on Radio 5 last Sunday night, talking about the NSPCC's report on child abuse. Mary informed listeners she had done some private research on the subject, and announced her findings: that incest "nearly always happens within the family".

 Last week at the Cafe Royal, my friend Michael Winner presented his "Winner's Dinners" awards upon the paperback publication of his book. As last year, the Patio restaurant in the Goldhawk Road - that road again, the one on which, according to Lord Henderson, my capacious arse and I are often seen waddling - won the prize for best value, while my mother defended her title for best chopped liver.

With the winter epidemics upon us and recent medical evidence, supported by the World Health Organisation, suggesting there is little better at fighting colds and flu, her recipe for chicken soup will appear here in the weeks ahead. Step one: buy a kosher chicken (a boiler).

webTitle: TV and Radio: Answer me

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with Adam Woodyatt (aka Ian Beale)
fields.trailText: Getting personal with Adam Woodyatt (aka Ian Beale)
fields.body:
Full name: Adam Brinley Woodyatt

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and if so, why?

On the internet, because nobody would believe who I am.

Have you ever lied about your age and if so, why?

When I was younger - to get into clubs and pubs.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?

God! or more likely ... professional liar, seeks time off work for good behaviour.

What was the last illegal thing you did?

Speeding - oh and I got caught running down the Elstree corridors last week.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

Everything I do is done with a kind heart - believe it or not, I'm not Ian Beale.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?

Gilly Taylforth and Bill Treacher.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've worked with?

XX.

Has a critic ever made you cry?

Only with laughter.

What would you advertise without a fee?

Beer and chocolate.

What would you never advertise?

Anything with wings.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning?

Nothing can wake me at 4am.

What takes you to a "happy place"?

My car - to work.

A big week for Ian Beale in EastEnders, BBC1.

Speeding - oh and I got caught running down the Elstree corridors last week. What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? Everything I do is done with a kind heart - believe it or not, I'm not Ian Beale. Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? Gilly Taylforth and Bill Treacher. What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've worked with? XX. Has a critic ever made you cry? Only with laughter. What would you advertise without a fee? Beer and chocolate. What would you never advertise? Anything with wings. What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning? Nothing can wake me at 4am. What takes you to a "happy place"? My car - to work. A big week for Ian Beale in EastEnders, BBC1.

webTitle: Leader: Was Ms Keppel already a millionaire?

fields.headline: To them that hath ... Was Ms Keppel already a millionaire?
fields.standfirst: Was Ms Keppel already a millionaire?
fields.trailText: Any chance of a recount? Judith Keppel will certainly hope not, as she cheerfully tots up the £1m she won on last night's jackpot episode of Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? ITV will be only too happy with the result, as well. They needed a winner - and yesterday they certainly got one.
fields.body:
Any chance of a recount? Judith Keppel will certainly hope not, as she cheerfully tots up the £1m she won on last night's jackpot episode of Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? ITV will be only too happy with the result, as well. For the best part of two years, Chris Tarrant has taunted contestants by dangling that seven-figure prize before them - only to keep it just out of reach. Viewers were getting restless, wondering if the real booty would ever be given away. So ITV needed a winner - and yesterday they certainly got one.

Still, there may well be some Florida-style rumblings of discontent with the outcome. For Ms Keppel may have been a millionaire on paper even before she was asked the question: "Who was married to Eleanor of Aquitaine?" Though billed as "a gardener from Fulham", she is, in fact, the proud owner of a three-storey home in that rather posh London neighbourhood. Her first marriage was to one of the capital's leading art dealers.

To cap it all, Ms Keppel has blue blood. She came out as a debutante in 1959, her grandfather was the ninth Earl of Albemarle and she is the great great niece of Alice Keppel, a mistress of the future Edward VII. As if that was not enough, she is a distant cousin of Camilla Parker-Bowles.

Now, is it only the hard core class warrior who will see something amiss in all this? Or might the great British viewing public also baulk at ITV helping an aristocrat make her already highly agreeable life £1m better? For surely the appeal of all shows of this kind, including the national lottery, is the Robin Hood factor: this is the possibility that even the least well-off can become a millionaire in a flash. When Robin Hood gives to someone who is already rich, the thrill is not quite the same. So we congratulate Ms Keppel on her well-earned win - even as we hope that the finger of luck points in a slightly less well-heeled direction the next time round.

webTitle: Letters: Greens fuel the debate

fields.headline: Greens fuel the debate
fields.trailText: Peter Preston berates the Green parties of the world (Driving to doom, November 20) for not being clear about whether we're inside or outside the system and for remaining silent during the fuel protests. Now we are being elected, and are putting the arguments vigorously in the corridors of power.
fields.body:
Peter Preston berates the Green parties of the world (Driving to doom, November 20) for not being clear about whether we're inside or outside the system and for remaining silent during the fuel protests.

British Greens are absolutely clear where we should be: we've worked for over 25 years to be elected to all levels of government even though the UK electoral system is stacked against emerging politicians. Now we are being elected, and are putting the arguments vigorously in the corridors of power.

It's true that if the US doesn't come on board and reduce its greenhouse gas emissions, sorting out the crisis will be more difficult. But the rest of the world produces three-quarters of C0<->2 and we will have to get on with reducing it anyway. We can't delay action here, while waiting for vicious weather caused by climate change to blow off the dome of the White House.

And by the way, I joined Green party and Transport 2000 members in blockading the lorry cavalcade in Park Lane last week. I then spoke at the fuel protestors' rally and told them that reducing fuel taxes was misguided, especially in the light of the recent floods. At the first stage of the hauliers' action the Green party was putting the message that the real fuel crisis is that motorists and lorry drivers expect to drive as much as ever despite climate change. Your readers didn't hear about these contributions to the fuel crisis because you didn't mention it in your reports. Are we silent, or are your reporters?
Dr Caroline Lucas MEP

 Peter Preston says that those who voted for the strongest action on global warming will, by voting for Nader, have prevented Gore from achieving progress on that issue. Yet, based on the evidence of the past eight years, there is no reason for optimism that a Democratic president can make any progress on reducing US over-consumption.

Nader's campaign at least had the virtue of challenging the undemocratic and unaccountable power wielded by business in the US. Without significant democratisation in the first world, sustainability of any kind looks impossible to achieve.
Brian Doherty
School of Politics, International Relations and the Environment, Keele University
b.j.a.doherty@keele.ac.uk

 Peter Preston is absolutely right about the challenge of climate change for western democracies. However, his view of Nader's campaign is at best a misleading partial truth. If all Nader voters in Florida had voted for Gore instead, all other things being equal, Gore would indeed be president-elect. So would he, however, if he had simply won his home state.

More importantly, although Gore's position may be marginally better than Bush's on environmental matters, he showed no evidence of working for the environment as vice-president. Faced with the evil of two lesser candidates, many chose instead to vote with their conscience.
James Mackenzie
Scottish Green party
james@mackenzie.nu

 During the week of the petrol blockade the Green party conference passed an emergency motion in favour of maintaining vehicle fuel duty and ring-fencing the extra revenues generated by crude oil price rises in order to invest massively in more sustainable alternatives such as public transport, rail freight, energy efficiency and renewable energy technologies. This was not reported in the national press, any more than were dozens of other press releases sent out by the party during the crisis.
Brian Fewster
Leicester
bfewster@gn.apc.org

webTitle: Letter: Angry scientist on 'anti-science'

fields.headline: The angry scientist
fields.trailText: Your report on Tony Blair's speech to the European Bioscience Conference raised my hackles (Blair derides "anti-science", November 18). It is galling for one's considered scientific standpoint to be dismissed as "anti-science".
fields.body:
Your report on Tony Blair's speech to the European Bioscience Conference raised my hackles (Blair derides "anti-science", November 18). There are many scientists of independent views in this country who oppose, in a measured way, the government's unconditional support for the gene-science industry. It is galling for one's considered scientific standpoint to be dismissed as "anti-science".

It is true that the potential benefits of bioscience are "massive"; I support, for example, research into aspects of medical biotechnology such as GM drugs. (I would support it even more if public investment in such research meant the results would be freely available for anyone.)

I oppose the activities of seed and fertiliser firms that have tried to force GM foods on both farmers and consumers. As a vegetarian, I rely for part of my protein intake on soya beans. I do not wish to eat GM soya beans resistant to specific herbicides for three reasons: first, I believe the use of such seeds encourages farming techniques that are bad for the environment; second, it is clear that genetic material from GM plantations does escape into the wild, and the effect of such releases is unpredictable; and third, I am not confident that such soya is safe.

I am angry that the UK and US governments have colluded with seed firms whose marketing strategy has resulted in nearly all supplies of commercial soya being contaminated with GM material. This has deprived me of a choice as to what I eat.

Mr Blair needs to appoint some scientific advisers who are not on the payroll of big business - there are some left - and then listen to them.
Jack Cleaver
Oxford
jack.cleaver@hummingbird.com

webTitle: Letters: Into battle over Europe's model army

fields.headline: Into battle over Europe's model army
fields.trailText: When is an army not an army (Europe sets up rapid reaction force, November 20)? If the force is going to have committed troops, an arsenal and a unified military command, that is the dictionary definition of an army. What is it for?
fields.body:
When is an army not an army (Europe sets up rapid reaction force, November 20)? If the force is going to have committed troops, an arsenal and a unified military command, that is the dictionary definition of an army. What is it for?

"Humanitarian" missions? Who defines the humanitarian cause? Who is "the enemy"?

Why, if it is thought there may be more situations that need armed services and intervention, are we not strengthening the UN's forces? The UN is seriously underfunded. Already the member states of Nato spend obscene amounts of money on the military. The EU states are now being urged to spend even more on the military for parallel forces.

The EU should be looking to increase support and budgets for conflict prevention not war preparation.
Rae Street
Littleborough, Notts
raecnd@gn.apc.org

 Britain's defence is already completely catered for by Nato, which has been effective for 50 years. The new force is not about the defence of Britain but war-fighting, referred to euphemistically as "peace keeping", or "humanitarian intervention".

In Kosovo Britain took part in an aggressive and illegal war. It increased the humanitarian problems in the region. It contravened the terms of the Nato treaty which allows for wars only in self-defence. What this new rapid reaction force is about is the ability to carry out aggressive action on humani tarian pretexts without contravening the treaty.
David Roberts
Campaign for Justice for the Peoples of Yugoslavia
dave@saxonbooks.co.uk

 The tragedies of Bosnia and Kosovo demonstrated the great need for Europe to have its own military wing capable of "firefighting" within Europe's own boundaries. Now that the Soviet Union no longer exists we really should not need the US to come to our rescue any more. The formation of the "rapid reaction force" is most welcome and long overdue. The hysterical antics of the isolationist anti-Europeans in Britain merely emphasises the fact that it is a very good idea.
David G Sawtell
Luton
david.sawtell@ukonline.co.uk

webTitle: On the web: Space and the universe

fields.headline: On the web: Space and the universe
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor gets out of this world
fields.body:
Spacekids - Science
***

Aimed at: KS1-3

Plenty of information on rockets, astronauts and other achievements of the US space programme, including stories, colouring pages, things to make and a Nasa Kids email club to join.

Liftoff
***
Aimed at: KS4

Nasa's site for teenagers. Rockets and astronauts are covered in greater depth. Other sections invite visitors to think about the universe, gravity, light and satellites.

The Nine Planets
***
Aimed at: teachers

A virtual tour of the solar system which, although it suggests a number of unanswered questions for discussion, might be more useful as an English language resource than a source for science. Taking the raw data here as a starting-point, teachers might ask pupils to investigate the origins of planets' names or imagine their atmospheres and surfaces. Because of the level of detail (photographs, statistics, diagrams), this would also be an excellent resource for primary projects about space.

The Space Place
*****
Aimed at: KS1-2

A wonderful collection of activities for younger children. Make Asteroid Potatoes, construct a galactic mobile, bake star cookies, fall into a black hole (via a board game), draw a dot-to-dot spacecraft, or test a new spacecraft material. Adult supervision is sometimes necessary. More web-based activities can be found at amazing-space.stsci.edu.

Guardian report

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

The latest news on space exploration, photo galleries and a collection of links.

SETI

**
Aimed at: teachers

The Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence first came to attention because it invited web users to download chunks of data from monitoring equipment and process them while their computers were idle. The lessons here, unfortunately, are only available in sample form, but the Who's Out There? interactive guide is a useful stimulus for older children.

Space.com

**

Aimed at: teachers

As the dot.com suffix suggests, this is a highly commercial site, and the lesson library here is a little thin and designed for the US curriculum. However, with a little adaptation the suggestions would suit food science, design and technology, physics and English lessons.

Your Sky

****

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

Create a map of the night sky tonight as it appears from any part of the world. Now that dusk falls early, this is an activity which could take place during an after-school club or as informal homework. Links to the earth and moon viewer, which follows the same principle.

Mars Education

*****

Aimed at: KS3-4 teachers

Several Mars-related classroom investigations and lesson plans are available here, all centring on Nasa's 10-year investigation of the planet.

webTitle: Business: News Analysis

fields.headline: Cisco practises what it preaches
fields.standfirst:
Fastest-growing company says internet will change your life, your world and your business

Net news
fields.trailText: Fastest-growing company says the internet will change your life, your world and your business.
fields.body:
It is 8am and the parking lots at Cisco City are already filling up fast. A queue of cars is filing off the San Thomas Expressway that skirts the northern edge of San Jose down towards what is fast becoming the largest and most important business park in the internet world.

Each morning 13,000 people make this trip to Cisco headquarters, an expanding spread of 40 identical green and beige four-storey buildings that occupies an area a little over one square mile.

Many of the staff are already in their work cubicles, casually dressed and beavering away at computer screens. Their workstations are spartan. The glass-fronted meeting rooms that line the sides of the open-plan offices are bare except for the odd poster and a speaker phone on each conference table.

Cappuccino machines, ping-pong tables and the other goodies that clutter the offices of most other hi-tech firms in Silicon Valley are conspicuous by their absence. But no one feels like they are missing out. They are too busy to care. Their only concern is to take over the networked world.

Welcome to Cisco, the fastest growing company in the internet economy and for a brief period earlier this year the biggest company on the planet. (It surpassed the mammoth General Electric Corporation, but the old economy giant has since muscled its way back to the top).

Cisco is at the heart of the internet. It dominates the markets for routers, switches and connections that allow computers to talk to each other over the internet. Cisco says that 75% of all net traffic travels over its products. The market is one of the most important and fastest growing of the world's economy and has helped write one of the most extraordinary corporate success stories in history.

Founded in a husband and wife's bedroom in the mid-1980s, Cisco today employs 40,000 people worldwide and in the past three months it generated revenues of $6.5bn (£4.5bn). Its market is expected to grow by three times in the next five years.

Cisco's mantra is simple: the internet will change your life, your world and your business. You cannot afford to ignore it.

The company is aiming to convert the world - and Cisco practices what it preaches. Almost every administrative procedure possible is executed over the web in the name of efficiency. Ninety per cent of orders are taken online generating $80m of product sales a day.

Staff members book their own travel requirements on the company intranet and everyone flies economy class, even the most senior executives. Expenses are filed online and only two accountants are needed to administer the process for 26,000 American staff.

In the finance department the balance sheet is constantly monitored online. A trading quarter can be audited and closed in a single day - a fact that amazes most rivals. "One of our great strengths is our predictability and accuracy," says Ron Willis, vice-president of marketing for small and medium sized businesses.

Employees are given bonuses in shares not cash. The award is based on customer satisfaction surveys. There is no hiding - everyone's performance is published, including chief executive John Chambers.

"It's pretty intimidating at first," says Peter Alexander, vice-president of enterprise marketing. "You soon get used to it though. It's less about personal criticism and more about producing the data to let you know how you can improve."

Cisco's staff is growing by 4,000 people a quarter. Fourteen consecutive quarters of 40% growth and one of the strongest bull markets in US history has seen its market value soar from $9bn in 1995.

The run has created more than 2,000 millionaires among the staff but very few have left. Conspicuous wealth is frowned upon and the only Ferrari in the parking lot is parked in a visitor's bay.

"Plenty of people could buy their own Hawaiian islands but we love coming to work," says Peter Clarke, a director of business development and originally from the UK. "I've got a small cottage on the Yorkshire Dales and I sometimes think to myself that it'd be nice to go and hang out there. But what would I do? After a month the novelty would wear off. After three months I'd be going nuts."

The central character at Cisco is Mr Chambers, a former IBM salesman who was promoted to the top job in 1995. Brought up in West Virginia, he likes doing things the old fashioned way. He wears a suit and tie (a rarity in Silicon Valley) and prefers a handshake to a contract. In every other respect he is the modern, egalitarian business leader who has an office the same size as his middle managers. He cannot get enough of the internet and evangelises about it constantly.

Since Mr Chamber's arrived Cisco's market value has leapt to about $370bn, making him a billionaire in the process. While other firms have fallen by the wayside as technology has overtaken them Cisco has simply issued more shares to buy the gadgets it needs. Chief executives from America's greatest corporations flock in their droves to San Jose to drink in the Cisco culture. Presidents and prime ministers listen in awe as Mr Chambers speaks out on behalf of the internet.

Even Wall Street has stayed loyal, as Cisco's share price rise has generated huge returns for more than 3m shareholders. But cracks have recently started to appear in the relationship, with big investors questioning whether Cisco can maintain its growth rate or afford to carry on buying the technologies it needs to stay ahead of the game. Yesterday Morgan Stanley Dean Witter cut its price target on Cisco to $75 from $90 - and the shares fell $2 to just above $50.

"Our share price is down at the moment but so is everyone else's. It's not affecting our ability to do deals or changing our strategy in any way," said Mr Alexander.

The only people to sell the stock in any great quantities have been Cisco's founders. Len Bosack and Sandy Lerner started Cisco while at Stanford University in 1984 by building a "router" that enabled them to send messages between their computers while they worked.

The couple went looking for funding to turn it into a business and were turned down by 75 venture capital firms before little known Sequoia Capital hit one of the greatest home runs in history. It paid $2.5m for 32% of the company, a coup that has built it a reputation as one of the area's hottest venture capital firms.

Cisco went public in 1990 but the founders and the financiers quickly fell out of love. Six months after the flotation Sandy was fired. Len quit shortly afterwards. Later that year they sold their shares for about $170m - the stake would have been worth more than $100bn today.

Len now lives in Seattle, Washington. Sandy bought Chawton House, in Hampshire, England and runs a cosmetics firm.

Their "loss" is Cisco's gain and helps explain why so staff remain so loyal. "That's the great thing about this place - you never know for certain what is going to happen tomorrow," said Mr Clarke.

Its market is expected to grow by three times in the next five years. Cisco's mantra is simple: the internet will change your life, your world and your business. You cannot afford to ignore it. The company is aiming to convert the world - and Cisco practices what it preaches. Almost every administrative procedure possible is executed over the web in the name of efficiency. Ninety per cent of orders are taken online generating $80m of product sales a day. Staff members book their own travel requirements on the company intranet and everyone flies economy class, even the most senior executives. Expenses are filed online and only two accountants are needed to administer the process for 26,000 American staff. In the finance department the balance sheet is constantly monitored online. A trading quarter can be audited and closed in a single day - a fact that amazes most rivals. "One of our great strengths is our predictability and accuracy," says Ron Willis, vice-president of marketing for small and medium sized businesses. Employees are given bonuses in shares not cash. The award is based on customer satisfaction surveys. There is no hiding - everyone's performance is published, including chief executive John Chambers. "It's pretty intimidating at first," says Peter Alexander, vice-president of enterprise marketing. "You soon get used to it though. It's less about personal criticism and more about producing the data to let you know how you can improve." Cisco's staff is growing by 4,000 people a quarter. Fourteen consecutive quarters of 40% growth and one of the strongest bull markets in US history has seen its market value soar from $9bn in 1995. The run has created more than 2,000 millionaires among the staff but very few have left. Conspicuous wealth is frowned upon and the only Ferrari in the parking lot is parked in a visitor's bay. "Plenty of people could buy their own Hawaiian islands but we love coming to work," says Peter Clarke, a director of business development and originally from the UK. "I've got a small cottage on the Yorkshire Dales and I sometimes think to myself that it'd be nice to go and hang out there. But what would I do? After a month the novelty would wear off. After three months I'd be going nuts." The central character at Cisco is Mr Chambers, a former IBM salesman who was promoted to the top job in 1995. Brought up in West Virginia, he likes doing things the old fashioned way. He wears a suit and tie (a rarity in Silicon Valley) and prefers a handshake to a contract. In every other respect he is the modern, egalitarian business leader who has an office the same size as his middle managers. He cannot get enough of the internet and evangelises about it constantly. Since Mr Chamber's arrived Cisco's market value has leapt to about $370bn, making him a billionaire in the process. While other firms have fallen by the wayside as technology has overtaken them Cisco has simply issued more shares to buy the gadgets it needs. Chief executives from America's greatest corporations flock in their droves to San Jose to drink in the Cisco culture. Presidents and prime ministers listen in awe as Mr Chambers speaks out on behalf of the internet. Even Wall Street has stayed loyal, as Cisco's share price rise has generated huge returns for more than 3m shareholders. But cracks have recently started to appear in the relationship, with big investors questioning whether Cisco can maintain its growth rate or afford to carry on buying the technologies it needs to stay ahead of the game. Yesterday Morgan Stanley Dean Witter cut its price target on Cisco to $75 from $90 - and the shares fell $2 to just above $50. "Our share price is down at the moment but so is everyone else's. It's not affecting our ability to do deals or changing our strategy in any way," said Mr Alexander. The only people to sell the stock in any great quantities have been Cisco's founders. Len Bosack and Sandy Lerner started Cisco while at Stanford University in 1984 by building a "router" that enabled them to send messages between their computers while they worked. The couple went looking for funding to turn it into a business and were turned down by 75 venture capital firms before little known Sequoia Capital hit one of the greatest home runs in history. It paid $2.5m for 32% of the company, a coup that has built it a reputation as one of the area's hottest venture capital firms. Cisco went public in 1990 but the founders and the financiers quickly fell out of love. Six months after the flotation Sandy was fired. Len quit shortly afterwards. Later that year they sold their shares for about $170m - the stake would have been worth more than $100bn today. Len now lives in Seattle, Washington. Sandy bought Chawton House, in Hampshire, England and runs a cosmetics firm. Their "loss" is Cisco's gain and helps explain why so staff remain so loyal. "That's the great thing about this place - you never know for certain what is going to happen tomorrow," said Mr Clarke.

webTitle: Letters: Peasants in new revolt

fields.headline: Peasants in new revolt
fields.trailText: So the Queen was exercising humanity (Queen wrings pheasant's neck, November 20) to prevent further suffering? Who caused the suffering in the first place?
fields.body:
So the Queen was exercising humanity (Queen wrings pheasant's neck, November 20) to prevent further suffering? Who caused the suffering in the first place?
Pat Griffin
Cambridge

 For a moment I thought it was one for Corrections and Clarifications. "Queen wrings peasant's neck" - now that would have been newsworthy.
Charles Sandeman-Allen
Icklesham, East Sussex

 Now that we are nearing the end of Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies (A century of films, November 16), can we look forward to his 100 worst movies, which hopefully are not so obscure?
Roy Hollister
Dartford, Kent

 If Al Gore loses the US election due to faulty punch card equipment in parts of Florida, will he be able to sue the maker for loss of earnings?
Alan Reeves
Broadstone, Dorset

 I have just been forced to cancel attendance at a conference on privatisation in education. The reason? the chaos caused by the privatisation of British Rail.
Ruth Knox
Liverpool

 The more one reads your letters page, the more it becomes clear that the anachronistic distinction between fewer and less is only maintained so that 43% of the letter-writing public can have a complaint to fall back on when they can't think of anything witty to say.
Daniel Lewis
Chingford, Essex

 Michael Pritchard writes: (Letters, November 20) "...and have noticed an increasing number of letters complaining about the standard of readers' letters. The letters page is now the first page I turn to." That should, of course, be: "to which I turn".
Reg Dixon
Burnley, Lancs

webTitle: Internet know-how: The National Grid

fields.headline: Internet know-how: The National Grid
fields.trailText: The National Grid for Learning, not to be confused with the National Grid, is at least as complex as its namesake and often seems to have been designed with the interests of quangos rather than teachers and parents in mind.
fields.body:
The National Grid for Learning, not to be confused with the National Grid, is at least as complex as its namesake and often seems to have been designed with the interests of quangos rather than teachers and parents in mind.

If you're a parent, the Parents site is the best place to start. Unlike Parents Online - to be avoided at all costs - it manages to be both informative and well-organised. From here, you'll find a link marked School Search, a usefulresource that allows visitors to look up Ofsted reports, school performance tables and school websites all at the same time.

The full national curriculum lives at: www.nc.uk.net, although a more readable guide for parents can be found by going to the Parents site and clicking on the "Learning Journey" icon.

Teacher and parent governors have their own site at: www.dfee.gov.uk/governor which holds important information about legal responsibilities and duties. The Department for Education will also supply teachers and governors with relevant press releases in an online folder: visit www.easea.co.uk

The recently launched TeacherNet is still in preview form, and little more than a hit-and-miss search engine for all the Department of Education's sites. Try the curriculum area of the Virtual Teachers' Centre instead. Each subject has its own collection of ICT teaching ideas, links (occasionally reviewed), associations, syllabuses and national curriculum requirements. Maths teachers will also be interested in the outstanding Maths Year 2000 sites and, for science teachers, next year's Science Year 2001 - although it doesn't start until next autumn.

Meanwhile, recommended schemes of work for every subject are on the Standards site at: www.standards.dfee.gov.uk/schemes This is also the place to find out about beacon schools and the Excellence in Cities project. Special Educational Needs has its own site at: www.dfee.gov.uk/sen although a few documents on SEN are found at inclusion.ngfl.gov.uk

If your school is buying ICT equipment and you want to delegate the job, the NGfL's Managed Services www.managedservices.ngfl.gov.uk can do it for you. The British Educational Communications and Technology agency The British Educational Communications and Technology agency also offers all sorts of ICT advice.

webTitle: Letter: Chris Smith MP on the BBC shake down

fields.headline: Shake down
fields.trailText:
You state (BBC shake-up shelved, November 20) that I have "long harboured ambitions to abolish" the board of governors of the BBC. This is not so. I have never harboured such ambitions, I have never said that this was my view. What we are doing, in the preparation of our white paper on communications, is to seek a careful balance - that can be sustained in the fast-changing digital world - between simplifying over-complex regulation and maintaining proper protection for the public interest.
Chris Smith MP
Secretary for Culture, Media and Sport

webTitle: Letters: A Tory report

fields.headline: A Tory progress report
fields.trailText: The Conservatives as the progressive party (Leader, November 20)! What's happening to the Guardian?
fields.body:
The Conservatives as the progressive party (Leader, November 20)! What's happening to the Guardian? The Conservatives are pledged to bring back subsidies for private schools, take away pensioners' allowances, isolate us still further from Europe, reverse tax policy aimed at tackling climate change, and switch resources from public health to their friends in the private insurance business.

When the Tories drop their isolationism on Europe, their hate language against refugees and immigrants, their contempt for regional government and electoral reform, then perhaps they might make some progress. Your leader writer should close his or her eyes and imagine Britain back under Tory control. There are many adjectives that come to mind. Progressive isn't one of them.
Rose Ellard
Fulwood, Lancs

 I'm too young to remember what I was doing the day Kennedy was shot, but I remember every moment of Thatcher's downfall on November 22, 1990. I still smile when I think of it - do others have the same vivid memory of this great event?
Richard Burningham
Plymouth

webTitle: TV and Radio: Last night's TV

fields.headline: The bitter end
fields.trailText: I Don't Believe It! The One Foot In The Grave Story | Human Remains | Andes To Amazon
fields.body:
BBC1 made a bit of an event out of the death of Victor Meldrew, preceding the last ever episode with a 45-minute clip-and-comment celebration of TV's greatest old fart. I Don't Believe It! The One Foot In The Grave Story was presented by Angus Deayton in inappropriately clever-clever mode, trying to be funnier than his subject.

He was better when interviewed about his own role in the show, as irritable neighbour Patrick, a sort of Meldrew-in-waiting. Helpful insights came from Annette Crosbie ("I am far more like Victor Meldrew than Richard Wilson is" - and, seeing the steely glint in her eye, you could believe it), and David Renwick, who confirmed that the name "Victor" was always meant ironically.

The clips, of course, were the best bit. Margaret (Crosbie) complained that "I could stuff a mattress with your pubic hair." Mrs Warboys (Doreen Mantle) was surprised by Victor in the bath. And they even showed the funniest One Foot joke ever: on taking receipt of a parcel, Victor reads only one flap of the marked-up carton and sees the legend MELDREWS A TURD, which, on fuller inspection, reads MELDREW DELIVER SATURDAY.

The episode that followed was far in mood and substance from such high jinks. It opened with Margaret, five months a widow, struggling to fill her days in a strangely quiet, orderly house. Flashbacks took us through Victor's final days, piecing together the events surrounding his death in a weirdly fragmented manner.

Just as Margaret had confessed to a priest that she would like to "find the bastard who was at the wheel of the car" that knocked Victor down and "kill them with my bare hands", she discovered that the hit-and-run driver was none other than new friend Glynis (Hannah Gordon). We were left half-believing that Margaret had indeed wrought her revenge with half a pint of fruit juice and an entire packet of paracetamol. It was a satisfyingly bleak ending to a series that never went out of its way to be cheerful.

There was black humour of a less subtle kind on BBC2 in the second part of Human Remains. This week Rob Brydon and Julia Davis hid behind protruding false teeth (we must hope they were false) to become Gordon and Sheila Budge, hoteliers-cum-swingers, who welcomed fellow sex fiends to their well-appointed Budge Lodge Guest House.

This kind of mockumentary is nothing new - Victoria Wood mastered the art over 15 years ago, and earlier this year That Peter Kay Thing made a sharper, funnier attack on the dross that is docusoap. What marks Human Remains out is its subject matter. Gordon and Sheila were like a benign Fred and Rosemary West, existing in a world of constant sexual violence while comatose sister Val died next to the S&M playroom.

"Funnily enough I was actually abused in Devon by an uncle," recalled Sheila, "but it didn't stop me from having a nice holiday." Gordon demonstrated the correct use of a string of love balls and discussed his taste for "junking off over other people's wives", while Sheila "spent the morning with some elderly lesbians". God only knows what was hidden under the patio.

Biggest thrill of the night was the sight of a grinning cayman emerging from liquid mud, the surface boiling with trapped fish desperate for air. This was just one of many dreamlike images in Andes To Amazon (BBC2), which took us to the swamps and grasslands of Brazil. You might think that, with so many nature series having been made in South America, there would be nothing left to surprise.

Andes To Amazon, however, is a series of revelations. A weird pink-grey tentacle bursting into a termite mound turned out to be attached to a giant anteater; a ten-metre anaconda swam, nightmarishly, underwater to ambush a baby capybara. For six months the plains bake and burn; for the remaining six months, they are under water.

Anything that survives here has to be pretty strange - and Andes To Amazon did not disappoint. The caymans and the anteaters were the obvious stars of the show, but the prize for specialist adaptation must go to the beetle grub that lurks unchallenged inside the termite's towers.

Once a year, when the termites swarm on the wing, the resourceful grub becomes fluorescent, luring the fliers to its powerful jaws. In the half-light of the grassland night, the mounds light up like modernist blocks of flats.
