webTitle: G2: Avalanche in Austrian Alps

fields.headline: When the snow falls
fields.standfirst: Avalanche season opened in the Alps this week, with at least four skiers swept to their deaths by torrents of snow, ice and rock. But with millions spent on shoring up the slopes each year, why is the death toll still mounting? Oliver Burkeman and Kate Connolly investigate
fields.trailText: Avalanche season opened in the Alps this week, with at least four skiers swept to their deaths by torrents of snow, ice and rock. But with millions spent on shoring up the slopes each year, why is the death toll still mounting? Oliver Burkeman and Kate Connolly investigate.
fields.body:
The initial impact happens too fast to register on the brain: by the time the distant rumble has grown to an ear-splitting thunder, the snow can be moving at 140mph. When it hits, it can do so with a crushing pressure of 100 tonnes per square metre.

But what follows is a slow death, usually by suffocation: within 15 minutes, nine out of 10 victims trapped beneath the surface will still be breathing. After 45 minutes, the figure drops to 25%.

Those who survive clutch at pitifully inadequate metaphors to describe the experience: the blinding impact "as though a bomb had gone off"; the sensation of being trapped in churning snow "like being in a washing machine".

We may never know whether this Sunday's victims of a spate of avalanches in Austria lived for hours, or merely seconds, after the wall of snow consumed them. A group from Mannheim in Germany, attracted by knee-deep powder snow near Obergurgl, strayed off the main slopes in search of adventure.

In doing so, experts believe, they set in motion an avalanche which caused almost an entire slope to come crashing down about 10,000ft, burying eight of them. Five pulled themselves out; a search team of 100, supported by helicopters and rescue dogs, mounted a search for the rest.

Within hours, news reached them of another avalanche, a few miles up the valley, in the ski resort of Hochgurgl: eyewitnesses reported seeing a skier disappear as clouds of snow swallowed him up.

Two more avalanches would be reported later in the day. A few hours later, with two of the German group found dead, the Tyrol began mourn its first avalanche victims of the season. The number of confirmed victims of the weekend's avalanches now stands at four.

These are entries on a list that seems to be growing faster by the year, as the perils of avalanches impress themselves ever deeper on the public imagination.

It is a terrifying litany of deaths, even taking into account only the last two winters: the toll of 38 near Galtür in Austria; the 23 skiers killed last December, when avalanches thundered down from the mountains near Ischgl; the six tourists who died in two snowslides in Switzerland and Italy in February, one of them caused when a German man and his son ventured off into deep snow; the 11 deaths at Kaprun in March, when a group of ski instructors from across Europe were obliterated by an avalanche 150ft wide.

And then there are the countless deaths, in ones and twos, that rarely merit even a sentence in the local newspapers, unless they happen to be friends of Prince Charles.

Experts are divided on whether the number of avalanches really is increasing - and, in the long term, the number of deaths is actually falling, according to the Swiss Federal Institute for Snow and Avalanche Research. But one thing is indisputable: the exposure of the averagely inexperienced tourist skier to the dangers of avalanches is rapidly increasing.

"The snow is living material," says Yves Détry, a veteran mountain guide based in the French Alps with 28 years' experience of the vagaries of the mountains. "It is always changing, from the morning to the evening, and from one day to the next. And it is very difficult to predict, even if you know the snow well.

"It's now very easy to go off piste even if you're a beginner, but you have to obey the rules of the mountain. They're very harsh: you get them right, you live; you get them wrong, you're dead. It's very difficult to understand the mechanics of the snow. Skiing in the powder is the best thing; the piste is dead snow for me. But you have to be safe."

It seems like the most biblically implacable of natural disasters: a massive reminder to blasé holidaymaker that life is not a climate-controlled theme park; that Nature-with-a-capital-N never misses the opportunity to underscore the frailty of human capabilities.

And yet all the evidence seems to suggest that, in 2000, the "white death" of medieval folklore is at least in part a very human phenomenon. From the recklessness of individual daredevils accidentally dislodging slabs of hard-packed snow to global warming, it is too simplistic to dismiss this weekend's deaths as an act of God.

"Advances in ski technology, and the increase in popularity of free-ride skiing and snowboarding, mean people can get to a standard where they can venture off piste much more quickly than ever before," says Vanessa Haines, of the Ski Club of Great Britain.

"Previously, it would take years of experience to head off into the powder - but now people can put themselves in danger without necessarily knowing it, either putting themselves in the path of avalanches, or actually triggering them by disturbing the snow."

But the German group struck down at the weekend were hardly beginners: they went off piste as part of a course for ski instructors. This, though, is another hazard of the explosion of popularity in skiing: instructors are being confronted more and more frequently with requests to venture into areas outside the secure pistes - often simply to avoid the weight of tourists.

Ernst Schöpf, mayor of the village of Sölden, near the site of this weekend's deaths, was reduced to shaking his head in despair. "What more can we do to persuade mad skiers from skiing into such a dangerous pass?" he asked.

Notices had been displayed, warning that the area in question was classified as level five - the greatest danger - but these had apparently been ignored. The group was not equipped with specialist airbags, which can be inflated in the event of an avalanche to keep the skier above snow level.

Mayor Schöpf's frustrations are shared by alpine governments, who have developed a complex network of warning and prevention systems which seem utterly impotent in the face of a single overadventurous skier.

Last year, authorities in the Tyrol alone spent more than £12m maintaining a safety system that includes bombing mountaintops with heavy explosives, dropped from aeroplanes, in order to trigger controlled snowslides, along with an infrastructure of automatic weather stations, websites with cameras primed on the mountaintops, and tranceivers which off-piste skiers are required to carry.

Global warming may be playing a role, too. Some blame climate change for the avalanches of last winter, when some parts of the Alps received almost four times their average snowfall. Temperatures fluctuated wildly, and heavy wet snow fell on top of newly settled lighter snow - a fatal recipe.

But there is another side to the story, one that implicates cash-hungry developers in previously small alpine towns and villages. In the late 1970s, a strict system of danger-zone planning was introduced in the Austrian mountains, in which zones were colour-coded yellow - fairly risky, only rarely to be built on - and red: highly risky, and never to be built on.

Since then, though, the pressure to increase accommodation in the Alps has risen as winter tourism has boomed, leading to a trend towards what has been called "zoning with one eye closed".

In one case, in the early 1990s, of 130 houses found to be in the red zone near Salzburg, half had been built since the zones were introduced. Kaprun, a village in the shadow of Austria's Kitzsteinhorn glacier, now has accommodation for 14,000 people. Sure enough, avalanches in these burgeoning areas have begun to hit chalets and houses where once they struck only skiers on the most remote slopes.

At Galtür, in 1999, amid impending local elections, the tourist trade had become a political football, and the valley where the 38 died stood to lose £5m annually if tourists stayed away. Some suggested this had led to a downplaying of safety warnings and building regulations.

We may never know whether this Sunday's victims of a spate of avalanches in Austria lived for hours, or merely seconds, after the wall of snow consumed them. A group from Mannheim in Germany, attracted by knee-deep powder snow near Obergurgl, strayed off the main slopes in search of adventure. Two more avalanches would be reported later in the day. A few hours later, with two of the German group found dead, the Tyrol began mourn its first avalanche victims of the season. The number of confirmed victims of the weekend's avalanches now stands at four. These are entries on a list that seems to be growing faster by the year, as the perils of avalanches impress themselves ever deeper on the public imagination. It is a terrifying litany of deaths, even taking into account only the last two winters: the toll of 38 near Galtür in Austria; the 23 skiers killed last December, when avalanches thundered down from the mountains near Ischgl; the six tourists who died in two snowslides in Switzerland and Italy in February, one of them caused when a German man and his son ventured off into deep snow; the 11 deaths at Kaprun in March, when a group of ski instructors from across Europe were obliterated by an avalanche 150ft wide. And then there are the countless deaths, in ones and twos, that rarely merit even a sentence in the local newspapers, unless they happen to be friends of Prince Charles. From the recklessness of individual daredevils accidentally dislodging slabs of hard-packed snow to global warming, it is too simplistic to dismiss this weekend's deaths as an act of God. webTitle: Letter: Frightners for motorists

fields.headline: Frighteners
fields.trailText: I enjoyed Ian Traynor's piece about Moscow's gangster GAI police (Highway robbery - Russian style, November 18). However Moscow is not the only place where such types instil fear and rob motorists. Here they are called "traffic wardens" and councils who use CCTV cameras illegally.
fields.body:
I enjoyed Ian Traynor's piece about Moscow's gangster GAI police (Highway robbery - Russian style, November 18). However Moscow is not the only place where such types instil fear and rob motorists.

Here they are called "traffic wardens" and councils who use CCTV cameras illegally. Last March I was caught on a CCTV camera which the traffic appeals adjudicator ruled Croydon council was using illegally. I paid my £40 fine, as did tens of thousands of others. Despite appeals, the council refuses to return the illegally purloined fines.

It's not the price of petrol that is the motorists' bane - it's greedy councils like Croydon and the nightmare of finding somewhere to park.
Harry Bramson
London

webTitle: Arts: Monster-actor Lon Chaney

fields.headline: Warts and all
fields.standfirst: How Lon Chaney, Man of a Thousand Faces, brought a more human side to the movie monster. By Ronald Bergan
fields.trailText: How Lon Chaney, Man of a Thousand Faces, brought a more human side to the movie monster. By Ronald Bergan.
fields.body:
In Hollywood in the 1920s, director Marshall Neilan gave this warning to a studio workman whose foot was poised over a spider: "Don't step on it: it may be Lon Chaney." Chaney's reputation as the Man of a Thousand Faces, an actor who could metamorphose into a vast array of monsters, was everywhere.

For his most famous role in The Phantom of the Opera (1925) - the make-up for which was kept secret during the shooting - Chaney designed a device that, when inserted in the nose, tilts the tip and spreads the nostrils. Prongs attached to protruding false teeth pulled his mouth back at the corners. "Feast your eyes - glut your soul on my accursed ugliness," says the Phantom as he removes his mask.

But, as Orson Welles said, "Chaney was a great deal more than a make-up artist. He was an actor of great power." Of all the so-called horror stars, Chaney reigns supreme. His acting range was wider and more naturalistic than Boris Karloff's or Bela Lugosi's.

His transformation scenes were most often executed with no make-up changes and without the aid of trick photography. According to the writer Ray Bradbury, "Chaney acted out our psyches: he somehow got into the shadows inside our bodies.

He was able to nail down some of our secret fears and put them on the screen." (Bradbury is quoted in Kevin Brownlow's illuminating documentary Lon Chaney - A Thousand Faces, to be premiered as part of the Lon Chaney season at the National Film Theatre.)

Principally, he created roles with a masochistic relish implicit in the title. In He Who Gets Slapped (1924), Chaney is a circus clown whose nightly routine is to be slapped and humiliated, and who has fallen hopelessly in love with the bareback rider (Chaney's love was always unrequited).

He reversed the expression "One must suffer to be beautiful", by suffering in the pursuit of ugliness. In The Penalty (1920), he plays a legless gangster seeking revenge against society because a surgeon botched an operation. He decides to cut off another man's legs and have them grafted onto his own. For the part, Chaney had to walk on leather stumps, binding his ankles to his thighs and cutting off the circulation.

"Every moment before the camera was one of excruciating agony," he recalled, "yet I must not let it show in my face. I had to be the character I was portraying, and disregard the pain. I could only wear the harness 10 minutes at a time, as the pain soon became intolerable, but after a brief rest I'd put it on again and go on with the scene. I've never gotten over the strain that I was put to in this picture. In fact, every grotesque character I've played on the screen has taken its toll of me, physically."

For The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1923), Chaney wore a hump modelled from 40lb of rubber. The burden of carrying that extra weight was almost unbearable. "There were times when I felt that I simply could not go on," Chaney admitted. "Another terrible feature of the part was that Quasimodo has an ugly wart on his eye. I had my right eye covered for so many weeks that I had spasms in it and have been forced to wear glasses."

In a way, Chaney's films are anti-horror movies, because they urge the spectator not to be repulsed by the deformed characters he portrays. In The Blackbird (1926), he plays two brothers; in a reverse of the Jekyll and Hyde theme, the physically straight man is crooked, and the physically crooked man is good.

"I wanted to remind people that the dwarfed, misshapen beggar of the streets may have the noblest ideals," explained Chaney. "I have come in actual contact with such people, the underdogs, the very dregs of humanity.

"When you see a deformed, wretched creature, you instinctively shrink from him. Your children are afraid of him. Older boys may mock and taunt him. But what do you know of him, really? If I have given one person a feeling of brotherly love, of sympathy and understanding for the downtrodden creatures of the earth, I feel well repaid for all that I went through."

Born Leonidas F Chaney on April Fool's Day, 1883 in Colorado Springs, Chaney was the son of deaf-mute parents. Lon didn't speak for the first four years of his life, having learned only sign language. He had to leave school aged nine to look after his mother, who had become bedridden, crippled by rheumatism and could no longer use her hands to communicate. Her son developed his pantomimic skills trying to convey the day's events to her.

Before entering movies, Chaney started in show business as a dancer and comedian. At 23, while playing in a musical comedy, he met the 16-year-old singer Cleva Creighton. They married three months after Cleva gave birth to a son called Creighton (later to become the horror-movie actor Lon Chaney Jr).

According to Chaney Jr, "I was born dead. My mother gave birth to me after seven months. My father was the midwife. He took me to the edge of a frozen lake, broke the ice and dipped me in it and brought me to life."

The marriage was a tempestuous one: Cleva was a flirt, Lon a jealous man. In a melodramatic suicide attempt, Cleva drank a vial of poison backstage during one of the shows. She damaged her vocal chords and her singing career was finished. Their relationship ended in divorce in 1914.

Chaney's film career began in 1913, but his breakthrough success came in 1919 with The Miracle Man, where he played a beggar pretending to be paralysed so he could be cured by the charlatan of the title.

The director, George Tucker, wanted to get a contortionist who was also an actor, but Chaney convinced him that he was double-jointed. After Chaney became a star, he persuaded MGM to hire director Tod Browning; it was the beginning of a hideous friendship. They made eight horror movies together between 1925 and 1929, although the term would not be coined until after Chaney's death.

The first Chaney-Browning picture was The Unholy Three (1925); Chaney spends much of the film in drag as a kindly old lady whose baby grandchild is actually a midget. The two are working with a circus strong man as jewel thieves. The Unknown (1927), one of their best films together, was also one of the most bizarre and macabre.

Chaney plays Alonzo the Armless, who throws knives with his feet in a circus. Actually a fake - his arms are hidden - he falls for Joan Crawford, the bareback rider (yes, another one), who hates being touched by men. Mistaking her sympathy for love of him, he has his arms amputated only to find she has fallen for the strong man.

Burt Lancaster said that the moment when Chaney discovers that he had done the horrible deed to no avail was "the most compelling scene I've ever seen an actor do".

Chaney, who said that "between films there is no Lon Chaney", added to his mystique by avoiding publicity. He resisted sound for as long as he could, feeling that his voice would dispel the mystery. He spoke for the first and only time on screen in the remake of The Unholy Three (1930); playing a ventriloquist, he is billed as The Man With a Hundred Golden Voices. The rest is silence.

In a twist of fate worthy of one of his films, Chaney suffered from bronchial cancer and was forced to revert to mime in his last days, communicating with his second wife (Hazel Hastings, whom he married in 1915) and son in sign language. He had been slated to star in Browning's Dracula, but in 1930, just before filming began, he died aged 47. He is buried in Forest Lawn cemetery in Glendale, California, in an unmarked crypt.

 The Lon Chaney season is at the National Film Theatre, London SE1 (020-7928 3232), until December 29. Kevin Brownlow's documentary Lon Chaney - A Thousand Faces is screened on December 3.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: File On 4 | Evening Concert
fields.body:
When General Pinochet dodged that Spanish warrant nine months ago and flew to Chile, there was a widespread belief that his return would galvanise the extreme right who supported his regime. In fact, as Maurice Walsh reports for File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4), the national reaction to his arrest seems to have veered the other way. The army has acknowledged its part in the atrocities and many officers now face trial. Could there be a happy ending after all?

Nicolas Tresilian combines today's anniversary of Henry Purcell's death with tomorrow's celebration of the patron saint of music in choosing works for the Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM). His first recording has Robert King directing six star soloists and the King's Consort in a performance of Purcell's splendid Ode For St Cecilia's Day. That is followed by Benjamin Britten's 1942 setting of WH Auden's poem, Hymn to St Cecilia.

Nicolas Tresilian combines today's anniversary of Henry Purcell's death with tomorrow's celebration of the patron saint of music in choosing works for the Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM). His first recording has Robert King directing six star soloists and the King's Consort in a performance of Purcell's splendid Ode For St Cecilia's Day. That is followed by Benjamin Britten's 1942 setting of WH Auden's poem, Hymn to St Cecilia.

webTitle: Corrections and clarifications

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.body:
In a report headed Stranger than fiction, pages 2 and 3, G2, November 16, about Florida and its way with elections, we said that Carol Roberts, a member of the Palm Beach electoral board, was forced to step down after being charged with ballot-tampering. In fact, she defended herself against the charges and was vindicated. The attempt to unseat her was therefore unsuccessful. In the same piece we said "a man in south-central Florida was charged with shooting his dog because he suspected it of being gay". The reporter who covered the case says the dog, a neutered Yorkshire terrier-poodle cross, was not shot but struck on the head with a plastic piece of a vacuum cleaner, because the owner believed he was attempting an unnatural act with a Jack Russell terrier. The blow fractured the dog's skull and a local veterinary surgeon put the dog down. The dog's owner was sentenced to six months in prison, a term now nearing its end. Finally, Ocala is in north-central Florida, rather than south-central [Thanks to Rick Cundiff of the Ocala Star-Banner].

Contrary to what we said in a report headed Paris bailiffs on trail of rent-shy aristocrat, page 23, November 17, Henri d'Orleans, the comte de Paris, is not a direct descendant of Louis XIV, the Sun King. Louis XIV's branch of the House of Bourbon became extinct in the late 19th century. Henri d'Orleans belongs to the House of Orleans (which produced only one French king, Louis-Philippe I).

The top rate for prostitutes in the red light district of Amsterdam, according to a television review, page 22, G2, yesterday, is 1,000 guilders or £30 "per trick". In fact, 1,000 guilders is closer to £300. What the reviewer intended to say was that the top rate was about £30 and that the prostitute would therefore get about 1,000 guilders from 10 men.

Not really a homophone, from an account of life in the floods, page 8, November 18, "Started car to venture out for provisions ... brakes have ceased, won't move."

webTitle: G2: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Cheshire
fields.trailText: Cheshire
fields.body:
Walking through the village at present does make one wonder what has happened to the seasons. Whereas sycamore and horse chestnut have shed their leaves, most of the oaks, ash, and especially alders are only now beginning to change into their autumn colours, and the gardens and hanging baskets outside some of the cottages are still bright with flowering roses, impatiens dahlias and geraniums.

We could still be in early October instead of mid-November - no doubt it will all change with the first frosts. Like so much of the farmland, the large town field has been unable to cope with all the rain over the past weeks - it has soaked up as much as it can and now a large lake has appeared, providing yet another playground for the wandering flocks of black-headed gulls.

Our extended autumn must have been a welcome sight for the thrushes from eastern Europe who arrive each October to spend the winter here, and with their main source of food being the autumn berries, this year's bumper crop will keep them happy for some considerable time.

The hawthorns and the rowans are especially well loaded with heavy clusters of red fruit. In recent weeks there has been a noticeable increase in the blackbird population, and although when they first arrive redwings are discreet and retiring, small flocks of these handsome birds have also become a familiar sight overhead. The size of these wintering flocks will gradually increase as birds move in from the east, and a large part of this migration happens at night when the thin "seep" call notes of the redwing can often be heard as they pass over in the darkness.

webTitle: Women: Sidelines

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Just when it looked as if Elton John was going to steal all the headlines on conspicuous consumption, Sidelines is heartened to see there are still some women who know the value of (spending) money.
fields.body:
Just when it looked as if Elton John was going to steal all the headlines on conspicuous consumption, Sidelines is heartened to see there are still some women who know the value of (spending) money. Weddings don't come cheap these days, after all, particularly when you're Catherine Zeta Jones and need at least £100,000 for a frock, a quarter of a mil for the wedding breakfast and - beat this, Elton - £300,000 for flowers.

Still, it's good to see our Catherine has not forgotten her Welsh roots. While the groom reportedly sloped off after the ceremony to have a cigar with the boys, the bride was shaking her expensively clad booty on the dance floor to the cheese-grater strains of Bonnie Tyler's Total Eclipse of the Heart and (apparently a particular favourite) Ashford and Simpson's tub-thumping classic, Solid as a Rock. All that cash just to recreate a girls' night out in Mumbles circa 1985.

Sidelines is, of course, not so superficial as to measure masculinity by size alone, but we confess our ears did prick up at new research suggesting smaller is better. "Blokes fiddle and play with them and get them out of their pockets and put them on the table," the study from Liverpool university found. "Even if they are in a briefcase, as soon as the men sit down and they see women around, out come the mobiles."

As readers will have guessed, we refer to mobile phones (what else?). "Your phone is a symbol of what you have got to offer," the study concluded, and the more minuscule the phone, the more masculine the owner. We can only guess at the significance of those phones that pop open when you press a button.

webTitle: Women: Is female masturbation still a taboo?

fields.headline: Good vibrations
fields.standfirst: Is female masturbation still the last taboo? Rowan Pelling reports
fields.trailText: Is female masturbation still the last taboo? Rowan Pelling reports.
fields.body:
Stuff the American elections; the big news of the weekend was the UK sex aid industry's announcement that it has founded a trade organisation and is applying to the British Standards Institution so its products can carry the Kitemark. A little late in the day for some punters since, according to Channel 4's A Girl's Best Friend (to be screened tonight as part of its Hidden Love series), 2m vibrators were sold in the UK last year.

This equals the total sales of washing machines and tumble dryers and means that, when you take into account the number of housewives who use the fast spin setting for a knee-trembler, 4m quivering electrical appliances were sold to a grateful British public in 1999 - though only half of them will guarantee your safety.

Unfortunately, the programme does little to enlighten us on the veiled world of vibrator use. It implies that most purchasers are women, but gives no evidence to back this up (the largest collection I ever saw belonged to a male journalist) and there are no statistics on the amount of vibrators bought by men for women, or by gay men. A quick wander down Brewer Street in Soho does not dispel the idea that it's middle-aged men who still number highest among the vibrator-buying public.

This lack of hard information may not be the programme-makers' fault, however, as Kathryn Hoyle, owner of the Sh! Women's Erotic Emporium in Islington, north London, explains. "The reason there are no statistics for vibrator sales is that the DTI doesn't compile figures for the sex industry," she says, which is careless when you consider the sums of money involved. Hoyle sells "thousands and thousands" of vibrators every year to her mainly female clientele (men are allowed in only if accompanied by a woman). Hoyle says Sh! shoppers are "a real cross section, though the largest group are in their 30s and 40s" which is when she says women start to feel more confident about their desires.

Despite her booming sales, however, Hoyle is convinced that the subject of female masturbation is still taboo, citing Jonathan Green's Dictionary of Contemporary Slang which has 12 pages of terms for male manual relief and only one for women. Magazines such as Cosmopolitan and Company are almost always tilted towards partner satisfaction, she points out, so that masturbation is something a man does to a woman or a woman does for a man. "They are terrified of showing a lonely, sad single person who might look as if they can't get the real thing."

The truth is, of course, that many of us are sad and single for large periods of our life. When Cosmopolitan ran a feature on single women and sex aids which featured merchandise from Sh!, Hoyle was inundated with requests - something that hadn't happened in response to partner-based pieces. She sold 600 of the vibrators she recommended ("Jessica") in 10 days. She thinks the article gave legitimacy to many single women's need to assuage sexual frustration.

Dr Petra Boynton, a psychologist who has researched the portrayal of women and sex in the media, is equally convinced that women are traditionally cast in the role of nurturer in the bedroom and that this makes it hard for them to adapt to the monomaniacal pleasure a vibrator offers. Boynton thinks most women still see sexual activity as being something you do to pleasure the man and that "women don't have the strategies" to claim pleasure for themselves. If you've been telling your partner he's hot stuff for 10 years, she argues, you're not suddenly going to change your tune and tell him he can't reach the parts a vibrator can.

Despite Boynton's and Hoyle's sage words, I remain uncertain that the topic of women and masturbation is still a great taboo. We are, after all, 30 years on from the first Hite report which covered the subject in extravagant detail and are inundated with erotic fantasies from female pens such as Nancy Friday or any of the Black Lace stable.

And it's a good 10 years or more since Betty Dodson released her female self-help masturbation video, Self-Loving, to aid orgasmically challenged women everywhere. Furthermore, our antecedents left evidence of licentious behaviour which suggests you can't keep a good woman down. Take the dancing girls of Ancient Greece who have been depicted amusing themselves with improbably large dildos.

And those who visit the Museum of Ancient Chinese Sexual Culture in Shanghai, according to the Erotic Print Society's Illustrated Book of Gadgets, will find "a battery of antique phalluses in stone, jade and ivory from Europe, Asia and Africa as well as China itself". The authors admit the precise function of these phalluses remains unproven, but argue: "You can't tell us that any self-respecting Tang Dynasty housewife could keep a giant stone cock on the mantelpiece for more than a week without taking it down, slapping on a bit of pig fat and hopping aboard."

Perhaps the twin topics of female masturbation and vibrators are not so much taboo as ghettoised: perfectly appropriate for hen parties, Cosmo and Ibiza, but not for dinner parties, the Spectator or BBC dramas. Television takes its lead from the movies.

I asked the film critic Anne Billson if she could remember any mainstream films that featured women masturbating or the appearance of a vibrator. The only one she could think of was Parenthood, in which one of Dianne Wiest's on-screen kids locates a torch during a power cut and it transpires to be Wiest's vibrator: cue embarrassment all round.

Conversely, on the male masturbation front, we quickly rounded up Ben Stiller's jism in hair shot for There's Something About Mary, Vince Vaughn jerking off as he spies on his victim in the remake of Psycho, and pretty much all of the dysfunctional male characters in American Beauty and Happiness.

A Girl's Best Friend presents the vibrator as women's key fight-back weapon in the sex war, the tool that will help them express their sexuality and release them from inhibitions. As evidence, six women talk enthusiastically about their favourite sex toys while sitting coyly on their beds, and the director ensures that no cliche is left unturned as she intercuts interviews with shots of a faceless woman in fluffy mules traipsing round a house in which every draining board, mouse-mat or teatray boasts a large, fluorescent vibrator.

The implication is that this is a female utopia in which women can finally claim their tally of multiple orgasms - but I couldn't help wondering what we'd make of a similar film about men who owned blow-up dolls or vibrating pussies. Not very much, I think.

The truth is that masturbation is a secret pleasure for both men and women, not something you share with your mates down the pub. And as for sex aids, they can act as vital substitutes for sex and can augment the sexual experience when used by couples, but as any fule kno: they're no replacement for the real thing.

 A Girl's Best Friend is screened on Channel 4 tonight at 10.30. Rowan Pelling is editor of the Erotic Review.

webTitle: Women: Leanda de Lisle on feather hats

fields.headline: Killer queen
fields.standfirst: Her Maj wraps her hands around a pheasant's neck and the nation is aghast. Leanda de Lisle wonders why
fields.trailText: Her Maj wraps her hands around a pheasant's neck and the nation is aghast. Leanda de Lisle wonders why.
fields.body:
In the rainforests, there are tribesmen who wear feathers in their hair, just as the Queen wears them in her hat. I'm uncertain how the tropical birds killed by these tribesmen meet their end. However, I'm fairly sure it's not in an abattoir subject to EU regulations. Doubtless there are some women who think this "savage", but such people are the ineffably twee products of a decadent society.

God save the queen from the Hyacinth Buckets with their propensity to go around "civilising" anybody who fails to buy their meat from supermarkets or serve drumsticks without doilies.

There she is, poor woman, 74 years of age, spending the weekend on her ancestral lands at Sandringham, when the busybodies of the press turn up and spot one of her Labradors picking up a wounded bird. Will she rush it to the local infirmary? The Queen gently takes the bird out of the dog's mouth and ... wrings its neck. Shock! Horror!

It is not exactly news that the Queen approves of field sports. It is not exactly news that the Queen goes to the lavatory. But to see her doing something as basic as killing a bird is as novel and shocking as watching her take her tights down.

To some it seemed quite disgusting. But in the countryside the only criticism I have heard has centred on whether the Queen killed the bird in the best possible way. I know a gamekeeper who swears that the most efficient method of dispatching a wounded pheasant is to put it in your mouth and crack its skull with your teeth.

A Sunday paper spread of the Queen with a bird hanging from her mouth could have triggered an uprising. We'd have seen the housewives of Middle England leaving their plates of chicken tikka masala and heading for Norfolk waving their forks threateningly above their heads. By now the poor Queen might have been stuffed and placed in a museum.

I don't think even Robin Hanbury-Tennison, of the Survival Trust, would have been able to save her. He tells me he's finding it a great deal easier trying to save the disappearing tribes of the rainforests than it was to defend British field sports as chairman of the Countryside Alliance. Women like exotic tribes (all those lovely bangles). They loathe those involved in shooting.

It's not that the average suburban woman has any moral objection to birds being killed. She just feels, very strongly, that helping our feathered friends flap off into the hereafter should be the exclusive preserve of two groups: the employees of slaughterhouses and domestic cats. People with guns and the women who associate with them are beyond the pale. This has something to do with class hatred and a horror of violence, but rather more with straightforward squeamishness.

In Britain, the vast majority of us are three generations removed from the countryside. More and more women are becoming vegetarians and the last thing the remaining meat-eaters want is to be reminded that that thing on their plate ever had a face, or feet, or anything else that suggests it may once have moved about.

Our supermarkets sell flesh in absorbent packaging, so that no free blood is visible. It is uniform in appearance and certainly has no beaks or suchlike attached. Cheap, mass-produced meat fits the bill and is more popular than that from expensively raised animals. A McNugget seems more civilised than raw breast, just as raw breast seems more civilised than a bird being strangled - and by the Queen, of all people.

Whatever tribesmen may get up to in the rainforests, they live far away. The Queen is in every home. She is on stamps and in people's dreams. Now she's going to be in the nation's nightmares, too, her feathered headdress taunting the twee for days and nights to come.

webTitle: G2: Dea Birkett on child abuse

fields.headline: Why little boys are not sex offenders
fields.trailText: Yesterday the NSPCC published a report which should horrify every adult. Child Maltreatment in the United Kingdom surveyed almost 3,000 18-24-year-olds about how they were treated as children. One in 10 said they were forced or threatened into sex acts against their will before reaching 16.
fields.body:
Yesterday the NSPCC published a report which should horrify every adult. Child Maltreatment in the United Kingdom surveyed almost 3,000 18-24-year-olds about how they were treated as children. One in 10 said they were forced or threatened into sex acts against their will before reaching 16.

Only 14% of this abuse was said to be carried out by the person we would most readily point a finger at - the father. The most frequent culprit was, it was claimed, another child.

It is a phenomenal claim. Look around your children's class. According to this report, at least one of those schoolboy faces struggling with his five times table masks a sex offender. Then turn your eye towards your own sitting room. The child most likely to abuse your daughter is the boy watching the Tweenies with her. Forty three per cent of abuse was said to be perpetrated by a sibling. It's no longer big brother, but little brother we have to watch out for.

It is not surprising that the report's findings show physical abuse to be seven times more prevalent than sexual abuse. But the coverage has focused almost entirely on the sexual element. This focus on child-on-child sex abuse has arisen from exactly the same professional quarters that introduced us to the atrocities of adult sex offenders.

But you cannot and should not apply the same judgments and analysis to children's behaviour. A seven-year-old showing his willy to a four-year-old is not the same thing as a 40-year-old man flashing at a woman in the park.

Kiss chase in the playground is not a form of indecent assault. It's a game, even if occasionally an unwelcome or unwanted one. The intention, understanding, meaning and effect are entirely different.

The respondents to the survey endorsed this. They identified the most distressing form of abuse by far as not sexual nor even physical abuse, but bullying.

Of course, not all children's activities are harmless, but some are more harmless than others. The report encompasses a wide range of actions that could count as sexual abuse, from kissing and cuddling to forcible oral and penetrative sex.

What inevitably happens is that overall terrifying statistics are quoted, then, as an example, an incidence of the most extreme kind is given. The London Young Abusers Centre cites oversexualised five-year-olds, sexually abusive 11-year-olds, 14-year-old rapists and even sexual homicides. The impression is that a huge number of young teenagers are buggering little boys.

Yet even according to the NSPCC's own calculations, the more extreme examples only make up a small minority of the abusive actions that actually occur. The commonest form of sexual contact was "exposed their sex organs or other private parts of their body to you in order to shock you or excite themselves"; by far the least common was anal intercourse.

I hope this report's intention is to alert us to an under-reported problem. But my concern is, as with the attention given to "stranger danger" after the murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne last summer, it will not make us more alert; it will simply make us more fearful. We will redirect our suspicion away from adult males to our own children. Brothers and sisters sharing baths, helping each other to dress, even showing each other their genitals will be revisited with an over anxious eye.

The case of 11-year-old Raoul Wuthrich, who was accused by a watchful neighbour in Colorado, US, of touching his five-year-old sister "in an inappropriate way" while helping her to pee in the garden, is a sign of just such presumptions. The case against him eventually collapsed.

There is one more worrying aspect of the report. It automatically assumes that the respondent is a victim, not a perpetrator. Of the 213 questions in the survey, not a single one asked the interviewee if he or she had ever committed abuse as a child. It all happens to you, and is never done by you. So who are these children who sexually abuse others of a similar age? The answer is simple: it wasn't you, and it certainly isn't your child. It's somebody else's family; somebody else's problem.

You should be afraid. You should be very afraid. But the fear should not be of our children, or those of our next-door neighbour, or the stranger's son with the lousy hair who lives up the street. We should be afraid that childhood has become the latest landscape to be invaded by often misrepresented statistics that can fill even the most stalwart and sensible parent with terror.

There is a real problem of child physical abuse. There is terrible emotional neglect. There is even some sexual abuse by children of children. Let's tackle it. But let's not try and make cheap points for our own ends and not the wellbeing of damaged children. It only makes us worry far more and helps far less towards solving the real problems.

webTitle: G2: The Fujimori-Montesinos political scandal

fields.headline: Best of enemies
fields.standfirst: President Fujimori of Peru and his secret service chief were so close they were known as 'the twins'. But their 10-year rule has crumbled, leaving the spymaster on the run and Fujimori out of power. By Alex Bellos and Jane Diaz-Limaco
fields.trailText: President Fujimori of Peru and his secret service chief were so close they were known as 'the twins'. But their 10-year rule has crumbled, leaving the spymaster on the run and Fujimori out of power. By Alex Bellos and Jane Diaz-Limaco .
fields.body:
Wearing a black leather jacket and lemon tie with a print of tiny leopards, President Alberto Fujimori of Peru looked like an extra from the television show Miami Vice as he swept out of his presidential palace into a cavalcade of police Jeeps.

The convoy drove straight out of Lima, through the old centre and past working-class districts of tyre repairers and welding workshops. By the time they reached the winter holiday resort of Chaclacayo, where wealthy Peruvians have ranch-style residences overflowing with bougainvillaea, dozen of journalists and TV crews were in hot pursuit.

Fujimori hopped out of his jeep and with officers and sniffer dogs swooped on a walled private housing estate. Two hours later he emerged. Perched on a police car and shouting through a hand-held loud-hailer, he told the press that his lightning raid had failed to capture the country's most wanted man.

Vladimiro Montesinos was still at large. He might have been talking about his worst enemy, rather than the old friend and right-hand man who, as head of Peru's feared secret service, the Sin, had helped to keep him in power: the pair had ben so close they were known as the Siamese twins.

Four weeks on, Fujimori's very public manhunt can be seen as the last gasp of a dying regime. The search now reads as the final eccentric chapter in the career of Latin America's longest-serving leader after Fidel Castro. Early yesterday, Fujimori announced from a hotel in Japan that he would resign the presidency within 48 hours.

It was an ignominious end to a controversial political era. Since his election victory over the writer Mario Vargas Llosa in 1990, Fujimori had won plaudits for taming hyperinflation and eliminating the threat of leftwing guerrillas. He had reduced inflation to single digits, made peace with Ecuador after several wars, and significantly reducing both coca cultivation and cocaine trafficking.

But his demagogic style was often undemocratic and hundreds, if not thousands, of innocent people were jailed. And Montesinos was in the background, exercising control over large parts of the country's media, courts and military. It seems unlikely that Fujimori would have been re-elected earlier this year without his friend's help. But it was precisely this string-pulling that plunged Fujimori's rule into freefall.

The collapse began in September, when clandestine footage that appeared to show the spymaster offering £10,000 in cash to an opposition politician reached the television networks. The video was the strongest evidence so far that Fujimori's election victory may have been bought.

Attempting to win back control of the ensuing crisis, Fujimori announced new elections in which he would not stand and said he would close the SIN - signalling, for the first time, a split with his top adviser.

The focus immediately turned to the secret service chief, considered by many to be the real power in Peru. How would he react? The military was run by friends, hand-picked by him. Would heinitiate a coup?

The violence never came. In the political vacuum that followed, thousands of Peruvians took to the streets to celebrate what they believed would be the end of Fujimori's regime. A few days later, Montesinos fled to Panama. With Montesinos in exile, Fujimori could at least maintain the appearance that he was in control. He began to dismantle the secret service. But on Sunday October 22 there was bad news: Montesinos was flying back, his bid for asylum refused.

In desperation, Fujimori called Guayaquil airport in Ecuador, where Montesinos's plane had stopped to refuel, and urged him to stay away. But within hours he landed at Pisco, a small military airport three hours south of Lima. The political temperature immediately shot from hot to boiling point. One of Fujimori's vice-presidents resigned in disgust. With no option but to show force, Fujimori, according to media reports, sent out an order to capture Montesinos "dead or alive".

Montesinos was then charged with a string of offences ranging from paramilitary killing and torture to money laundering and extortion. Plastic surgeons were threatened with prison if they helped the fugitive disguise himself. The cat-and-mouse search was played out as a combination of spy thriller and high farce. It transfixed Peruvians who, shocked by the revelations of the extent of Montesinos's power, realised that they were witnessing the endgame of Fujimori's regime.

A fortnight ago, Fujimori orchestrated another high-publicity stunt, holding a press conference to parade the haul of a police raid on the home of Montesinos's estranged wife, Trinidad Becerra, in an apartment on one of Lima's busiest avenues, Javier Prado.

The president joked that getting into Becerra's apartment was more difficult than getting into the Japanese embassy - the scene of a four-month rebel siege that ended in 1997. On a green velvet cloth were laid out six gold watches encrusted with diamonds and three heavy gold chains.

The raid also yielded 120 Italian and French-made suits, more than 1,200 Christian Dior shirts (hundreds each in white, cream and pale blue), coloured silk shirts, dozens of French ties, gold cuff-links and tie pins and 16 pairs of Italian crocodile shoes.

Montesinos's dandyish wardrobe was a surprising insight into a man who has cultivated almost complete media invisibility. The tall 56-year-old lawyer, who brushes the little hair he has left over his pate, has rarely been photographed.

Journalists have for the first time been allowed into the SIN headquarters where he used to live, protected by 800 elite police agents. Above the front door of the building, with its neat patio and smart gardens, is a shield with the inscription "In pursuit of knowledge".

The prime minister, Federico Salas, last week said that a corridor leading to underground cells had been discovered behind a bricked-up wall inside. He said it was not clear whether these had been used to torture detainees. "They are barred, but not spinechilling; they are not dark and they even have air-conditioning."

A former intelligence agent, Leonor La Rosa, has alleged that she was held in the basement of another intelligence service building and tortured by fellow agents for passing on information to the press. La Rosa was left disabled and is suing the government.

Many people believe that the chase was nothing but a deceptive game of good cop-bad cop. Asked about the level of complicity between Montesinos and Fujimori, Jaime Salinas Sedo, a retired general, says: "It's very difficult for a 10-year-long marriage to be broken. They are not divorced. They are united until death. I wouldn't be surprised if Montesinos were in hiding where we least expect it, even in the government palace. I think Fujimori knows where he is and is protecting him."

Congressman Rafael Rey thinks that now the relationship is "one where they are enemies - Montesinos continues to blackmail Fujimori". Montesinos is believed to have many incriminating documents, including a birth certificate that is said to prove Fujimori was born in Japan, making him ineligible to be president.

Last week, as his control over congress crumbled, Fujimori displayed all his old unpredictability by jetting off to the Asia-Pacific summit in Brunei rather than confront his domestic crisis. Rumours circulated that he would try to seek political asylum in Malaysia.

Then he flew to Japan, where his parents were born, and where his son lives. Over the weekend, conflicting reports emerged as to why he was extending his stop-over there: he wanted to see his son, or he had a cold, or he had meetings with Japanese business men. Then, in the early hours of Sunday, a written communiqué was issued in Tokyo, stating that Fujimori would resign in 48 hours.

Japan has denied reports that Fujimori has applied for asylum. But should he return to Peru, he could find the investigations into Montesinos's affairs that have come to light over the past frantic weeks returning to haunt him too.

The Swiss justice ministry, suspecting money-laundering activities, has frozen £30m in Zurich bank accounts tied to Montesinos. Reports have also surfaced alleging that Montesinos was a middleman for an arms deal between Jordan and a leftwing rebel group in Colombia.

In another development, Roberto Escobar, brother of the late Colombian drug cartel boss, Pablo Escobar, has alleged that Montesinos gave him $1m (£700,000) to fund his 1990 election campaign. Montesinos has not been contactable to answer these accusations.

Fujimori patently enjoyed the public humiliation of his former sidekick but the irony was that the more he discredited Montesinos the more he discredited himself, because they were so close for so long. The duo's iron-fisted rule disintegrated into a desperate scramble for authority - both men pulling each other into the same hole.

webTitle: Business: At this price? Kingfisher

fields.headline: At this price?  Kingfisher
fields.trailText: Kingfisher's shares have been staging a mini-revival over recent weeks after slumping to 343p, but investors expecting a full recovery may have some time to wait.
fields.body:
Kingfisher's shares have been staging a mini-revival over recent weeks after slumping to 343p, but investors expecting a full recovery may have some time to wait.

While it is generally agreed that the group is undervalued, a re-rating is highly unlikely until a further news on its proposed demerger.

This move, which will see the DIY and electricals side split from general merchandise, is expected to take place in the first half of next year, with some predicting April.

Meanwhile a trading statement scheduled to be released today is expected to heap more short-term misery on the group, with news of a slowdown in sales at B&Q, its DIY business.

The finger of blame is pointed by observers at the disruption caused by the fuel protests, as out of town stores became no-go areas when petrol tanks ran low.

But the recent bout of bad weather is expected to eventually help-kick start DIY sales as people begin repairing storm-damaged homes.

"There's a lot of nervousness about trading, especially at B&Q and Castorama," said one analyst. "The bad weather and the fuel protests will have damaged sales and it will be difficult for them to claw these back in the fourth quarter."

Results from Woolworths and Superdrug, two of Kingfisher's well known names, are expected to be poor, with the blame falling on a highly competitive market.

Apart from these factors, Kingfisher has done itself no favours in the presentation of the demerger plans, which appeared lacking in detail.

It is now up to chief executive Sir Geoff Mulcahy to state his case to institutional investors over the next few months.

Yesterday was a prime example of Kingfisher's volatility, with shares initially weakening 2.6% to 403.25p by mid-morning before mounting a comeback to end the session up 2.5p at 418p.

Those looking for a longer-term punt may be tempted to acquire some stock, but they certainly should not expect to make huge gains. Hold.

webTitle: TV and radio: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Mona Lisa | Deliverance | Mutiny On The Bounty | Mrs Dalloway
fields.body:
Mona Lisa

(Neil Jordan, 1986)

10pm, FilmFour

An accomplished thriller that creates a touching, doomed romance in a menacing London: we're talking prostitution, drugs, blackmail. Little Bob Hoskins gives a giant performance as ex-con George, reduced to chauffeuring Cathy Tyson's West End call-girl. An unlikely relationship blossoms as they search a grubby underworld for her young hooker friend (Kate Hardie). Michael Caine is perfectly sleazy as the vice-king, but it's Hoskins, in silly sunglasses and out of his depth on the pier, who lingers in the memory.

Deliverance

(John Boorman, 1972)

10pm, Sky Cinema

Four city slickers go canoeing in the wild Appalachians and are sorely tested in a clash with weird, inbred backwoodsmen. Burt Reynolds is at his best leading the fight for survival, while Jon Voight sinks his liberal principles when their chum Ned Beatty is raped. It's a powerful, gut-churning adventure, with Boormanesque state-of-the-planet undercurrents.

Mutiny On The Bounty

(Frank Lloyd, 1935)

10pm, TCM

Glossy, Oscar-winning MGM treatment of the infamous 1787 mutiny, with a memorable confrontation between Charles Laughton's weak and vicious Captain Bligh and Clark Gable's Fletcher Christian. Lloyd focuses on Bligh's 3,500 mile open-boat voyage to safety, fuelled by the desire for revenge: "I'll live to see you - all of you - hanging from the highest yardarm."

Mrs Dalloway

(Marleen Gorris, 1997)

3.45am, Sky Premier

Vanessa Redgrave's Clarissa Dalloway, radiant politician's wife, is preparing for one of her famous parties, but wandering in bittersweet reveries of youthful romance: in flashback Natascha McElhone, as her younger self, is wooed by Peter (Alan Cox); and coming to the party is the mature, still ardent Peter (Michael Kitchen). Eileen Atkins's adaptation of Virginia Woolf's novel is deeply wistful and touching, in an elegantly evoked 20s London.

Little Bob Hoskins gives a giant performance as ex-con George, reduced to chauffeuring Cathy Tyson's West End call-girl. An unlikely relationship blossoms as they search a grubby underworld for her young hooker friend (Kate Hardie). Michael Caine is perfectly sleazy as the vice-king, but it's Hoskins, in silly sunglasses and out of his depth on the pier, who lingers in the memory. Deliverance (John Boorman, 1972) 10pm, Sky Cinema Four city slickers go canoeing in the wild Appalachians and are sorely tested in a clash with weird, inbred backwoodsmen. Burt Reynolds is at his best leading the fight for survival, while Jon Voight sinks his liberal principles when their chum Ned Beatty is raped. It's a powerful, gut-churning adventure, with Boormanesque state-of-the-planet undercurrents. Mutiny On The Bounty (Frank Lloyd, 1935) 10pm, TCM Glossy, Oscar-winning MGM treatment of the infamous 1787 mutiny, with a memorable confrontation between Charles Laughton's weak and vicious Captain Bligh and Clark Gable's Fletcher Christian. Lloyd focuses on Bligh's 3,500 mile open-boat voyage to safety, fuelled by the desire for revenge: "I'll live to see you - all of you - hanging from the highest yardarm." Mrs Dalloway (Marleen Gorris, 1997) 3.45am, Sky Premier Vanessa Redgrave's Clarissa Dalloway, radiant politician's wife, is preparing for one of her famous parties, but wandering in bittersweet reveries of youthful romance: in flashback Natascha McElhone, as her younger self, is wooed by Peter (Alan Cox); and coming to the party is the mature, still ardent Peter (Michael Kitchen). Eileen Atkins's adaptation of Virginia Woolf's novel is deeply wistful and touching, in an elegantly evoked 20s London.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Soaps' inconsistencies

fields.headline: Believe it or not
fields.standfirst: Last week Friends fans were up in arms after it transpired that Ross had seemingly lost his virginity twice. It's not the first example of scriptwriters getting it wrong. In fact, it happens all the time. By Matthew Baylis
fields.trailText: Last week Friends fans were up in arms after it transpired that Ross had seemingly lost his virginity twice. It's not the first example of scriptwriters getting it wrong. In fact, it happens all the time. By Matthew Baylis
fields.body:
TV fans suffered a double blow last week. Not only did Inspector Morse ascend to that great pub in the sky, but Ross Geller, neurotic star of Friends, revealed himself to be a liar. Having maintained for years that he lost his virginity to Caroline, his first wife, it now transpires that the lucky lady was someone else - a cleaner at Ross's university.

What are we to make of this inconsistency? That the first time was so dreadful, Ross simply blotted it from his memory? That Ross was raised by nuns and hence had only the shakiest grasp on what constituted a sexual act? Or did the scriptwriters just screw up?

We know the answer, of course. The illusory world created by TV shows is a fine membrane, stretched tight and constantly threatened by reality. Actors get sick and stroppy. Audiences become bored. Writers think of better ideas.

The longer a show runs, the greater the likelihood of something occurring that is inconsistent with its past. And the more popular a show, the greater the likelihood of people watching vintage episodes at the same time as fresh ones are being screened.

Friends is not the only sinner. Devotees of Cheers will know that psychiatrist-barfly Frasier Crane was an orphan. His deceased father was a scientist and his mother died during the series. But the lucrative prospect of a spin-off made the writers abandon this biography. Frasier's dad is now resurrected, a curmudgeonly ex-cop, whose values clash continually with his son's.

And nobody seems to mind. The tension between Frasier and his dad is right at the heart of the show, providing a rich vein of comedy. Petty quibbles about lines spoken in old shows are successfully drowned out by the laughter.

Viewers don't fret over details, provided that their emotions are being stretched to extremes. Frasier does it with laughter. The recent film What Lies Beneath did the same by frightening us. If Inspector Morse had ever been led to the solution of a mystery by the appearance of a ghost, then viewers would have switched off in their millions.

Writers cannot switch genres in this way - audiences will accept things in a ghost story that they will not in a thriller, and vice versa. But this, essentially, is the stunt that What Lies Beneath pulls - and it succeeds, by scaring its viewers witless for two hours.

Soap operas cannot hide behind fear and laughter. Consistency is all-important and the top British contenders employ archivists and script editors to ensure that no inaccuracies creep in. On EastEnders, the minutiae of every character's life are set in stone, from their birthday to their phone number.

That does not mean inconsistencies never occur. Sometimes details are changed deliberately, to fit in with a more important story. Take Coronation Street - Mike Baldwin's son Mark was born on April 13 1983. But on his re-entry to the Street, Mark was a full two years older than that. There were good reasons for the shift. It would have been stretching credibility far more to have the hard-headed Mike entrusting key business roles to a 17 year old.

There was no outcry about this, because the detail was buried in a colourful story about sons betraying their fathers. Soaps may not be able to perform the tricks that sitcoms and horror movies can, but they can use complex, well-drawn characters to distract us from the artificialities of the genre. That's why we accept that genteel Emily Bishop would happily sup sherry alongside Les Battersby. Or that everyone in Walford can afford the rent.

There are limits, of course. Recall the fury with which the world greeted Dallas's attempt to re- introduce Bobby Ewing. He'd been shot in series six, but due to flagging ratings, Bobby was brought back in series eight. The whole of the intervening series was explained as his wife Pam's dream. This led to some real oddities. Some people who'd been introduced during Pam's "dream" vanished. But so did Dusty - who'd been there before Bobby was shot. And Ray and Donna's house was destroyed by floods during the dream, but remained absent after Pam woke up.

But it would be wrong to blame Pam's dream for Dallas's eventual demise. The show was in ratings hell before Bobby's resurrection. The audience were already looking for an excuse to turn off. Pundits said that the shooting of Bobby was the cause, but a show's popularity never hinges on one character.

Just look at how EastEnders has continued to capture huge audiences since the departure of Grant Mitchell. In a healthy show, it is never necessary to contemplate bringing back departed characters, because fresh blood has taken their place, and captured the audience's imagination. It was the pre-existing malaise - a disaffection with the characters - more than the nuttiness of the rescue attempt, which sealed the fate of Dallas.

So the writers of Friends should be nervous. The "outcry" of fans was doubtless exaggerated in the media; and the show's ratings will probably not suffer visibly - for now. What's worrying is not what the fans noticed. It's that they noticed anything. A happy, totally entertained audience might not have made such a fuss.

webTitle: Parties in Pakistan unite against military

fields.headline: Parties in Pakistan unite against military
fields.standfirst:
Supporters of the jailed prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, split by formation of alliance to restore democracy and oust coup general

Special report: Pakistan
fields.trailText: Pakistan's biggest political parties have finally agreed to end their bitter feuding and work together to bring down the military regime which seized power in a coup more than a year ago.
fields.body:
Pakistan's biggest political parties have finally agreed to end their bitter feuding and work together to bring down the military regime which seized power in a coup more than a year ago.

The agreement caused a serious row yesterday in the ranks of the Pakistan Muslim League, the party of Nawaz Sharif, the ousted prime minister who is serving a life sentence for hijacking.

Senior members opposed to an alliance with their erstwhile opponents stormed into the party headquarters in the capital, Islamabad, ripped portraits of Mr Sharif from the wall, and burned them, cheered on by hundreds of supporters outside.

But Kulsoom Sharif, Mr Sharif's wife, is in favour of the alliance and has most of the Muslim League firmly on her side.

"I will make it a national movement so that the entire political fraternity joins hands against the military rulers for the restoration of democracy," she said.

The agreement, which aligns the League with Benazir Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party and most of the smaller political groups, comes at a difficult time for the military government. General Pervez Musharraf, the army chief who led the coup, has been struggling to revive the economy and is facing a growing chorus of criticism in the press.

Since the coup in October last year, 14 senior civilian appointees have resigned from his government The latest, last week, was his outspoken corruption prosecutor, Farouk Adam Khan.

He announced his departure after the general running the anti-corruption body, the National Accountability Bureau, was replaced.

"This has been a task of gigantic proportions," he said. "I think we made our share of mistakes, and when I approached this job I think I was naive." Mr Khan's draconian laws, under which the bureau could hold suspects for 90 days without charge, brought a barrage of criticism. He was under pressure from politicians and businessmen to ease up on his prosecutions and received death threats from corruption suspects in Peshawar, in northern Pakistan.

"The situation in Pakistan is such that only a draconian law could even begin to set right what is there for everyone to see," he said. "We are talking about a culture of corruption that is widespread and pervasive." The flood of resignations has raised questions about the freedom given to civilians to operate under military rule.

Others who have resigned include the information minister, Javed Jabbar, who was asked to quit by Gen Musharraf last month for failing to project a sufficiently positive image of the regime.

The general said at the time that nobody was indispensable and he would accept resignations from anyone.

"Selection is on merit and continuation is on performance," he said.

Gen Musharraf has been hoping to improve his government's image abroad by holding local elections, starting next month.

But a new computerised electoral rollcompiled at the cost of £7m by an agency run by one of his generals was rejected last week after it was found to be riddled with errors.

fields.headline: Passport control
fields.standfirst: Who's in town and why
fields.trailText: Who's in town and why.
fields.body:
Proper Charlie's... Should you hear the hellacious sound of a grotesque, otherworldly hiss buried beneath the terrifying creak of mass rictus grinning this week, fear not: it's just the premiere of retro chick flick Charlie's Angels, for which stars Drew Barrymore, Cameron Diaz and Lucy Liu are pitching up as you read this.

Foul and nefarious rumour, of course, has it that none of the above were actually speaking to one another by the time the end product hit the can, such was the air of epic backbiting that pervaded the set - not that we believe a word of it.

The famously choleric Bill Murray, for example, is obviously not avoiding accompanying his co-stars solely because he has something more important to do back on the ranch, and we're certain the three immaculate leading ladies were the epitome of thoughtful professionalism both during and after the shoot. Yup. That's why we'll be ducking for cover with our fingers in our ears when they turn up at the Odeon Leicester Square tomorrow night for their ritualised preening before the paparazzi.

Kiss kiss bang bang... Elsewhere, Ricky Martin - the Latin answer to Dale Winton - transports himself to the UK as of Friday morning for a three-day stint hawking his quaintly-titled single She Bangs. The erstwhile Martinez records a celebrity-laden (ie they're hoping for Chris Eubank and Denise Van Outen) TV special at Wembley's Fountain Studios on Saturday, before returning whence he came on Monday.

Moving pictures... Which, sadly, means he'll miss the arrival of Patti Smith, in town to attend next Monday's private screening of Still Moving, a short film concerning William Blake on which she collaborated with the late, great Robert Mapplethorpe. Sticking around for longer than we deserve, Smith then delivers a spoken-word tribute to Blake at central London's St James' Church the following Friday. And that's that.

webTitle: Tories dub spectrum auction a flop

fields.headline: Tories dub spectrum auction a flop
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The government yesterday was accused of presiding over "an embarrassing flop" after its much-touted auction of licences to run high-speed internet services only raised a fraction of the anticipated proceeds and left most of the licences unsold.
fields.body:
The government yesterday was accused of presiding over "an embarrassing flop" after its much-touted auction of licences to run high-speed internet services only raised a fraction of the anticipated proceeds and left most of the licences unsold.

The failure means 40% of the population could be left with web access 20 times slower than the rest of the country despite a commitment by Tony Blair to put the UK at the top of the new economy league.

The inability to dispose of more than 16 of the 42 licences up for grabs and take just £38.16m, compared with independent estimates of £1bn was attributed to the complex bidding system.

But analysts said it also underlined the new cautious attitude of the telecoms companies which have run into criticism from shareholders for running up massive debts by extravagant bidding in recent mobile phone auctions.

Patricia Hewitt, minister for e-commerce and small business, put a brave face on the latest results by pointing out that 60% of the population would be able to take advantage of a system which would provide competition to fibre optics, cable links and specialist phone lines.

She also called for an immediate investigation into the licensing round which was managed by the Radiocommunications Agency on behalf of the Department of Trade and Industry.

"This will involve talking to operators and other interested parties on how broadband fixed wireless access can be developed into a commercial proposition in all parts of the country," she said.

The Tories described the auction as a flop and said its failure would leave rural Britain to remain an e-commerce backwater. David Heathcote-Amory, shadow trade and industry secretary said: "It comes on top of the government's failure to press BT to make available the local loop to genuine competition. It blows a hole in the empty govern ment rhetoric that Britain is leading the e-commerce and internet revolution."

The provisional winners were led by Energis which took six licences including ones in London, Manchester and Scotland. Norweb took four licences and Eircom one in Northern Ireland.

In all six companies were successful out of the 10 which originally lined up for the spectrum licences in the 28GHz band. Those who left empty handed included Winstar Communications.

Even now the granting of the licences is not ensured as pre-conditions - including shareholder approval - has been given by some of the successful bidders.

The auction began on November 10 and was expected to run for at least a month following the success of the competition for next generation of mobile phone licences which raised £22.5bn. The latest auction was brought to a faltering halt last night as fresh bids failed to materialise. Each licence allows phone companies to beam streams of internet data to rooftop aerials.

Lucky six line up

Provisional licence winners:

Energis Local Access - six licences: Greater London, Greater Manchester, West Midlands, Yorkshire, Scotland and Northern Ireland

Norweb Telecoms - four licences: Greater Manchester, West Midlands, Yorkshire and North England

Faultbasic (owned by the US telecom group XO) - three licences: Greater London, Greater Manchester and West Midlands

Broadnet (owned by US cable company Comcast) - one licence: Greater London

Chorus Communication (owned by Liberty Media and Independent News and Media) - one licence: Northern Ireland

Eircom - one licence: Northern Ireland

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Sudan jet kills 10 in market attack
fields.body:
Sudan jet kills 10 in market attack

At least 10 people died and dozens more were injured when a Sudanese air force plane bombed a market in the rebel-held southern town of Yei yesterday.

An official of Norwegian People's Aid working in Yei, the largest town held by the Sudan People's Liberation Army, said the bombs apparently landed "smack in the middle of a marketplace - it was carnage."
Reuters, Nairobi

Czechs to ban French beef

The Czech Republic is about to ban imports of French and Portuguese beef and cattle from today because of growing fear of mad cow disease, according to reports from the Czech news agency CTK. Beef and cattle imports from Britain, where the disease was first detected, have been banned since 1996.
AP, Prague

Two arrested for factory fire

Police yesterday arrested the owner and manager of a South African factory where 11 people burned to death at the weekend after allegedly having been locked in for a 14-hour shift.
Reuters, Johannesburg

webTitle: Nazi camp guard on trial

fields.headline: Nazi camp guard on trial
fields.trailText: One of the last trials for alleged war crimes during the second world war began before a military tribunal in Verona yesterday. A former concentration camp guard is accused of torturing and murdering civilians.
fields.body:
One of the last trials for alleged war crimes during the second world war began before a military tribunal in Verona yesterday. A former concentration camp guard is accused of torturing and murdering civilians.

Ukrainian-born Misha Seifert, 76, who as an SS corporal was a guard at a prison camp near Bolzano in northern Italy, is charged with 18 counts of murder between December 1944 and April 1945.

Mr Seifert, now known as Michael and living in Vancouver, Canada, is not attending the trial. He faces a maximum sentence of life imprisonment, and the Canadian authorities say they are prepared to extradite or expel himif he is convicted.

The victims of his alleged sadistic behaviour were held in a transit concentration camp set up in northern Italy by the German military authorities for prisoners en route to the death camps at Mauthausen and Dachau.

Mr Seifert is accused of killing two Jewish prisoners, Giulia Leoni and her daughter Augusta: "torturing them for about two hours, pouring ice-cold water on them and finally strangling them".

It is also alleged that he killed a young Jewish woman by striking her with the necks of broken bottles and that, together with an SS officer, Otto Sein, he tortured a 17-year-old woman to death over a period of five days.

Other victims were raped, beaten to death or left to die of starvation, according to the military prosecutor.

Nella Mascagni, a former camp inmate, said Mr Seifert and his friend Sein would return drunk to the camp in the evenings "and for all of us that meant an indescribable nightmare: anyone could become a victim."

Mr Seifert is reported to have lived in Canada since the mid 1950s. He worked for more than 30 years at a Vancouver sawmill, and had one son.

The Italian authorities have acknowledged that, for reasons of political expediency, they have refrained from investigating numerous war crimes committed in Italy.
