Mr Seifert is accused of killing two Jewish prisoners, Giulia Leoni and her daughter Augusta: "torturing them for about two hours, pouring ice-cold water on them and finally strangling them". It is also alleged that he killed a young Jewish woman by striking her with the necks of broken bottles and that, together with an SS officer, Otto Sein, he tortured a 17-year-old woman to death over a period of five days. Other victims were raped, beaten to death or left to die of starvation, according to the military prosecutor. Nella Mascagni, a former camp inmate, said Mr Seifert and his friend Sein would return drunk to the camp in the evenings "and for all of us that meant an indescribable nightmare: anyone could become a victim." Mr Seifert is reported to have lived in Canada since the mid 1950s. He worked for more than 30 years at a Vancouver sawmill, and had one son. The Italian authorities have acknowledged that, for reasons of political expediency, they have refrained from investigating numerous war crimes committed in Italy.

webTitle: Iranian student faction plans civil disobedience

fields.headline: Iranian student faction plans civil disobedience
fields.trailText: Leaders of sections of the Iranian national student movement, which was largely responsible for Mohammad Khatami's rise to power, have declared his presidency a failure and are vowing to take radical action to bring about change.
fields.body:
Leaders of sections of the Iranian national student movement, which was largely responsible for Mohammad Khatami's rise to power, have declared his presidency a failure and are vowing to take radical action to bring about change.

Students in the Office to Consolidate Unity, which claims 500,000 members, accuse the president of passing up every opportunity to force the conservatives who have reasserted their control over the state to come to heel.

As a result, a growing number of campus activists want to desert Mr Khatami and form an alternative organisation to promote "civil disobedience".

That would include strikes at universities and in bazaars aimed at forcing a confrontation with the security forces, something President Khatami has tried to prevent.

"We have watched the conservatives attack civil institutions. They closed all the reformists newspapers. They shot Saeed Hajjarian [a top presidential aide who was paralysed in an attempt on his life last year]," said a student leader in the group, who did not wish to be named.

"Now we think that anyone who [subscribes] to passivity is helping the conservatives. The government should have helped political parties develop and social organisations grow," he said.

"Instead, the reform movement became too passive and moved backward."

The group, which is known in Farsi as Daftar-e Tahkim-e Vahdat, comprises Islamic student organisations on about 60 campuses.

It has been a formidable force in Iranian politics since the early days of the Islamic Revolution - its forerunners helped to bring Ayatollah Khomeini to power.

In 1996 Mohammad Khatami, an intellectual cleric then on the fringes of politics, appeared at the Daftar's headquarters in Tehran, produced a miniature constitution, and vowed to enforce the rule of law.

With that promise, the group rallied behind his presidential bid and he won by a landslide in 1997.

Since then students have sacrificed their lives in demonstrations supporting Mr Khatami's ideas of a "civil society", only to find that the president condemning their protests in order to avoid a showdown with conservatives.

When students demonstrated in July last year after conservatives closed a leading progressive newspaper, they were beaten by the police, the Islamic militia, and the elite Revolutionary Guards.

Scores were injured and an unknown number died in five days of unrest in Tehran. At the same time an even bloodier protest erupted in the town of Tabriz.

The parliament prepared a detailed report exposing the culprits of the violence in Tabriz, but sources say it remains top secret because the government fears its contents will provoke a national crisis.

The growing split in the ranks of the Daftar became public after Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, intervened in August to order parliament to quash a bill aimed at reviving the reformist press, said Ibrahim Sheikh, another student leader.

"Some students have reached the conclusion that elections don't matter and they want more radical solutions," said Mr Sheikh, who represents the half of the student movement that still supports President Khatami.

But he said that only a gradual approach to reform could bring about lasting change.

"Some say no generation can tolerate two revolutions," he said. "So the only recourse the reformers have is a peaceful atmosphere."

fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Online boost Music firm EMI Group boosted its net potential yesterday, signing access deals in Europe and the US a day before it was due to post first-half results. EMI's Recorded Music division and subscription provider US Streamwaves signed a deal under which north Americans will gain access to music over the net.
fields.body:
Online boost Music firm EMI Group boosted its net potential yesterday, signing access deals in Europe and the US a day before it was due to post first-half results. EMI's Recorded Music division and subscription provider US Streamwaves signed a deal under which north Americans will gain access to music over the net.

 Earth calling Media group Time Warner and ISP AOL said they expect to close their merger by early 2001 after extending the regulatory review for two weeks to allow it to consider a cable services link-up between Time and broadband ISP Earthlink .

 Purchase Long distance communications carrier Teleglobe said yesterday it would buy $400m (£281m) of optical networking equipment from Nortel Networks. The equipment will be used by Teleglobe to transport high-speed internet and voice traffic on its GlobeSystem networks in north America, Europe and Asia.

 Counterpunch Software supplier Baltimore Technologies and register.com , the No 2 registrar of internet domain names, yesterday announced they had forged a digital security pact in a competitive counterpunch to market leader VeriSign .

webTitle: Popo exhales behind a smokescreen

fields.headline: Popo exhales behind a smokescreen
fields.standfirst: Locals scorn warning of Mexican mega eruption
fields.trailText: Billowing plumes of sulphur dioxide, water vapour and ash have been shooting miles up into the sky from Popocatepetl's crater for weeks. But Antonio Analco has nothing but disdain for the official alert.
fields.body:
Billowing plumes of sulphur dioxide, water vapour and ash have been shooting miles up into the sky from Popocatepetl's crater for weeks. But Antonio Analco has nothing but disdain for the official alert.

"I know nothing is going to happen," he says.

Don Antonio is a shaman and rainmaker and the Mexican volcano's "spirit" comes to him in dreams, personified as an old man called Don Gregorio - Don Goyo for short.

"If Don Goyo warns me, then I'll warn everybody else. These scientists and their instruments are a big con trick."

Don Antonio's village, Santiago Xalitzintla, nestles about seven miles from the crater on the volcano's north-eastern flank. It would almost certainly be wiped out by the avalanche of sludge and acidic gases surging down the canyons at more than 60mph which is likely to accompany a major eruption, even before the lava reached it.

Geologists believe that this last happened 1,200 years ago, and none of the experts are predicting a repeat. They think Popo's huffing and puffing may intensify to the point of producing incandescent material, but they do not expect the sacred mountain of the Aztecs to blow.

But they could be wrong. The prediction that Pinatubo volcano in the Philippines would erupt in 1991 is the only significant example of accurate scientific forecasting.

"At Popo they just don't know what's going to happen, and it is not for want of trying; but it's the same problem we face with any volcano," says Jim Luhr a volcanologist from the Smithsonian Institution in Washington DC.

"What we get up to is barely a science."

So why bother trying? asks Don Rufino, standing in front of the 5,465-metre (17,930ft) symmetrical cone."If the volcano decides it's time, we won't have time to do anything about it."

He is more worried about soldiers enforcing the ban on going within six miles of the crater, which prevents villagers reaching their fields to harvest their maize.

The National Disaster Prevention Centre says that about 30,000 people living in the nearest villages are at serious risk from a major eruption. There are about 300,000 people in the second-tier danger zone, and 800,000 in the entire risk area, while the tens of millions in Mexico City to the north-west and Puebla to the east could be affected by ash clouds.

This is why Popocatepetl is the most closely monitored of Mexico's 14 active volcanoes, with a special unit in the capital to keep a 24-hour watch on it.

Instruments on the mountain relay the seismic activity caused by smoke exhalations and deep molten-rock movements, tiny increases in volume which could indicate the build-up of pressure, and changes in the the gases emitted.

"We are pretty certain to see a big one coming hours to days before it actually happens," says Enrique Guevara, the unit's coordinator, pointing to the automatic alarm systems which would give the signal to evacuate the area.

But people on the volcano are often reluctant to abandon their houses and animals.

"They can keep their shelters and their second-hand clothes. I'm not going," says Dona Ines.

She has bad memories of the last and only evacuation in December 1994, when the volcano awoke after being dormant for almost 70 years.

"The volcano is only breathing. It has always smoked," she says.

Popocatepetl smoked for the Aztecs, in whose mythology it was a torch-bearing warrior mourning his dead love - a nearby volcano called Iztaccihuatl, which resembles a reclining woman.

It smoked when the Spanish conquistador Hernan Cortes passed by on his way to the Aztec capital, and it went through several heavy puffing bouts in subsequent centuries, with the last one in 1921.

The 1994 reawakening, the scientists say, was triggered by a new injection of molten rock into the magma chamber, and the current intensification of activity is due to the formation of a lava dome inside the crater which is obstructing the regular release of energy.

But although Popocatepetl even means "smoking mountain" in the indigenous Nahuatl language, its main sacred function is its relationship to water, and it particular the pre-Colombian rain god Tlaloc.

"The conquest suppressed the large-scale rituals but the small community rites to bring rain or keep away bad weather continue until today," says Julio Glokner, an anthropologist, who has been traipsing up and down the volcano after Don Antonio and other shamans since 1989.

Every community on Popocatepetl has its traditions and every rainmaker his or her own style.

In Don Antonio's dreams Don Goyo asks for specific offerings that are carried up to mountain shrines. In recent years these have included a business suit, an accordion and a warrior costume.

Don Antonio says he would be willing to talk to the scientists in Mexico City, but "only if they are willing to listen to what I have to say too".

But it is not just the experts who are loathe to rely on the shaman's confidence that the volcano would not erupt without telling him first.

"I've been a sceptic ever since I was a little boy. I used to throw things at their rituals," says Raul Sanchez, whose family has lived for decades in Amecameca on the side of the volcano.

He has worked out his own system for understanding the clouds around the summit, and has collected ash samples to investigate the probability of a major eruption.

He believes that Popocatepetl may erupt, but not on his side of the mountain.

"I do this to see whether we really have to start running or not, and the truth is we don't."

webTitle: Obituary: Vernel Fournier

fields.headline: Vernel Fournier
fields.standfirst: Jazz drummer who mixed ensemble subtlety and rootsiness
fields.trailText: The jazz drummer Vernel Fournier, who has died of a cerebral haemorrhage aged 72, was a superb ensemble player - one of those drummers so good at complementing the leader's train of thought that an audience would be almost unaware of his crucial presence.
fields.body:
The jazz drummer Vernel Fournier, who has died of a cerebral haemorrhage aged 72, was a superb ensemble player - one of those drummers so good at complementing the leader's train of thought that an audience would be almost unaware of his crucial presence.

It was for two periods of work with the pianist Ahmad Jamal (1957-61 and 1965-66) that he will be most respectfully remembered. Jamal's music has always depended on a drummer almost telepathically capable of following his capricious imagination; his improvisations on a tune rarely establish a single mood and stick with it, but career through episodes of delicacy, ferocity, the explicit, the covert and the downright spine-chilling.

Jamal's arpeggios can thicken up so much as to border on free music. His percussionists, often obliged to be subtle hand-drummers as well as orthodox traps-players, have to keep pace with all this, and Fournier was probably his most apposite and sensitive partner.

Jack DeJohnette, the former Miles Davis drummer, has said that it was hearing Fournier on the album Ahmad Jamal At the Pershing (1958) that made him understand quiet playing and want to go out and buy a set of brushes before he even had a drumkit. On that disc, Fournier's soft, fluttering brushwork, subtle accents and pursuit of Jamal's wilful muse testify to what a modestly formidable performer Fournier was. He never loses the fundamental pulse.

Fournier was born in New Orleans. He took up drums at the age of 10, participating in that city's vibrant jazz culture through street concerts and parades. His early experiences were in traditional and swing-based jazz, studying with the drummer Sidney Montague. He went to college in Alabama, joined a student orchestra and, between 1946 and 1948, was in King Kolax's rhythm and blues band.

The sophisticated modern jazz and bebop subculture of the 1940s was mostly concentrated on the east and west coasts, but Fournier became interested in this more rhythmically oblique and improvisationally demanding style even before he left for Chicago in 1948. In 1953 he became the house drummer at a club, the Bee Hive.

Jamal, who had grown up in a free-thinking Pittsburgh musical culture that had allowed jazz and classical music to influence him equally, had also moved to Chicago. He got work at the Pershing Lounge, where, in 1957, Fournier became his regular drummer. The following year, recording for the Chess label, and with Israel Crosby on bass, the trio cut At the Pershing, one of the best-selling of all jazz records. The trio capitalised on this success, touring the US constantly. But from 1962, the worldly and practical Jamal devoted himself to running his own Alhambra club and the trio disbanded.

Fournier played with George Shearing through the mid-1960s, converted to Islam in 1975 (becoming Amir Rushdan) and moved to New York in 1979. His mix of ensemble subtlety and rootsiness made him attractive to jazz players of many persuasions, and he worked in the groups of the distinctive saxophonist Clifford Jordan, with the singer Billy Eckstine, and, sometimes, in a trio of his own.

Fournier taught drumming at Barry Harris's Jazz Cultural Theater, the New School and the Mannes College of Music. But his playing career ended with a stroke in 1994, and four years later he moved to Mississippi to join members of his family.

Fournier is survived by his daughters Taliah and Renee Howard, sons Aaron and Eric, three stepchildren and 12 grandchildren.

 Vernel Anthony Fournier (Amir Rushdan), musician, born July 30 1928; died November 4 2000

webTitle: Obituary: Mervin Glasser

fields.headline: Mervin Glasser
fields.standfirst: Leading researcher into the origins of perversion and delinquency
fields.trailText: The psychoanalyst Mervin "Chips" Glasser, who has died aged 71, brought a South African colonial vigour to his professional world. He was chairman of the Portman Clinic in north London from 1971 until his 1994 retirement, and during those years the centre, which is a National Health Service psychotherapy clinic for people with criminal and sexual behaviour problems, regained its international reputation.
fields.body:
The psychoanalyst Mervin "Chips" Glasser, who has died aged 71, brought a South African colonial vigour to his professional world. He was chairman of the Portman Clinic in north London from 1971 until his 1994 retirement, and during those years the centre, which is a National Health Service psychotherapy clinic for people with criminal and sexual behaviour problems, regained its international reputation.

Glasser was best known for his writing and teaching on the origins of delinquency and perversion. His research work included his new concept of the "core complex", formulated as a universal early developmental step with anxieties of abandonment and engulfment at early separation and individuation from the child's mother.

At the Portman, Mervin organised conferences that brought in academics from all over the world. He built links with the Institute of Psychiatry's forensic department, the Tavistock Clinic and the Home Office; with academia, particularly the London School of Economics; with London hospitals, the police, the prison service and the Inner London Probation Service. His clinical seminars on the psychotherapy of sexual deviations and delinquency became a day-release course in conjunction with the British Postgraduate Medical Federation.

Away from the Portman, Mervin lectured internationally and in many hospitals and centres in Britain. He advised the British Board of Film Classification and was a frequent consultant to government departments.

The son of a Jewish émigré businessman, Mervin was born in Johannesburg and educated at King Edward's School. From his early teens he developed an interest in functions of the mind and psychoanalysis. At the University of Witwatersrand he read psychology and created a university arts festival. He had black friends at a time when this was inconceivable to most white South Africans.

He left the country in 1952 to study psychoanalysis in London and - since at that time medical qualification was usual as a background to this - he trained at Westminster hospital medical school, graduating in 1958. He qualified as an associate member at the London Institute of Psychoanalysis in 1963 and subsequently taught his speciality there, becoming a training analyst at the institute in 1980 and director of the clinic after retiring from the Portman in 1993.

Early in his career he worked with the psychoanalyst Moses Laufer, whom Anna Freud had asked to inaugurate a psychoanalytical service for young people in north London. This developed into the pioneering Brent Adolescent Centre, which continues to offer a walk-in psychoanalytic and psychotherapeutic service to people aged 14 to 21.

Mervin was the deputy director at Brent, where he gained clinical and administrative experience that was to be invaluable when he left to join the Portman.

His work continued after retirement from the Portman. He researched and published with former Portman colleagues on the "act of violence". A retrospective report (in collaboration with Professor Issi Kolvin, Don Campbell and others) on understanding how early-life victims of sexual abuse can become perpetrators later will shortly appear in the British Journal of Psychiatry. He taught regularly on sexual deviation, delinquency and perversions at the Anna Freud Centre.

Mervin was a member of many committees and working parties in Britain. With the release of Nelson Mandela from jail, some London-based psychoanalysts and psychotherapists of South African origin discussed ways of taking their knowledge and experience back. In 1995 Mervin became the first chairman of the South African Psychoanalytic Trust; and he contributed a vivid paper to its first international psychoanalytic conference in Cape Town in 1998.

He became a fellow of the Royal College of Psychiatrists in 1978, and an executive member of its psychotherapy committee. He was on the editorial board of the Journal of Forensic Psychiatry.

Mervin could meet resistance because he would never compromise about what he saw as right or true, but he was universally respected. Full of innovative ideas, humane and generous, he was renowned for his humour, clinical acumen, commitment to his patients, profound knowledge and modesty. As a teacher he had an extraordinary capacity to enthuse students, and he was still teaching and practising up to his dying day. He loved art, music, literature, film, and watching football.

He is survived by his wife, Kath, a son, a daughter and three grandchildren.

 Mervin Glasser, psychoanalyst, born December 7 1928; died November 9 2000

He built links with the Institute of Psychiatry's forensic department, the Tavistock Clinic and the Home Office; with academia, particularly the London School of Economics; with London hospitals, the police, the prison service and the Inner London Probation Service. His clinical seminars on the psychotherapy of sexual deviations and delinquency became a day-release course in conjunction with the British Postgraduate Medical Federation. Away from the Portman, Mervin lectured internationally and in many hospitals and centres in Britain. He advised the British Board of Film Classification and was a frequent consultant to government departments. The son of a Jewish émigré businessman, Mervin was born in Johannesburg and educated at King Edward's School. From his early teens he developed an interest in functions of the mind and psychoanalysis. At the University of Witwatersrand he read psychology and created a university arts festival. He had black friends at a time when this was inconceivable to most white South Africans. He left the country in 1952 to study psychoanalysis in London and - since at that time medical qualification was usual as a background to this - he trained at Westminster hospital medical school, graduating in 1958. He qualified as an associate member at the London Institute of Psychoanalysis in 1963 and subsequently taught his speciality there, becoming a training analyst at the institute in 1980 and director of the clinic after retiring from the Portman in 1993. Early in his career he worked with the psychoanalyst Moses Laufer, whom Anna Freud had asked to inaugurate a psychoanalytical service for young people in north London. This developed into the pioneering Brent Adolescent Centre, which continues to offer a walk-in psychoanalytic and psychotherapeutic service to people aged 14 to 21. Mervin was the deputy director at Brent, where he gained clinical and administrative experience that was to be invaluable when he left to join the Portman. His work continued after retirement from the Portman. He researched and published with former Portman colleagues on the "act of violence". A retrospective report (in collaboration with Professor Issi Kolvin, Don Campbell and others) on understanding how early-life victims of sexual abuse can become perpetrators later will shortly appear in the British Journal of Psychiatry. He taught regularly on sexual deviation, delinquency and perversions at the Anna Freud Centre. Mervin was a member of many committees and working parties in Britain. With the release of Nelson Mandela from jail, some London-based psychoanalysts and psychotherapists of South African origin discussed ways of taking their knowledge and experience back. In 1995 Mervin became the first chairman of the South African Psychoanalytic Trust; and he contributed a vivid paper to its first international psychoanalytic conference in Cape Town in 1998. He became a fellow of the Royal College of Psychiatrists in 1978, and an executive member of its psychotherapy committee. He was on the editorial board of the Journal of Forensic Psychiatry. Mervin could meet resistance because he would never compromise about what he saw as right or true, but he was universally respected. Full of innovative ideas, humane and generous, he was renowned for his humour, clinical acumen, commitment to his patients, profound knowledge and modesty. As a teacher he had an extraordinary capacity to enthuse students, and he was still teaching and practising up to his dying day. He loved art, music, literature, film, and watching football. He is survived by his wife, Kath, a son, a daughter and three grandchildren.  Mervin Glasser, psychoanalyst, born December 7 1928; died November 9 2000

webTitle: Obituary: Charles Ruff

fields.headline: Charles Ruff
fields.standfirst: Defender of Bill Clinton at impeachment hearing
fields.trailText: Charles Ruff, who, as White House counsel, presented President Bill Clinton's defence at last year's impeachment hearing, has died in an accident at his Washington home at the age of 61.
fields.body:
Charles Ruff, who, as White House counsel, presented President Bill Clinton's defence at last year's impeachment hearing, has died in an accident at his Washington home at the age of 61. His fearsome legal reputation and his unrivalled contacts across the political spectrum made him the favourite choice for almost any prominent American politician running into serious trouble.

Ruff's past clients included Senator John Glenn, accused of political corruption, Senator Charles Robb, caught dallying with a young beauty queen, and Professor Anita Hall, who stunned the Senate judiciary committee by charging a Supreme Court nominee with sexual harassment. Ruff also fought a long and eventually successful court action for the American Tobacco Institute against claims that it had deliberately misled cigarette smokers about the risk to their health.

Ruff's remarkable professional rise had been achieved in the face of what could have been a personal disaster. After graduating from Columbia law school in 1963, he received a grant from the Ford Foundation to run a law course in Liberia. Shortly after arriving in the country, he contracted a viral paralysis similar to poliomyelitis, which confined him to a wheelchair.

Ruff did not, however, allow this disability to affect his career. From 1967 he gained valuable experience and contacts in the criminal division of the Justice Department. After five years there, however, he returned to teaching. He had barely settled at Georgetown University before Archibald Cox, the newly appointed Watergate special prosecutor, approached him to become a senior member of the team investigating President Richard Nixon and his White House staff. A colleague there was Hillary Rodham, who later married Bill Clinton.

Ruff's personal role in the investigations focused on the vast range of illegal financial contributions made to Nixon's 1972 campaign. The evidence he amassed was so incontrovertible that most of those responsible, including the oil tycoon Armand Hammer, pleaded guilty.

In 1975, with most of the key defendants convicted, Ruff took over as special prosecutor and found himself in the middle of a political storm, investigating charges that President Gerald Ford had diverted political donations to his personal use. In the highly charged final days of the 1976 presidential campaign, Ruff (well known as a Democrat) stuck firmly to his legal last, dismissed the charges and wrote finis to the special prosecution report.

He returned to the Justice Department for a time, but was then hired by one of the most prominent Washington law firms, then acting for the tobacco institute. Its most threatening case came from the family of Rose Cipollone, who had died of lung cancer after a lifetime of smoking.

Ruff tackled it head on. In one legal conference he told the opposing lawyer: "You've tried the front door, the back door, the side door, and now you're trying the trap door. It isn't going to work." And, after years of litigation, Ruff ensured that it did not, a success he later tended to omit from his biography.

Such courtroom successes put him near the top of the Washington ladder. His argument to the Senate ethics committee got John Glenn off the hook in 1989 after he was accused of influence-peddling in return for campaign contributions. Even more remarkably, Ruff persuaded the Federal Election Commission to grant Glenn an unprecedented waiver from its stringent fundraising rules.

Ruff's initial involvement with the Clinton White House came from defending one of Hillary Clinton's principal assistants, Ira Magaziner, who helped to prepare her ill-fated healthcare plan. Magaziner was accused of perjury, but in a complex presentation to the US attorney's office in Washington, Ruff managed to shift the blame to some unspecified White House officials and Magaziner was never charged.

It was against this background that Ruff became President Clinton's fifth White House counsel within four years. As the ripples of the Whitewater affair widened and allegations about the president's sexual behaviour proliferated, insiders joked that Clinton needed a lawyer smart enough to do the job and dumb enough to take it. Ruff defended his recruitment with the comment: "When the president of the United States asks you to do something, you don't say, 'Let me think about it.' You say, 'How can I help you, Mr President?' "

The eruption of Monica Lewinsky on to the scene and the soaring political temperature in Congress eventually left even a practised operator like Ruff with little room for manoeuvre. Impeachment by the Republican-controlled House became a virtual certainty, and the principal article, charging Clinton with lying to the grand jury about his relationship with Ms Lewinsky, sailed through.

Ruff put up the best moral arguments he could find in his statement at the Senate hearing. He accused the prosecution of having "a vision too little attuned to the people ... more focused on retribution, more designed to achieve partisan ends". After 14 days of hearings he did, indeed, win his case - by a margin of nine votes on the perjury charge and by a single vote on the obstruction of justice count. But Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania could only bring himself to vote "not proven".

Ruff is survived by his wife, Sue, and two daughters.

 Charles Frederick Carson Ruff, lawyer, born August 1 1939; died November 19 2000

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Postman Pat

fields.headline: No: 1765
fields.standfirst: Postman Pat
fields.trailText: Postman Pat
fields.body:
Oh, I love Postman Pat. Is he undergoing a Flowerpot Men-style revival? No, no. He's got the sack.

Of course he has. He's a postman. I mean he's been fired.

What for? Steaming open the post? No, the Royal Mail has simply decided that he's bad for their image. Too slow and old-fashioned.

Hang on, hang on, "early in the morning, just as day is dawning, he picks up all the letters in his van". That's how the song went. Pat is evidently a man dedicated to his job. Yeah, okay, so Pat may have risen early, but he spent the rest of the day shilly-shallying around Greendale helping farmers tug tractors out of ditches and drinking cups of tea with the local postmistress. "Fancy a brew, Pat?" "Oh, yes please, I'm parched..." Every single bleeding episode.

So what will be replacing Pat? Oh, robots, probably.

Robots? Are you sure? Yes, well, it's what the kids want nowadays, isn't it? Robots, with guns and super-human powers, not some speccy Welsh bloke in a blue serge suit.

And Jess? Well, to be honest, allowing a cat into a post office vehicle contravenes rules 781 (a) of the Postal Workers' Handbook. Therefore Jess will be replaced with an electronically generated moggy, who can, er, fly.

Jess the flying cat? We're not too sure about the "Jess" bit, either. He'll probably be called Mograa or something. Sounds a bit more aerodynamic, eh?

Are you sure this will catch on in Greendale? Greendale's changed, sweetheart. These days it's not so much a village as a commuter settle-ment. The people of Greendale need their post, and they need it fast. They haven't got time to sit around waiting for some curmudgeonly postie to finish his cuppa and his Jammy Dodger in the village post office...

At least there still is a village post office. Not for much longer. No, come January, Mrs Goggins is being given early retirement, and the residents of Greendale will have to journey to the main PO branch in the out-of-town Asda. Next week: Bagpuss is evicted to make way for new branch of Starbucks.

webTitle: Hackney wrangle hits Itnet profits

fields.headline: Hackney wrangle hits Itnet profits
fields.trailText: Itnet, the information technology contractor, yesterday revealed that its troublesome relationship with the scandal-hit London Borough of Hackney has triggered an accounting shake-up that will wipe out its profits this year.
fields.body:
Itnet, the information technology contractor, yesterday revealed that its troublesome relationship with the scandal-hit London Borough of Hackney has triggered an accounting shake-up that will wipe out its profits this year.

The company has been warned that it is likely to lose a £70m 10-year deal to administer the cash-strapped London council's housing benefit payments. It could also lose business running the authority's payroll and providing IT services. The warning sent the company's shares crashing by 102.5p to 187.5p.

Itnet's chief executive Bridget Blow said the company had found it "difficult" to negotiate with the borough, which was the subject of a scathing report by the Audit Commission this month.

The borough has a backlog of thousands of benefit payments. Itnet blames new government regulations requiring claimants to provide extra proof of their identities, which has caused a flood of extra paperwork.

Ms Blow said: "At the beginning of the benefits contract, we did as good a job as we could in carrying out due diligence. But when we actually went in there, various other things took place."

As a result of the controversy, Itnet is changing the way it accounts for costs in long-term contracts. Instead of writing off its spending on staff and systems gradually over the life of such agreements, it will account for the entire expense up front. This will reduce its pre-tax profits this year by £10m to £11m, while £15.3m will be knocked off restated profits from previous years.

Ms Blow said the setback was "disappointing" but insisted that Hackney was a unique situation: "This is not a problem for us anywhere else."

In a further blow to the company's investors, Itnet said sluggish general activity in the IT industry, together with problems at its recently acquired Technosys business, would cost it between £2m and £3m.

Analyst Ian Mitchell of Beeson Gregory said he now expects the company to break-even this year, rather than make profits of £13.3m.

webTitle: Help them to see

fields.headline: Help them to see
fields.trailText: Beverley Stott is 11. She enjoys maths, science and swimming. She also happens to have albinism/nystagmus - everything she sees is intensely bright
fields.body:
Beverley Stott is 11. She enjoys maths, science and swimming. She also happens to have albinism/nystagmus - everything she sees is intensely bright. To reduce the glare, she wears dark glasses even in winter and when she is indoors. She is one of Britain's 22,000 children who are blind or partially sighted.

A report by the Royal National Institute for the Blind (RNIB) just out, looks into the experience of young people with visual impairment. It shows that much still needs to be done to ensure children with sight problems can enjoy full lives. And, it says, all too often their difficulties spring from sighted people's attitudes and behaviour.

What is blindness?

It is thought that two people in every 1000 under 16 years old may have a sight problem that has a big impact on their quality of life.

Few people are completely blind. There are about 80 different eye conditions (problems) and they can affect sight in a variety of ways. Understanding this is important. The reason partially-sighted people may behave in ways that seem strange is because they are trying to make the most of what vision they have.

What do young people with visual impairment want?

The RNIB asked 1,000 young people in this category this question. Unsurprisingly, their desires are just the same as those of their sighted friends. They are interested in the same games, want to take part in the full range of school activities and seek to be as independent as they can. Sadly, the RNIB research showed young people with sight problems often face barriers blocking their path to these goals.

Are schools doing enough?

Over the last 20 years it has become rarer for people whose sight is their only disability to go to special schools. But, according to the RNIB report, mainstream schools are still failing to give their visually impaired pupils the support they need. For example, nearly a quarter of those questioned said that they are often unable to read the worksheets handed to them in class.

The report also highlighted how just under 75% of young visually impaired pupils received no mobility education to teach them how to get about the streets, at home or travel around their schools safely.

Isn't there classroom equipment that can help?

Yes. There is technology to support people whatever their level of need. It can be expensive and there are reports of parents having to battle with their local education authorities to get the best resources for their children.

Isn't it against the law to prevent people with disabilities being stopped from attending ordinary schools?

Until now schools have not been expected to fit in with the Disability Discrimination Act (1995). Changes are due early next year. Some campaigners fear there will still be opportunities for schools to get out of their obligations because of the vague language used in the new rules.

Do sighted people make life harder for people with visual impairment?

The research proves that young people with visual impairment still face stupidity and hostility from other people. 90% of the parents that took part in the research reported that their children were always being stared at in public. Half said they and their children frequently met rude remarks and questions. Beverley is often asked why she wears shaded glasses.

Worse still, up to 60% of visually impaired people said they had been bullied at school - unpleasant for anyone but horrible when a person's tormentors may be unidentifiable.

What can be done?

The RNIB report is full of recommendations and is part of a general education campaign, carrying advice for ordinary people to help them become more sensitive in their dealings with visually impaired people. This includes simple things like saying who you are when you start a conversation. For David Wilkins, featured in this week's First Edition, bags left in corridors are one of his pet hates. Beverley is also clear about what she wants - "Tell people to stop staring."

Further information

 RNIB website

 Website for blind and partially-sighted children: www.sortit.org.uk

 For details of forthcoming changes in the law on educational access for disabled people visit the Council for Disabled Children pages.

webTitle: If you ask me...music lessons

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: I would like my sons, aged seven and nine, to learn to play a musical instrument. How can they learn without me paying a lot of money for private tuition? Their school tells me it doesn't run classes, and the local education authority has referred me back to the school!
fields.trailText: I would like my sons, aged seven and nine, to learn to play a musical instrument. How can they learn without me paying a lot of money for private tuition? Their school tells me it doesn't run classes, and the local education authority has referred me back to the school!
fields.byline: Compiled by Amanda Roper and Katy Randles
fields.body:
 Before 1988, all local education authorities provided instrumental tuition, usually through peripatetic teachers employed by the authorities. In 1988, the Education Reform Act allowed schools to opt out of local authority control through the local management of schools (LMS). Schools therefore have greater control over their budgets and what these are spent on.

In the 1990s, many local authority music adviser posts disappeared, and LMS in effect undermined the strategic planning of instrumental services previously organised at a local level.

The present government introduced the Music Standards Fund in 1999 to halt the decline in school music. This year alone £50m has been allocated. This central funding is intended to ensure that every local education authority in the country offers children the chance to learn to play musical instruments.

Replies:

Children should have access to music tuition. Coming from an economically deprived background should not stop them learning to play an instrument.

In practice, many schools do provide lessons but local music services are responsible for this provision. It's up to individual schools whether they choose to provide instrumental tuition and it's also their decision whether they pass on the fees to parents.

But schools are usually asked to have a fees remission policy in place for children who also receive free school meals. So parents can apply for free music tuition from the local music service, subject to their criteria.

The situation is improving because the government is increasing funding through the Standards Fund. What remains a real problem is the level of support local education authorities give to schools, ranging from nothing to £1m. This is why children in some areas are losing out from the arrangement.

The government is doing its best to address the problems created by the decline of music services in recent years, but this will take time and there is a long way to go. In the meantime, contact your local music service directly to clarify what should be available for your children.
Richard Hickman, chief executive, the Federation of Music Services

Birmingham City Council has always been very supportive of the music service, which has expanded every year since the delegation of funds to schools. Obviously, the injection of cash through the Standards Fund has had a positive effect on the range of projects we can offer schools.

Because the decision of whether to "buy in" music tuition ultimately rests with the headteacher and the board of governors, there are schools where no instrument tuition is provided.

In the Birmingham area, a minority of primary schools do not use our service. A few might buy the services of an individual, and either fund the cost or ask parents to pay. However, such individuals rarely provide free instruments, making it an expensive option.

webTitle: Drama courses that may cause a crisis

fields.headline: Manage it!
fields.standfirst: Do let your daughter off the stage, Mrs Robinson, urges  Peter Cheeseman
fields.trailText: Do let your daughter off the stage, Mrs Robinson, urges Peter Cheeseman
fields.body:
Since government started funding colleges and universities according to the number of students they attract, the country has been awash with courses in media and performing arts. Further education has literally thousands of them. The Higher Education Funding Council funds over 700 degree courses with the drama or theatre in the title. All these courses may appear to have a connection with the industry, but most do not.

There are only 28 courses recognised by the drama sector of the performing arts industry as proper training for a career in acting and 17 for stage manager/ technicians.

It is important to stress that although most actors and actresses seriously following a career have been trained on an industrially approved course, an unacceptably high level of unemployment still waits for them. But not for the trained stage manager. Virtually all stage managers get employment in their chosen fields within six months of graduating. And they are likely to stay employed.

But however attractive stage-management is as a career option for anybody wanting to be involved in creating drama without having to act, it needs more recruits.

There is much less competition for places on stage-management courses than on acting courses. Many courses are fully funded, and the new dance and drama awards scheme provides scholarships for stage-management students studying at private institutions like Rada and Lamda. Most of the accredited stage-management courses offer BA degrees; others offer diplomas validated by Trinity College London.

The stage-management team are the key co-ordinators in the theatre production process. It is fundamentally a people-organising job. There are plenty of training and work placement opportunities to gain a broad range of skills. Training options can lead down a pure stage-management path - assistant stage manager through to production manager - or in a more technical direction, where students get hands-on experience in lighting, sound, scenic construction and painting or prop and costume-making. Both routes develop skills that can be used in other working contexts. Many stage managers move across into arts administration, as well as into theatre management or directing. But they've also got the basic training to allow them to move into the production side of television and film. Many find employment in the expanding field of trade exhibitions, rock concerts or industrial conference presentation.

But the key to this broad range of employment is training on an industrially-accredited course. Neither amateur experience nor a non-vocational university degree are an adequate basis for the industry today.

 For more information contact The National Council for Drama Training, 020 7387 3650, www.ncdt.co.uk or the Conference of Drama Schools, 01603 702 021, www.drama.ac.uk

 Peter Cheeseman is Chair of the National Council for Drama Training.

webTitle: Furthermore: Spiced ham

fields.headline: Spiced ham
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock plots the screenplay of "Rogue Luncheon meat - The Movie"
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock plots the screenplay of "Rogue Luncheon meat - The Movie"
fields.body:
I have had another stressful day at college, but at least it has given me an idea for a film. It is based on real events that happened to me yesterday.

Its working title is Run Lecturer Run, and it goes something like this:

A lecturer is in his office trying to retrieve a piece of luncheon meat that has inexplicably been propelled from his sandwich and landed down the back of his computer. He swears, disengages leads, finds a shuttlecock and a scrunched up memo from the principal. But no luncheon meat.

The phone rings. It is his team leader reminding him about his appraisal lesson observation in five minutes. For a moment he cannot find his lesson plan. He swears, knocks over his coffee cup and eventually finds what he is looking for. He rushes out of the office, almost tripping over his mate Colin from maths, who has bent over to pick up a pound coin from the floor. They both swear.

The lecturer goes down the stairs and outside. He strolls purposefully across to the Ronald Smedley building. When he gets there he dashes in to the campus shop for some breath mints. He meets Gerald from Leisure and Tourism who is stealing a Kit-Kat. Gerald smiles and continues to load his pockets with confectionery. He slips the lecturer a Twix and leaves.

Cut to black and white and the lecturer walks down a long empty corridor in slow motion to his classroom. When he gets to the door it is locked. There is a sign that says the lesson has been moved to the Fenella Povey Annexe. This means crossing to the other side of the campus, beyond the playing field and the student car park. He has no option but to run. He looks up at the clock on the outside of the Admin Block, but it is broken, stuck at 12.35. In college administration it is forever lunchtime.

Cue loud music. He runs like the wind. Actually, he runs like he is suffering from wind. I quite fancy a montage sequence during this bit. You know, slice of luncheon meat, scowling face of team leader, hedgehog curled in a ball, picture of Karl Marx, close-up on a mouth eating chocolate.

He is delayed in the student car park by one of his students, Roxanne. She won't let him pass without signing a petition. He is out of breath and cannot talk. He can see up to the room where he should be teaching. He signs and runs on.

He rushes to the room only to find that all the students are on their mobile phones and his team leader is scribbling notes on a clipboard. Fade to black; the music stops and he is hit on the head by a giant slice of luncheon meat that appears out of nowhere.

Then the action starts all over again, but this time it's different. In this version his team leader gets hit by the luncheon meat. Cut to black and white and it all happens for a final time. Only now Colin has his hand stamped on, Gerald is caught shoplifting, Roxanne is turned into a tin of luncheon meat and the team leader is impressed when the students get down to work without being asked.

I will let you decide which version of events I did actually experience. But in no version was any luncheon meat harmed during the making of my day.

webTitle: A theatre that provides a course for budding playwrites

fields.headline: Write on cue
fields.standfirst: One theatre is running a practical course for budding - but broke - playwrites.  John Crace  went behind the scenes
fields.trailText: One theatre is running a practical course for budding - but broke - playwrites. John Crace went behind the scenes
fields.body:
Ask any writer what he or she hates doing most and you're almost guaranteed to get the answer "writing". They like thinking about writing, talking about writing and, most especially, they like having written something. But the process of writing is a complete no-no, a one way journey into lonely, atavistic despair. And the pay off? For most first-time authors, it's a book that almost no one reads and an income less than a supermarket shelf-stacker.

It's just as bad for playwrights, whose early successes may be measured by a single performance in a room above a pub. Which is why the Soho Theatre in London recently introduced a new Attachment Programme for six promising playwrights. "I had organised an MA in playwriting for a university", says Paul Sirett, literary manager of the Soho Theatre, "but it seemed that entrance to the course was predicated on an ability to pay. Bearing in mind that playwrights are often broke and don't necessarily even write good essays, it seemed there was room for a more practical course."

But the academic model wasn't abandoned entirely with the new course being divided into three terms of eight weeks with a six-week break between. "We felt we needed to squeeze the course in between March and November", says Lin Coghlan, director of the programme, "as most writers can't financially commit to being in one place for much longer."

The first term focused on playwriting, and the six students, who were chosen from among 2,000 playwrights who submitted scripts for the theatre's annual competition, spent one full day per week developing the spine of a story and a central knot of characters for a new play. During the six-week break, the ideas were knocked into some kind of shape.

In the second term, the writers received feedback on their rough draft, while taking time out to study TV and radio with Alex Perrin, a former producer on The Bill, and Lucy Hannah, head of the new writing initiative at the BBC. "Most writers can't make a living just writing plays", Coghlan explains, "so they need to know how to explore other writing avenues."

The second six-week break saw the rough draft mutate into a first draft, and during the third term the writers explored film scriptwriting with David Evans, producer of Fever Pitch, before each play had a rehearsed reading in front of an audience.

The plays themselves are not always what you might call accessible. Martha Emmitt's, Mister Love, is set in a Texas cafe run by gay women, where the only male regular is a derelict homeless man until an anarchic biker rides into town. The woman who runs the community falls in love with the biker and destroys the community. "It sounds realistic", says Emmitt, "but it owes more to magic realism."

The writers say they learned a lot about the technical demands of playwriting. "I've started to create stories for my characters," says Emmitt. "In the past, I used to just work from images and I don't think there was a strong enough narrative structure for an audience to get a sense of the characters completing a journey."

But the most valuable part of the course for all writers seems to be the feeling of being provided with a home. "So often a writer feels unsupported in their work," says Chris Chidmore. "I have a sense of belonging at Soho. I feel there are people who care about what I do and are keen to discuss it." It's a feeling that is unlikely to go away. All six writers will return next year as mentors for the next course.

webTitle: Rostrum: Mission possible

fields.headline: Mission possible
fields.standfirst: Simply thinking about your college mission is not enough, says  Graham Peeke
fields.trailText: Simply thinking about your college mission is not enough, says Graham Peeke
fields.body:
It is increasingly important for colleges to have a clear sense of purpose and distinctiveness - a college mission. Not least because the new post-16 sector is one in which the consumer will be king.

The local learning and skills councils are purchasing bodies: they will buy education and training on behalf of learners. Quality of provision will be of paramount consideration, and when it comes to large generic providers they will look carefully at services they want to buy and those they feel can be bought elsewhere at an equivalent price, but of a better quality.

This fact alone should cause further education colleges to reflect on their mission as providers of all things to all people, a strategy driven by a funding methodology that operated without a planning or strategic dimension.

Other factors, too, have stimulated ministers' interest in college missions. These include the success of the sixth-form colleges and the perceived success of European vocational institutions.

The policy crosses from the schools sector, where initiatives involving more specialist provision have been introduced. David Blunkett plans to make a major statement about vision and strategy for colleges, and the Further Education Development Agency has been exploring models for the creation of centres of excellence in colleges.

The claims for having clarity of mission are impressive. A clear sense of mission, it is argued, can lead to a sense of purpose that provides direction and self-determination.

Mission facilitates decision-making because all decisions, plans and acts can be consistent with the mission, thus clarifying choices at times of expansion and contraction. A clear mission also improves communication with key stakeholders and the development of a marketing strategy.

Establishing a mission can only improve a college's performance if staff and management behave as if they really have one. They must believe in it. They must live it. The literature on mission establishment has not been too concerned by this - it holds that thinking about a mission is valuable in itself, and that moving from rhetoric to changed reality needs little attention. This attitude has devalued the concept of mission establishment.

For the mission to be any use to learners, it has to be demonstrated in the behaviour and attitude of all staff. Terms such as "excellence" and "high quality" have to be experienced.

To students in cold, leaky terrapin huts the excellence of delivery does not always come across as quickly as it might - too often they do not experience excellent or high-quality guidance.

If we are to re-examine the college mission in the hope of providing better quality learning experiences what steps do we need to take? First, we must ensure that the spirit of the mission is obvious in the actions of managers and staff.

Second, we have to make sure that the mission is shared among all those with a hand in its realisation. There has got to be far greater involvement among all the staff in agreeing the mission and implementing it.

Third, the mission must be responsive to the real world. It has got to be compatible with conditions in the local learning market. Above all it must be responsive to the needs of that market and of employers.

 Graham Peeke is Director of Professional and Organisational Development at the Further Education Development Agency.

webTitle: Adults are he fastest-growing museum audience

fields.headline: Museum piece
fields.standfirst: The best adult show in town can be a real education, says  John Reeve
fields.trailText: The best adult show in town can be a real education, says John Reeve
fields.body:
If I say museums and education you may picture children - perhaps yourself years ago - in a crocodile on a school trip: dinosaurs, mummies, a bit of the moon, a first world war trench, art. But the fastest-growing museum audience is not the first age, but the third: over 70% of museum visitors are adults, alone, with other adults in groups or with children.

That this is the case right across Europe is shown in the recently-published Museums and Adults Learning: Perspectives from Europe (edited by Chadwick and Stannett, Niace).

Adults have always been a significant audience for museums: there were no school parties when the British Museum opened in 1759, and only a certain kind of adult. Victorians in Britain and America saw the value of museums for public education and morals, social control and the improvement of taste.

In our own time adults are living longer and longer in the northern hemisphere: someone retiring at 60 in Europe has on average 8,000 days of leisure ahead. Soon 20% of the population of Europe will be retired.

While still working, however, they may have less leisure time than before. Providing quality use of limited leisure time is one of the challenges for museum programmers today. Many museums provide rich programmes at weekends and are opening later.

A museum is one of the few reliable, permanent, but flexible resources for lifelong learning to which we can return as and when we feel the need. It combines the advantages of a library with the inspiration and challenge of the real object and the unexpected -increasingly supported by diverse interpretation for diverse needs.

Museums are developing new partnerships for adults, as for schools, with the Workers' Educational Association, the National Association of Decorative and Fine Arts Society, the Open University, the Open College and many others. A new joint post for lifelong learning has been created by Birkbeck's Further and Continuing Education Division and the British Museum's Education Department. And new structures nationally for further education present many new opportunities for partnerships.

Some of the assumptions about what young visitors need now inform programming for older ones: if learning from objects is important in schools, why isn't it important in further, higher and adult education? Many museums are providing interactive opportunities, such as handling sessions or practical art classes for all. Adults may want to drop in on Indian dance in a gallery, try wearing Arab clothes or experience a recreation of stories from the Trojan Wars, just as much as children do. Different adult learning styles, appetites and energies need to be matched with different kinds of learning opportunity and different voices.

There are 50,000 volunteers in museums, for example, and trained volunteers can offer an informal introduction for adult visitors. At the British Museum a team of nearly 100 volunteers provide eight or more Eye Opener tours every day in galleries ranging from North America to Ancient Greece.

Moving up the escalator, curators as well as educators and freelance lecturers give in-depth gallery talks and lectures. You can then go on to take evening classes and courses, attend study days and events on gladiators or mosaics, Korea or Impressionism, Chaucer's London, miniature painting, gardening or dance - all these are now on offer in London's museums and galleries.

Not only is the range of programmes on offer widening, but so, we hope, is the audience. As Eilean Hooper-Greenhill, Professor of Museum Studies at Leicester University, has pointed out, "museums, although not galleries, are much more democratic in their audience profiles than opera, ballet and the theatre, but there are still gaps ... deep-seated cultural reasons underlie the exclusion felt by black, Asian and other groups in Britain and by women and the white working class."

There are countless examples from all over Britain of museums and galleries responding to this challenge. Adults have been encouraged to curate exhibitions and share their own collections with the public, for instance at the Museum of London. There are "people's shows" in Sunderland, Walsall, Glasgow and many other places.

Real community involvement is crucial, whether Arab, Afro-Caribbean, Maori or Mexican. Performance, food and dance all offer tastes of other cultures. webTitle: Planning your first lesson as a teacher trainee can be daunting

fields.headline: I stood up in front and ...
fields.standfirst: Planning your first lesson as a teacher trainee can be daunting, but it gets better, says  Helen Carter
fields.trailText: Planning your first lesson as a teacher trainee can be daunting, but it gets better, says Helen Carter
fields.body:
When Jenny Bell first had to stand up in front of a class of students in a classroom she felt apprehensive. She had only ever given a presentation to five people before. But once she had faced up to her fears and done the deed, she felt a different person.

Bell, 23, and her fellow student Emma Bullock, 23, are both doing one-year postgraduate certificates in education at Manchester Metropolitan University and training to be maths teachers. Their first teaching placement is at Droylsden High School for Girls, Manchester, on the eastern tip of the city.

Bell says she and all her fellow students on the course found the first teaching practice the most daunting. "The thought of having to stand up in front of a class and running out of things to teach them and not having things to say was awful. At first, it felt like we didn't know what we were doing. But as soon as we stood up in front of them it was fine, because when they are all sat down they are at a lot lower level than you are."

In the first lesson both students had jointly planned, they found three students had finished their work earlier than anticipated.

"We had to find them something else to do fairly quickly," said Bell. The trainee teachers soon realised that students work at different speeds.

On the other hand, Bullock said it could be frustrating trying to explain the same simple mathematical concept repeatedly to less able students: "We are teaching top set year sevens the same topic as the year 10s, who are set five out of eight."

Discipline can be a problem, too. "My mum is a primary school teacher and her advice was to be firm with the students from the start and then be nicer to them later," said Bullock. "We had been told by our tutors that if you are too slack at first then you can't be firm later as it won't work."

Both women are working in pairs preparing lessons and taking turns to teach the students. They say that even though the students know they are trainees, they have not caused them any problems as they are strict with them. "If they do not do their homework, then we have the power to give them detention," said Bullock.

Colleen Ellis-Jones, a maths teacher at the school and one of the trainees' mentors, says the students have to set the ground rules from day one.

"The key to teaching is planning. If they don't plan lessons, they are more likely to get it wrong. They also have to think about how they will teach the students. Some teachers seat the children in alphabetical order. It is important that they think about all aspects of the lesson."

Phil Page, a senior teacher at Droylsden and the students' professional mentor, said: "One key thing trainees have difficulties with at first is planning lessons. They tend to overplan and not realise the amount of work students can get through. Suddenly they realise there is no way they will get through their whole lesson plan.

"Also, they often find they are trying to impart fairly complex ideas down to the ability level of the students they are teaching."

He says it can be quite difficult to come from an academic environment, in which lectures and independent learning are familiar, and to try to relay some of those concepts to students.

Page says it was a two-way process because, as the students were being evaluated, the more experienced teachers could pick up on their ideas and develop them in their own lessons.

"They bring lots of fresh ideas, energy and enthusiasm into the classroom," he said. "They are only here for eight weeks and within that time they are expected to establish relationships with the students, pick up on a scheme of work and teach it."

webTitle: The Arts and Humanities Research Board gets serious

fields.headline: Money for starving garrets
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod  meets the new humanities power broker
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod meets the new humanities power broker
fields.body:
You know who you are ... the Arts and Humanities Research Board is about to publish the list of departments in which PhD completion rates have fallen below 50%. This blacklisting will be serious for the departments involved, cutting them off from the board's funding of postgraduate students, but it is the price of taking arts and humanities research seriously. The upside is the chance of more money for departments that do perform well.

True, the board's £52m budget is puny against that of the big science research councils. However, in two years of existence under Paul Langford it has firmly established itself, raising both the profile of this kind of research and also the morale of academics, according to its new chief executive, David Eastwood.

He and his heavily oversubscribed budget are now in the sights of about 12,000 staff and researchers in the arts and humanities. An Oxford historian like Langford, Eastwood even shares the same specialism of 18th- and early 19th-century English history. Perhaps a thorough grounding in the intricacies of patronage and politics is deemed essential?

He says he has three rules in life - never draw up a seating plan (he was a senior tutor at an Oxford college), never choose a menu and never follow someone who has done a really good job. "I have broken that spectacularly following Paul," he smiles. He comes from being head of the history department and pro-vice chancellor at Swansea.

In the new year he will unveil an innovation fund he hopes will foster the equivalent of blue skies research in the sciences, including possible joint work with the Natural Environment Research Council. "We want new ways of researching new forms of knowledge. We want something that will make people sit up." The board will also consider bids for another five or six research centres to add to the 10 existing ones. This continues the policy of promoting collaboration and research teams in the arts and humanities - although Eastwood insists the lone scholar is still catered for in the board's research leave scheme.

Longer term, he wants to see the board become a fully-fledged research council.

webTitle: No more jacks of all trades - colleges are told specialise

fields.headline: Build up your strengths
fields.standfirst: No more jacks of all trades - colleges are told specialise.  Peter Kingston  reports
fields.trailText: No more jacks of all trades - colleges are told specialise. Peter Kingston reports
fields.body:
Britain's further education colleges must specialise in order to regain their crucial role in boosting the nation's economic productivity, David Blunkett will tell them today.

Impressed by the improved results notched up by specialist schools, the education secretary wants colleges over the next three years to move towards becoming regionally- and nationally- recognised vocational centres of excellence. Ministers reckon this is the best way to upgrade skills in key sectors where the UK still lags behind its main competitors.

Blunkett is also expected to announce that next year's extra £50 million for improving lecturers' pay will be doubled in 2002/3, when he addresses the Association of Colleges' annual conference in Harrogate today.

The money will depend on ministers being satisfied that teaching standards are raised and that they are getting "something for something" in the now familiar DfEE refrain.

The pay gap between schools and colleges continues to widen, the education secretary will no doubt be reminded by his audience of principals.

New classroom teachers can expect to get 10% (£15,141) more than their college equivalents (£13,745), according to the Association of Colleges. At the top of the scale, the gap between teachers on the new advanced teacher pay scale (£42,981).and the highest lecturers' band (£24,907) could be as great as 35%.

The education secretary's key message to principals today will be the need for them to change focus radically if the UK is to close productivity gaps with its competitor economies.

Currently, the widest differential is with the United states at an estimated 45%. To close this gap, for instance, would mean boosting output in the UK by £6,000 a head.

The productivity gaps with France and Germany are reckoned at 18% and 11% respectively.

Current government thinking is that colleges have not properly restored links with employers which were broken with the withering of the old coal- and steel-based industries in the 1970s, nor have they recovered their most effective role for aiding the economy.

They became providers of more general education as they reinvented themselves in the following decades.

In the 1990s, after incorporation, they were forced into competing for units of funding in a "pseudo market".

Today Blunkett is expected to renew his call for the whole sector to bury the competitive approach and collaborate with sixth forms and sixth-form centres in a tertiary strategy for 16-19-year-olds.

He will call specifically on the 350 general further education colleges, in consultation with their Local Learning and Skills councils, regional development agencies and the national training organisations representing all sectors of industry, to identify their specialisms.

By 2004/5, a half of all colleges will be expected to have become vocational centres of excellence.

webTitle: The student body of 2009

fields.headline: Change will come
fields.standfirst: Roderick Floud describes the student body of 2009
fields.trailText: Roderick Floud describes the student body of 2009
fields.body:
"Fifty per cent of the population will experience higher education" - Tony Blair's promise for 2009 heralds another expansion of Britain's universities. But how easily will it be done and what will society, and the graduates themselves, be like when this ambition is achieved?

Superficially, perhaps not so very different from today. Already about 40% of the English population - and more in Scotland and Northern Ireland - goes to university, a figure that always surprises those who remember the equivalent figure of 12% from the early 1960s.

One reason why it may not be too difficult for us is that by 2009 we shall be healthier, wealthier and wiser. If the economy continues to grow as it has done for the past 40 years, we will all on average be nearly 25% better off than we are today. Even if only a small part of the hype about the internet revolution is true, normal productivity growth will see to that.

As for health, our expectation of life continues to rise, but still has some way to go to match other European countries and Japan. Medical science has conquered or palliated many diseases, but our overall nutritional status can still improve. It is a sure sign of what is possible that Dutch young men are 5cm taller than our young men.

Wealthier and healthier, yes, but wiser? A chorus of scepticism still greets the year-on-year improvement in A-level and GCSE passes, but there is nothing inherently improbable in it. After all, human knowledge has increased and with it, probably, our ability to teach and learn. Even in the short period before 2009, we can expect to see the full effects of the national curriculum and the Curriculum 2000 reforms to post-16 education, which have only just begun. We may even simply be getting more intelligent as our nutritional status improves; we have stopped poisoning our children with leaded petrol.

Many of the conditions for creating more graduates are therefore in place or under way. A further necessity, however, is that the economy should need them and employers be prepared to give them jobs. Here, too, the portents are good. In Britain today the average male graduate earns £400,000 more over his lifetime than a non-graduate; the advantage for women is smaller but still substantial. Increasing the number of graduates might erode this advantage, but it has persisted despite the growth in numbers of graduates in recent years. It also still exists in countries like the US, with higher proportions than ours.

The reason, it seems, is the insatiable ability of "knowledge economies" to absorb highly skilled labour. Graduates are needed, in small numbers, to create knowledge, to invent and investigate. They are needed in much larger numbers to use knowledge in the myriad of service industries - the media, banking, insurance, design - on which we spend our wealth.

So in many ways the graduates of 2009 will be like those of today. But - and here's the tricky question - where will they come from? It will have to be from those parts of our society which "widening participation" has not yet reached.

The extra graduates will come from the large areas of our inner cities and our countryside that are today still higher education-free zones. Recruiting from these areas, and particularly from the white working-class, will be difficult and expensive; the £20m recently announced by the government is welcome but a drop in the ocean. Even more expensive will be helping these new students to get their degrees; it is here that the greatest changes will have to come. Universities will have to adapt to more flexible study patterns.

Students in 2009 are even more likely than today to combine study with work. Already many students have paid work while they study, and vacation work is already near universal, as students try to reduce debt. The new foundation degrees, which the government sees as the main vehicle of expansion, are designed to merge study with work. By 2009, these trends will have made obsolete the tradition of going away to university for three years. Instead, the typical student is likely to be a commuter. Hostels will survive for overseas students and the conference trade, but the average student will live close to home. They will need to, to maintain contact with the networks that help them to get work, and to economise on travel and living costs.

Such students will have to be good at managing time. But they will also demand tuition at times that suit them; the rigid timetables of the past, even the concepts of "term" and "vacation" will wither as internet and intranet give access to learning 24 hours a day throughout the year. Examinations, too, will have to be more frequent, even perhaps "on demand"; the student will decide how long to take over a course - two, five or 10 years compared with today's three years. There will be changes to university buildings which, with satellite facilities in FE colleges, will become study centres for those who have no room to study at home.

The coming expansion, in short, will require changes in attitudes, funding and facilities. The students of 2009 will be a real challenge to a university system which, many would say, already thinks it has changed enough.

 Roderick Floud is Provost of London Guildhall University. This article is based on a lecture recently given to Gresham College.
