fields.trailText: Peter Kingston meets John Cavendish, the would-be architect whose life has been wrecked by taking his former college to court - and losing
fields.body:
John Cavendish has something of the air of a character from Dickens. To be more specific, he reminds you of one of those driven, desperate souls in Bleak House who spend their days hanging around the High Court of Chancery waiting for a judgment that never comes.

Grey at 38, he wears the hunted look of someone who has been through a significant ordeal. After eight years, Cavendish has finally had a judgment on his own legal struggle with East London University over an architecture MSc. It wasn't the verdict he wanted and he could fight on to appeal. But he has had enough.

Pursuing the case has wreaked a heavy cost. His house has been repossessed and he says he will have to go bankrupt because he cannot pay the £80,000 costs. It has killed off any hope he once had of qualifying as an architect.

His preoccupation with the case caused a split with his girlfriend and affected other friendships back in Dublin where he hails from.

"I'm sick of hearing about the case," the actor Paudge Behan, adopted son of Brendan, told him, implying he could find someone else to have a pint with.

It's all a very heavy price to pay and it begs a number of questions. Should Cavendish have had to go all the way to the high court to get an independent adjudication on his complaint? Is this another example of glaring deficiencies in higher education grievance procedures, especially in the former polys, which don't even have that creaky old curio, the Visitor system?

It adds weight to those backing the proposal being considered by the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals: independent panels to be set up with transparent procedures, to which students from the new universities may appeal if they are not satisfied with how their complaints are handled internally.

Cavendish agrees: "You would think there should formally be some sort of simple external arbitration system to deal with student grievances so they didn't have to go to court."

Most people with a gripe against their university would not have pursued it to the lengths Cavendish went. "I do have a tendency to get obsessive," he admits.

He has other tell-tale signs of the dogged long-haul litigant: bulging lever-arch files of documentation, the faint - sometimes not so faint - suspicion that they are fighting a conspiracy, and the total immersion in the case which makes it impossible to give simple answers to questions.

Cavendish also joined the band of "litigants in person", individuals in the grip of long-running legal actions who are going it alone without legal representation, although likely to have sought advice from more than one lawyer along the way.

Cavendish didn't go to university at first. "My school results were lousy," he says. While working in the architecture business as a draughtsman in 1984 he started a part-time Part 1 architecture degree at the then South Bank poly in London. The four-year course stretched to six in his case, because he took one year off and illness wiped out another. He transferred to the East London poly for his final year. He got a BSc in 1990.

He says he was then encouraged to continue his journey towards the career he wanted by doing a new course - an MSc architecture: computing and design - that East London poly was starting up.

Successful completion of the first year would get the MSc, and finishing the second would win a diploma and exemption from the Royal Institute of British Architects Part 2 exams - essential for anyone wanting to practise as an architect.

Cavendish did successfully complete the first year but he and all bar one student on the course failed the second year, he says. His appeal against the failure was turned down in January 1993. The university has maintained that he was a weak student whose work in that second year was well below acceptable; nevertheless they asked him to teach undergraduates in the first MSc year.

He says he then found out the two-year course he had done would not have exempted him from Part 2 of the professional exams anyway, because it had not been recognised by the Architects Registration Council of the United Kingdom (ARCUK).

After rooting around a bit more, he says he established that the MSc course was not included in the European Commission's list of recognised courses leading to the professional architect's qualification which would enable the holder to practise across the EU. Thus, he says, he would not have been able to go back home to work in Dublin.

Cavendish was angry at wasting two valuable years - they had brought him no nearer his dream of becoming an architect and needlessly cost him money. He had borrowed thousands from his bank to tide him through the course and wasted the grant he had managed to get from Ealing borough. The university consistently maintained the course had necessary recognition.

In April 1998, Cavendish got a letter from the Architects Registration Board (ARB), which had superseded ARCUK. It said the MSc/Diploma course had gained recognition in 1994, and that this was retrospective. "That would not have been a lot of use in 1992 if I had passed the course," Cavendish says.

On October 24 this year his case for breach of contract, misrepresentation and negligence began in the high court, and failed. It was struck out, he says, because the formula he had used to calculate damages for loss of earnings over the past eight years was ruled inappropriate for a breach of contract claim.

East London University's registrar, Alan Ingle, says: "Any student who wishes to dispute an assessment decision may appeal in accordance with the University Regulations. Mr Cavendish did submit an appeal in 1993, which was dismissed. He was advised at the time his appeal was dismissed that the responsibility for the investigation of complaints regarding course delivery resided with the Pro-Vice-Chancellor (Academic Affairs). The Pro-Vice-Chancellor investigated the complaint but found it without substance. Later that year the Academic Board approved the Student Complaint Regulations which have been in force since then."

Cavendish says: "It's destroyed my working life. These courses are supposed to improve your careers. It's done the opposite for me."

webTitle: Puccini wants you to weep

fields.headline: Puccini wants you to weep
fields.standfirst: Ann Rachlin used to tell her own children stories at concerts. Now she imparts a love of music to hundreds of others.  Peter Kingston met her
fields.trailText: Ann Rachlin used to tell her own children stories at concerts. Now she imparts a love of music to hundreds of others. Peter Kingston met her
fields.body:
As bells ring for the end of school up and down the country, children are now faced with a huge choice of activities, from aikido to xylophone. And of course, there's the telly. So you wouldn't have a punt on many kids choosing the lives and works of the great composers to fill that awkward hour before tea.

But over the past 35 years, the thousands of three- to nine-year-olds who have turned up for Ann Rachlin's Fun With Music sessions have done just that.

Watching her lay out the hall in St John's Wood, London, it is still hard to make the leap of faith. Is she really going to deliver 45 minutes of Prokofiev to 25 seven- to nine-year-olds, three-quarters of them boys, without a serious riot?

For one thing, the neat rows of tables and chairs with an exercise book at each place look uncannily like the classrooms the kids will have just been detained in for a large part of the day.

But to this frankly unpromising setting opposite the main entrance to Lord's cricket ground kids come week after week from all over the capital and beyond, even from as far as Coventry. And, she says, they're from all social classes.

Princes William and Harry came for four years. At the end of sessions, Princess Diana would be waiting outside with the other parents.

There's a three-year waiting list. "Three months ago a lady rang me up saying she had a little girl she wanted to put on the waiting list," Rachlin says. "I asked for her date of birth. She said: 'Today. I had her two hours ago'."

This afternoon a senior class is going to do the great Sergei's ballet Romeo and Juliet. Or rather they are going to listen to Ann Rachlin tell the star-cross'd lovers' story accompanied by judiciously sliced musical excerpts.

While the tale is being told, they can doodle or scribble. And at each child's place is a plate of sandwiches and biscuits with a beaker of orange squash. "I realised when I started this that you can't tell stories to empty tummies," she explains.

And this is her secret, her little deception, if you like. "The children are utterly convinced that they are coming to have tea and hear stories. They are not aware they are learning about music."

The other crucial ingredients in the concoction are Rachlin's considerable gift for narrating a yarn and her wonderful rapport with children.

Some wear their days heavy. Shirt-tails hang out of trousers, ties are askew, hair is tousled, and one little lad inexplicably has a trainer on one foot and a shoe on the other.

Rachlin sits in a winged wickerwork chair, which is her trademark. "My peacock chair," she says.

When everyone has settled she throws out a question: who wrote the original Romeo and Juliet story? "Shakespeare," replies a small girl with a black pony tail.

And then we get the story. The two families who hate each other. She presses a remote control and a huge DAT player comes to life with the opening crescendo sequence.

"This is a story of fighting . . . of duals . . . of deception . . . and death ." At each word the music grows louder.

The blending of text and music is instantly effective. The children sit rapt. Some are concentratedly drawing the scenes being described. At certain points, Rachlin is almost rapping her words to the music.

As she describes the fatal Romeo-Tybalt duel, one lad is waving his arms, conducting the music.

"Next time," she announces at the end, "it'll be the wonderful opera Carmen with exciting bullfighting."

You realise that the children have been led gently by Rachlin through Prokofiev's great work with the minimum reference to the music. There is none of the obvious attempt to deconstruct the piece that used to happen in music appreciation classes.

And yet the music sticks with the children, she says. At the end of term she gives all her classes - the tiddlers (three to five), juniors (five and six) and seniors (seven to nine) - a quiz. They are asked to identify a medley of excerpts from the pieces they have covered that term.

"It's astonishing. They always get all the questions right," she says. Either they simply remember the music, or they make the link with the story or with the drawing they were doing at the time.

Like many marvellous ideas, this one started almost by accident. In 1965, Rachlin, then recently divorced, moved to London from Leeds. She took her small son for interview at a prep school and was miffed to have him described as "average" after a brief assessment.

"I told them that I had told my children stories when I took them to concerts." The school immediately asked her to come and teach what she had been doing. "My son and I started at the school on the same day."

After a year she branched out on her own. The first term, she started with three children after school. The second term, she had 180.

At her busiest she was running 10 classes a week with 260 children. Now she does three afternoons with 160-odd. Among them are the children of her earlier pupils. Last week her pupils past and present honoured her with a do at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden.

Over the years she has done her "Water Music" trip 77 times, taking a boatload of children along the Thames following the route Handel would have taken. And she's done umpteen Beethoven excursions through the Buckinghamshire countryside. Soon EMI will issue the twentieth CD of her narratives with music.

Ask if any of the children she has taught over the years has become a musician and she says she's not sure. "I'm not training musicians, I'm really training tomorrow's audiences," she says. "I want them to have a wonderful experience of music."

"I teach them that grown-ups sometimes are inhibited about listening to music. That if a composer has written funny music it's good to laugh, and if it's sad, then cry.

"If any of the children cry when Mimi dies at the end of La Bohème, I tell them I'm really proud of them. They're doing just what Puccini wants them to do."

webTitle: Trading places

fields.headline: Trading places
fields.trailText: Primrose Hill Primary School, London
fields.body:
Primrose Hill Primary School in London recently had a new head for the day, and in a rather unusual interview process involving nearly 500 applicants, the winner was chosen by raffle.

Initially proposed as a "fun day" fundraiser, the idea was that for one day only, a pupil would take over as head. But as the day drew nearer, the school decided to look at the wider education implications.

As well as the head, there would be an acting deputy and a member of the dinner staff. All the children were asked to "apply" for jobs by stating what they would do if they got one of them. Headteacher Koushi Silva was happy to let someone take over her role and she volunteered to take the winning child's place in class. "The whole school was buzzing," says Silva.

Although the initial plans involved the rather obvious - "If I were head of the school for the day, I would close it" - they opened up many opportunities for discussion. The children began to grasp the legal requirements of their education: that they have to receive education for five and a half hours on a specific number of days per year.

Lots of children seemed to like the idea of bossing people around, but ideas and views developed rapidly and by the end of the week things were serious. Silva was asked by one 10-year-old how to get government approval in time to complete the changes she wanted to enforce.

A week after the initial announcement, the raffle was drawn and the winners planned an agenda for the day. The new staff were Daniel Turner, age seven, headteacher; Keira Snoek, age 10, deputy head; and Kunle Joacquim, eight, dinner helper.

A newsletter announced the changes and forewarned staff they were to "wear something different" - most opted to wear their night clothes. Daniel and Silva swapped places in assembly, and Silva then spent Friday going from class to class, which is school policy for a new child. Meanwhile, Daniel and Keira also went from class to class - asking what the children had learnt and checking on continuity, presentation and handwriting.

They threw themselves into their roles, starting with playground duty while Silva was waiting for the lollipop man to help her cross the road. Keira took the infant assembly and admitted, "It was quite scary. My legs were all wobbly."

Their busy schedule was interrupted by naughty children who had been sent to the head. They were dealt with calmly, the problem resolved. Keira said an earlier tussle with a boy who had spat on the floor didn't go so well: "I had a bit of trouble with him."

Kunle Joacquim had a lot of fun being a dinner helper. His main duty appeared to be "telling people to be quiet and stuff". Some didn't take any notice, he said, but then, neither did he usually.

The three children all agreed they had a better understanding of what teachers do, and that it was easier to be children. The head - interrupted from his executive toy jigsaw - agreed that it was very hard work, and shot off for some more playground duty. Joacquim went to help clear up after lunch. And Keira looked at a huge pile of post and wondered how on earth she would stay awake at a party that evening.

For Silva, it was an opportunity to see what really mattered to the children. "I've got a different perspective on the school. I had a different level of conversation with the children." Silva stressed that one of the attractions of the project was the chance of creating a better understanding. "Adults don't always take the time to explain decisions that are made on behalf of the children, and through this role reversal, the children clearly saw what is involved in the running of the school."

Not only was a good time had by all, but £250 was raised, and the exercise is already being spoken of as an annual event.

webTitle: The Leadership College prepares for the 21st-century

fields.headline: 'Very nice, and very busy...'
fields.standfirst: ... one child's definition of a good headteacher. As the new Leadership College for senior teachers prepares to open its doors,  Dave Hill asks its director - and others - to define the role of the 21st-century head
fields.trailText: ... one child's definition of a good headteacher. As the new Leadership College for senior teachers prepares to open its doors, Dave Hill asks its director - and others - to define the role of the 21st-century head
fields.body:
They are remote megalomaniacs. They are charismatic human dynamos. They are tyrants, heroes, team-builders. They are monsters, managers, oddballs. And sometimes they are all these things at once. They are, of course, headteachers and what ever else is felt about them it will never be indifference. But what is their job really all about in the modern world? Are they as good at it as they should be?

On Thursday, a new seat of learning will be launched, dedicated to making heads and other senior teachers better at their job. The National College for Leadership in Education will eventually be based in Nottingham. Its director is Heather Du Quesnay (pronounced "Du Kenny"), former director of education at Lambeth and a former secondary deputy head, too.

Du Quesnay explains that a key aim of the college, proudly billed as the first of its kind in the world, is to develop "a coherent approach", a "more continuous strategy" for different stages of a head's career. At present there are three quite separate programmes of leadership training: the National Professional Qualification for Heads; the Headship Leadership and Management Programme; and the Leadership Programme for Serving Heads. The national college will preside over all these.

But so much for the rationalising remit. What sorts of skills and qualities will the college be seeking to develop in those who head our schools? Du Quesnay has a list:

 a real passion to make a difference

 an ability to motivate and inspire

 a vision for the school's progress; the capacity to implement that vision in a manner that is manageable for the school community

 a commitment to continuous monitoring and checking

 and "a steely will, a real determination to see things through - stamina"

The last of these rings an immediate bell with many heads. "Boundless energy is what you need," says Judith Mullen, brought in to lead a "fresh start" initiative at Leicester's New College secondary school. It's "the ability to go without sleep," says Steve Crowther - a female Steve - who is the new head at Durrington High, Worthing.

Pupils see it that way, too: "She's busy," said a group of reception class pupils from St Scholastica's primary school in Hackney when asked about their head. "Very nice, and very busy."

Even those who regard heads as egomaniacs first and anything else second usually agree the job is more pressured now than ever. Gerald Harley is a former head who now helps serving heads in various Midlands local education authorities as a trainer and consultant. At a recent gathering of primary heads he was hugely depressed by what he heard. Asked to list the things that made their jobs rewarding and those that made them despair, they had far more of the latter type to offer. "They were so stressed, so pissed off," Harley laments.

Most complaints were all too familiar: the ever-growing paper mountains of guidance and directives; the looming spectre of Ofsted; the horrible kids who won't behave. But there are newer things, too. Harley notes in particular the seemingly inexorable increase in what he calls "rottweiler parents," the ones who sink their teeth in over one grievance or another and won't let go, threatening legal action, attending exclusion hearings armed with barristers.

"As a head you only need two or three of those on the go and you've got almost no time left for anything else."

Another growing problem is finding and retaining teaching staff. "Some schools have had to stop modern languages because they just can't get the teachers," says Harley. Then there are the primary teachers who won't take on a Year 6 class because they don't need the grief of SATs targets. The same goes for secondary school teachers over GCSEs. "I know one school where a very good classroom teacher has just told the head she will leave unless she's let off teaching Year 11."

Not everyone sympathises. It does not take much digging to find teachers who think heads have too much power and exercise it badly. June Summers, an experienced head of department at a secondary school in Cornwall, has had a succession of bad experiences with heads. "In comparison with leaders in industry they are way out of date," she says. "While all the talk in modern firms is about co-operation and teamwork, heads are still busy bossing everyone about."

Summers has found most of her bosses autocratic, absurd, or both. Not that a big personality is always a bad thing. Ted Smart, an English teacher at a Yorkshire secondary, describes his long-serving head as stamping his unique style on everything. No one can quite fathom what he's up to half the time, but somehow it seems to work. "He gives staff reasonable freedom to do things their own way and he's a bit of a character. On non-uniform days he always turns up dressed like some kind of Latin lover and he acts up to the part. He's pretty eccentric, but he's well respected. The welfare of his kids always comes first with him. It's quite a tough school and if he wasn't there it could easily become a disaster."

And what of heads themselves? For Steve Crowther at Durrington High, Worthing, patience, determination and "a commitment to caring for others" are top of her list - "others" meaning her pupils and all her staff equally.

New College is different. It has 226 staff and 1,620 pupils mostly drawn from what used to be three separate schools, two of them placed under special measures, while the other had many serious weaknesses. "In this school the bottom line's got to mean the bottom line."

In it he does his best to tease out the essentials: "The art of it is having the vision, articulating it to the school community, and then taking staff and pupils with you down that road. You have to be prepared to put your head above the parapet, and you have to realise it can be a very lonely job indeed."

webTitle: Sweet-talking lawyers hit by home truths

fields.headline: Sweet-talking lawyers hit by home truths
fields.standfirst: Work of 47 lawyers put to the test as Florida's supreme court reserves judgment on validity of hand recounts
fields.trailText: Two of the most eminent big city lawyers in the United States were subjected to a workout based on down-home jurisprudence yesterday as they attempted to sweet-talk their respective clients into the White House.
fields.body:
Two of the most eminent big city lawyers in the United States were subjected to a workout based on down-home jurisprudence yesterday as they attempted to sweet-talk their respective clients into the White House.

Never mind clause 103.101, or even 102.001, when did Florida's votes really need to be in? And what was wrong with a new state-wide election, the seven members of the state supreme court wanted to know.

Chief Justice Charles Wells, a gap-toothed natural for the Raymond Burr role of Perry Mason, and his colleagues interrupted constantly the perorations of the stars of the north.

New York's David Boies, the $700-an-hour lead lawyer in the US government's case against Microsoft, was attempting on behalf of Al Gore to persuade the judges that manually recounted votes should be valid; Washington's Michael Carvin, a former deputy assistant attorney general in the Reagan administration, was trying to do the opposite in the cause of George W Bush.

"Are you telling the court that any mark made by the voter on the ballot should be counted?" Mr Boies was asked. "I think so," he replied. If manual recounts are acceptable in Texas - where Mr Bush is governor - what's wrong with having them in Florida, it was demanded of Mr Carvin. "I really don't know about Texas law."

Forty-seven lawyers represented the parties before the court yesterday in a part of the state that gives the lie to the perception that Florida is not really in the deep south.

Some of them must have seen the sign outside a business that might otherwise have been recommending its catfish and chicken wings: "Lawyers go home. Take media with you."

Only a few of the presidential candidates' attorneys had a role in the two hour and 30 minute hearing in the court framed by palms and oak, a building seemingly plucked from Gone with the Wind and deposited at the feet of the state's 22-storey seat of government.

Normally these branches of government are separated by the constitution, but yesterday nine satellite broadcast trucks also drew a line in the street between the executive and the judiciary.

Only 128 seats were available for the public, interested members of which were advised to start forming an orderly line at 8am, six hours before the hearing started. But the people of Tallahassee were not exactly falling over themselves at first to see "history in the making".

By 8.45am five were there to claim places on the stained-wood benches, among them John Trommershausser, a 79-year-old former air force colonel. "I never get tired of something like this," he said from within a beige raincoat rebuking the reputation of the Sunshine State. "It's like a carnival. We want to see the supreme court in action."

But the colonel with the white moustache, who would otherwise have been playing golf, was not there just to see the show. "I don't have a problem with one recount, but when they go on and on and on ... the Queen of England wrings the neck of a pheasant? What's she doing that for? Not that I'm against it. I'd like to wring the necks of some of those recounters."

As he spoke, the band played on, or at least a woman dressed in red, white and blue and alternating between accordion and banjo. "Put the vote back the way it's suppos'd to be/please put the world back in order for me," she sang.

Inside, up 10 marble steps, through metal doors and under portraits of former members of the court, the judges decided not to issue a ruling before today.

Only one voice in Tallahassee spoke with certainty about what was going to happen. Pastor J Douglas Dortch had posted his daily message outside the First Baptist Church on Adams Street a few blocks away from the court: "Thank God it's nearly all over."

webTitle: Fowl play triumphs in dockside stunt

fields.headline: Fowl play triumphs in dockside stunt
fields.standfirst:
Greenpeace operation springs a surprise on soya bean importers as lifesize 'Rhode Island reds' mix it with disgruntled guards

Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Chickens about to be slaughtered go very silent, hold their wings to their breasts and huddle together with large sad eyes.
fields.body:
Chickens about to be slaughtered go very silent, hold their wings to their breasts and huddle together with large sad eyes.

We know this because, at 7.35am yesterday, a delivery of 60 of Britain's finest naturally-reared arrived at Liverpool docks in the back of several large rented vans, courtesy of well-known global poulterers Greenpeace.

Waving tickets for the Ireland ferry, the vans sped through the perimeter wall of the docks with ease. Half a mile further they reached the gates of Cargill's, Britain's largest importer of GM soya beans, which are fed mainly to animals.

The first two vans passed four sleepy guards, saying only that they had a "delivery". The third stopped on the corporate weighbridge and immobilised its air brakes blocking the route into the factory yard.

On a co-ordinated squawk the rear doors of the vans were flung open and the chickens rushed out into the vile-smelling, steam-shrouded works. Flapping their little felt wings, tripping over their giant talons and clucking like a coach load of VIPs at the dome, the liberated flock danced their way in as Tannoys blared out from the vans the sound of an industrial poultry shed.

Cargill's, which also happens to be the world's largest grain and food trader, turning over £40bn a year, was metaphorically stuffed. "Tossers," yelled one of the guards flapping his own arms in sympathy with 30 chickens who flew past him.

Fair and foul

It probably helped that at this very moment, a mighty hail storm broke - summoned, it is thought, by John Prescott and environmentalists at the Hague global warming talks. What until then had been 60 passable Rhode Island reds and four cocky-looking guards became in one minute sodden, floppy-combed, wilting beaked fowl and even fouler-mouthed security men. Dry chaos, in short, became miserable farce. "Shit, shit, shit," yelled a guard, cursing the weather as much as the chickens. "Stop, stop. This is private land. Leave at once. Now!"

"Chicken tonight," taunted a funky giant rooster leading a dash for one of the many 80ft high silos where the GM soya is stored before being crushed into oil and distributed to animal seed companies around Britain.

Within 10 minutes eight well-seasoned climbers had locked themselves to a conveyer belt 60ft above ground, intending to roost at least two nights. Meanwhile, eight more poultry were getting broody up on the silos, while the rest of the flock was being shooed off lorries and out of buildings by whoever Cargill's could persuade to brave the storm.

A giant alsatian barely restrained by a guard nipped the wing of one chicken; but most were led away as first the dock police, then customs and excise, and finally Liverpool's finest arrived on the scene.

Outside the perimeter fence 10 chickens who had been prevented from entering performed for the benefit of arriving Cargill's drivers and workers. Opinions were divided on the quality of the matinee theatre.

"I haven't laughed so much on a Monday morning in years," said one. "Chicken shit," said another.

A third declared his undying respect for Greenpeace and hatred for the company where he had worked for years: "Good on them. It's about time someone took these bastards on. They think they can get away with anything." He then whispered loudly that Greenpeace should try another Cargill depot.

"They're canny. They keep the GM well clear of this place." He drew a map suggesting the best way in.

Greenpeace was positively clucking at its success following its recent acquittal for partly destroying a GM maize field last year. The 60 chickens were cock-a-hoop too. They included a vicar, teachers, an athletic coach, an accountant, and a sewing machinist.

Having largely persuaded the super markets and food processors to ban GM soya in human foodstuff, the Cargill's attack opened up a whole new front for the anti-GM protesters.

"Few people know that almost every chicken and pig sold in Britain in the past three years has been fed on GM food. It is still massively in the food chain," said a Greenpeace spokesman yesterday.

A recent poll, he said, suggested that 57% of people did not want animals to be fed GM food, and 90% said they wanted full labelling on all meat rearedusing GM food. No one knew the exact quantities of GM animal foodstuff imported into Britain. A 1999 agriculture minister report suggested that "a substantial proportion of the 2m tons of soya, 1.1m tons of maize and 0.5m tons of distillers' grains used in animal feed [in Britain] could contain material derived from GM varieties".

Segregation

In April the then farms minister, Jeff Rooker, told a select committee: "You have to assume that anything imported from America will probably be mixed up with GM organisms."

A spokeswoman for Cargill's was at a loss yesterday to understand why Greenpeace kept targeting the firm. Earlier this year the group occupied a GM soya boat, and last week it projected "nasty" videos on one of the firm's sheds.

"But we do segregate GM and non-GM soya. We are very responsible. We only respond to what our customers want. If they specify GM soya, we will provide it. If they want non-GM, we will get it for them, too."

She said that more companies were specifying non-GM animal feed, even at a higher price.

"But we don't want to sit down to talk about it with Greenpeace. They don't seem to like us for some peculiar reason. We even work with children to educate them about the environment."

Last week both McDonald's and Burger King said they would no longer sell meat from animals fed GM foods, following Sainsbury's, Iceland, Marks and Spencer, Nestle, Unilever and others. Anti-GM campaigners said there was still uncertainty as to whether commitments applied to all foods and ingredients.

Last night police said eight people had been arrested, and Greenpeace said four people remained chained up on the silos. "We'll continue to harass Cargill's until it ends these GM food imports and stops contaminating our food chain," clucked their spokesman.

webTitle: Jail for detective who got Ripper to confess

fields.headline: Jail for detective who got Ripper to confess
fields.trailText: The detective who persuaded Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutcliffe to confess was yesterday jailed for six months at Leeds crown court for selling confidential information from the police national computer to private detectives.
fields.body:
The detective who persuaded Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutcliffe to confess was yesterday jailed for six months at Leeds crown court for selling confidential information from the police national computer to private detectives.

Detective Inspector John Boyle, 64, retired after 31 years' distinguished service, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit misconduct in a public office.

The serving officer who supplied him, PC James Burrell, 47, admitted the same offence and was jailed for 15 months.

Boyle, of Wyke, Bradford, was instrumental in getting the Yorkshire Ripper to con fess as he interviewed him at Dewsbury police station in January 1981. Sutcliffe admitted being the serial killer after Boyle questioned him about his trips to Sheffield.

The court heard how Boyle, who worked as an agent for detective agencies, got PC Burrell, of Wakefield, West Yorkshire, to pass on information from vehicle registration and criminal background checks.

PC Burrell, the crime evaluator in the divisional intelligence unit at West Yorkshire police, bought cheap liquor from Boyle in return for the confidential information.

The court heard how Boyle earned as little as £10 and £20 for passing on information to Bradford-based private investigator Javid Butt, 36, who in turn passed some of the information on to Manchester-based investigator Nitin Patel, 35, between February 1998 and January 1999.

PC Burrell made 121 non-authorised vehicle checks and 32 criminal record checks during the 12-month period.

Two undercover police officers posing as criminals went to the respective private investigators and successfully bought information from them.

The court heard how the chief constable of West Yorkshire authorised a phone tap on Burrell's line at the force's Wakefield base.

When interviewed by police Boyle immediately confessed his actions. The court heard how some of the information he obtained from his police contact was used by a large company in the north east to get background information on employees engaged in a union dispute.

Other people found themselves being followed by their former partners, ex-husband, co-habitee or inquiry agent and one person took out an injunction to prevent further harassment.

Butt, from Idle, Bradford, was jailed for four months after admitting conspiracy to commit misconduct. Patel, from Cheetham Hill, Manchester, was jailed for two months after admitting a similar offence.

Passing sentence, the judge told Boyle he had thrown away his reputation as a distinguished detective.
fields.bodyText: The detective who persuaded Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutcliffe to confess was yesterday jailed for six months at Leeds crown court for selling confidential information from the police national computer to private detectives. Detective Inspector John Boyle, 64, retired after 31 years' distinguished service, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit misconduct in a public office. The serving officer who supplied him, PC James Burrell, 47, admitted the same offence and was jailed for 15 months. Boyle, of Wyke, Bradford, was instrumental in getting the Yorkshire Ripper to con fess as he interviewed him at Dewsbury police station in January 1981. Sutcliffe admitted being the serial killer after Boyle questioned him about his trips to Sheffield. The court heard how Boyle, who worked as an agent for detective agencies, got PC Burrell, of Wakefield, West Yorkshire, to pass on information from vehicle registration and criminal background checks. PC Burrell, the crime evaluator in the divisional intelligence unit at West Yorkshire police, bought cheap liquor from Boyle in return for the confidential information. The court heard how Boyle earned as little as £10 and £20 for passing on information to Bradford-based private investigator Javid Butt, 36, who in turn passed some of the information on to Manchester-based investigator Nitin Patel, 35, between February 1998 and January 1999. PC Burrell made 121 non-authorised vehicle checks and 32 criminal record checks during the 12-month period. Two undercover police officers posing as criminals went to the respective private investigators and successfully bought information from them. The court heard how the chief constable of West Yorkshire authorised a phone tap on Burrell's line at the force's Wakefield base. When interviewed by police Boyle immediately confessed his actions. The court heard how some of the information he obtained from his police contact was used by a large company in the north east to get background information on employees engaged in a union dispute. Other people found themselves being followed by their former partners, ex-husband, co-habitee or inquiry agent and one person took out an injunction to prevent further harassment. Butt, from Idle, Bradford, was jailed for four months after admitting conspiracy to commit misconduct. Patel, from Cheetham Hill, Manchester, was jailed for two months after admitting a similar offence. Passing sentence, the judge told Boyle he had thrown away his reputation as a distinguished detective.

webTitle: Timetable despair

fields.headline: Timetable despair
fields.standfirst:
Passengers face delays and changes

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Train companies finally published their emergency timetables yesterday but ran into a storm of protest that they were not worth the paper they were written on.
fields.body:
Train companies finally published their emergency timetables yesterday but ran into a storm of protest that they were not worth the paper they were written on.

Passengers were infuriated by warnings to expect long delays on some routes. They were told that timetables could be changed from week to week.

George Muir, director general of the Association of Train Operating Companies, said that the new timetable would only cover this week and that it was hoping to roll out future timetables.

He told the BBC's Today programme: "I am afraid it does remain uncertain. These are very difficult times."

Later Mr Muir said that 16 operators would be running near normal services with minor adjustments and delays on some longer journeys.

Stewart Francis, chairman of the rail passengers' council, said: "We do need to know whether these emergency timetables will stick and so far there is little evidence that they are doing so."

Mr Francis travelled by train yesterday from Peterborough to London, a journey which would have normally taken 50 minutes. The emergency timetable said it would take 90 minutes, but it was two hours before he arrived at King's Cross.

Mr Francis said: "Passengers have been amazingly patient, but this is wearing thin. People are simply not travelling by train while the uncertainty lasts and this is not good for the long term future. It needs to get back to normal as soon as possible."

Great North Eastern Railways, which operates the east coast main line, warned that the normal London to Edinburgh journey of four hours 20 minutes was now taking about eight hours.

Under the Virgin west coast timetable, half the off peak trains London to Birmingham trains will not be running.

webTitle: US elections: Tellers count their blessings

fields.headline: Tellers count their blessings
fields.standfirst:
Thanksgiving: Turkey takes precedence over ballots

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The eyes of the world may be focused on Florida's turkey of an election, but later this week the eyes of Florida will be fixed firmly on the turkey on the dinner table, while the election and the world will both be strictly ignored.
fields.body:
The eyes of the world may be focused on Florida's turkey of an election, but later this week the eyes of Florida will be fixed firmly on the turkey on the dinner table, while the election and the world will both be strictly ignored.

Everything in America stops for Thanksgiving - including the nail-biting recounts in Florida. For most Americans, the four-and-a-half day holiday consists of a series of unchanging rituals, starting with a rush to the airports tomorrow, traditionally the busiest civil aviation day of the year.

The turkey dinner with relatives, consumed against a televised backdrop of the Dallas Cowboys versus Minnesota Vikings football game, takes place on Thursday. This is followed by two time-honoured days of frenzied Christmas shopping, and a final day on Sunday queuing at the airports before the return journey.

The three Florida counties engaged in the massive task of recounting 1.7m votes face very different schedules as the holiday deadline approaches.

In Broward county, the tellers are well advanced with the recount of 588,000 votes and were hoping to have completed their task by 6pm yesterday.

In Palm Beach county, tellers expected to reach the halfway point sometime yesterday in their recount of 462,000 votes, and the prospects of finishing the whole exercise in time for Thanksgiving are too close to call, just like the election itself.

Counters in the third county, Miami-Dade, face a hopeless task in meeting the holiday deadline. Their recount of 654,000 votes only began yesterday, and is scheduled to proceed on an 8am-8pm timetable today and tomorrow.

"We will stop recounting a bit early on Wednesday and resume again on Friday," a spokeswoman said. "Then we'll count [on] Saturday and Sunday and until the job is done".

webTitle: US elections: few attend high court verdict

fields.headline: No clamour to see history made
fields.standfirst:
Work of 47 lawyers fails to pull in the public at supreme court
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: At least something was clear at the start of the hearing yesterday that just might determine the identity of the next president of the United States: the sound of an official booming "Oyez, oyez, oyez," to bring the court to order.
fields.body:
At least something was clear at the start of the hearing yesterday that just might determine the identity of the next president of the United States: the sound of an official booming "Oyez, oyez, oyez," to bring the court to order.

Not that this was a particularly onerous task in the Florida supreme court, with no witnesses, jury, or cross-examination but only the arguments of lawyers, 47 of whom now represent the three parties appearing before the court.

Some of them must have seen the sign outside a business that might otherwise have been recommending its catfish and chicken wings: "Lawyers go home. Take media with you."

Vice-president Al Gore wants the seven members of the supreme court - six Democrats and one independent - to allow hand recounts in south Florida to be included in the final tally because he believes that would put him in the White House; Texas governor George W Bush wants the counts stopped for the same reason; and the state's secretary of state Katherine Harris wants the bench to rule that she is right in refusing to accept votes received after last Tuesday's deadline.

But only a few of their attorneys had a role in the court, framed by palms and oak, a building seemingly plucked from Gone With The Wind and deposited at the feet of the state's 22-storey seat of government.

These branches of government are separated by the constitution, but yesterday nine satellite broadcast trucks also drew a line in the street between the executive and the judiciary.

Only 128 seats were available for the public, interested members of which were advised to start forming an orderly line at 8am, six hours before the hearing was to start. But the people of Tallahassee were not exactly falling over themselves at first to see "history in the making".

By 8.45am only five people were there to claim places on the stained-wood benches, among them John Trommershausser, a 79-year-old former air force colonel.

"I never get tired of something like this," he said from within a beige raincoat rebuk ing the reputation of the Sunshine State. "It's like a carnival. We want to see the supreme court in action."

As he spoke, the band played on, or at least a woman dressed in red, white and blue and alternating between accordian and banjo. "Put the vote back the way it's suppos'd to be/ Please put the world back in order for me," she sang

Inside, up 10 marble steps, through metal doors and under portraits of former members of the court, the three main lawyers went about their tasks: David Boies, the $700 (£492) an hour Willie Nelson fan who was lead lawyer for the US government in its case against Microsoft, speaking for Mr Gore; Michael Carvin, a deputy assistant attorney-general during the Reagan administration, for Mr Bush; and Joseph Klock, from a Democrat-leaning Miami law firm who nonetheless represents Ms Harris, a multi-millionaire friend of the Bushes.

After the legal argument, the judges met in private to consider the matter. They were expected to take up to two days mulling over the ruling. The court is regarded as independent and has clashed with Governor Jeb Bush over use of the electric chair and affirmative action.

Only one voice in Tallahassee spoke with certainty about what was going to happen. Pastor J Douglas Dortch had posted his daily message outside the First Baptist Church on Adams Street a few blocks away from the court: "Thank God it's nearly all over."

webTitle: Democrats divided on how long to fight

fields.headline: Democrats divided on how long to fight
fields.standfirst:
Tactics: Fear of backlash if recount hands Gore the presidency

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The Democrats were divided yesterday over how much further Al Gore should pursue his post-election struggle for the White House, as analysts predicted that a Gore presidency could inflict more damage on the party than a graceful surrender.
fields.body:
The Democrats were divided yesterday over how much further Al Gore should pursue his post-election struggle for the White House, as analysts predicted that a Gore presidency could inflict more damage on the party than a graceful surrender.

Meanwhile, Republicans closed ranks behind George W Bush, and threatened to fight the vice-president all the way to the electoral college and beyond if Mr Gore continued his attempts to force acceptance of Florida recount results through the courts.

Bob Dole, the former Republican presidential candidate, called for a boycott of a Gore inauguration. And Tom DeLay, the majority whip in the House of Representatives, has sent out a memorandum to congressional Republicans reminding them they have the right to challenge the electoral college votes of any states where the presidential election is disputed - a clear sign that the Republicans could try to overturn a Gore win arising from the manual recount in Florida.

The top Democratic leadership in Congress has so far stood by the Gore campaign's insistence on a hand recount. "We want you to know all of us are behind you," Dick Gephardt, the House minority leader, said. He was echoed by his Senate counterpart, Tom Daschle.

However, many inside the party are increasingly concerned that if Al Gore won as a result of the manual recount his presidency would be crippled by vengeful Republicans, who would be mobilise for a backlash in the 2002 congressional elections.

Senior officials in the Gore camp have promised the Democratic Party hierarchy that they do not intend to pursue new legal challenges, and John Breaux, a centrist Democratic senator from Louisiana, called for the vice-president to throw in the towel if he lost his case in Florida's highest court.

"I would like to see that be the final decision. It's called the supreme court for a reason," Senator Breaux said.

Mr Gore and his running mate, Joe Lieberman, are said to be convinced they won the popular vote in Florida. But as the hand recount process has dragged on with no significant gains for Mr Gore, rank-and-file restlessness has increased tangibly.

The Democrats failed in their bid to take control of the House of Representatives, while the Senate will either be tied 50-50 or will have a 51-49 Republican majority, depending on the outcome of a count of absentee ballots in Washington state. In preparatory meetings for the new Congress Democrats have openly been talking about the prospects of working with a Bush administration.

Meanwhile, Republicans in Congress would almost certainly present a united front against a Gore attempt to work with Congress.

Norman Ornstein, an analyst at the American Enterprise Institute, said: "I can't think of a single Republican who, if Gore became president, would serve as an intermediary. That will make it tough."

As a newcomer, Mr Bush would have fewer enemies from past Washington battles, but is unlikely to benefit from the normal presidential honeymoon. Meanwhile, as the recount further delays the result, the time remaining for a presidential transition is eroding.

The Texas governor would have to put together an entire political class, filling 3,000 jobs in the new administration, 600 of which are subject to Senate confirmation which can take up to eight months. A transition office in Washington is currently standing empty as the government general services administration does not know which side to hand the keys to. Similarly, the FBI has been unable to begin security clearance interviews with new appointees.

Mr Gore, as an incumbent vice-president, would suffer less from the truncated transition than the Texas governor, an unknown quantity in the capital. Deriding Washington politics was a keynote of Mr Bush's election campaign.

Republican officials have repeatedly insisted that a wafer-thin victory margin would not necessarily handcuff a Bush administration. They point to John F Kennedy's iconic presidency, still remembered affectionately as "Camelot", which arose from an extremely tight election race with Richard Nixon in 1960, in which the results were just as controversial as the present scramble for ballots. Democrats, just as frequently, have pointed out that George W Bush is no Jack Kennedy.

webTitle: Fresh inquiry as dome sold for £125m

fields.headline: Fresh inquiry as dome sold for £125m
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The government yesterday tried to lay to rest a disastrous year of financial ineptitude and incompetence over the running of the Millennium Dome by selling the building to a company owned by a Labour donor for £125m.
fields.body:
The government yesterday tried to lay to rest a disastrous year of financial ineptitude and incompetence over the running of the Millennium Dome by selling the building to a company owned by a Labour donor for £125m.

The deal however immediately triggered fresh embarrassment for ministers as Parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office, confirmed it is to launch a second inquiry - this time into how ministers handled the sale.

The investigation follows a damning report from the auditors on the fiasco from which neither the directors of the dome company nor the cabinet office minister and sole shareholder in the project, Lord Falconer, emerged with any credit.

Half the projected visitors never materialise, it had to be bailed out to the tune of £229m from the national lottery and Chris Smith, the millennium chairman and culture secretary, twice had to overrule senior civil servants to prevent it going bust.

The deal, finally approved by John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, and Lord Falconer yesterday, means property developer Legacy will turn the dome into a hi-tech business park which it claims will create 14,000 jobs on the peninsula in north Greenwich, London.

Legacy is headed by property entrepreneur Robert Bourne, who has financially backed the Islington South Labour constituency party of Chris Smith. This connection has meant that Mr Smith has not been involved in negotiations to choose a company to take over the dome, which is owned by regeneration company English Partnerships.

Mr Bourne said last night: "I am delighted that we have now been selected as preferred bidder to take purchase of the Millennium Dome."

Mr Bourne, 50, said his company's creation - to be known as Knowledge City - would aim to become "one of the world's leading centres of innovation and excellence in the fields of high technologies, e-commerce and bio-science, so that the dome can become a real symbol of Enterprise Britain".

The deal and the collapse of the previous bid from Dome Europe, a company set up by Japanese bankers Nomura, will be the subject of forensic scrutiny by auditors and the Commons public accounts committee. They will also want to know what weight was given by ministers to knocking down the building and selling the site - particularly as that could have raised up to £300m, more than double the money obtained from Mr Bourne.

David Davis, Tory chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, said: "We will want to examine all the negotiations surrounding the sale of the dome including the failed bid by Nomura."

Ministers strongly defended the deal. Lord Falconer last night hailed the plans as offering "a high-quality, hi-tech and exciting future for the dome, for Londoners and especially the people of Greenwich."

Hilary Armstrong, minister for local government and the regions, said Legacy had "confirmed that they will resolve all outstanding contractual issues within an agreed timetable".

Dome chief executive David James defended the decision not to knock it down. "I am certain they are not going to bull doze it. That would not be part of the acceptable arrangement."

The Tories were highly critical of the deal. Shadow culture secretary Peter Ainsworth said the deal smacked of "dither, delay, prevarication and cronyism". He added: "Despite receiving a number of expressions of interest, the government insisted on continuing a hole-in-the-corner exclusive dialogue with Legacy plc, headed by Labour donor Robert Bourne.

"This deal has more to do with political expediency and prime ministerial face saving than it has to do with value for money."

webTitle: Straw extends youth tagging

fields.headline: Straw extends youth tagging
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The government last night signalled a crackdown on yob culture by announcing a nationwide electronic tagging scheme for all 10 to 15-year- olds as a part of an attempt to extend curfew orders on the young.
fields.body:
The government last night signalled a crackdown on yob culture by announcing a nationwide electronic tagging scheme for all 10 to 15-year- olds as a part of an attempt to extend curfew orders on the young.

Most curfews will require convicted youngsters to stay off the street at night.

The measure follows a pilot project in 20 courts in Greater Manchester and Norfolk initiated by the last Conservative government's home secretary, Michael Howard.

The powers to impose the curfew orders nationwide will be handed to courts early next year.

The Home Office claimed commissioned research showed that the tagged curfew orders were popular with sentencers and that, generally, offenders and their families preferred to deal with the restrictions of the tagged curfew rather than the alternative of a custodial sentence.

However, the study of the pilot programme also showed that low use of curfews stemmed from the belief that they were suitable only for a small number of young offenders. Social workers pointed out that nigthtime curfews could exacerbate tensions at home or add to a lack of familiy stability.

The scheme was attacked by the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders and by Harry Fletcher, assistant general secretary of the National Association of Probation Officers.

webTitle: CJD fears could lead to blood donor ban

fields.headline: CJD fears could lead to blood donor ban
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: The NHS is considering banning anyone who has received blood transfusions from giving blood themselves amid rising concerns that they may unknowingly pass on the fatal human variant of BSE.
fields.body:
The NHS is considering banning anyone who has received blood transfusions from giving blood themselves amid rising concerns that they may unknowingly pass on the fatal human variant of BSE.

Such a move could cut Britain's 1.9m volunteer donors by up to 10% and create such huge shortages that transfusion services would struggle to meet demand.

The possibility, first secretly investigated two years ago, is being re-examined as EU scientists and officials decide whether guidance should be offered on blood safety throughout the union.

But some insiders are concerned that such a drastic step could create a level of panic among the whole donor population that would threaten more lives through shortages than might be saved from what is, at present, regarded as only a theoretical risk.

Seven of the 85 British victims of variant CJD, the human equivalent of BSE, have been identified as donors before they showed obvious symptoms of the disease. Recipients of their blood have not been informed but the Department of Health and ethics committees on health authorities are seeking to develop protocols for doing so in the future.

There is as yet no test for detecting vCJD and many patients might not wish to know whether they had been exposed to the risk of a condition for which there is not even at present a treatment to moderate its effects, let alone cure it.

White blood cells are already filtered out of blood donations because they have been thought most likely to carry the agent responsible for vCJD and there is a ban on most British-sourced plasma products.

But the government is anxious to test whether red blood cells carry the agent too. Importing enough blood to meet needs in operating theatres in this country - 2.5m units a year, each about a pint - would be impossible because of its short shelf life so all options that might minimise the threat of contamination are now being reassessed.

The health department confirmed last night that it had ordered the review as to whether those who had received transfusions should be eligible to be blood donors. "The whole issue of cleanliness [of blood] is under review. This is just part of that."

A spokesman for the national blood service said: "We have been working on the basis [that] between 5% and 10% of blood donors have received transfusions. If it were the case that 10% were knocked off our donor data base, we would be struggling to meet the needs of the country."

At present, potential donors are not routinely asked whether they have received blood themselves. Some donors may not even know because by no means all operations involve transfusions.

But the service is to question new donors among the 10% of volunteers it has to recruit each year to replace those who can no longer donate blood, or choose not to, in an effort to assess the position more accurately.

Belgium, Austria and some German states, as well as Switzerland, are already following the example of the United States, Australia, Canada and New Zealand in banning donations from anyone who spent more than six months in the UK between 1980 and 1996, the years in which exposure to BSE through infected meat, vaccines, cosmetics or other possible routes was highest.

The blood authorities in those countries considered they could stand the loss of such donors.

It is also understood that the NHS is in discussions with Jehovah's Witnesses about their experience with recycling of patients' own blood during operations and other blood-saving techniques, as officials and surgeons step up their search for alternatives to traditional donation so they can eke out supplies.

Witnesses have already raised funds for several machines in NHS hospitals that wash and process blood lost in surgery for transfusion back into the same patients.

webTitle: Yesterday in parliament

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText:
Good day
Quote of the day
Today
fields.body:
Good day

Residents plagued by nuisance neighbours. Anti-social behaviour orders which aim to rid estates of "neighbours from hell" are making a real difference, the Home Office minster, Paul Boateng, told MPs. The orders have been used to target car thieves, prostitutes, and juveniles, with one order imposed on a boy of 10.

Quote of the day

Home secretary Jack Straw, to his Tory opposite number, Ann Widdecombe, in a debate over police numbers and crime: "If I was not such a generous man, I might say after that that you had gone to pot." Miss Widdecombe's had to rethink her policy on cannabis after she was ridiculed for her Tory conference speech saying there should be fixed fines on anyone caught in possession of the drug.

Today

Commons: Health questions. Police (Northern Ireland) bill, Lords amendments. Westminster Hall: Backbench debates on European commission's proposals for the EU sugar regime; educational maintenance allowance for Cornish students; coastal environment of the eastern region; post office closures. Lords: Political parties, elections and referendums bill, report.

webTitle: Sketch: Screen grotesques and the comedy of horrors

fields.headline: Screen grotesques and the comedy of horrors
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Home Office questions these days looks as if two popular films have been jumbled together. The reels are all over the place and the spotty youth up in the projection room doesn't know in which order to run them.
fields.body:
Home Office questions these days looks as if two popular films have been jumbled together. The reels are all over the place and the spotty youth up in the projection room doesn't know in which order to run them.

The government home affairs team are taking part in that well loved Ealing comedy The Ladykillers. The late Sir Alec Guinness stars as the leader of the gang, trying to persuade a sweet old lady to rent out a room to them as a base for their heist. Jack Straw, as the boss, has the same big sad saucer eyes as Sir Alec, the same sinisterly deferential courtesy, and I picture him with a long woollen scarf around his neck.

Behind him are his thuggish sidekicks: Clarke, the gang's hard man, and Boateng, its dodgy brief. They are trying, vainly, to look cultured since, in order to allay the old lady's suspicions, they are pretending to be members of a musical quintet. Whenever her doubts are aroused, the Straw/Guinness character flashes her an especially cadaverous smile.

But just as we've watched the first reel of this vintage comedy, suddenly we're switched to the Tory benches, and an Austin Powers movie, all madcap surrealist capers and improbable grotesques. The star villain is Dr Evilette, played by Ann Widdecombe. She also has a miniature version of herself, three feet tall, called Mini-Me, played by John Bercow, the rebarbative and quarrelsome MP for Buckingham.

Dr Evilette began by quoting some secret document she had come by. It recounted a meeting between the home secretary and the prime minister, at which they discussed, she said, "a new agenda for reform of the police - and I quote - 'this was not being brought forward because of the risk of alienating the police at a crucial time'."

What, she demanded, was this reform which was going to trouble the police so much?

Mr Straw pulled his scarf round his neck (so to speak) and smiled a wolfish smile. Why, he said, all the proposals had been discussed openly and publicly, at a seminar four weeks ago.

Dr Evilette cackled her evil cackle. "I think we have just heard the home secretary refuse to say what it is that risks alienating the police at such a sensitive time!" she cackled, evilly, and somewhere in Kent 5,000 startled starlings suddenly flew off into the purple dusk.

"He looks rather tired!" she went on in a threatening way. "But it is his duty to come here to answer questions. If he is tired now, let's see what he's like at the end of question time! After his underpants have been stuffed with ants' eggs and he's been dropped into a tank full of starving piranhas! Ha! Ha!" (Yes, of course I made the last bit up.)

Then suddenly up sprang Mini-me. Mr Bercow, his voice an eerie echo of his simulacrum, Dr Evilette, shouted that crime was "four and a half times higher than the level recorded, after the government has chucked out 27,000 criminals early!"

He screeched on: "Is it any wonder that the home secretary is widely regarded as a lily-livered liberal, and that the criminal classes of this country are PRAYING for a Labour victory!" He slumped on to the bench, prior to Ms Widdecombe tucking him safely back into her handbag.

Back at the Ealing comedy, Mr Straw smiled gently and tugged on his scarf. "Why," he said softly, "I keep being told by my friends that whether I'm a liberal or not, I have no reputation to lose.

"But it looks as if he is going to resurrect it, and make me popular in Hampstead."

Over in the Austin Powers film, Dr Evilette harrumphed an evil harrumph. It was time for us puzzled filmgoers to file outside.

webTitle: Health: Underage sex campaigner Victoria Gillick

fields.headline: 'I will not let it go'
fields.standfirst: She's lost yet another battle in her war against underage sex. But is Victoria Gillick ready to give up? Not likely, says Sally Weale
fields.trailText: She's lost yet another battle in her war against underage sex. But is Victoria Gillick ready to give up? Not likely, says Sally Weale.
fields.body:
A small item appeared in the news pages of the Daily Telegraph yesterday. Tucked away under a generous page three spread on the nuptials of Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas, it was reported that Victoria Gillick, the indefatigable campaigner against underage sex, was facing financial ruin after a libel action she had brought was thrown out of court.

Gillick, it emerged, had sued her old adversary, Brook - which provides advice on sex and contraception - over a factsheet in which, she claimed, it was alleged that she was responsible for the rise in teenage pregnancies in the 80s.

In a preliminary hearing last week, a high court judge ruled that the words about which she complained were not capable of bearing the meaning she claimed. Mr Justice Eady dismissed the case, Gillick was refused leave to appeal, and she left the court in tears. "I don't have any money. I possess nothing and I own nothing," she was reported to have said. It sounded like the end of the road.

For those women in their late 20s and 30s who reaped the rewards of battles fought by an earlier generation in the struggle for sexual liberation, Gillick has been there throughout, like a troubling spectre hovering in the wings as we indulged our sexual freedoms.

Could it be that after more than 20 years of campaigning against such freedoms, Gillick - she of the long dark tresses and large family - had run out of steam? Would she finally admit that not only was she struggling Canute-like against the tide, but the waves had crashed up the beach and were well over the sea defences?

In a word, no. Absolutely not. How wrong can you be? Within a couple of minutes of talking to Gillick, it becomes abundantly clear that far from reaching the end of any road, she is as unstoppable as a Terminator cyborg in her quest to enlighten the world about the dangers of sex too young.

"I will not let it go," she tells me. "It's a dirty job, but it's a necessary one. I still think that ultimately the truth will out."

Gillick, a mother of 10, first achieved notoriety in 1984 when she won an appeal court ruling that girls under 16 should not be given contraception without parental consent. She was euphoric.

The following year, the judgement was reversed by the House of Lords. She was devastated: "I felt like I had been stamped on by the system," she says. Typically she recovered sufficiently to take part in an Oxford Union debate with Germaine Greer on the evening of the judgment.

And despite this most recent setback, she has lost none of her crusading zeal. She is already planning to appeal against Mr Justice Eady's decision to refuse her leave to appeal. She faces having to pay Brook's costs, though she says she has no money. The house is in her husband's name. "I shall fight to clear my name by whatever means I can. The rest is in God's hands," she says.

Gillick, now in her mid-50s, is committed to her work as a pregnancy counsellor on behalf of the anti-abortion group Life, and she runs a one-woman organisation called Inform, gathering statistics on contraception and pregnancy among young women, and monitoring the effects of the House of Lords ruling.

"I suppose I'm an old romantic. I still believe that if you present the facts, people will understand and take sensible action," she says, her voice deceptively soft and gentle.

"The free availability of contraception to young girls does not reduce underage pregnancy rates. It does encourage girls to think that sex is safe. Having been a voluntary pregnancy counsellor for nine years I now see at first hand how the policy is impacting on the young.

"I've seen children as young as 11 who have been put on the pill and they've forgotten to take it within a couple of weeks of being prescribed it. They are only children. Unfortunately children cannot take the pill consistently. Nor can they use condoms properly. The more youngsters that are trying to use contraceptives, the more likely we are to get pregnancies.

"I feel very, very sad for this younger generation who have been sold the line that sex is safe and just a form of recreation with no consequences. I think we are living in an age which is doing untold damage to women's reproductive health."

And so on. As though she never went away. Which she didn't - despite the personal cost to herself and her family. "I've been called everything under the sun, including teenage magazines calling me Mrs Pillock in the 80s. They were so cruel, really spiteful."

Then there were the consequent pressures for her five sons and five daughters, who grew up in the glare of the media spotlight - thrust into the headlines themselves whenever they appeared to stray from the papers' perception of the Gillick straight and narrow. One daughter was spotted sunbathing topless on a beach to the delight of the tabloids; another had a baby out of wedlock.

"The distressing thing about that was the way they were pursued," says Gillick. "It was difficult for them because of their high profile mother, but they don't resent me.

"The 80s were hard times for us as a family. If you are a mother who raises her head above the parapet you are always vulnerable. People who opposed me often said a woman who has children should not take on these issues, which I think is desperately unfair."

She is now a grandmother with 16 grandchildren, aged between 11 and just a few weeks, and her children have thrived in their chosen careers, as sculptors and painters (one of her twins, Jim, painted Lady Thatcher's portrait), designers and cabinet makers

This has been a particularly tumultuous year. In September, after 32 years of child-rearing, Gillick's youngest daughter left home - the last to fly the nest - to train as a teacher, leaving her and her artist husband, Gordon, rattling around their rambling house like a pair of dried beans in a tin. "At first it felt very empty and peculiar," she says. "Within a week Gordon and I were scampering around and thoroughly enjoying it."

As far as the future is concerned, Gillick is happy to carry on swimming against the tide. "They say that only dead fish swim with the tide. I don't want to be one of those dead bloaters."

She is now a grandmother with 16 grandchildren, aged between 11 and just a few weeks, and her children have thrived in their chosen careers, as sculptors and painters (one of her twins, Jim, painted Lady Thatcher's portrait), designers and cabinet makers This has been a particularly tumultuous year. In September, after 32 years of child-rearing, Gillick's youngest daughter left home - the last to fly the nest - to train as a teacher, leaving her and her artist husband, Gordon, rattling around their rambling house like a pair of dried beans in a tin. "At first it felt very empty and peculiar," she says. "Within a week Gordon and I were scampering around and thoroughly enjoying it." As far as the future is concerned, Gillick is happy to carry on swimming against the tide. "They say that only dead fish swim with the tide. I don't want to be one of those dead bloaters."

webTitle: Israelis bombard Gaza after bus bomb

fields.headline: Israelis bombard Gaza after bus bomb
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli gunboats and attack helicopters executed their most devastating strike against Palestinian targets in nearly two months of bloody confrontation last night.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg  in Gaza City and  Virginia Quirke in Jerusalem
fields.body:
Israeli gunboats and attack helicopters executed their most devastating strike against Palestinian targets in nearly two months of bloody confrontation last night.

The attack was Israel's explosive reply to yesterday morning's attack on a school bus in the Gush Katif bloc of Jewish settlements in the south of the Gaza strip, which killed two adults and severely injured nine people, five of them pupils.

The two-hour bombardment, piling Israeli wrath on Yasser Arafat's head, destroyed hope that the two sides were edging towards a truce and a resumption of talks.

Afterwards, Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak claimed he would continue to work to stop the violence but pledged to "make the Palestinian Authority understand it will not achieve anything with violence".

Palestinians in turn vowed to respond. "It is a new declaration of the aggressive war against the Palestinians," said negotiator Hassan Asfour. "The killers ... will pay the price." He mentioned Mr Barak, foreign minister Shlomo Ben-Ami and army chief Lt Gen Shaul Mofaz by name.

Israeli helicopters targeted police headquarters, television stations, the small Palestinian navy and the training camp for guards who protect Yasser Arafat.

Mr Arafat, who had earlier denounced the bombing of the school bus, was in his seaside Gaza office during the Israeli offensive. One of the buildings rocketed by the Israeli helicopters was about 200 metres from his office.

Many of the offices were under the control of Mohammed Dahlan, head of the Preventive Security Service, who Israel suspects of being behind the bus attack, according to Israel television. There was no word on Mr Dahlan's whereabouts.

Three different groups - Palestinian Hezbollah, Al Aqsa Martyrs and Omar Al Mukhtar - claimed responsibility for the bus bombing.

The armoured Israeli bus was travelling under military escort out of the isolated Kfar Darom settlement when it was hit by a roadside mortar bomb, sending heavy pieces of shrapnel slamming through the side. Two adults accompanying the school children were killed instantly.

The dead were identified as Gabriel Biton and Miriam Amitai, 35, a mother of four. The nine wounded included five children, three of them from one family - Orit Cohen, 12, lost her right foot, her brother Israel, eight, lost part of one leg, and Tehila, seven, suffered serious wounds to both her legs.

The Israeli military said three Palestinians set off the bomb and fled on foot from near the road, which is under Israeli control, into nearby Palestinian-controlled territory.

The bomb unleashed a wave of fury in Israel. A large crowd assembled outside as Mr Barak convened an emergency cabinet meeting. Settlers ac cused Mr Barak of having "blood on his hands" and others cried: "Arafat is a murderer."

As Gaza City plunged into pitch darkness, hundreds of people poured into the main avenue to gawk at a sky lit up a brilliant blue by tracer fire guiding the helicopters to their targets on all sides of the city. More than 30 missiles were launched in a two-hour bombardment.

Israel's fire was directed against the buildings of the several police organisations of Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority, including his elite Force 17 bodyguard, the headquarters of his Fatah movement, and the Palestinian radio tower. Doctors at Gaza's Shifa hospital said 50 people were wounded. Within minutes of the attack, Gaza City was reduced to chaos. As babies wailed in darkened tower blocks, the footsoldiers of the Fatah militia, blamed by Mr Barak for yesterday's attack, roamed the streets with assault rifles.

"O Barak, listen, listen," they said scrunching over broken glass in front of the Fatah headquarters on Charles de Gaulle avenue, a three-story building whose facade was punctured by three missiles. "Our people will never kneel."

Even old men threatened revenge. "Israel's mothers will suffer as much as our own," said Atta Abu Karish, a member of Fatah's higher council, struggling to turn back the crowds as the rattle of helicopters signalled a further attack.

In the emergency room of Shifa hospital, armed men in the various uniforms of the Palestinian Authority shoved their way through the crowds, bearing in stretchers of their wounded comrades.

One man in khaki uniform, with his face bloodied by shrapnel, stretched his arms out into peace signs as he arrived.

But a coastguard had no remorse. "If I haven't shot any Israelis until today, then tomorrow I will hit them," said Saifuddin Abu Shahala. He was hit in the knee in one of the first strikes. "The helicopter just stopped in front of us, and hung over the beach. Then I was hit," he said.
