webTitle: Brown amassed record surplus

fields.headline: Record £35.4bn surplus signals pre-poll giveaway
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown has amassed the largest government surplus ever recorded - a war chest equivalent to nearly £600 for every man, woman and child in the country - official figures revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown has amassed the largest government surplus ever recorded - a war chest equivalent to nearly £600 for every man, woman and child in the country - official figures revealed yesterday.

Booming tax receipts and an embarrassing failure by Whitehall departments to spend all their budgets has resulted in government revenues outstripping spending by £35.4bn so far this financial year, according to the Office for National Statistics.

This is a record, even allowing for the windfall £22bn the Treasury gained from the auction of mobile phone licences.

With five months to the end of the financial year, City analysts said pointed out that the government was heading for a significantly larger surplus than the chancellor predicted in his pre-Budget statement two weeks ago. This gives him room for a pre-election tax cut or spending giveaway.

The Treasury has pencilled in a cash surplus of £28bn, but even allowing for faster department spending in the second half of year, analysts expect the final total to be significantly higher.

"This figure confirms that the chancellor's pre-budget statement of what the surplus is likely to be ... is still an underestimate," said Trevor Williams, of Lloyds TSB. "I think he'll exceed it by about £5bn and that gives scope for further tax cuts or even public spending increases in the March 2001 budget," he added.

Government revenues are also outstripping spending on the government's preferred measure of the public finances, which smooths out one-off jumps in spending or revenues such as the proceeds of the mobile phone auction. On this measure, the ONS said the surplus stood at £11bn, the largest since records began in 1993.

Core government spending is £3.6bn short of government's projections and unless it accelerates rapidly the spending undershoot for the whole year could reach £6bn, according to Ciaran Barr, chief UK economist for Deutsche Bank.

Despite Treasury pressure on departments to increase infrastructure spending, public sector investment is also running about £1bn below forecasts.

The failure by departments to meet investment plans will cause red faces in government. Labour has promised to repair public infrastructure after years of neglect under the Tories, but last year capital expenditure was down by 50% on the final year of John Major's government.

webTitle: Blair spin doctors told to stifle 'bad news' on Europe

fields.headline: Blair spin doctors told to stifle 'bad news' on Europe
fields.standfirst: Special report: European Integration
fields.trailText: Downing Street has set up a media unit to smother "bad news stories " from Brussels with the aim of stopping the Eurosceptic press getting bona fide tales which could embarrass Tony Blair.
fields.body:
Downing Street has set up a media unit to smother "bad news stories " from Brussels with the aim of stopping the Eurosceptic press getting bona fide tales which could embarrass Tony Blair.

Whitehall has leaked to the Guardian five instances where civil servants in Brussels have been asked to feed Downing Street's strategic communications unit and the Foreign Office on "lines to take" on embarrassing tales of Britain appearing to be losing out to Europe.

The unit, known as the Eurogrid, provides Alastair Campbell, the No 10 press secretary, with advance warning of damaging European commission and European parliament decisions which can put Britain in a bad light.

The existence of the grid - which is prepared weekly for distribution by the Foreign Office - has been confirmed by Whitehall press officers in London and Brussels. It parallels a grid for domestic news, which sets the timing of government announcements.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, and Gordon Brown, the chancellor, are embroiled in rows over the presentation of Britain's attitude towards Europe and the government is involved in large scale media planning for the European summit in Nice.

The five instances where Downing Street has been reported to be alarmed about developments in Europe in the past year were a European directive demanding equal rights for gays and the disabled; the challenge from the commission about state aid to the Rover group; cuts to Britain's European Union regional aid by redrawing the UK aid map; new European rules on takeovers; and the scandal over allegations that Britain was giving away state secrets to the Americans on the Echelon spy comunications programme.

According to Whitehall sources, Downing Street was alarmed that Britain would seen as being ordered by the EU to introduce equal legal rights for gays and the disabled and as being forced to replace the present code of practice.

The row over the redrawing of the European regional aid map caused alarm in Downing Street because it would mean that Labour heartland areas and Labour and Liberal Democrat strongholds in Devon would be hit by the changes

Similar concerns were expressed about the possibility of aid to Rover being stopped because Longbridge in Birmingham was a Labour seat. The advice sought over Echelon followed a row in the European parliament when the French accused the British of leaking secrets to the Americans.

Last night John Redwood, Conservative MP for Wokingham and a former front bench industry spokesman, said: "This is news management of the worst kind - by trying to deny or smother the existence of news that ought to be debated by both pro and anti Europeans. It is nothing more than manipulation of unpalatable stories."

He is to demand an explanation about the operation of the Eurogrid system and how it is used by Downing Street.

The official explanation is that the Eurogrid served to warn the government in advance of events that might be about to break in Europe so it could issue press statements on the developments.

webTitle: Settler children lose limbs in bomb attack

fields.headline: Settler children lose limbs in bomb attack
fields.standfirst:
Three siblings on their way to school in the Gaza Strip were among nine passengers wounded by a mortar shell fired by Palestinians
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Two years ago Noga Cohen's children escaped injury when a suicide bomber blew himself up near their school bus in the Gaza Strip.
fields.body:
Two years ago Noga Cohen's children escaped injury when a suicide bomber blew himself up near their school bus in the Gaza Strip.

On Monday their luck failed

Three of her seven children - a boy, Israel, seven, and two girls, Tehila, nine and Orit, 12 - were on their way to school from the Kfar Darom settlement when their bus was sprayed by shrapnel from a mortar shell fired by Palestinian militants.

Israel lost a leg, Orit part of a foot, and Tehila was badly hurt in both legs.

"It looks like there are no more miracles," Mrs Cohen said as she waited at Soroka hospital in the Negev desert town of Beersheba for the doctors to say whether they would have to amputate Tehila's legs.

Mrs Cohen, 32, and her husband Ofir, 33, have lived in Kfar Darom, a settlement of 250 families now surrounded by Palestinian-controlled areas, for the past 10 years.

Ideology brought the Cohens to Gaza. They wanted to claim some of the poverty-stricken strip, overcrowded by 1m Palestinians, for the Jewish people. The Cohens, who are among 6,500 settlers in Gaza, believe Gaza is part of Eretz Israel, the biblical land God promised to the Jews.

Mrs Cohen said she had never imagined that she would have to pay such a heavy price "for safeguarding our homeland".

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, visited the Cohen children last night.

"These are children who will carry on their bodies, for the rest of their lives, the scars of this grave, criminal, barbaric act which we saw today," he said at a news conference at the hospital.

The Cohen children, along with other youngsters and adults from Kfar Darom, boarded an armoured bus at about 7.30am yesterday for the 15-minute drive to their school in Gush Katif, a cluster of Jewish settlements in southern Gaza.

About three minutes after the bus left the heavily guarded settlement a 155mm mortar shell exploded several dozen metres from the vehicle.

Shrapnel tore holes into the right side of the bus, killing two adults on the spot. Nine passengers were wounded: the driver, three women and five children.

Mr Cohen said that when he heard the explosion he raced to the main road, only to learn that his children had been taken to Soroka hospital.

His daughter Orit, recovering in hospital after the amputation of part of her right foot, whispered "It hurts, it hurts" to her grandmother, watching over her.

Even now, she said, she did not want to leave Kfar Darom. "Then the Arabs would take it all."

Israel, who lost part of a leg, was in the recovery room. His uncle Yaacov said the boy liked to rollerskate and play soccer.

Mrs Cohen said Orit, who will turn 13 next month, was getting ready to mark her Bat Mitzva, the Jewish rite of passage into adulthood.

The family had wondered whether to hold her party in Kfar Darom or a more accessible place.

The bombing helped to make up her mind, she said. "We decided it's dangerous everywhere, so we will do it in Kfar Darom." AP

webTitle: Business: £450m for City pair

fields.headline: £450m for pair that City firm want to keep
fields.trailText: Two fund managers virtually unknown outside the United States are to be paid more than $640m (£450m) to keep the pair at the City firm Old Mutual, which bought their business last month.
fields.byline: Jill Treanor  and  Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
Two fund managers virtually unknown outside the United States are to be paid more than $640m (£450m) to keep the pair at the City firm Old Mutual, which bought their business last month.

In one of the largest retention packages ever seen in the City, Harold Baxter and Gary Pilgrim stand to share at least that sum over the coming seven years. In addition, they are expected to receive payments from a "phantom" stock scheme designed to lock them in until 2008 which could pay them an extra £8m a year.

The pair - dubbed the Wizards of Wayne, a reference to the small Pennsylvania town where they set up their business - are receiving the payments after Old Mutual bought a US fund manage ment group, United Asset Management (UAM), which owned their company Pilgrim Baxter & Associates (PBA).

PBA sells and manages mutual funds, the US equivalent of unit trusts. Old Mutual is based in South Africa but is listed on the London Stock Exchange.

The terms of the payments give a rare insight into the unusual and lucrative payment structures that fund managers and investment bankers negotiate with their employers.

It was revealed yesterday that the studious and quietly spoken Mr Pilgrim, aged 60, and the gregarious New Yorker Mr Baxter, 54, gave to UAM only 35% of the $160m (£112m) of revenues PBA generated each year.

This is why Old Mutual, which also owns stockbrokers Albert E Sharpe and Greig Middleton, took the costly step of buying the two men out of the arrangement which had allowed them to earn as much as $70m (£50m) a year. Under the new deal, more of the 95 employees of PBA will receive a bigger slice of the profits, as will Old Mutual.

Neither of the two men would comment yesterday. Mr Pilgrim, who decided where to invest the money, was expected to turn up at the office at 7.15am after a quick trip to the gym. Mr Baxter is the marketing man.

Old Mutual admitted it would have to raise $220m (£155m) by selling shares to investors to pay for the first of the instalments to the two. They will receive half, $110m (£77.5m), later this month in cash with the remainder in the first three months of next year.

They stand to receive another $420m (£295m) in six $70m (£49.2m) annual instalments from January 2002 They will participate in phantom stock plan worth nearly 14% of their company, shared between them and 95 employees.

Eric Anstee, chief executive of Old Mutual Financial Services, denied the firm had overpaid for the business, saying similar businesses in the US had been valued higher. "These chaps have done a fantastic job building up what is one of the fastest growing mu tual fund (unit trust) operations in the US," he said. He admitted Old Mutual would need to spend another £90m buying out similar arrangements with other management groups.

Other sources agreed the amount being paid was below the industry average. "Very successful aggressive people are worth a lot of money," said one investment banker.

webTitle: Journalist 'knows Lockerbie killers'

fields.headline: Journalist 'knows Lockerbie killers'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText: An American journalist who has interviewed the two Libyans accused of the Lockerbie bombing yesterday told a court they had nothing to do with the atrocity.
fields.body:
An American journalist who has interviewed the two Libyans accused of the Lockerbie bombing yesterday told a court they had nothing to do with the atrocity.

As the prosecution concluded its case, Pierre Salinger told the Scottish court in the Netherlands that he knew who was responsible for the bombing.

Mr Salinger, former chief foreign correspondent at ABC News and press secretary to President Kennedy, was called as one of the crown's final witnesses only to offer testimony which appeared to undermine its case.

The two Libyans accused of the biggest act of mass murder in British history, Abdelbaset Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, deny all charges relating to the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 in which 270 people died on December 21, 1988.

webTitle: Good crickets take eyes off ball.

fields.headline: Batsmen avert their eyes to deal with the best that bowlers can offer
fields.trailText: Good cricketers really do take their eyes off the ball. They do not have a choice, according Michael Land, a neuroscientist at Sussex.
fields.body:
Good cricketers really do take their eyes off the ball. They do not have a choice, according Michael Land, a neuroscientist at Sussex.

A batsman squaring up to a fast bowler is facing a 90mph delivery - with less than 0.4 of a second to decide what to do, Professor Land and Peter McLeod, a psychologist at Oxford, report in the December issue of Nature Neuroscience today.

The great sporting mystery is: how does a batsman come to a decision about whether to attack or defend, and when to start his swing? The orthodoxy, according to Prof Land, is that sportsmen calculate when a ball will arrive by the rate at which it seems to get bigger. The two scientists were not so sure.

"The ball doesn't start expanding with anything like credibility until it is too close, maybe halfway down the pitch. That information is too late. And it is too late because in the 0.2 of a second before you hit it, you can't change anything," said Prof Land.

He provided the head-mounted cameras to monitor eye movements. Dr McLeod provided the volunteer batsmen and the nets. The two scientists called on the services of a Sunday morning player, a talented amateur and a county player.

All three, without exception, looked at the ball as it came from the bowling machine. Then 130 milliseconds or thousandths of a second later, each made a "saccade" - an extremely fast eye movement - to roughly where the ball was likely to bounce.

The two scientists concluded that when a batsman knew the time of delivery and the place of the bounce he had enough to decide whether to go for a six or play a defensive bat.

Prof Land was not sure what help his discovery might be to the England team. "If they have not got it by now, they never will."

webTitle: Bloody Sunday death was 'murder'

fields.headline: Bloody Sunday death was 'murder'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A Royal Ulster Constabulary investigation into Bloody Sunday 28 years ago concluded that the first of the 13 civilians killed in the shooting was murdered by the army, the official inquiry into the Londonderry killings was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A Royal Ulster Constabulary investigation into Bloody Sunday 28 years ago concluded that the first of the 13 civilians killed in the shooting was murdered by the army, the official inquiry into the Londonderry killings was told yesterday.

Opening his submission for the families of the victims, Arthur Harvey QC said that no soldier was made accountable for the death of John "Jack" Duddy, 17, because the soldier could not be identified.

Mr Harvey added that priests and journalists who witnessed the attack on the civil rights demonstration in Londonderry on January 30, 1972, "all unanimously came to the conclusion that what they saw was unjustified shooting at unarmed people".

A film of Mr Duddy being carried dying through the streets with Father Edward Daly at the head of the rescuers, crouching and waving a white handkerchief became the iconic image of the day.

Mr Harvey said: "There is no explanation for the shooting ... and, indeed, the police investigation came to the conclusion that Jackie Duddy had been murdered."

Referring to film footage, photographs and reporters' accounts, Mr Harvey said: "When one looks independently at each of those pictures, it does tell a story, and all that one has to do is to use one's eyes and open one's mind to see it." Army gunfire directed towards one of the "killing zones" near the rubble barricade across Rossville Street was so intense that anyone there was bound to have been shot dead.

Only one man survived after being shot there - Alexander Nash, who ran to the aid of his son, William, 19, who died in the street along with Michael Kelly, 17, Michael McDaid, 20, John Young, 17, Hugh Gilmour, 17, and Kevin McElhinney, 17.

Mr Harvey said: "The criss-cross of trajectories is such that anyone beyond that barricade at that time was likely to be killed."

Mr Harvey said pictures showed that none was carrying guns or bombs - and yet the soldiers claimed that there were three riflemen, three nail bombers, one machine-gunner and three pistol men.

Mr Harvey said more deaths remained unaccounted for including that of Jim Wray who had been shot in the back in Glenfada Park. He suggested that a soldier known as G, who is now dead , killed Mr Wray as well as two others, Gerald Donaghey and Gerard McKinney, in the neighbouring complex of Abbey Park.

Mr Wray, 22, was calling out for help when he was shot "despatched in a murderous way while was lay prone and injured". Gerard McKinney "had his arms up pleading for his life". A bullet belonging to soldier G was recovered from the body of Gerald Donaghey.

At the original Widgery inquiry in 1972, G was asked if he fired through the alleyway linking the two complexes. He was recorded in the transcript as answering "yes", but he was asked nothing else about it.

"The most peculiar thing about the cross-examinations ... is the simple fact that not one question was asked of Soldier G about the murder of Gerald Donaghey."

The hearing continues.

webTitle: 2m leaseholders to get right to buy

fields.headline: 2m leaseholders to get right to buy
fields.trailText: Up to 2m leaseholders will get new rights to rid themselves of unscrupulous landlords under sweeping reforms to the archaic leasehold system.
fields.body:
Up to 2m leaseholders will get new rights to rid themselves of unscrupulous landlords under sweeping reforms to the archaic leasehold system.

A bill will be introduced in next month's Queen's speech to give leaseholders the right to buy homes outright.

With an eye on potential Labour voters in swing seats, the bill also helps leaseholders of former council flats facing high service charges. The commonhold and leasehold reform bill will give 200,000 such homeowners similar rights to other leaseholders for the first time.

Ministers will hail the bill as the most ambitious overhaul of English and Welsh property law for more than a century. Labour promised leasehold reform in its 1997 manifesto, but only introduced a draft bill in last year's Queen's speech.

Disclosure that the full bill will be included in the coming Queen's speech, expected to be the last batch of government bills before the election, came by accident yesterday when the government appointed a minister in the lord chancellor's department, Lord Bach of Lutterworth, who will oversee the bill's progress in the Lords.

The bill has three main points:

 A new form of tenure, known as commonhold, will enable joint ownership of freehold and creation of a management company to run communal parts. Commonhold, which draws on schemes in the US and Australia, will give all flat-owners rights in a property without a lease which would diminish in value over the years.

 The number of leaseholders required to purchase a freehold will be cut from two-thirds to 50%. A requirement that half of participating leaseholders have lived in their flat for at least 12 months will end.

 New rights will be given leaseholders who do not want to buy, but would like to manage their property. At present they have to prove incompetence by a landlord, which involves spending thousands of pounds going to a tribunal.

The bill will be welcomed by Labour MPs who feared the government would abandon its manifesto commitment.

webTitle: So you want to learn... travel consultancy

fields.headline: So you want to learn...
fields.standfirst: Travel consultancy
fields.trailText: Travel consultancy
fields.body:
Wotcha! Good morning, sir.

Me and me mates wanna go on 'oliday. Where?

That place on the telly. Could you be a little more specific?

Nah, not the Pacific. Oibeezer. You mean Ibiza.

Right. Where the birds are up for it and there's loadsa booze. We can get you to Ibiza.

But no bucket deal, mind. Only sick buckets, eh, sir?

Oi! Just a joke.

What's your game, then? I'm a travel consultant, sir.

Yer what? Travel consultants chat to clients wanting package holidays, find out what they are looking for then show them brochures containing suitable packages.

OK. Then what? If a client is interested in a particular holiday, the consultant checks its availability by telephone or on the computer system linked directly to the tour operator.

And if it is? Once the client has chosen a holiday, the consultant collects a deposit and makes a booking with the tour operator. We also advise on health requirements, visas, insurance and foreign currency. We can arrange holiday excursions, passports and car hire or airport parking. And we can provide a service to independent travellers, helping them work out itineraries by consulting travel timetables and booking accommodation and tickets.

Could you have 10 crates of lager waiting in our hotel room as a first night warm-up? That may be stretching our powers a bit, sir.

So, what do you need for your job? Good communication skills above all, face to face and on the telephone. Obviously knowledge of geography is essential, so we can discuss travel and holiday resorts. Other relevant skills are being computer literate, numerate and polite, and being friendly and a good listener. We are essentially sales people, so we have to meet targets and be able to work under pressure with good organisational skills.

And what prospects are there? Many small travel agencies have little or no promotion options, so promotion can be achieved by moving between agencies. The chance for getting on is much greater in larger agencies, where you can progress from travel consultant to senior consultant or even to manager or area manager. Consultants can also consider transferring to other areas of travel and tourism such as tourist information and resort representative.

How about qualifications? There are no set entry requirements, but a reasonable standard of secondary education is expected. Employers prefer GCSE grades A-C, particularly in English, maths and geography. Entrants to travel-agency work also come with an NVQ in travel services or intermediate and advanced GNVQ levels 2 and 3 in leisure and tourism. Does sir have an NVQ?

Nah. Just a Cambridge classics degree.

webTitle: Police not to be prosecuted over man's death

fields.headline: Police not to be prosecuted over man's death
fields.trailText: The mother of a man who died after he was restrained by eight policemen yesterday condemned a crown prosecution service decision not to charge anyone on the grounds of "insufficient evidence".
fields.body:
The mother of a man who died after he was restrained by eight policemen yesterday condemned a crown prosecution service decision not to charge anyone on the grounds of "insufficient evidence".

Sheila Sylvester said she was "shocked but not surprised" by the CPS announcement, which came 22 months after the death of her son, Roger, in January 1999, eight days after he was arrested outside his home in Tottenham, north London. "I'm so weak and worn out that I can hardly speak. Nothing can describe how unbearable it is not to know how your son died."

Several MPs immediately called for a public inquiry, describing the CPS decision as perverse. Campaigners, led by the pressure group Inquest said it showed the CPS had not learned the lessons of the Macpherson report into the death of Stephen Lawrence and was still unwilling to press charges against police officers.

Eight officers, including four in a van, were sent to a road in Tottenham after reports that a man was naked and causing a disturbance. It later emerged that Mr Sylvester, 30, was banging on his own front door.

He was held under section 136 of the Mental Health Act and taken to nearby St Ann's hospital. Still handcuffed, Mr Sylvester collapsed in a coma moments after being examined by a doctor. Police officers tried to resuscitate him but he did not regain consciousness.

Suspicion about what happened to Mr Sylvester, who suffered superfical injuries to his head, arms, body and legs, heightened when the Metropolitan police apologised for issuing a false statement.

Scotland Yard initially said it received a 999 call suggesting Mr Sylvester had been acting in an "aggressive and vociferous" manner. Later, the force admitted no caller had made such a claim.

An inquest was opened and adjourned so Essex police, under the supervision of the police complaints authority, could conduct an independent inquiry.

A report was sent to the CPS which ruled yesterday there were no grounds to charge officers "for manslaughter, assault or false imprisonment either during Mr Sylvester's detention and removal to a place of safety or during his detention at St Ann's hospital".

Medical opinion and issues of bad faith, lack of reasonable care and negligence by officers were also taken into account, a spokesman said.

Mrs Sylvester said the officers who were under investigation had not cooperated with the Essex inquiry and would not have to give evidence when the inquest resumed.

"The coroner will tell them they do not have to give answers that may incriminate themselves. There is something shameful about a system where when people die in cus tody their custodians never give a proper account of what they did."

Tottenham's Labour MP, David Lammy, said: "If eight of us in this room, three quarters of a football team, had pounced on any other individual, charges would have been brought."

The chairman of the Metropolitan police authority, Toby Harris, said the length of the investigation and the "inconclusive outcome" had damaged confidence in the way the case had been handled.

The Metropolitan police said: "We wish to extend our sympathies to the family and understand the distress felt by them. It would be inappropriate for us to comment in any further detail pending the coroner's inquest."

webTitle: Girl 'tied in binliner died of cold and neglect'

fields.headline: Girl 'tied in binliner died of cold and neglect'
fields.trailText: An eight-year-old girl died of hypothermia and neglect after being tied in a black binbag and forced to eat and sleep in the bath, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.
fields.body:
An eight-year-old girl died of hypothermia and neglect after being tied in a black binbag and forced to eat and sleep in the bath, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

Anna Climbie was tied by her hands and feet by her aunt and her boyfriend and put in a binliner because she had been wetting herself, a jury was told.

The child's aunt, Marie Therese Kouao, 44, and her boyfriend Carl Manning, of Tottenham, north London, are alleged to have subjected the child to months of abuse and neglect.

Anna died in February from hypothermia caused by severe neglect, in spite of her case being drawn to the attention of two different social work departments, the police and medical staff. She had 128 scars caused by beatings, some of which were administered with a belt buckle or trainer shoe.

Kouao, who is unemployed, and Manning, a bus driver, deny murdering Anna. Kouao also denies child cruelty and manslaughter. Manning has admitted child cruelty, but the prosecution has refused to accept his plea of guilty to manslaughter.

The case continues.

webTitle: MI5 sued over bugging of Sinn Fein car

fields.headline: MI5 sued over bugging of Sinn Fein car
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: MI5 is being sued for bugging a car used by Sinn Fein leaders Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness, security sources disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
MI5 is being sued for bugging a car used by Sinn Fein leaders Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness, security sources disclosed yesterday.

A bugging and tracking device was found hidden in the roof of a Ford Mondeo carrying the two men at a highly sensitive time during the review of the Good Friday agreement last December.

The owner of the car, understood to be the wife of Martin Lynch, who was convicted for arms offences in the early 1980s, is demanding exemplary damages for breach of privacy.

Her lawyers originally planned to sue the Ministry of Defence in the belief that the bug was planted by military intelligence. They turned on MI5 when they discovered that agency was responsible.

MI5 is vigorously contesting the claim for damages, defending its action under the 1994 Intelligence Services Act. It states: "No entry on or interference with property ... shall be unlawful" [in helping MI5 carry out its functions] if it is authorised by a warrant issued by the secretary of state".

In an unusual intervention - ministers rarely comment on security operations - Mo Mowlam, the former Northern Ireland secretary, admitted this summer that she had sanctioned the bugging to "save lives".

She told BBC1's You Only Live Once in July: "Lives were being lost. It was done to make sure we knew what was going on". Sinn Fein described Ms Mowlam's admission as "disappointing but not surprising".

Official sources say MI5's intention was to target Mr Lynch rather than Mr Adams or Mr McGuinness. Mr Lynch was convicted for arms offences after he was seriously injured when he was shot at by police in 1982. Police found weapons in a car.

Last year's decision to place a large bugging device in the one-year-old Mondeo surprised independent security experts because of its audacity and risk of political fallout.

The owner's suspicions were apparently aroused when the car was stopped by the RUC at a roadblock and the driver detained.

Mr Adams described the bugging as a "hugely serious breach of faith" and accused the intelligence services of attempting to sabotage the peace process.

The Mondeo had apparently been used regularly by Sinn Fein, suggesting that the party's counter-intelligence experts had been lulled into a false security by the developing peace process. In the past Sinn Fein leaders and the IRA have regularly switched cars to avoid detection.

The bug was equipped with aerials, a digitally-enhanced transmission system and a digital tracking capability which could be picked up by satellite. A Sinn Fein news release said it was "linear amplified" and had a built-in transmission aerial.

Sinn Fein said a microphone had been built into the roof of the Mondeo, and wiring ran along the skin of the car.

The device, which had rechargeable batteries, could be switched on and off by remote control, according to Mr Adams. It could be voice-activated or switched on by a remote radio signal operated by a computer or by an individual.

The idea would be to conserve the battery's life, but, more importantly, to prevent the occupants from detecting the device by discovering an alternative energy source.

webTitle: Tube derails capital's new year festivities

fields.headline: Tube derails capital's new year festivities
fields.standfirst:
Underground chiefs' reluctance to run services after 4pm leaves London as the only leading city not to have official celebration

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, yesterday cancelled the capital's New Year's Eve celebrations leaving it as the only British city not officially marking the occasion.
fields.body:
The mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, yesterday cancelled the capital's New Year's Eve celebrations leaving it as the only British city not officially marking the occasion.

The mayor said he was "caught between a rock and a hard place" as the London Underground's reluctance to run services after 4pm meant commercial sponsors had pulled out fearing small crowds.

Mr Livingstone declared that if the same "negative atmosphere" had prevailed at the time of the Blitz, "we would have lost that battle as well".

London Underground had insisted that it could not cope with more than 1m revellers expected to converge on the capital on December 31.

A fireworks display was moved to 5pm to help ease potential crowd congestion but the ever-changing programme had left sponsors nervous about backing the event.

Emergency services said their safety plans could not be formalised without confirmation of the full details.

Another use will now have to be found for approximately 500,000 fireworks which are being imported from India.

Leeds, Birmingham, Glasgow and Cardiff have all unveiled plans which in some cases are being billed as parties to top the millennium while Edinburgh and Manchester will launch their festivities with similarly proud boasts in the coming days.

Irish dancers, reggae artists, chart stars Daphne and Celeste, and Motown singer Edwin Starr will perform in a Countdown to Midnight concert in Birmingham's Centenary Square at the end of a day of public entertainment beginning with tea dances at the International Conference Centre.

Cardiff will celebrate with three days of free entertainment beginning on December 30, featuring one of the Britain's largest winter fairgrounds and a twilight lantern procession starting at Cardiff Castle and ending in Coopers Field, Bute Park, with a 20-minute show of music and fireworks.

In Glasgow, "Scotland's second biggest Hogmanay" will feature a Radio 1 dance party, and the Riverside Spectacular, a family-oriented music and pyrotechnics display at the city's Pacific Quay.

Belfast will celebrate with an outdoor concert at the City Hall, and an indoor music performance at St George's market. There will also be a fireworks display. A new £12m public space, the Millennium Square, will be opened to celebrate the new year in Leeds.

Last year, Manchester celebrated with parties and performances featuring former Stone Roses singer Ian Brown, local DJs and fireworks displays. This year's celebrations will be unveiled next week.

The millennium commission had earmarked £1.5m for the London celebrations, and will now be looking at alternative ways to spend the money.

A spokesman said that as a grant-giving body it did not have the power to run a new year's event.

The capital's woes are expected to prompt an inquest which may point the finger at London Underground.

Rock star Bob Geldof, whose Ten Alps company was contracted to produce the celebrations, called Mr Livingstone's efforts "magnificent", but said: "The rail companies must take a huge part of the blame for this."

Trevor Phillips, Greater London assembly chairman, said: "People will want to know why, at this late stage, matters were not clear and had not been sorted out. This is, of course, why the assembly was pressing this issue last week. Now we have the worst possible answer delivered in the worst possible way."

Bob Neill, leader of the GLA Conservative group, said: "It is extraordinary that every other major city in the world can successfully and safely celebrate new year, except for London."

London Underground said it was "disappointed" at the cancellation and would now have to review its plans for services on New Year's Eve. "Whether or not there is a major event many people will travel into London on New Year's Eve to shop, celebrate and work who will rely on us to get them there and back."

webTitle: Fox's Biscuits: Flexible and child friendly

fields.headline: Flexible and child friendly
fields.trailText: Fox's Biscuits was presented by the government yesterday as an example of an enlightened firm that was helping to improve the work-life balance of its staff.
fields.body:
Fox's Biscuits was presented by the government yesterday as an example of an enlightened firm that was helping to improve the work-life balance of its staff.

The company, based in Batley, West Yorkshire, offers flexible working hours including a "child friendly" shift from 9am to 4pm and an evening shift from 5pm to 10pm.

Rebecca Cain, the employee development manager, said the firm offered summer and Easter clubs for children of school age, including day supervision at a local sports club. Working parents could make use of facilities at a nearby creche.

Ms Cain said she took advantage of the company's flexibility herself when she arranged a job share with another manager after the birth of her second child.

The company, a subsidiary of Northern Foods, also allows maternity leave of up to a year with guaranteed job security.

Benefits to the firm include retention of skilled staff, savings on recruitment and training, and a motivated and loyal workforce.

webTitle: FE colleges urged to concentrate on specialist roles

fields.headline: FE colleges urged to concentrate on specialist roles
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Half of all further education colleges will be expected to specialise in a particular field within five years, the education secretary, David Blunkett, will announce today.
fields.body:
Half of all further education colleges will be expected to specialise in a particular field within five years, the education secretary, David Blunkett, will announce today.

In what is being billed as his most important speech on further education, Mr Blunkett will tell the Association of Colleges in Harrogate they have to become more in tune with the needs of the local economy.

He will also announce that an extra £100m will be made available for further education in 2002, including an extra £50m for improvements to lecturers' pay.

Mr Blunkett believes it is increasingly important to have a number of recognised "cutting edge" centres of excellence in skills, such as information and communications technology, or science and technology.

He also believes that the 350 general further education colleges should become more tightly focused on particular subjects.

Mr Blunkett believes it builds on some of the success of the government's specialist schools, which showed good results in official performance tables last week. But like the schools blueprint, the colleges plan is expected to attract criticism that he is creating a two-tier further education system.

The education secretary is impressed by the likes of Reading college, which has created a "digital academy". Colleges in regions strong in manufacturing, for instance, will be encouraged to become specialist centres in design and technology. They will get extra cash for becoming specialist sites.

The colleges will come under the aegis of the learning and skills council from April. On the 47 local LSCs, 300 of 700 posts will be filled by business people.

The colleges will have to show that the extra money for pay - doubling the amount available this year - is linked to raising teaching standards. Further education lecturers are protesting that their basic pay still lags way behind classroom teachers.

A source close to Mr Blunkett said extra funding for colleges came with an expectation that they would contribute to the local economy.

"The colleges play a very important part in the education system and yet that importance has gone without proper recognition for too long."

webTitle: PMFJI, almanacs and emoticons

fields.headline: PMFJI, almanacs and emoticons
fields.trailText: Almanacs, which are as old as the ancient Greeks, used to confine themselves to listing tides and phases of the moon for the more highly educated classes. But now, PMFJI (pardon me for jumping in), they need to include a host of acronyms and hieroglyphics.
fields.body:
Almanacs, which are as old as the ancient Greeks, used to confine themselves to listing tides and phases of the moon for the more highly educated classes.

But now, PMFJI (pardon me for jumping in), they need to include a host of acronyms and hieroglyphics to rescue mobile phone messagers from FUD (fear, uncertainty and doubt) and feeling :- (sad), :-t (angry) or I-I (bored).

For the first time the new Hutchinson Almanac lists 46 of the top emoticons, or "smileys" and 46 of the abbreviations required for burgeoning silent mobile communication in all walks of life from the comprehensive classroom to boardroom.

Emoticons, the 854-page almanac explains, are symbols designed to communicate emotion in text using punctuation marks and other symbols. Most "take the form of a human face and should be viewed sideways". They originated in email messages and are still sometimes used there.

In its plunge into the 21st century, the almanac lists hundreds of "useful facts" which well-informed citizens will wish to have at their fingertips. Among these nuggets, mostly drawn from official reports and surveys, are that:

 Barracudas are attracted by "all things yellow" - including swimming trunks. This is why fishermen use yellow-feathered lines to catch them

 On average, everyone in the UK spends 39% more time travelling by car and 21% less on foot than in 1985. We also spend 85% more time in taxis or minicabs

 School-run traffic at 8.50am in term time rose from 14% of total traffic in 1990 to 18% in 1998.

Keeping it short

BCNU Be seeing you

DQM Don't quote me

FOAF Friend of a friend

FOCL Falls off chair laughing

FUD Fear, uncertainty and doubt

HTH Hope that helps

IMHO In my humble opinion

IMNSHO In my not so humble opinion

LCW Loud, confident and wrong

LOL Lots of luck/ Laughing out loud

PMFJI Pardon me for jumping in

ROTFL Rolling on the floor laughing

TIC Tongue in cheek

TTYL Talk to you later

TTFN Ta ta for now

webTitle: Bank's £1.7m opens up Scots universities

fields.headline: Bank's £1.7m opens up Scots universities
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Three hundred Scottish students from poor families are to be given grants of £4,000 to go to university in a sponsorship deal announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Three hundred Scottish students from poor families are to be given grants of £4,000 to go to university in a sponsorship deal announced yesterday.

The Royal Bank of Scotland is putting £1.7m into schemes to widen access. It will fund the bursaries, worth £1,000 over the four-year Scottish degree course, for 60 students each at Edinburgh, Glasgow, St Andrews, Aberdeen and Dundee.

The same universities will also get £100,000 a year over four years to run pre-entry summer schools for 1,700 working class pupils to encourage them to apply.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, who began a national furore by criticising Oxford university for rejecting the Tyneside state school pupil Laura Spence, launched the scheme at Lochgelly high school in his Dunfermline east constituency, with the new Scottish first minister, Henry McLeish.

"This is an important partnership if we are to widen access to higher education," Mr Brown said. "I want Scotland to lead the way in this area, giving every child the chance to make the most of their talents."

Sources close to the chancellor were last night likening the Royal Bank of Scotland deal to US-style public-private partnerships in higher education. He is enthusiastic about summer schools because 80% of all pupils who attend them go on to university. The bank's money will provide 340 summer school places a year at each of the five universities.

Mr McLeish said: "Often people talk about excellence and access as if they were two different considerations. I firmly believe that we can extend excellence but at the same time improve access to a whole number of young people who see barriers to their progress."

The bank bursary students are also guaranteed a job interview with the bank.

Wendy Alexander, the Scottish enterprise and lifelong learning minister, is ring-fencing £18m in funds for access initiatives. She is telling universities that from 2001 they will get around £750 extra for each of their students whose parents earn less than £10,000 a year. She has also told universities to create another 800 places for students from poorer families, although the details of how that will be achieved have still to be worked out.

St Andrews, where Prince William will soon study, is arguably the worst offender in the UK when it comes to admitting working class students. About 59% of its undergraduates attended state school, when, according to the higher education funding council for England, based on entry requirements and subject mix, it should be admitting 80%. No other university is as far off its "benchmark" figure.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Enigma theft case remand
fields.body:
Enigma theft case remand

An antiques dealer was remanded yesterday on charges of blackmail and receiving stolen goods after the theft of the second world war Enigma encoding machine from Bletchley Park, Buckinghamshire. Dennis Yates, 57, of Sandiacre, Derbyshire, was given bail to reappear at Milton Keynes magistrates court in January.

Child porn found on prison laptop

A manager at Cardiff prison has been suspended following the discovery of child pornography on a laptop computer he used at work, the Home Office revealed yesterday. The 54-year-old has been bailed until February to allow time for an inquiry.

Date-rape drug warning

Thames Valley police officers will visit schools in Reading, Berkshire, to warn sixth form girls about the dangers of sex attackers using date-rape drugs such as Rohypnol over Christmas.

Needles light nearly goes out

Yachts dropping anchor almost plunged the Needles lighthouse on the Isle of Wight into darkness. Two of the three cables were put out of action and £170,000 has been spent on laying new cabling for the 142-year-old lighthouse on one of the busiest shipping lanes .

Council buys in Xmas police

Twelve new police officers began pounding the beat in Liverpool yesterday as part of a £360,000 council-funded scheme to make Christmas shoppers feel safer. Mike Storey, the council leader, said: "The people of Liverpool want to see more bobbies on the beat."

Britons held in drugs inquiry

Five Britons, three of them women, have been arrested in the United Arab Emirates on suspicion of dealing in cocaine and hashish on an internet website, according to local police. A conviction could result in the death penalty.

Avalanche warning

Climbers bound for the Highlands were yesterday warned after avalanches on the Cairngorm mountain above Aviemore. Blyth Wright, of Sportscotland, said: "There is more November snow than anyone can remember."

Ripper detective jailed

The detective who got the Yorkshire Ripper to confess was yesterday jailed for six months at Leeds crown court for selling information from the police national computer to private detectives. Detective In spector John Boyle, 64, who retired after 31 years service, pleaded guilty, as did his source, PC James Burrell, 47, who got 15 months.

Guns haul at birthday party

A raid by police found handguns and a shotgun hidden by guests at a club in Camberwell, south London; seven arrests were made. It followed a young man being shot in the head, though not seriously injured, at a birthday party in the club, where party-goers cooperated with police.

Vicar given time to repent

Trevor Jones, 50, vicar of St Mary and St Peter's in Stowmarket, Suffolk, was given a nine-month prison sentence at Ipswich crown court after admitting swindling parish officials out of thousands of pounds. He was ordained eight years ago despite a lengthy criminal record for dishonesty.

Paradise found in jam jar

A jar of jam made from the fruit of a mulberry tree planted by the poet John Milton in the gardens of Christ's College, Cambridge, has been sold for £3,000 to aid a charity for the homeless.

Paradise found in jam jar A jar of jam made from the fruit of a mulberry tree planted by the poet John Milton in the gardens of Christ's College, Cambridge, has been sold for £3,000 to aid a charity for the homeless.

webTitle: Business: Golden handcuffs at Barings

fields.headline: Golden handcuffs for top Barings staff
fields.trailText: Golden handcuffs will be offered to senior staff at ING Barings in an attempt to deter their defection to rivals after its Dutch owner said it would break up the investment bank.
fields.body:
Golden handcuffs will be offered to senior staff at ING Barings in an attempt to deter their defection to rivals after its Dutch owner said it would break up the investment bank.

Speculation mounted last night that Dutch bank ING will have to pay hundreds of millions of pounds to retain bankers crucial to the short-term survival of its investment banking operation, even though it is expected to pull out of the business. Up to 2,000 jobs are at risk in London.

David Robins, who heads the investment banking operation, yesterday wrote to his London staff, and another 8,000 around the world, to say he was "saddened" by the change in strategy of ING. Six months ago the Dutch bank was building up the business, buying stockbroker Charterhouse.

"Until the exact outcome of the review is known, it is important for all of us to continue working as members of ING Group," Mr Robins said.

The bank will have to pay the additional incentives, and make pledges to pay bonuses,despite its decision to review the operation, after blaming the rising cost of paying bankers and mergers of other banks.

ING bought Barings, brought to its knees by rogue trader Nick Leeson, in 1995 for £1.

webTitle: Ministers plan to widen net as job pledge is met

fields.headline: Ministers plan to widen net as job pledge is met
fields.standfirst: Reshaped new deal will focus on the long-term unemployed, including lone parents and disabled and older unemployed will face benefit sanctions
fields.trailText: Ministers are preparing to announce a major revamp of the new deal for the unemployed in the wake of meeting one of their five key manifesto pledges, to take 250,000 youngsters off the dole.
fields.body:
Ministers are preparing to announce a major revamp of the new deal for the unemployed in the wake of meeting one of their five key manifesto pledges, to take 250,000 youngsters off the dole.

Employment ministers hope to announce they have met the pledge next week. The announcement will trigger a wider political debate on the value of the new deal and the need to help the economically inactive into work.

A more flexible new deal will be aimed at bringing over 1m people into contact with the labour market, including lone parents, the disabled and the older long term unemployed. The aim is to target the hard core unemployed, including tens of thousands put onto incapacity benefit in the 1980s. The labour force survey shows that as many as 800,000 who claim sickness and disability benefits actually want to work.

As a first step, the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, is considering requiring new incapacity benefit claimants to attend "a work-focused interview".

At the same time the employment minister, Tessa Jowell, is determined to ensure the government reaps political benefit from its record of job creation - something the US Democrats conspicuously failed to do in the presidential elections.

The government celebrated the creation of 1m extra jobs in the economy last summer with a press conference in Downing Street given by Tony Blair. A similar fanfare is planned for the new deal figures for the young unemployed.

Officials say it is "touch and go" whether they meet the 250,000 target for the young unemployed this month, or at the end of December.

Latest statistics published in October show that almost 245,000 18-24 year olds unemployed for six months or more have found work, just 5,000 short of the manifesto pledge. Critics claim 58,000 found work for less than 13 weeks and many of them would have work anyway.

Ministers are confident that the announcement will be followed quickly by other achievements in job creation.

Despite the surprise 3,500 rise on the unemployment count last week to 1.047m, the government expects to see this measure of unemployment fall below the politically sensitive 1m within four months, for the first time since the mid-70s.

Ministers also hope that they will be able to claim Britain is becoming a full employment economy for the first time since the 60s. The chancellor, Gordon Brown, in his first full budget redefined full employment as 75% of the population of working age in jobs. At present, the figure stands at 74.7%, the second highest figure in Europe.

The numbers in work, compiled on the basis of a rolling three month average, is increasing at a rate of 0.1% two or three months, suggesting Britain will reach the 75% target by the time of an election in late spring next year.

Although the 75% figure, then measured annually, was reached in 1990, this temporary success was immediately followed by recession. Employment officials insist the chancellor wants to be able to project a sustained period of employment growth.

The post-war peak in employment took place in 1974 when 75.7% of the working age population was in work.

With the population of working age growing by 134,000 over the past year, employment will need to grow by an additional 110,000 to reach the 75% target.

Key elements of the new deal mark two include from April next year transformation of the current employment service into a working age agency responsible for the administration of a much wider range of benefits. The agency will not simply be aimed at the unemployed, but all the economically inactive.

Ministers are also providing tougher and longer procedures for those going through the new deal in a bid to ensure they stay in jobs longer.

The 150,000 people aged 24 to 55 and unemployed for 18 months or more will be subject to the same sanctions regime as the young unemployed. They will be guaranteed a job or training place, and like those aged 16-24 could lose benefit for as long as 26 weeks if they break the sanctions regime three times.

The government has already toughened the regime for 900,000 lone parents on income support by requiring them to attend initial job advice interviews, if their children are aged over five. The offer of training course or jobs will remain voluntary for the forseeable future.

In two extensions of the scheme, lone parents with children as young as three will now be offered interviews. Help will also be extended to the 150,000 workless lone parents not on income support.

Ministers recognise that the short term impact of bringing people currently not registered as unemployed onto the claimant count will be to boost the headline total of the unemployed. However, they believe that in a second term Labour government this will be a price worth paying.

webTitle: Business: 50 potential bidders for Go

fields.headline: Flock of Go bidders amid burgeoning no frills market
fields.trailText: Barbara Cassani, the chief executive of low cost airline Go, has confirmed that the firm has received about 50 interested inquiries from potential bidders for the business.
fields.body:
Barbara Cassani, the chief executive of low cost airline Go, has confirmed that the firm has received about 50 interested inquiries from potential bidders for the business.

She told senior managers at an Institute of Directors' meeting in London that she was confident the airline - which was put up for sale earlier this month by BA - would be sold for between £300m and £500m in the next few months. One of the options is a management buyout by Go's 500 staff, led by Ms Cassani.

Ms Cassani suggested that it could be several months before the airline, launched by BA three years ago, was sold. One potential bidder for Go to emerge yesterday was Iberia, the Spanish flag carrier.

Among the other potential buyers are Air France, Buzz, the low cost airline operated by Dutch carrier KLM, and EasyJet, based at Luton. Other names to appear include the Indian Hinduja brothers, who are also bidding to take over the Daily Express group.

BA is no hurry to sell Go. After a long period of consolidation, Go is now making a profit on a month-to-month basis, and Ms Cassani claims it will have made an overall profit when its accounts are published next year.

The Dutch airline, Transavia, yesterday entered the highly competitive, low-price market with a new service. The move is the result of extensive research into the Dutch market, which has shown a demand for the low fares available in the UK and the US.

The new service will start on December 18, aimed at Christmas and the New Year, with flights from Amsterdam to Nice and Barcelona. One way fares will start at £17.50 for Nice and £23.50 for Barcelona.

Passengers will follow the norm already established by Go and EasyJet. They will be able to buy drinks and sandwiches, but any baggage beyond normal allowances, such as golf clubs or diving equipment, will attract an additional charge.

Peter Legro, Transvania's chief executive, said: "The European airline business has become a price driven market in which there is no room for sentiments. There is no time to wait any longer. We know that the competition has its eyes on our market."

The entry of Transvania into the low cost area reflects the growing interest in Europe in the expanding business.

Because of its size, travellers can reach their destination within two hours from their point of departure.

webTitle: Business: Majestic sales down

fields.headline: Flat season
fields.standfirst: Majestic's post-millennium hangover
fields.trailText: Plunging champagne sales after last year's millennium celebrations have taken the sparkle out of trading at Majestic Wines, the wine warehouse chain.
fields.body:
Plunging champagne sales after last year's millennium celebrations have taken the sparkle out of trading at Majestic Wines, the wine warehouse chain.

The firm yesterday revealed demand had flattened by a third in recent weeks - and it expects champagne sales over the entire festive period to be as much as 40% lower.

Chief executive Tim How said both the public and the catering trade had supplies left over from last year: "Coming out of the millennium, everyone was fairly well stocked. There was a tremendous boost in sales last year, but we won't see any particular benefit from this new year."

Champagne accounted for 17% of Majestic's total business a year ago but the proportion has since fallen to 12%. The problem has affected others - champagne maker Laurent-Perrier has seen its market value fall by more than a quarter this year due to excess post-millennium stock.

Half-year profits at Majestic - whose Highbury, London, branch is pictured above - slipped 7% to £1.1m, despite a boost from buying 11,000 bottles of vintage claret from the Swedish government at a knock-down price. The Swedes found the £80 a bottle vintage tough to sell due to high duty, but Majestic offloaded it within minutes on the net.

Analyst Mark Reed of Teather & Greenwood said he had reduced his forecast for full-year profits to £4.2m: "Some customers clearly got overexcited over the millennium, but you've got to put it in context."

webTitle: Wall Street wizards: how to lock in your asset values

fields.headline: Wall Street wizards: how to lock in your asset values
fields.standfirst: Old Mutual has two star money managers - at a cost of £450m
fields.trailText: The studious and quietly spoken Gary Pilgrim, 60, and gregarious New Yorker Harold Baxter, 54, are worth more than their weight in gold.
fields.body:
The studious and quietly spoken Gary Pilgrim, 60, and gregarious New Yorker Harold Baxter, 54, are worth more than their weight in gold.

The two founders of Pilgrim Baxter will have $220m (£154.5m) to spend this Christmas, with a further $420m paid in six annual tranches as well as share options and a generous pay package under yesterday's deal, agreed with Old Mutual, the South African financial services group.

The latest Wall Street superstars set up their firm in the early 1980s after leaving the unglamorous sounding Philadelphia National Bank's trust department.

Their business really took off in 1992, when they started to push a small mutual fund to retail investors at the start of what has been the longest bull run in US stock market history. Over the next three years, to the end of 1995, PBHG Growth, as its new aggressive fund was named, rose exponentially from $3m to $2bn.

Pilgrim, who hails from Oklahoma and wears the square-rimmed spectacles of a bean counter, was dubbed the guru of growth stocks in a wave of positive publicity as the technology companies he invested in achieved record gains.

Neither man was available for comment yesterday, but sources close to them indicated that they would be celebrating their new found wealth in different ways.

Pilgrim was expected to turn up at the office at 7.15am as usual yesterday after his usual trip to the gym.

While Pilgrim pored over the numbers and chose the companies to invest in, Baxter hustled business.

The stocky man from Queens was a top sales rep. Over a $300 bottle of wine or game of golf, he would encourage people to invest in his funds or advise others to do so.

Ebullient and ambitious, he said: "I wake up optimistic and aggressive every morning. That's why I like myself."

Baxter's exuberance often grated with staff. Some complained that Baxter had found highly paid jobs for his two daughters; Patty Baxter was reported to have received a six-figure bonus for her office manager job. Chrissie, her sister, was said to have been given a portfolio for a graduation present, while others sniped she was promoted above her peer group. Chrissie moved to private equity early this year.

The founders have long wanted a bigger slice of the action. Burt Greanwald, a mutual fund consultant, told Money magazine last year that the United Asset Management deal - which saw their fund taken over - left the two founders feeling short-changed. "The people at the top [of PBHG] saw the money flowing in and said, 'we could have been twice as wealthy if we hadn't done that deal'."

Baxter and Pilgrim were careful with their cash. Last year it was reported the pair bought a grand headquarters for their business in 1997 and then charged rent for it. The two men said it had saved money for Pilgrim Baxter.

Baxter did a similar deal with his corporate jet, which he bought and leased back to the fund. He justified the contract by saying he charged his own company below cost to travel on its behalf.

Any disatisfaction with how much money they were making was likely to have led directly to takeover talks with Nationwide financial services, a US company, in the summer of 1998. Nationwide offered UAM less than $600m for the whole of the business, only to withdraw the offer a few months later as stock markets crashed around the world. In two weeks Pilgrim Baxter's assets sank from $12bn to $8bn.

Until yesterday, the abortive bid appeared to represent the high water mark for Pilgrim Baxter as the market turmoil highlighted internal divisions.

By early 1997, the firm was behind in performance league tables and losing accounts.

But as analysts and journalists rushed to write them off, Pilgrim Baxter staged a remarkable recovery. Six of its nine growth funds returned more than 100% in 1999.

Last year assets jumped from $13.1bn to $18.2bn. By the end of September, they had risen to $26bn, although this is thought to have fallen because of the downturn in the market for technology shares.

webTitle: RM halts school PC bid talks

fields.headline: RM halts school PC bid talks
fields.standfirst: Bid process falters for Northern Irish IT provision
fields.trailText: The government's plan to put computers in all Northern Ireland's schools was on the verge of collapse last night after RM, the only IT supplier bidding for the project, refused to continue talks with ministers unless its bid was accepted.
fields.body:
The government's plan to put computers in all Northern Ireland's schools was on the verge of collapse last night after RM, the only IT supplier bidding for the project, refused to continue talks with ministers unless its bid was accepted.

The announcement from RM,the UK's biggest supplier of technology to schools, came as the company reported a £2.7m drop in pre-tax profits.

Richard Girling, the chief executive of RM, said 18 months of negotiations with the Department for Education in Northern Ireland had been "more difficult than expected" and had cost £5.4m.

As a result, pre-tax profits for the 12 months to the end of September fell to £9.5m.

"The [DfE in the province] is still continuing to look for 'more for less'," he said.

"But we cannot be pushed any further on the provisions we offer or the risks we are prepared to take.

"I would like to have signed the deal a long time ago but that has not been possible. We won't be signing off any more money on the bid."

He said he expected to have an answer on the deal, which is a PFI contract, by Christmas. The bid for the £300m project was tendered with ICL, and could be worth £150m over a period of 10 years to RM.

A spokesman for the DfE in Northern Ireland denied that talks with the IT supplier had reached an impasse. "We are hopeful of reaching an agreement fairly shortly," he said.

But one IT analyst said he had been looking for a decision on the deal to accompany yesterday's results.

"RM had invested an enormous amount of capital in research and development, secure in the belief it would get the contract as the sole bidder," he said, adding the decision to cut spending looked like an end to the bid.

But Will Wallis, from RM's broker, UBS Warburg, said the protracted and expensive negotiations were the result of the bid not facing a rival offer. Yesterday RM's share price fell 12.5p to 715p.

webTitle: Film: The best airport scene

fields.headline: The best airport scene
fields.standfirst: Wonder Boys
fields.trailText: Wonder Boys.
fields.body:
Pittsburgh Airport. Professor of English Literature and sometime novelist Grady Tripp (Michael Douglas) stands at the arrivals gate as the vulpine Terry Crabtree (Robert Downey Jr) emerges with a statuesque young woman (Michael Cavadias) on his arm. Grinning, Crabtree whispers something in his companion's ear. He spots Grady, approaching him warmly.

"Tripp!"

"How are you Crabtree?"

"Brimming. Say hello to my new friend, Miss Antonia... uh..."

"Sloviak," the woman smiles.

"I took the liberty of inviting Antonia to tonight's festivities. You don't mind, do you Tripp?"

"The more the merrier."

webTitle: Black workers fear discrimination under best value

fields.headline: Black workers fear discrimination under best value
fields.standfirst: Wilf Sullivan, national black members officer at public service union Unison, says black workers are alarmed at the prospect of racial discrimination in the best value process
fields.trailText: Wilf Sullivan: , national black members officer at public service union Unison, says black workers are alarmed at the prospect of racial discrimination in the best value process
fields.body:
Around 300 delegates are in Southport today for the eighth Unison national black members' conference. Many are from local authorities - traditional areas of black employment. A major issue for discussion is the effect of the government's best value process on black workers in the public sector.

In the last 20 years, the number of black workers in local government has declined because of cuts in funding for local authorities and compulsory competitive tendering (CCT) - where councils have to compete with private companies to provide some services. Workers in traditional, manual jobs such as those involved in school meals, cleaning and grounds maintenance have seen an erosion of pay, terms and conditions. Black workers complain that their pay has been cut, that they are more likely to be made redundant than white workers and that gaining employment in privatised areas is increasingly difficult.

White-collar black council workers are alarmed at the prospect of a new form of privatisation. They fear they will suffer the same fate as manual workers in the late 80s and 90s.

The government will no doubt argue that best value is different from CCT in that quality and not the price of the service is paramount. Under CCT, councils could not examine how prospective service providers treated their staff, so in that sense best value is an improvement.

Following the MacPherson inquiry into the murder of the black teenager, Stephen Lawrence, the commission for racial equality set standards which councils are meant to take notice of. And the government has introduced six race equality questions which must be answered under best value. However, they do not go far enough. The questions offer no serious examination of the commitment of service providers to employing black staff, nor any indication of how they treat black staff. There is no guidance on what happens to the procurement process if the service providers do not meet the standards set by the commission for racial equality.

In a country where councils are still required to make annual efficiency savings and where many authorities lurch from one financial crisis to another, the reality of best value in most local authorities is that it is financially driven. Equality comes way down in the list of considerations when contracts are awarded.

Black Unison members feel that best value brings pressure to reduce numbers of staff and to change terms and conditions, and a vast increase in temporary workers doing jobs that used to be filled by permanent staff.

A two-tier workforce has developed. At the top level are staff who have been transferred from local authorities and had their pay and conditions of service protected by the transfer of undertakings (TUPE) regulations. At the bottom level are non-council staff who have been taken on by external contractors at reduced pay, terms and conditions, but who are expected to carry out the same work as those that have been transferred.

Unison believes that the government should be careful that discrimination against black workers does not become inherent in the way the best value system is implemented, thereby removing black workers from areas where they have been able to secure employment.

webTitle: No go for Flo as £12.5m deal founders

fields.headline: No go for Flo as £12.5m deal founders
fields.trailText: Tore Andre Flo's £12.5m move from Chelsea to Rangers was on the brink of collapse last night over the striker's financial demands.
fields.body:
Tore Andre Flo's £12.5m move from Chelsea to Rangers was on the brink of collapse last night over the striker's financial demands.

The Norwegian international's agent Gunnar Martin Kjenner confirmed that the impasse concerned Flo's demands and added: "The deal is finished as far as I know. There are no further talks planned."

Earlier, Rangers' chairman David Murray held talks with Kjenner at which the Ibrox club were understood to have offered Flo a 3-year contract worth £32,000 a week.

But even then Murray hinted at complications at the Chelsea end. It is understood that Flo was reluctant to jeopardise a substantial sum by putting in an official transfer request at Stamford Bridge.

Murray, having made a Scottish-record offer for Flo, added: "We will find out in the next 24 hours if he is coming. He has individual matters to resolve with Chelsea and if these are resolved I am hopeful he can become a Rangers player."

Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson said the club did not want to sell the 27-year-old and yesterday tried to persuade him to stay. But Flo has lost patience with his role as regular substitute. This season he has made only three starts in 16 games.

After missing out on Wimbledon's John Hartson and Espanyol's Raul Tamudo, Rangers last Friday saw Chelsea turn down their written offer of about £11m for a player they signed from Brann Bergen for £300,000 in 1997.

The Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale yesterday put pressure on West Ham to accept his club's long-standing £15m offer for Rio Ferdinand, who gave a fine display in his team's 1-0 win at Elland Road on Saturday.

Ridsdale told the Yorkshire Evening Post: "West Ham can take it or leave it. The player might be worth only £5m to them in the near future depending on the outcome of EU deliberations.

"Our bid already constitutes a world record for a defender and is a measured valuation. There will be no more. We already have alternatives in mind should Ferdinand go elsewhere."

Tottenham's manager George Graham gave a broad hint yesterday that Sol Campbell will leave the club, and for nothing. He said Spurs could not cash in on the £15m-rated defender because Campbell insists on staying until his contract expires at the end of this season.

"You cannot sell a player without his permission," Graham said. "Sol's position is that he's not going anywhere until he sees his contract out. What I can't understand is him not listening to our offer to stay."

Graham is more optimistic about Stephen Carr. "I think that in the next few weeks Stephen will sit down and agree a new contract."

webTitle: Wilnis piles on woe as storm clouds gather for Sky Blues

fields.headline: Wilnis piles on woe as storm clouds gather for Sky Blues
fields.trailText: A last-minute header from Fabian Wilnis sent Ipswich fifth and Coventry deeper into depression.
fields.body:
For Ipswich, fifth place; for Coventry, five defeats in a row. Midway through two minutes of stoppage-time at the end of the game Fabian Wilnis, the Ipswich right-back, sneaked into the area and, as Paul Williams moved helpfully out of the way, dived to meet Martijn Reuser's cross and win the game.

After dominating much of the match it was a harsh blow for Gordon Strachan's side, but such things happen when you are struggling against relegation. Coventry, by now, must know that.

For all their possession they never offered much more than menace. Coventry flowed forward in the first half, frightening Ipswich with pace and willingness to run with the ball, but shooting opportunities were rare and, tellingly, frequently passed up in favour of over-elaboration. As the profligacy of Cedric Roussel and Craig Bellamy became apparent, the more dangerous-looking David Thompson came close to scoring, heading just over in the 83rd minute and hitting the bar with an astonishing 40-yard free-kick. His man-of-the-match award, though, was scant consolation for the result, and it was not a night to savour champagne.

It was an atypical performance from Ipswich, marked by hopeful long balls and searching for scraps at set pieces. It almost paid dividends, as twice first-half corners threatened to break the deadlock, with both Jamie Scowcroft and Marcus Stewart missing presentable opportunities.

They even got a booking, their first in seven games, although as the culprit went on to score the winner it will be swiftly forgiven.

"All credit to Coventry," said the manager George Burley. "They worked very hard to close us down and we didn't play as well as we have so far this season. We never passed the ball particularly well, but it shows you the standard we've reached when we come to Coventry, get the three points and we're still not satisfied."

It was also atypical Strachan, who did his best to appear cheerful. "I'm not raging," he said. "I'm proud of the way we played tonight. We were the better side, we made the better chances."

As the match progressed and a goal failed to materialise, Coventry seemed to relax, content at least to avoid defeat. Ipswich, having beaten Charlton last week with two late goals, pushed more men forward.

Wilnis almost engineered an earlier breakthrough, racing down the right and seeing his low centre cleared by Williams with Scowcroft lurking. "We were never happy with 0-0," said Burley. "We didn't sit back, and sometimes you get the breaks for being brave."

So for Ipswich the success story continues. In winning yesterday the pre-season relegation favourites equalled the number of victories they achieved in the whole of their last, calamitous, Premiership season in 1994-95. They have won four of their last five matches, scoring in each of their last 23 league games, the best record in the country.

For Coventry, though, another relegation battle looks likely. They are out of the bottom three only through the miserable form of those below them and through back-to-back wins in a promising start three months ago. Only Bradford have scored fewer goals and no one has conceded more. They may be the great escapologists but that alone cannot instil much confidence. It would appear nothing else will either.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk
