webTitle: Spielberg and Howard remain committed to the net

fields.headline: Spielberg and Howard remain committed to the net
fields.standfirst: Steven Spielberg and Ron Howard are working on two animated films which will be screened on the world wide web, and Spielberg has given internet users a behind-the-scenes look at the creation of his latest movie, A.I.
fields.trailText: Directors Steven Spielberg and Ron Howard are working on two animated films which will be screened on the world wide web, and Spielberg has given internet users a behind-the-scenes look at the creation of his latest film, A.I.
fields.body:
The much publicised demise of Steven Spielberg and Ron Howard's internet venture, pop.com (see our earlier story), which folded before it even launched, does not seem to have put the directors off making films for the world wide web.

The Hollywood Reporter has reported that both directors are working on their own animated short film - which will feature a caricature version of themselves - for the online film fanzine CountingDown.com, the site bought by pop.com before its demise.

Both shorts will be based on dreams experienced by the directors. Co-founder of CountingDown.com, Charles Segars, told the magazine, "Ron has been having recurring nightmares about being on a wild and crazy movie set he's making a short based on that nightmare."

However, Segars would not reveal the dream that has inspired Spielberg's film. The plan is to show one of the films in early December and the other in January.

Spielberg also allowed a 24-hour behind-the-scenes webcast to be broadcast from the set of his latest film, A.I. A 'Bagel-Cam', so called because it looked through a bagel hole on the craft-services table, showed the comings and goings on the set of the big budget sci-fi production which stars Jude Law and Haley Joel Osment.

"We asked Steven - because he's a better director than all of us - where to put the camera to see the most people, and he came up with the Bagel-Cam," said Segars. Although the live webcast has now finished, stills from the broadcast can still be seen on the site.

One lucky Bagel-Cam visitor, 18-year-old Josh Meeter, left a message on the bulletin board for Spielberg to have a look at Award Showdown, a short film he has made which features a clay model of Spielberg fighting a clay model of George Lucas. Spielberg apparently liked it so much that he has agreed to feature it on the CountingDown.com site next month.

webTitle: Review: Jazz

fields.headline: London's little backyard of jazz
fields.trailText:
La Banda
Huddersfield Town Hall ***
fields.body:
La Banda
Huddersfield Town Hall ***

La Banda is a collective name for a large group of wind musicians from Ruvo di Puglia in Italy. Led by renowned jazz trumpeter Pino Minafra, they embody a folk tradition going back more than 150 years, and they presented a show in two distinct halves.

Part one was a selection of classical lollipops rearranged for brass and woodwind. Clarinets, saxophones, trumpets and trombones took the parts of strings and voices as the ensemble whipped through favourites by Bizet, Rossini, Verdi and Puccini. The familiar tunes and arrangements were cleverly replicated, but how far this kind of ensemble can match the rich tonal palette of a full symphony orchestra, either in texture or intensity of emotion, is a matter of opinion. If you are into brass bands you'll not complain.

The second half of the concert was jazz-based and began with Lucilla Galeazzi singing a plaintive summery melody which gradually darkened into something altogether more tempestuous. The band here trod darker water, turbulent surges underpinning an agitated saxophone solo.

Abruptly it all came to a crashing halt. Accordionist Antenello Salis then launched into a dazzling, street-style display of wheezing virtuosity. Dressed in a red track suit and yellow baseball cap, he bellowed the tune to himself as he played, his infectious sense of swing encouraging his fellow musicians to tap their feet. The trombone and kit-drums joined in and suddenly, at last, they had the joint rocking. The second-line feel of some of these rhythms evoked the spirit of Mardi Gras and, as the band got looser, moments of comedy crept in, with tuba-player Michel Godard producing an uncanny impersonation of a shuddering didgeridoo and a couple of members of the audience being coaxed on stage for some impromptu amateur conducting.

The final stretch of the concert brimmed with old-fashioned good will. The music reverted to bouncing carnival, the audience clapped along, and the back-line of trumpet-players stood and shouted "Hey!" every eight bars. The conductor hopped off the stage, to be joined by half the band and hoisted aloft on their shoulders as they carried on playing.

An enjoyable evening, but it would have been so much better had we all been outdoors, in the sun, in Italy.

webTitle: Leader: We work too long and neglect our kids

fields.headline: The tribulations of job
fields.standfirst:
We work too long and neglect our kids

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Labour sometimes gets it in the neck for the way it puts work uppermost in its social policy. Single mothers, poor people, the young who are not in education or training, even the disabled: all are to be redeemed by finding jobs. But this focus has made it hard for ministers to get across other messages, especially those which urge a better balance of home and job or giving children the large amounts of time and attention they deserve.
fields.body:
Labour sometimes gets it in the neck for the way it puts work uppermost in its social policy. Single mothers, poor people, the young who are not in education or training, even the disabled: all are to be redeemed by finding jobs. The government is right. Emancipation does lie in the workplace; earning a living is the principal, sometimes the only route out of social exclusion. But this focus has made it hard for ministers to get across other messages, especially those which urge a better balance of home and job or giving children the large amounts of time and attention they deserve. Where work is "progress", who should regret the creation of a culture in which refusal to work excessive hours is regarded - by employees themselves - as damaging to career prospects or merely "soft"? But what kind of society is it where employers are more likely to offer their staff stress counselling than fork out to help them look after their children?

New research out yesterday contains more evidence of the extraordinary hold employment has over our lives and perhaps imaginations too - despite working-time directives and a panoply of formal rights and contracts. Such surveys may, it is true, accentuate the negative. Lots of people find work socially rewarding; some even play at work. But Margaret Hodge, the employment minister, is right to focus on the costs of the work culture for children. Fathers need flexibility - if the burden of child care is to be more equally shared.

The government might say it has done what it can. Laws to prevent staff from exploitation are in place; progress is being made on providing child care outside the home. It is up to employees, their unions and their employers to re-cut the cake. Especially the latter. Bosses would do well to study the finding in this new research that long hours can damage productivity; few French economists are predicting that the introduction of a much shorter working week in that country is going to reduce by much its impressive record in per-employee productivity.

The cultural ground for a shift in attitudes in this country has surely been prepared. In new work on the 50+ age cohort the Economic and Social Research Council complements earlier findings about young people to the effect that our identity is increasingly found in leisure hours, at home and in what we buy at Sainsbury's. Occupation no longer maketh the woman or man.

But Margaret Hodge, the employment minister, is right to focus on the costs of the work culture for children. Fathers need flexibility - if the burden of child care is to be more equally shared. The government might say it has done what it can. Laws to prevent staff from exploitation are in place; progress is being made on providing child care outside the home. It is up to employees, their unions and their employers to re-cut the cake. Especially the latter. Bosses would do well to study the finding in this new research that long hours can damage productivity; few French economists are predicting that the introduction of a much shorter working week in that country is going to reduce by much its impressive record in per-employee productivity. The cultural ground for a shift in attitudes in this country has surely been prepared. In new work on the 50+ age cohort the Economic and Social Research Council complements earlier findings about young people to the effect that our identity is increasingly found in leisure hours, at home and in what we buy at Sainsbury's. Occupation no longer maketh the woman or man.

webTitle: Review: Classical

fields.headline: Rihm and reason
fields.trailText:
Rihm and Lachenmann
Huddersfield contemporary music festival ****
fields.body:
Rihm and Lachenmann
Huddersfield contemporary music festival ****

Finding a successor to Richard Steinitz, who started Huddersfield's Contemporary Music Festival in 1978 and is stepping down as artistic director, will not be easy: Steinitz has unflaggingly nurtured the festival, until now it ranks with the best in Europe, and with almost saintly open-mindedness has encompassed the whole spectrum of new music in his programming. Consistently, too, Huddersfield has provided crucial opportunities to sample composers from both sides of the Atlantic whose music is otherwise hardly heard in Britain; thus the first weekend of this year's programme focused on Wolfgang Rihm and Helmut Lachenmann, pivotal figures in German music today.

It is a piquant coupling. Each acknowledges the achievement of Luigi Nono, who died in 1990, yet each takes a very different slant on what it means. While the astonishingly prolific Rihm (born in 1952) celebrates the musical freedom with which Nono composed his late works, the polemical Lachenmann, 65 next week, studied with Nono in the late 1950s and took on not only his radical political agenda but also his rigorous approach to musical organisation, scrutinising the act of composition itself in ideologi cal terms. It makes Lachenmann's music hard to confront, and in a work such as the 1985 Ausklang, a monumental piece for piano and orchestra which Uli Wiget played with the BBC Symphony Orchestra under Jac van Steen in Huddersfield Town Hall on Sunday, tough-going indeed.

The precision of his aural imagination and subtlety of his gestures had been easier to grasp in a programme by the wonderful Ensemble Modern, conducted by Dominque My in St Paul's Hall earlier in the day. There was a delicate percussion solo Intèrieur I, from 1966 dazzlingly played by Rumi Ogawa-Helferich, and the substantial "Zwei Gufuhle..." Musik mit Leonardo from 1992. In the latter, a text by Leonard Da Vinci is atomised into syllables and delivered by a pair of narrators while the ensemble creates a dazzling patchwork of sounds, some conventionally produced, others obtained by striking, stroking or blowing unexpected parts of the instruments. The fragments of the text dissolve into the textures in a teasingly allusive way.

It's all very different from Rihm's freewheeling approach. The BBC Symphony's programme coupled the Lachenmann with the superbly played British premiere of Rihm's latest big orchestral work, Vers une symphonie fleuve IV, a single movement of unstoppable momentum and power, which pays homage to the symphonic tradition yet finds territory of its own to explore too.

The finest score of the weekend had been presented in solitary splendour on Saturday in the first of the Ensemble Modern's concerts; Rihm's Jagden und Formen is a 45-minute single-movement work, finished two months ago, of astonishing power and resource; as one idea slides into the next, and massive, heaving textures give way to the most delicate solos, the tension never slackens.

Since the opening of the Lawrence Batley Theatre opera has become a feature of Huddersfield too, but this year's planned premiere, of John Casken's Tolstoy-based God's Liar had to be abandoned when funding collapsed. In its place came a production by the Toronto-based Autumn Leaf Company, of Claude Vivier's 1979 "rituel de mort" Kopernikus, which was staged at the Almeida Festival in 1985 but not seen in Britain since. For reasons that escape me, the French-Canadian Vivier (1940-83) is becoming a cult figure. Kopernikus and its mimsy story about a child's dreams and illusions, told in a mixture of nursery-speak and pseudo-philosophical posturing, is precious and ridiculous, while the naive charm of the score, heavily indebted to his teacher Stockhausen, wears thin very quickly indeed.

Radio 3 will broadcast the BBC Symphony and the Ensemble Modern concerts over the next three weeks.

webTitle: Review: Jazz

fields.headline: The sound of sunshine
fields.trailText:
Brad Mehldau/ State of the World
London jazz festival ****/***
fields.body:
Brad Mehldau/ State of the World
London jazz festival ****/***

Brad Mehldau is one of the best-loved jazz pianists to have appeared in the past decade - which was why the Queen Elizabeth Hall opened up its backstage area on Friday to accommodate more customers, in the process creating something like a club atmosphere. Mehldau was appearing as part of the trio that produced a remarkable sequence of recordings in the mid-1990s, with Larry Grenadier on bass and Jorge Rossy on drums. "We sort of draw [the audience] into our own little backyard," is how Mehldau describes their collaboration.

Mehldau embarks on most musical adventures as if he were trying to edge into a party without drawing attention to himself; he began with a soft mid-tempo and a typically fragile, unfolding flower of a tune. Having acclimatised the crowd to the fine details of the dynamics, the trio ran through the flowing waltz At a Loss, the plaintively reflective movie-score rhapsodising of the ballad Resignation (gently accelerating into a caressing Latin shuffle) and then the standard Alone Together. This was a delightful piece of Mehldau meditation, beginning unaccompanied with the tune disguised in darting left-hand figures against woodpecker clatterings in the right, then giving way to a clear, ringing and decisive bass solo by Grenadier, and a drum break of shrewdly controlled fire from Rossy.

One of the consistently mesmerising features of Mehldau's playing is his classical recitalist's left-hand independence, which gives even a bop-flavoured piece greatly expanded resources of melodic contrast and creative tension. He is also unpredictable in his treatment of familiar songs. If he hid the melody of Alone Together, he played the familiar belting confession of Secret Love absolutely straight - but at about a quarter of its usual tempo, and with the choked, elided, vocal cord of a torch singer somehow expressed in his delicate touch.

Nick Drake's River Man swelled into a drama of hissing cymbals and rumbling mallet-work, and Radiohead's Exit Music For a Film allowed the conversational interplay of the band to shine. Roars for encores brought the trio back plenty of times, but Cry Me a River was the most telling of them.

Mehldau and his trio were appearing as part of the London jazz festival. Every year someone complains that the event is trading under a false name because of the presence of hip-hoppers, turntable-whirlers, worldbeat ethnicists, classical players, performance art accordionists and so on. Saturday, the last big night of the festival, was definitely one for the fundamentalists to avoid. Yet there was plenty of jazz in it: it just played more of a character part in a different kind of show. A variety of spaces around the Festival Hall played host to some of the ensembles that had made the Serious Sampler series at the Spitz club such a fascinating diversion all year.

Andy Sheppard and Claude Deppa's encounter with avant-garde DJs Rita Ray and Max Reinhardt was a big feature, as was Asian programming-and-tablas duo Badmarsh and Shri. But the evening was kicked off by former Loose Tubes trombonist Ashley Slater, making the most of his expressive soul singer's voice.

Slater characterises what he does with his fusion band Big Lounge with such seductive terms as "Andy Williams on acid", but for the most part it's not so much wrecked cabaret music as a pretty convincing soul and funk act, despite the presence of jazzers Steve Arguelles on drums and Benoit Delbeq on keys. Eddie Stevens on Hammond and synths did, however, add wild forays of abstract, slashing organ chordwork, as well as riffs from such unlikely and distant sources as the Doors.

Big Lounge's frenetic whimsy was a long way from the earthiness of the next band, New Orleans funkers Galactic. Galactic blasted a half-full Festival Hall audience back in its seats with an infectiously ferocious - and typically Delta city - mix of honking, yelping funk sax playing, brilliant wake-the-dead drumming, and the raw and majestic singing of Theryl DeClouet.

The night also featured an unconventionally ambitious project in Spacer vs the Orchestra, an 18-piece ensemble of young British classical musicians and DJ Luke Gordon, aka Spacer. Spacer's headlong deckwork, and a churning drum'n'bass feel to the rhythm section, gave the set an edge-of-the-seat urgency, and the forcefulness and pin-sharp accuracy of the acoustic performers made the overall sound fitfully thrilling. But after a while the tonal resources of the band seemed underused by its frequent reduction to a riffing unit, and apart from a handful of rugged sax breaks, it lacked the improvising soloist that might have imparted more contrast. But it's an intriguing venture, and one there'll be plenty of variations on.

webTitle: Property prices start to go up again

fields.headline: Property prices start to go up again
fields.trailText: Britain's housing market is on the up again, with property prices rising in many parts of the country for the first time in five months, according to new figures published today.
fields.body:
Britain's housing market is on the up again, with property prices rising in many parts of the country for the first time in five months, according to new figures published today.

A report by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors said the revival had been fuelled by an upturn in the London housing market, which is now the strongest it has been since the spring. It came in spite of the fuel crisis and the recent floods and storms.

Nationally during October, 7% more estate agents reported rising prices than falling prices, compared with September, when the figure was minus 3%.

However, the revival in the market is by no means nationwide. While prices in London have risen for the first time since May, they are continuing to fall slightly in all the other southern regions, though the pace of decline has lessened, particularly in the south-east, said RICS.

By contrast, prices in all the northern regions are rising, albeit at a "moderate" pace. The comments come three months after RICS said across the country, house price growth had "all but come to an end".

The survey of England and Wales covers the three months to October 31.

RICS spokesman Ian Perry said: "Surveyors in many parts are reporting a rise in house prices for the first time in months. Most believe this does not herald a return of the rapid price inflation of 18 months ago."

He predits the pace of price inflation in the year ahead will be "substantially slower" than that seen earlier this year.

webTitle: Contract killer

fields.headline: Contract killer
fields.trailText: 21 November: I may want a baby in the next couple of years so should I give up my permanent job for a simillar position with more money but a short term contract?
fields.body:
The problem

I have been offered a new job on a two year contract. It is in the same field I work in now, which I love, and I'll be earning £4,000 more a year for less work.

But I am worried about losing my permanent contract. I've tried to persuade my present employers to pay me more but they refuse despite freely admitting they will readvertise my post at the salary I am requesting now. So I don't know what to do, It's all complicated by the fact that I got married this year and my husband and I want a baby within the next couple of years. With my present job I have all the stability, years of service, pension, maternity benefits I could want.

The solution

What a dilemma. If you had no ties or commitments, then it might be easier to pack in a steady job for a better one with a less certain future. However, your desire to start a family does complicate things a little. But, don't forget that you will still have some maternity rights in the new job - you can take 14 weeks of (unpaid) statutory maternity leave, regardless of length of service. Once you have worked for your new employer for twenty-six weeks ending with the fifteenth week before our due date, you can normally claim Statutory Maternity Pay as well (for 18 weeks). Speak to ACAS (number in your phone book) for more advice on maternity rights.

So what you do really depends on what plans you think you might have if and when a baby arrives. For example, some new mothers are happy to take six weeks off after the birth and go straight back to work. Others want six months and some want to stay with their child until s/he starts school. More commonly, women often decide to go back to work part-time. Your partner's financial situation is also an issue - could he support you for a while if the baby arrived at the end of the two year contract?

And, how would you feel about job-hunting towards the end of your contract if you were heavily pregnant?

The bottom line is that you don't know what the future holds. You might get pregnant within the next two years, you might not. You might find yourself out of work at the end of the two year contract, but you might not. If you stay put, you might get a rise but you might not. The only certainties are that you are currently overworked and undervalued, but secure, and have an opportunity to improve your conditions but at a cost - security. Is the risk of insecurity a greater stress than the overwork you have now? Only you can decide.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

Advice given to this problem should only be regarded as a guide based on the limited information provided by the letter-writer. No responsibility can be taken by Dr Mann for any outcomes following advice given.

webTitle: Excessive overtime causing havoc to families

fields.headline: Excessive overtime causing havoc to families
fields.trailText: Workaholic habits are damaging productivity and playing havoc with families' attempts to improve their work-life balance, the government warned yesterday in the first official report on the social consequences of excessive overtime.
fields.body:
Workaholic habits are damaging productivity and playing havoc with families' attempts to improve their work-life balance, the government warned yesterday in the first official report on the social consequences of excessive overtime.

One in nine full-time employees works more than 60 hours every week - mostly men with children. And one in eight regularly works both Saturdays and Sundays.

The survey found most men wanted more flexible arrangements such as job-sharing and a reduced working week. But two-thirds thought working part time would damage their careers.

Most women said they would rather work more flexibly after the birth of a child than have longer maternity leave. But almost half the employers thought this would be regarded as unfair by the rest of their staff.

The government billed the survey as the first and largest research into work-life balance in Britain. It was based on interviews with 7,500 employees, 2,500 employers and 250 company head offices.

Margaret Hodge, the equal opportunities minister, said the problem facing industry was not absenteeism but presenteeism. "The long hours culture is alive and kicking ... We are all working too long hours and it is making us ill. That doesn't help productivity and it certainly doesn't support families."

Mrs Hodge was disappointed that overtime had increased since 1997 when the government introduced the EU working time directive stopping most firms from making staff work more than 48 hours a week. "We need to ask why introduction of the 48-hour week has not led to greater change in hours of work and presenteeism."

But the government was encouraged that 55% of employers in the survey agreed it could be acceptable in some circumstances for staff to switch to part time working.

The survey found 14% of men who lived as a couple with dependent children worked more than 60 hours a week. This compared with 7% of women in the same family circumstances, 9% of single parents and 9% of people who were single or members of childless couples.

"The long hours of many males in couple households with children may reflect both a need for income (associated with children) and the opportunity to work long hours (associated with the presence of a partner)," the report said.

Almost half the employers offered stress counselling, but only 9% gave assistance with childcare. "It feels as if we are dealing with the consequences and not the cause of people not getting the right balance between work and the rest of their lives," Mrs Hodge said.

But the "good news" was that 60% of employers let staff vary their hours, 24% of employees work flexitime and 12% have arranged to work only during term time.

John Monks, general secretary of the TUC, said bad employers would not be forced to cut long hours until there were changes in the law. "The one thing the government could do is announce its intention not to renew the individual opt out to the working time directive which sees many people work excessively long hours."

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, said: "It is right that we should hold a carrot out to the thousands of good employers, but it is time that the government showed a willingness to wave a stick at the bad ones."

Peter Elwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB and chairman of Employers for Work-Life Balance, said: "We recognise that men need to balance their work and life outside work just as much as women."

Mrs Hodge, who admitted working "incredibly" long hours, said men had been excluded from previous campaigns for a better work-life balance. "Now fathers too are calling for a better deal. With 14% of fathers working over 60 hours every week, it means that men are less and less able to spend the time with the family that they want."

 Work-life Balance 2000 survey, by Institute for Employment Research, University of Warwick and IFF Research: 40-page summary report from DfEE publications

Rural bliss in a hi-tech haven

'Fortunately I'm married to someone who shares childcare'

 Joy Kingsley: managing partner of Manchester solicitors Pannone & Partners. Mother of two.

I start work after dropping the children off at school - they are four and eight - and finish between 7.30pm and 8pm. It takes me half an hour to get home. One night, normally Thursday, I carry on working at home.

The hours have increased over the years but my hours are not as bad as they are for those working in London. I don't work Friday afternoons - that is the time I have to pick the children up from school and be a normal mum. Since I was 23 or 24 I have worked long hours running branch offices and I came back to work four months after having each child.

"The hours lawyers work have increased dramatically, especially in London. It is because of client demand and increased competition. These days the rules have changed. Everything is a bit of a free-for-all. Before letters would be sent and a reply would have to be dictated and sent back. Now with faxes and e-mails, the process is speedier and clients expect more. Ten years ago lawyers would always finish work at 5pm or 6pm and make a good living doing that.

"Fortunately, I have good support at home. I'm married to someone who takes an equal share of childcare. I do the morning, he does the evening. It may get better if there is more working from home.

Journalist finds better lifestyle in home county environment

 Tim Dwelly, 36, freelance journalist in Cornwall. Father of three.

Until six years ago I was editor of the charity Shelter's in-house magazine, Roof. I suffered some health problems and decided to move to Cornwall, where I was born. The charity was supportive, allowing me to continue working from home as a staff reporter. I swopped my grotty flat in Lambeth, south London, for a regency townhouse.

I made enough contacts for me to get enough work to become a freelancer. Recently I wrote a paper for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation on working from home. I've also been able to team up with other people living in Cornwall doing the same sort of thing as me. There is quite a cluster of people here. I became chair of the Digital Peninsula Network, which has funding from the government and from Europe and work on projects with top quality graphic designers and website designers.

The new technology makes it possible to work from home. I've got the best of both worlds. Penzance has some of the best beaches in the country, good climate and a growing new technology industry. I have found that living in that city and having a family did not work.

Now I do not need to grab weekends in the country because I'm already here. I want time with the family and this style of working gives me that.
fields.bodyText: Workaholic habits are damaging productivity and playing havoc with families' attempts to improve their work-life balance, the government warned yesterday in the first official report on the social consequences of excessive overtime. One in nine full-time employees works more than 60 hours every week - mostly men with children. And one in eight regularly works both Saturdays and Sundays. The survey found most men wanted more flexible arrangements such as job-sharing and a reduced working week. But two-thirds thought working part time would damage their careers. Most women said they would rather work more flexibly after the birth of a child than have longer maternity leave. But almost half the employers thought this would be regarded as unfair by the rest of their staff. The government billed the survey as the first and largest research into work-life balance in Britain. It was based on interviews with 7,500 employees, 2,500 employers and 250 company head offices. Margaret Hodge, the equal opportunities minister, said the problem facing industry was not absenteeism but presenteeism. "The long hours culture is alive and kicking ... We are all working too long hours and it is making us ill. That doesn't help productivity and it certainly doesn't support families." Mrs Hodge was disappointed that overtime had increased since 1997 when the government introduced the EU working time directive stopping most firms from making staff work more than 48 hours a week. "We need to ask why introduction of the 48-hour week has not led to greater change in hours of work and presenteeism." But the government was encouraged that 55% of employers in the survey agreed it could be acceptable in some circumstances for staff to switch to part time working. The survey found 14% of men who lived as a couple with dependent children worked more than 60 hours a week. This compared with 7% of women in the same family circumstances, 9% of single parents and 9% of people who were single or members of childless couples. "The long hours of many males in couple households with children may reflect both a need for income (associated with children) and the opportunity to work long hours (associated with the presence of a partner)," the report said. Almost half the employers offered stress counselling, but only 9% gave assistance with childcare. "It feels as if we are dealing with the consequences and not the cause of people not getting the right balance between work and the rest of their lives," Mrs Hodge said. But the "good news" was that 60% of employers let staff vary their hours, 24% of employees work flexitime and 12% have arranged to work only during term time. John Monks, general secretary of the TUC, said bad employers would not be forced to cut long hours until there were changes in the law. "The one thing the government could do is announce its intention not to renew the individual opt out to the working time directive which sees many people work excessively long hours." John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, said: "It is right that we should hold a carrot out to the thousands of good employers, but it is time that the government showed a willingness to wave a stick at the bad ones." Peter Elwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB and chairman of Employers for Work-Life Balance, said: "We recognise that men need to balance their work and life outside work just as much as women." Mrs Hodge, who admitted working "incredibly" long hours, said men had been excluded from previous campaigns for a better work-life balance. "Now fathers too are calling for a better deal. With 14% of fathers working over 60 hours every week, it means that men are less and less able to spend the time with the family that they want."  Work-life Balance 2000 survey, by Institute for Employment Research, University of Warwick and IFF Research: 40-page summary report from DfEE publications Rural bliss in a hi-tech haven 'Fortunately I'm married to someone who shares childcare'  Joy Kingsley: managing partner of Manchester solicitors Pannone & Partners. Mother of two. I start work after dropping the children off at school - they are four and eight - and finish between 7.30pm and 8pm. It takes me half an hour to get home. One night, normally Thursday, I carry on working at home. The hours have increased over the years but my hours are not as bad as they are for those working in London. I don't work Friday afternoons - that is the time I have to pick the children up from school and be a normal mum. Since I was 23 or 24 I have worked long hours running branch offices and I came back to work four months after having each child. "The hours lawyers work have increased dramatically, especially in London. It is because of client demand and increased competition. These days the rules have changed. Everything is a bit of a free-for-all. Before letters would be sent and a reply would have to be dictated and sent back. Now with faxes and e-mails, the process is speedier and clients expect more. Ten years ago lawyers would always finish work at 5pm or 6pm and make a good living doing that. "Fortunately, I have good support at home. I'm married to someone who takes an equal share of childcare. I do the morning, he does the evening. It may get better if there is more working from home. Journalist finds better lifestyle in home county environment  Tim Dwelly, 36, freelance journalist in Cornwall. Father of three. Until six years ago I was editor of the charity Shelter's in-house magazine, Roof. I suffered some health problems and decided to move to Cornwall, where I was born. The charity was supportive, allowing me to continue working from home as a staff reporter. I swopped my grotty flat in Lambeth, south London, for a regency townhouse. I made enough contacts for me to get enough work to become a freelancer. Recently I wrote a paper for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation on working from home. I've also been able to team up with other people living in Cornwall doing the same sort of thing as me. There is quite a cluster of people here. I became chair of the Digital Peninsula Network, which has funding from the government and from Europe and work on projects with top quality graphic designers and website designers. The new technology makes it possible to work from home. I've got the best of both worlds. Penzance has some of the best beaches in the country, good climate and a growing new technology industry. I have found that living in that city and having a family did not work. Now I do not need to grab weekends in the country because I'm already here. webTitle: Review: Theatre

fields.headline: Bollywood comes to Manchester
fields.trailText:
Unsuitable Girls
Contact, Manchester **
fields.body:
Unsuitable Girls
Contact, Manchester **

Big on bhangra and dreamy rebellion, this new play, set in east London, is a shameless pastiche of the Bollywood romance, with plenty of dancing, lip-synching and enough insipid lines to recall the most cringe-worthy love story. Not to mention the many obstacles and incidents that prevent the two intended lovers from getting together.

Like Ayub Khan-Din's huge hit, East is East, Unsuitable Girls, by Guardian employee Dolly Dinghra, addresses issues familiar to British Asians - arranged marriages, generational tensions and modern life's threat to religion, tradition and place - but lightly and with little moralising. It is more of a spectacle than a play.

Keith Kahn's set boasts a backdrop of vivid spirals, a turning wall of coloured tubes, and a raised bedroom in gaudy burgundy and brown. Extras in Gap slacks and trainers strut round the large stage, poised to leap into dance when the bass-heavy bhangra kicks in, and, at times, the actors look lost in the space.

In a precarious blend of the earnest and the whimsical, the plot follows 28-year-old Chumpa, who has aspirations to be a journalist and no longer wants to marry her fiance, Ashok. Shelly Conn is captivating as the clever and beautiful heroine forever frustrated by her circumstances. One moment she is a no-nonsense go-getter (with a Cockney accent) trying to find a better job and a more suitable husband, the next she is a naive Bollywood-obsessed romantic enchanting everyone with a smile. And she can dance, too.

However, her character is given a few scenes of such cloying sentiment that you have to look away, or else laugh in embarrassment. And this is symptomatic of the play's main failure: it occupies an uneasy territory between social comment and pastiche, between a drama that has its own dynamic and an entertainment that is all affectation. There is simply not enough material to carry the narrative beyond its references.

There is much witty commentary on Asian culture, though occasionally it descends into Goodness Gracious Me farce, and the majority of the characters, though wilfully paraded as caricatures, do little to develop interest. In the end it's the dancing above all that you'll remember.

Until December 2. Box office: 0161-274 0600.

webTitle: Review: Theatre

fields.headline: A marriage made in the tearoom
fields.trailText:
Hijra
Bush, London ****
fields.body:
Hijra
Bush, London ****

Seven years ago Jonathan Harvey made his debut at the Bush with Beautiful Thing, a gay coming-out fantasy that was so touching and feel-good you could almost feel the audience tingling with delight. The Bush has done it again with Ash Kotak's debut play.

Like Harvey's work, it is a gay wish-fulfilment fantasy, it is funny and true - about feelings, if not realities - and it has a will-o'-the-wisp quality. It will probably look incredibly insubstantial in a few months, let alone years, but it provides an enormously enjoyable evening and offers a comedy of recognition for the Asian community and, for the rest of us, an opportunity to peep into an unfamiliar world.

On a visit to Bombay with his mother and aunt, Nils is constantly pressured to marry. When Sheila, unlucky in love and unlucky with her mother, turns up, it looks as if this will be a marriage made in the tea-room if certainly not heaven. But Nils has a secret called Raj, whom he has fallen for big time. Raj is the adopted son of a Hijra, India's third gender, who are both despised and revered because people believe they have the power to grant wishes and cast spells.

So it proves. Raj transforms himself into Rani to beat the immigration authorities, and he and Nils secretly marry and attempt to make a new life in Wembley. But they don't count on the nosiness of the local community, where gossip is a way of life, and Sheila's mum's capacity for revenge.

This is a play that knows it is a piece of fluff and revels in the outrageousness of fantasy. But in painting a picture of how we'd like things to be, rather than as they really are, it throws up a fascinating portrait of a community torn between past and present. There is an interesting take on motherhood, too, with the behaviour of the mothers of Nils and Sheila in sharp contrast with the enabling actions of Raj's mother, a fantasy we'd all like.

Ian Brown's production plays up the farcical elements of the play but never lets it slip into full-blown camp, and the performances are so lovely and well-judged you want to hug the actors. I suspect that Kotak is more likely to end up big in TV or film than the theatre. But grab a bit of him while you can, and rediscover the joy of having such a good time you want to skip out of the theatre with a silly grin.

Until December 9. Box office: 020-7610 4224

webTitle: Insurance standards code rendered toothless

fields.headline: Insurance standards code rendered toothless
fields.trailText: A new code from the insurance industry that sets out the minimum standards that customers should expect when making claims looks to be something of a paper tiger.
fields.body:
A new code from the insurance industry that sets out the minimum standards that customers should expect when making claims looks to be something of a paper tiger.

The code states, among other things, that insurers should respond to policyholder letters within two weeks or 10 working days. But whilst the code itself will be binding on the Association of British Insurers' (ABI) members from January, co-operation with the monitoring of the code will not.

Member companies will be asked to provide their own information on recent claims so the ABI can benchmark their performance against the code, but are under no obligation to co-operate.

This begs obvious questions about how the code can be binding if companies don't have to release information on their compliance.

The ABI's Malcolm Tarling said companies would want to provide the information of their own accord because getting a good benchmarking score would give them a competitive advantage. He points to the fact that 80% of motor insurers have already agreed to participate in the first study as proof. But as the results of the benchmarking will not be released to the public - consumers will only see a general report looking at standards across the industry - it is difficult to see why companies will care about their own score.

A spokesperson for the Consumer's Association said: "The code goes someway towards setting standards for policyholders, but the issue of how the code is policed is a major concern. I expect we'll have to wait and see what happens when claims written since the code's launch start coming in."

Insurance Ombudsman Reidy Flynn agrees it will be some time before the code's effectiveness can be evaluated, but says she hopes it will work, helping to cut the number of complaints received by her office. Around 25% of the complaints that reach the Ombudsman relate to problems with the claims and administration procedures.

The code requires that insurers deal fairly and promptly with you claims. More specifically it states that:

 When a customer first makes a claim, they can expect a response and a response and action from the insurer within five working days

 While a claim is being processed, the customer can expect replies to letters within 10 working days

 Once a claim has been agreed, payment, repair or replacement should take place within 10 days

 On making a written complaint, a customer can expect a written acknowledgement within five working days and a final response within 40.

webTitle: Art review: Cerith Wyn Evans

fields.headline: Cerith Wyn Evans
fields.standfirst:
Tate Britain
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Tate Britain
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
To see some of the publicity Tate Britain put out for its William Blake exhibition, you'd think Blake, far from living in obscurity in 18th-century Lambeth, was tutor in printmaking and prophecy at today's Goldsmiths College.

At one point, it was planned to have a section of the show curated by Chris Ofili. That having fallen through, the museum's insistence on a golden thread that links Blake's radical Albion with today's Hoxton manifests itself in Cerith Wyn Evans's installation, in which Blake's verse is flashed in morse code interrupting shiny disco lights, and the shadow of a glitterball stands in for the dark orb in Blake's picture The Ancient of Days.

Wyn Evans was around in the 1980s when, as a film-maker, he was part of a more counter-cultural generation, and a friend of Derek Jarman. In the 1990s, he remade himself into a glamorous Young British Artist.

He must be the only person to have his portrait painted by both Lucian Freud and Gary Hume. His art is self-consciously ephemeral, a joke at its own shallowness: a gold-plated crowd barrier, or the distorting mirror in Sensation at the Royal Academy.

The glitterball revolving at Tate Britain continues his love affair with shiny things and sense of their hysterical melancholy. A light is directed at the sphere; reflected forms swirl around the walls. But the disco ball casts a macabre shadow, like the sun in eclipse with a corona of light.

Every so often, the entire installation switches on and off as Blake's words are flashed in morse. I don't know the code well enough to translate them; nor apparently did anyone else who drifted in.

The trouble is that while I can guess what Evans is hinting at - Blake as a radical spectre haunting our cultural feast - it doesn't communicate more than sentimental tristesse. To be fair, the artist originally proposed to project Blake's words onto the MI6 building across the river. Here, his art becomes modern spin for an exhibition that doesn't need it.

What would it be like if today's British artists really emulated Blake? They would disappear into their studios to toil away for years creating crotchety, unfashionable works that centuries later would still feed the soul, intellect and morality.

But we know that isn't going to happen. The London art scene today has as little in common with Blake's conception of art as the Tory Party has the right to sing Jerusalem.

 Until February 11. Details: 020-7887 8000.
